title: Magic Carpets
description: Lina Zedig and Marcus Ahren, the founders of the Stockholm-based design studio Oyyo, have introduced a line of cotton dhurries that stands apart from the ubiquitous stripes and chevrons of flat-weave designs. With their soft pastels and spare patterns, these rugs have a definite Nordic accent, recalling the textiles of the Swedish designer Marta Maas-Fjetterstrom, but a closer look reveals more diverse influences  everything from the Bauhaus textiles of Gunta Stlzl to the tree markings of itinerant laborers in the 1940s.

title: Mens Watches that Stop the Hands of Time
description: That age-old obsession with halting the passage of time took a literal turn at the recently concluded Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) watch fair in Geneva. A multitude of styles on view there made use of the chronograph  a feature that enables the rapid starting and stopping of hands on a dial to measure specific segments of time. Primarily used in the world of sports, where fractions of a second can make the difference between winning, losing and shattering records, this function was the must-have add-on at the show.

title: As Peanut Allergies Rise, Trying to Determine a Cause

title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Reunions

(NBC) SPORTS ILLUSTRATED SWIMSUIT: 50 YEARS OF BEAUTIFUL Heidi Klum, right, hosts this 50th-anniversary celebration of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit franchise, featuring behind-the-scenes glimpses of photo shoots, a countdown of top covers and reminiscences by Tyra Banks, Christie Brinkley, Kathy Ireland, Marisa Miller and Kate Upton. Enrique Iglesias, Lady Antebellum, the Fray, John Legend and Tim McGraw serenade them.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Seattle Seahawks were so certain that Percy Harvin was the game-breaking offensive player they needed to advance to the Super Bowl that they traded first- and third-round draft choices in 2013 and their third-round selection this year to the Minnesota Vikings to obtain him.

title: U.S. Skates to 6th Place in Bandy Tournament

The American team, made up primarily of players from the Minneapolis-St. Paul and Duluth, Minn., areas, was 3-3 in the tournament, in which 17 countries participated. The matches, lasting 90 minutes apiece, were played outside in the Siberian cold.

I worried that I would remain forever a little girl with nothing on my chest but bumps  bumps that my busty classmate, Linda, referred to as pimples in need of Band-Aids.

title: Student With Rifles Kills 2 in Standoff at Moscow School
description: MOSCOW  A student armed with two rifles opened fire in a high school in Moscow on Monday morning, killing a geography teacher and a police officer as he held about two dozen students hostage in a rare case of gun violence in a school here.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: January 31, 2014
description: After months of steadily climbing and setting new records in 2013, the Dow Jones alone is down more than 4 percent this month. This downward slide comes even as the economy strengthens. This week on Money Talking, contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss the recent drops, the incoming Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen and whether theres more volatility in store in the coming weeks and months. And the Super Bowl: Just how much of a financial boon is it for the host city?

title: Finding the Discipline to Say No to Customers
description: Recently, the She Owns It business group welcomed three new members, Jennifer Blumin, founder of Skylight Group; and the founders of Hukkster, Erica Bell and Katie Finnegan. (Recent members Jessica Johnson, Alexandra Mayzler, and Beth Shaw may return occasionally to discuss major developments at their companies.) At the groups last meeting, the members learned more about each others companies, and discussed the challenge of saying no to new business and opportunities.

title: Behind the Cover Story: James Vlahos on the United States of Sports Betting
description: James Vlahos wrote this weeks cover story about hypercompetitive sports betting in Las Vegas. He last wrote for the magazine about life insurance.You note that one in five American men bet last year, according to a survey. Did you?

description: LONDON  The merger of two prominent South African political groups, announced with much fanfare last week as a political game-changer, collapsed in acrimony on Monday, further splintering the opposition to the governing African National Congress.

title: SAC Fashioning a New Identity
description: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund started by Steven A. Cohen, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it. The firm, whose reputation is now intricately linked to an insider trading scandal, is in the midst of rebranding itself, including changing its name and corporate structure. And recently, a major bank distanced itself from the firm. Together, these developments provide the most vivid illustration yet of SACs steep fall from powerful hedge fund to marginalized player,  Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

title: Golden Eyes
description: From a faint sheen to a strong metallic, fashions top makeup artists got glowing this season. Heres how to lay on the shine.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Michael Barrett joined Millennial Media, Baltimore, as chief executive. He succeeds Paul Palmieri, who founded the company; Mr. Palmieri resigned, Millennial Media said, and will join New Enterprise Associates as venture adviser. Mr. Barrett had most recently been chief revenue officer at Yahoo and before that was chief executive at AdMeld.

title: Officials Scramble to Modify Slopestyle Course After Accident
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Four years after a luge athlete died on a training run in Vancouver on an Olympic course that had drawn widespread criticism, the Winter Olympics faced another safety issue four days before the opening ceremony.

description: Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company under attack by the activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, said on Monday that it would increase its share buyback plan by $500 million.

title: Bernanke Starts New Role as Yellen Takes Fed Helm

On Monday, he drove himself to a new job as an economic studies fellow at the Brookings Institution, a research group about a mile north of his old office.

Despite warnings to the contrary, spoilers are routinely delivered via text and social media throughout the bicoastal event, as awards are announced at different times.

title: Raymond Weil, Whose Swiss Watches Told More Than Time, Dies at 87
description: Swiss watch companies had dominated the world of precision timekeeping for two centuries by the 1970s, when a technological marvel known as the quartz watch  a cheaper, more accurate work of horology mass-produced in Asia  threatened them with extinction.

title: New Ads Urge Northerners to Follow the Sun
description: For years, ads during winter have encouraged residents of cold-weather states to visit warm-weather locales. Is there a baby boomer from states like New York or Pennsylvania who does not recall campaigns in which an actor named Jim Dooley proclaimed, So come on down to Florida on Northeast Airlines?

title: Gyora Benedeks Hidato
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by Gyora Benedek, the Israeli computer scientist, inventor and adventurer. We first met Dr. Benedek while discussing Robert Torrences Lights Out Puzzle last September; Dr. Benedek shared, as one of the original inventors of Lights Out, some of the mathematics behind the game.

title: Stir-Fried Brown Rice With Red Chard and Carrots
description: A lush bunch of red Swiss chard that I got at the farmers market was the inspiration for this stir-fry. The stems, which stay nice and crunchy, are an important ingredient in the stir-fry, so look for chard with nice wide ribs.

title: Stir-Fried Rice and Black Quinoa With Cabbage, Red Pepper and Greens
description: This is the kind of dish you can make on a whim if you make it a habit to freeze leftover grains. I used a combination of red chard and beet greens for this, but regular chard and kale would also work. I love the texture, flavor and look of the quinoa.

title: Stir-Fried Rice Noodles With Beets and Beet Greens
description: I like to use golden or Chioggia beets for this stir-fry. Whatever beets you use, slice them very thin; for best results use a mandolin. Use a wok, not a pan, for stir-fried noodles as noodles will spill out of a pan. Tongs are a good tool for stirring and tossing the noodles, but a long-handled spatula will also work.

title: Heroin Scheme to Support Terrorism Is Foiled, Police in India Say
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian police said Monday that they had intercepted 22 pounds of heroin headed from Pakistan to South India, breaking up a network that included a police officer from Indian-administered Kashmir. The shipment was transported over the heavily militarized, hilly border between Pakistan and India, and was to be carried by train to New Delhi, said S.N. Srivastav, a senior police officer.

title: Stir-Fried Soba Noodles With Shiitakes and Baby Broccoli
description: Soba noodles are Japanese, not Chinese, but I love using them in Chinese stir-fries. They have a wonderful nutty flavor, and buckwheat has a lot going for it nutritionally  it is a good source of manganese, copper and magnesium, and it is also high in phytonutrients. To make a quick vegetable stock simmer the shiitake mushroom stalks in a small amount of water for about 20 minutes.

title: Presidential Elections in El Salvador and Costa Rica Are Headed for Runoffs
description: MEXICO CITY  Presidential elections in two Central American countries, El Salvador and Costa Rica, will head to a second round after top contenders in both nations failed to get enough votes on Sunday to win outright, in contests that tested the power of incumbent parties.

title: Kravis and Gordon Gekko at the Super Bowl
description: One of the more memorable commercials broadcast during the Super Bowl on Sunday night featured a bevy of pop culture icons from the 1980s, including Hulk Hogan and the actor John Ratzenberger.

title: Stir-Fried Soba Noodles With Turkey and Cabbage
description: Turkey cutlets are a great buy at most supermarkets. These thin medallions of turkey are perfect if you want to add small amounts of meat to a stir-fry. For the best texture, velvet the turkey before stir-frying (Steps 1 and 3).

title: Catherine Deneuve Film Opens French Cinema Series
description: This years Rendez-Vouz With French Cinema will focus on first and second features, including work by directors, like Rebecca Zlotowski, who are considered part of Frances next new wave, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced.

title: No Comment Necessary: Coca Colas Super Bowl Ad
description: Coca Colas Super Bowl ad, featuring a multilingual version of America the Beautiful, upset some right-wingers who apparently feel that the patriotic song should only be sung in English.

title: Philip Seymour Hoffman, R.I.P.
description: Sometimes you dont realize how much an actor has achieved until hes unexpectedly gone. Reading the tributes to Philip Seymour Hoffman, dead this weekend at forty-six, I have the sense that his passing woke a lot of people upto his true significance, the full measure of his greatness, his distinctive place among his generations great performers. Not that he was underappreciated, of course not with a Best Actor Oscar in his pocket and plenty of other critical garlands as well but I wonder how many writers would have reached for his name, or at least reached for it quickly, if they had been asked to pick the best English-speaking actor of the last two decades just a week ago. Not as many, I suspect, as are reaching for the greatest actor label now, to describe his tragically-truncated career.

title: Reaction Time May Predict Longevity
description: There are many well established risk factors for cardiovascular death, but researchers may have found one more: slower reaction time.

title: An Actor Who Made Unhappiness a Joy to Watch
description: It was clear, at least since he won the Oscar in 2006 for Capote, that Philip Seymour Hoffman was an unusually fine actor. Really though, it was clear long before that, depending on when and where you started paying attention.

title: Times Minute | Making Snow for Sochi
description: Also on the Minute, Thailand's political paralysis continues and controversy surrounding Woody Allen's Oscar nomination.

title: Monday Motorsports: Nascar Announces Sprint Cup Chase Changes
description: Nascar announced on Thursday changes to its end-of-season playoffs, the Sprint Cup Chase for the Championship. The changes, officials said, would place a greater emphasis on winning races. The old format pitted 12 drivers  the top 10 in points and two wild-card entries -- against one another in the final 10 races of the year in a runoff to decide the driving title. Jimmie Johnson, who won six races in 2013, collected his sixth championship, edging out Matt Kenseth, who had seven wins.

title: Times Minute | Making Snow for Sochi
description: In the Video

title: Frozen Takes Top Prize at Animation Awards
description: Talk about a thaw.

title: Barclays Chief Declines Annual Bonus
description: Updated, 1:54 p.m. | LONDON  Barclays chief executive, Antony Jenkins, said Monday that he would forgo a bonus for 2013 in light of the banks continued restructuring costs and litigation expenses.

title: British Regulator Warns Two of Potential Libor Charges
description: The Wells notice appears to be going global.

title: Hedge Fund Chief Makes a Lonely Bet Against Portugals Debt
description: David Salanic cuts a lonely figure among the Manhattan power brokers eating breakfast at the Loews Regency Hotel restaurant on Park Avenue. Sure, he runs a hedge fund, but with $50 million, his fund may represent a year of commissions for some of the heavy hitters in the room.

title: Beckham Back, as an Owner of a New Team
description: David Beckham is set to return to Major League Soccer on Wednesday, this time as an owner of a Miami team that will become the leagues 22nd club.

title: Fiat-Chrysler Merger Spawns New Logo
description: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, the new company created from the merger of Chrysler and Fiat, has introduced a new logo made from the letters F.C.A. and rendered in light blue.

title: Rene Fleming to Teach Master Class at Juilliard
description: Rene Fleming seems intent on giving Plcido Domingo a run for his money as operas busiest star. Apart from singing the title role in the Metropolitan Operas current production of Rusalka, Ms. Fleming turned up to sing at Marilyn Hornes birthday concert at Carnegie Hall a couple of weeks ago, and then, of course, there was her performance of The Star-Spangled Banner at the Super Bowl on Sunday, and the recent announcement that she will have her first role in a play, at the Williamstown Theater Festival in July. Between now and then, she plans to sing Strausss Arabella in Salzburg, in April.

title: Months After Typhoon, Philippine City Suffers From an Exodus of Jobs
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  As Jesse Siozon waited for his grandfathers funeral to begin, beneath the orange and blue tarps that serve as the roof for the storm-damaged Santo Nio Church, he spoke of a double loss.

title: Hacker Group Accuses Merkel Government of Helping to Spy
description: MUNICH  The Chaos Computer Club, a leading hacker organization based in Germany, filed a criminal complaint against Chancellor Angela Merkel and members of her government on Monday, accusing them of violating the law by helping intelligence agencies in the United States and Britain to spy on German citizens.

title: Seeking Views From Your High or Low Perch
description: Good afternoon, City Room.

title: The Read Around: Barry Werth
description: Our health care system is broken, says Barry Werth. In his new book, The Antidote, he provides an inside look at one companys efforts to find innovative ways to treat disease.

title: Auto Sales for January Held Down by Harsh Winter Weather
description: Automakers reported on Monday sharp declines in United States sales in January as a harsh freeze and winter storms thwarted purchases across much of the country.

title: Full Picture of Airlines Punctuality Is Elusive
description: Travelers on Monday experienced a new round of cancellations and delays as another winter storm grounded planes yet again. But many of those flights wont be counted as late or canceled in the governments on-time statistics.

title: A Souvenir and a Memory
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  As I cleaned out my room before moving to Washington, I found a small piece of red fabric crumpled among some keepsakes. I have stacks of journals that catalog my thoughts, hopes, fears and dreams, as well as anything and everything that reminds me of my various adventures over the years. You could say Im more than slightly sentimental. Writings, photos, objects and song lyrics all transport me in time.

title: Changing Circumstances, Graphed
description: One recurrent theme on this blog has been that the effects of shocks to the economy, including policy shocks, depend a lot on circumstances  in particular, on whether short-term interest rates are constrained by the zero lower bound. I was putting together teaching materials, centered around David Romers IS-MP exposition, and came up with a graph that I think illustrates this point, um, graphically.

title: At Canyon Ranch, Sensuality Sessions for Valentines Day
description: Most hotels tout Valentines Day packages with rose petals on the bed and chocolate-dipped strawberries on the nightstand. But Canyon Ranch Hotel and Spa in Miami Beach takes a therapists approach to intimacy with a three-day program devoted to sensuality and bond-building.

title: Gravity Cinematographer Wins Peers Award
description: Emmanuel Lubezki took the top prize from the American Society of Cinematographers this weekend, for his work creating and photographing outer space in Gravity. Mr. Lubezki, known as Chivo (Spanish for goat), is longtime friends and collaborators with Alfonso Cuarn, the director of Gravity: Mr. Lubezki was previously a winner for their film Children of Men in 2007 and is considered a favorite at the Oscars as well, although as the blog Gold Derby notes, the cinematographers group has a so-so track record in predicting the eventual Academy Award winner.

title: The Great Mystery of Chinese New Year
description: The week before the Lunar New Year, which fell this year on Friday, Jan. 31, is an exciting time in China. The streets are full of shoppers looking for last-minute gifts to take back to their relatives, and restaurants are packed with friends celebrating and companies holding their annual parties.

title: Safety Agency Says 22 Million Vehicles Recalled in 2013
description: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013.

title: Employees Get To Vote, Too?
description: This is kind of funny: Eric Cantor feels the need to explain to his fellow Republican legislators that most Americans not only dont own their own businesses, they have no desire to own their own businesses. Its a message hes apparently having a hard time getting across.

title: Smith & Nephew Pounces on a Wounded Rival
description: Smith & Nephew, the British medical technology giant, has agreed to buy ArthroCare, an American specialist in sports medicine, for an enterprise value of $1.5 billion.

title: The Value of Ripeness
description: Q. Do fruits that are ripe have greater vitamin value than those that arent? And what about sugar?

title: As the Latest Christie Story Evolved, The Times Should Have Noted a Change
description: In the digital age, news evolves before our very eyes. A story breaks and goes online with perhaps a few rough paragraphs. Soon after, more details are added, new angles explored and writing is tuned up. Finally  at least in organizations like The Times  a thorough and polished version makes its way onto the web and into both print and the archives.

title: A Farms Lessons in Long-Term Planning
description: When I ask you to think long term, what comes to mind? Ten years from now? One year? One week? In a world where excellence is now measured in milliseconds, it can be incredibly difficult to think past the moment thats right in front of us.

title: HP Revises Autonomy Financial Reports, Citing Accounting Errors
description: Hewlett-Packard has disclosed to the authorities that it found what it said were serious accounting errors at Autonomy, the British software maker it acquired in 2011, leading to a number of major revisions in the acquired companys financial report for 2010.

title: On the Verge | A Star Is Born
description: The French fashion designer Simon Porte Jacquemus is storming Paris with his superclean designs and rowdy runway shows.

title: Cutting Straight to the Chase With Dessert
description: Dessert can be excess or antidote, solace or provocation, a stampede of the senses or a tickling of the mind. Rarely is it all at once.

title: Both Sides Declare P.R. Victory in Skirmish Over SodaStream Super Bowl Ad
description: Updated, 5:10 p.m. | By the time the actress Scarlett Johanssons critically unacclaimed Super Bowl commercial for SodaStream finally aired Sunday night, both supporters and critics of Israels occupation of the West Bank had pronounced themselves satisfied with the new attention her endorsement brought to the companys factory in a Jewish settlement outside Jerusalem.

title: First Event of Sochi Olympics: The Hotel Construction Sprint
description: SOCHI, Russia  The official mascots for the Winter Olympics are a polar bear, a hare and a leopard. But walk around the complexes that will stage the Games here, with the opening ceremony Friday, and what seem more apt are a hand drill, a backhoe and a shovel.

title: Weighing Testosterones Benefits and Risks
description: Nearly a decade ago, researchers in Boston decided to see whether older men who were not in very good shape could benefit from daily doses of testosterone.

title: U.S. and Europe Work on Aid Package for Ukraine
description: BERLIN  Looking to defuse Ukraines crisis, the United States and Europe are trying to assemble a financial package that could ease the path for a new government there to guide the country out of its current impasse between Europe and Russia, American and European officials say.

title: In the End, It All Adds Up to  1/12
description: This is what happens when you mess with infinity.

title: Goldmans Charitable Foundation Chief to Lead Urban Investment Group
description: Dina H. Powell has already made a name for herself as the head of Goldman Sachss charitable foundation. Now, she is preparing to add a new revenue-generating role to her list of responsibilities.

title: A Doctor Bridging Arts and Sciences
description: In historys long parade of pushy mothers and miserably obedient children, no episode beats Dr. Frank H. Netters for a happy ending. Both parties got the last laugh.

title: Preschool Push Moving Ahead in Many States
description: Preschool is having its moment, as a favored cause for politicians and interest groups who ordinarily have trouble agreeing on the time of day. President Obama devoted part of his State of the Union address to it, while the deeply red states of Oklahoma and Georgia are being hailed as national models of preschool access and quality, with other states and cities also forging ahead on their own.

title: A Hard Climate for Penguins and Butterflies
description: Adaptation can be tricky. Extreme weather is challenging the survival of certain penguins and butterflies, yet DNA from Neanderthals lives on in modern humans 30,000 years after they went extinct. Its enough to turn a cave mans eyes blue.

title: Chris Christie Returns to High School
description: The investigations into Gov, Chris Christies traffic scandal are finally getting serious. The documents subpoenaed by New Jersey legislators are scheduled to start arriving at committee offices this week.

title: At Work in Subzero Temperatures
description: For this weeks Look column, we asked the photographer Massimo Vitali to visit Harbin, China, to take pictures of the Ice and Snow World there. Long days in the extreme cold  temperatures got as low as minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit  made for difficult work.

title: On Kristofs Column About Dylan Farrow and Woody Allen, Only Questions
description: As Ive been thinking about Nicholas Kristofs Sunday column and the related blog post that have caused so much discussion and disagreement, a number of thoughtful emails from readers have arrived.

title: Super Bowl Slide Show
description: The Seattle Seahawks overwhelmed the Denver Broncos to win their first Super Bowl.

title: Muti Signs New Contract With Chicago Symphony Orchestra
description: Riccardo Mutis relationships with American orchestras have been enigmatic: after leading the Philadelphia Orchestra for a dozen years, starting in 1980, he reportedlygrew weary of the social responsibilities that an American directorship involves. The New York Philharmonic courted him twice, with no joy, only to see him take up the baton in Chicago in 2010. Mr. Muti seems to have enjoyed his time there so far: On Monday, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra announced that the 72-year-old conductor has signed a second five-year contract, which will extend his tenure through August, 2020.

title: Alive With a New, Old Liver
description: Five days a week, three hours a day, Jonathan Nuez works out with a gymnastics coach on bars, rings, pommel horse and floor exercises.

title: In India, a Pilgrimage to a Feast for Thousands
description: RAYAVARAM, India  Palaniappa Chettiar has always been goal oriented, and when he turned 97 three years ago, he set himself a new one.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 28-Feb. 3, 2014
description: The Super Bowl, a paralyzing ice storm, a new head of the Federal Reserve and more: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

title: Amid the Wreckage of the Broncos, Sports Books Strike Gold
description: It was a good day at the office for Nevada sports books as the Seattle Seahawks 43-8 destruction of the Denver Broncos defied the expectations of the square money, representing the general betting public, which wanted to see a storybook ending to the record-breaking season of Denver quarterback Peyton Manning.

title: Preschools Benefits Extend to Parents
description: If preschool is having a moment, it is due in part to its appeal to voters as a program designed to help children: preschool is the most cost-effective educational intervention, one that can set children up for greater success not just in reading and math, but in their social and emotional development. Any parent who has raised children in a truly diverse environment has had occasion to grieve how the lives of toddlers who once shared a park sandbox can diverge so dramatically as they grow older. Making preschool available to more children feels like an effort to level that particular playing field.

title: For Hermione, It Shouldnt Have Been Ron, Rowling Says
description: Harry Potter fans who were disappointed by the series happily-ever-after scenario got an early Valentines Day present of sorts, thanks to an interview in which Potters creator, J.K. Rowling, said that the wrong guy got the girl in the epilogue of the final volume.

title: Alvin Ailey to Return to Koch Theater in June
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will return to the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center for a 15-performance engagement that will run from June 11 to 22, the companys artistic director, Robert Battle, announced on Monday. The residency more than doubles the number of performances the company gave at the house last year, in its first appearance there since 2000.

title: Two Families Battered by a Typhoon
description: TACLOBAN, the Philippines  Shortly before dawn, as Typhoon Haiyan thundered ashore, a man took his wife, son and very pregnant daughter on a motorcycle with a sidecar through rising winds to the hospital.

title: Former BBC Director Apologizes for Failure of Digital Project
description: LONDON  Mark Thompson, the former director general of the BBC, offered a general apology to a parliamentary committee on Monday for the failure of an expensive digital project, but he insisted that he had never knowingly misled Parliament or the BBC Trust, its oversight board.

title: As Recovery Looks Weak, Stocks Take a Deep Dive
description: Signs of weakness in the American economy pushed Wall Street to its worst day in an already bad year.

title: Demography and Employment (Wonkish)
description: A blog post reporting research by Samuel Kapon and Joseph Tracy of the New York Fed is creating a splash in wonkworld today, and it is making an important point. However, the way that point is presented is, I think, likely to mislead, because it mixes two propositions together. One, which is clearly true, is that the aging of the adult population would have meant a considerable decline in the employment-population ratio over the past 7 years even if the economy had remained near full employment.

title: Dull Super Bowl Made Downton Abbey a Thrill, as Nearly 7 Million Watched
description: Downton Abbey went once more unto the breach on Sunday night, unafraid, as so many other competitors were, to take on the Super Bowl with an original episode.

title: Weekend Gun Report: January 31-February 2, 2014
description: In September, Louis DiNatale and his wife, who are from Kentucky, drove over a bridge from New Yorkto Ontario, Canada. They claim they were on their way to Vermont but were misdirected by an unreliable GPS, and when they tried to reenter the United States they were asked by a Canadian border crossing guard whether they had any weapons.

title: Helping to Build a School for the Poor, by Selling One in a Wealthier Area
description: Ife Lenard, a charter school principal in the South Bronx, could not help but smile as she ran her hand over an architectural model of the school that the Childrens Aid Society plans to build for her young students, and described its future pottery kiln, science labs and library.

title: Looking Beyond the Canonical Masterpieces
description: Leon Botstein, the conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, is right. Classical music has far too long been in thrall to the cult of the masterpiece, the idea that the arts exist more or less solely for the purpose of identifying and codifying a canon of great works.

title: VW Workers in Tennessee to Vote on Union
description: In what will be one of the most closely watched unionization elections in the South in decades, Volkswagen announced on Monday that the 1,600 workers at its assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., will vote next week on whether to join the United Automobile Workers.

title: Tech Companies Offer Update on Government Data Requests
description: Updated: This post now includes reaction from the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: How It Happens | Snowmaking
description: Machines make snow the same way nature does  only much more quickly, and a lot closer to the ground.

title: An Olympian Snow Endeavor in Sochi
description: The people in charge of making snow for the Winter Olympics in Russia caught a break over the past two months, when for two periods of about a week each temperatures dropped enough to make good snow, and lots of it.

title: Artists Gather for a Spoken-Word Tribute to the Diabolical Wit and Wisdom of John Baldessari
description: WhoA motley crew of L.A.s artistic elite, including upstarts like Alex Israel, Sam Falls and Dawn Kasper and heavies such as Allen Ruppersberg, Suzanne Lacy, William Leavitt and Jim Shaw, gathered to read writings by John Baldessari, a father figure to the Angeleno art world. They were joined by the unlikely pair of the power curator Hans Ulrich Obrist and the child actor turned TV producer Fred Savage, who has no discernible connection to Baldessari and looks like hes barely aged since The Wonder Years. Savage read Baldessaris Advice to Young Artists (1968). Bettina Korek, founder of the arts organization ForYourArt, hosted.

title: Brain Science to Beat Mental Disorders, Snow Made by Machine, Obesity Takes an Early Hold
description: Dr. Thomas R. Insel, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, on attacking mental illness by way of brain research; the science of filling Sochis slopes with Olympic snow; a new study shows that obesity is established very early in life.

title: These Two Leap to Judgment (Not That You Should, Too)
description: Christina Masciotti treats her characters with a kindness and patience that are usually accorded to only the very young or the very old. Take the middle-age father and adolescent daughter who make up the entire cast of Adult, Ms. Masciottis gentle new comedy at the Abrons Arts Center.

title: China to Ramp Up Military Spending
description: China already spends more on its military than any country in the world except the United States. Now, as defense budgets at the Pentagon and in many NATO countries shrink, Chinas Peoples Liberation Army is gearing up for a surge in new funding, according to a new report.

title: Take a Dumpling Detour
description: Whats for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: Luminaries to Light Up Small Screen
description: Eleanor Cattons Booker Prize-winning novel, The Luminaries, will be turned into a television mini-series, according to New Zealands Greymouth Star.

title: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Australia, Russia, Central African Republic and Indonesia.

title: Ethics Questions Arise as Genetic Testing of Embryos Increases
description: Her first thought after she heard the news, after she screamed and made her mother and boyfriend leave the room, was that she would never have children. Amanda Baxleys doctor had just told her, over a speakerphone in her psychiatrists office, that she had the gene for Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker disease, or GSS, which would inevitably lead to her slow and terrible death.

title: A Life Full of Dreams That Are Now Coming True
description: The story of Patina Miller, a star of Pippin, follows a familiar template. A girl from Pageland, S.C., grows up singing in church under the watchful eye of her grandmother. After studying musical theater, she makes a splash in the London production of Sister Act. Eventually she wins a Tony Award for best actress in a musical (the current revival of Pippin) and is now planning a June wedding.

title: Witness Uganda Wins Richard Rodgers Award for Musical Theater
description: Witness Uganda, a musical by Matt Gould and Griffin Matthews, has won the 2014 Richard Rodgers Production Award for Musical Theater, the American Academy of Arts and Letters announced on Monday.

title: Whats Behind the Declining Abortion Rate?
description: A new study released on Monday finds that the abortion rate among American women declined to its lowest level in more than three decades in 2011. Prepared by the Guttmacher Institute, the report points to some intriguing trends directly relevant to the current political battle over the contraception mandate.

title: A Frenchman Finds Its True. They Really Are Out to Get Him.
description: Robert Harriss novel An Officer and a Spy has a point of high drama when the main character, Col. Georges Picquart, is ushered into a room full of atypical characters: people who will actually listen to him. For the first three-quarters of this book Picquart has operated quietly, trying to piece together the facts of the infamous Dreyfus affair, which culminated in the conviction, humiliation and banishment of Alfred Dreyfus, a French officer convicted on impossibly scanty evidence of being a German spy. Dreyfus is a Jew swept away on a wave of anti-Semitism, but there is also a major element of malfeasance among military officers that brought him to his fate.

title: ScienceTake: Fight Club for Flies
description: Why are males aggressive? Researchers have found clues in the brains of fruit flies.

title: A Waiting Game After the Super Bowl: Hours in Line for the Train
description: For months, the organizers of the Super Bowl coaxed fans to ride the rails, urging them to renounce private car travel in the name of the New York regions famed public transportation system.

title: New CDs From Broken Bells, Toni Braxton and Babyface
description: BROKEN BELLS

title: To Study Aggression, a Fight Club for Flies
description: Males aggression toward each other is an old story throughout the animal kingdom. Its not that females arent aggressive, but in many species, male-on-male battles are more common.

title: Youre a Suspect. Thats the Drill.
description: I Call My Brothers, by the Swedish playwright Jonas Hassen Khemiri, tracks a fraught 24 hours in the life of young Arab-American man as he runs errands in New York City. The play, mostly narrated by the protagonist, Amor (Damon Owlia), stokes suspense by intimating that the story will take a dark, dramatic turn. Perhaps Amor will be tragically mistaken for a terrorist. Or maybe his anxieties will get the better of him, and that knife in his pocket will come flashing out.

title: A Master of Percussion, in Its Sounds and Gestures
description: Steven Schick, the percussionist, conductor and San Diego author and educator, turns 60 this year. As he likes to point out, that makes him older than Stockhausens Zyklus (1959), the first major composition for solo percussion.

title: Dallas Museum Lands a Rich Trove of Islamic Art
description: While Texas may have the fifth largest Muslim population in the United States by some estimates, its public art collections have only recently begun to reflect the 14-century sweep of Islamic history. But on Friday, with the stroke of a pen  sealing a complex agreement hashed out over months  the Dallas Museum of Art will become the long-term custodian of one of the most important collections of Islamic art in private hands.

title: A Conductor to Flex and See Through
description: University of Houston researchers say they have developed an electrical conductor that is both highly flexible and transparent, an elusive combination that could help usher in an age of flexible flat-screen televisions and smartphones.

title: Carly Rae Jepsen Takes a Cinderella Risk
description: When you are a newcomer who takes the charts  and auditory nerves  by storm, as Carly Rae Jepsen did with her runaway single Call Me Maybe, the pop-music playbook dictates what youre supposed to do next: Get back into the studio and record another hit before the clock strikes midnight on your good fortune.

title: How Much Is That Seat? A Travel Site Breaks It Down
description: THE online travel company TripAdvisor will introduce on Tuesday an ambitious redesign of its Flights search feature that will provide detailed information globally on any given flights price  including added charges for options like extra legroom  as well as on in-flight amenities like the availability of Wi-Fi and in-seat power ports.

title: Hollywood Was Just One of His Stages
description: For all his success in Hollywood  hits like The Hunger Games, an Academy Award for Capote, a promising Showtime series in the works  Philip Seymour Hoffman was the rare star who also worked nonstop in the less glamorous world of Off Broadway. It was his one professional constant during a 23-year career.

title: New Book on Snowden Revelations From Guardian Writer
description: Only eight months after Edward J. Snowden engineered the release of some of Americas most closely held secrets on electronic surveillance by the government, the first major book on the subject will be published.

title: A Timeline for the George Washington Bridge Scandal
description: Events in the scandal that has settled around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey regarding the motives behind the shutdown of some traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

title: A Proud Daughter Sways to Her Own Beat, While Dancing With Her Past
description: The Brazilian singer Maria Ritas exquisite concert on Sunday night at City Winery was daringly exposed in more ways than one.

title: Australian Catch-and-Kill Shark Policy, Meant to Reassure, Horrifies Some
description: SYDNEY, Australia  As Australians flocked to the beaches at the height of a hot Southern Hemisphere summer, a commercial fisherman hired for the task hauled in a 10-foot tiger shark caught on a baited line. The fisherman shot the shark in the head four times with a .22-caliber rifle off the coast of Western Australia and then towed the carcass out to sea, where it was dumped.

title: Times Minute | A Push for Pre-K
description: In the Video

title: Times Minute | A Push for Pre-K
description: State-funded preschool becomes a bipartisan issue. Also on the Minute, genetic testing on embryos and a miracle in Tacloban, the Philippines.

title: Take the Road Less Traveled; It May Lead to Barbecue
description: I LOVE business travel. I mean, I seriously love it, because every time I leave my home that means Im doing something to develop my company. Im the founder and designer for my business, Clothing Arts. We make travel apparel, so I might be meeting with a new buyer or an existing buyer or visiting some place to get inspiration. Im a former Wall Street trader, and now Im in the clothing business. I love every second of it. One business trip was five days long, and I was in India for a few of them, then Canada, then back to India, and then home. It was great.

title: Losing Their Religion, and Whats Next
description: Breaking Amish, Amish Mafia, Amish: Out of Order, Amish in the City, Witness: What did one small, quiet group of religious orders do to deserve all this?

title: Intersection: Colorful Style in London
description: In Londons diverse Brixton neighborhood, Michael Donkor, a teacher, describes his style as smart with a playful edge.

title: Rihanna Joins Viva Glam by MAC to Fight AIDS
description: Slowly, the sales of one lipstick brand have grown so large that the little-known charity it supports, the MAC AIDS Fund, has become the second-largest private donor to AIDS organizations, after the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

title: A. O. Scott on Philip Seymour Hoffman
description: The Times movie critic A. O. Scott talks about some of his favorite Philip Seymour Hoffman roles, and what defines the actors legacy.

title: Three Views of Philip Seymour Hoffman
description: Moved by the news of Philip Seymour Hoffmans death, we immediately thought of these photographs, which the magazine had specially commissioned of the notable actor over the years.In the summer of 2002 the magazine asked Gregory Crewdson to create the pictures for the inaugural edition of a photo essay section of the magazine, Portfolio. For his setting, he chose an empty house in Rutland, Vt., that had caught his imagination, and for our part we decided to pair him with well-known actors, a departure for Crewdson, whose mysterious, haunting images until then had all featured anonymous subjects. Our hope was to bring a new twist to celebrity portraiture and produce some unusual images. One of the actors cast for the Dream House portfolio was Philip Seymour Hoffman. He agreed to go up to Rutland on a Sunday in August. I remember thinking, as we were driving to meet up with him at our rendezvous in a shopping center parking lot, How will we know which car he is in? But there in the big empty lot, in one lone car smack in the middle of it, was a man reading The New York Times. Philip Seymour Hoffman knew how to make an entrance.

title: Back to Job Hunt After Sharing State of the Union Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  For a brief moment last week, at the request of the White House, Misty DeMars was the face of long-term unemployment in the United States. The attention has not led to any job offers, not yet at least, but she is hopeful. I think I can boost my rsum by adding that I wrote part of the State of the Union 2014, Ms. DeMars, 37, said wryly.

title: Blazing Trails in Brain Science
description: BETHESDA, Md.  The police arrived at the house just after breakfast, dressed in full riot gear, and set up a perimeter at the front and back. Not long after, animal rights marchers began filling the street: scores of people, young and old, yelling accusations of murder and abuse, invoking Hitler, as neighbors stepped out onto their porches and stared.

title: Joan Mondale, Who Merged Politics With Art, Dies at 83
description: Joan Mondale, whose promotion and advocacy of painting, sculpture and other fine arts earned her the nickname Joan of Art in Washington during the vice presidency of her husband, Walter F. Mondale, in the late 1970s, died on Monday in Minneapolis. She was 83.

title: Tax Expert Sees Abuse in a Stream of Private Equity Fees
description: The tax practices of private equity firms have come under scrutiny from the authorities on several fronts. But there is an additional tax strategy that should merit a skeptical look, an academic argues in a new article.

title: Art Matters | An Outlaw Art Fair Sets up Shop on L.A.s Frontier
description: Despite its rising profile as an art capital, Los Angeles has never quite mustered an internationally attended art week until, arguably, just now. This years festivities, which concluded yesterday with the close of the Art Los Angeles Contemporary fair at the Barker Hangar in Santa Monica and the LA Art Book Fair at The Geffen Contemporary at MOCAin the Downtown area, felt buzzier than in years past  due, in part, to the addition of a newcomer to the circuit.

title: Iran Giving Food Away to Millions for Relief
description: TEHRAN  The Iranian government has started handing out food packages for millions of its citizens both to help those with low income and to try to lower inflation on food, local news media reported on Monday.

title: In Switch, Refusal to Testify Wins a Brooklyn Man His Freedom
description: For the last eight months, a Brooklyn man had been held in jail because of his refusal to testify before a grand jury that was believed to be examining a 2008 explosion in Times Square.

title: Dutch Reporter Is Forced to Flee Egypt as Pursuit of Al Jazeera Journalists Snares More Victims
description: Last Updated, Tuesday, 2:18 a.m. | As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, the Qatari news network Al Jazeera condemned on Monday what it described as an attempt to demonize two of its reporters, Peter Greste and Mohamed Fahmy, with the release of video recorded during their arrest in December at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo.

title: Fast Internet Is Chattanoogas New Locomotive
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  For thousands of years, Native Americans used the river banks here to cross a gap in the Appalachian Mountains, and trains sped through during the Civil War to connect the eastern and western parts of the Confederacy. In the 21st century, it is the Internet that passes through Chattanooga, and at lightning speed.

title: Catering to the Chinese Shoppers Grand Tour
description: PARIS  Xiaoyan Mao had not yet collected her luggage after landing at Charles de Gaulle Airport from Shanghai recently. But she and a friend were already mapping out a game plan for the three days they would spend in Paris before continuing a 10-day European blitz with additional stops in Switzerland, Italy and Germany.

title: Trade Issue Goes Untouched as Obama and Reid Meet
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama met with Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, at the White House on Monday but made no effort to change Mr. Reids mind on the trade initiative that has divided them, according to Democrats briefed on the session.

title: Tacloban Three Months Later
description: Nearly three months after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the Philippines, many still live in tents with little electricity. Keith Bradsher reports from Tacloban.

title: U.S. Plans Car-to-Car Warning System
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government said on Monday that it planned to require all new cars to broadcast their location, speed, direction and other data, and to receive similar data from other vehicles, to warn drivers of impending collisions. But regulators cautioned that any new rules would be years away.

title: Boycott Israel? A War of Words
Russia: 3 Jailed in Anti-Gay Case
description: A court in Russias Far East on Monday found three men guilty of murdering a man in an attack that prosecutors said was motivated by homophobia. The three men were convicted of stabbing and beating the man, Oleg Serdyuk, to death in a forest near the village of Ust-Bolsheretskii in the Kamchatka region in May, and then burning his body in a car. Prosecutors said the defendants had killed Mr. Serdyuk because they believed he was gay. The men received sentences ranging from nine to 12 and a half years in a labor camp. Advocates for gay rights in Russia have claimed that the number of homophobic attacks has risen since the introduction of a law last year banning gay propaganda among children.

title: Legalizing Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: French Comic Barred
description: The controversial French comedian Dieudonn MBala MBala has been barred from entering Britain because of his extreme views, the Home Office said Monday. Mr. MBala MBala has been repeatedly convicted in France for inciting racial hatred, and his shows have been banned in several French towns. He has been criticized more recently for having invented the quenelle, a gesture that resembles a Nazi salute and carries anti-Semitic overtones, critics say. He says the gesture is social criticism, not aimed at any particular group. A spokeswoman for the Home Office said that Mr. MBala MBala was subject to an exclusion order, citing public policy or public security reasons.

title: Outdated Missile Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Quality in High Rises
description: To the Editor:

title: Advice for a Tall Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemical Safety: Views From Industry Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: I.V.F. in Israel, With Unexpected Help From a Stranger
description: Decisions about fertility often come down to what you can change and what you have to accept. Do you accept an infertility diagnosis? Do you detoxify to conceive naturally, as suggested by Julia Indichova (Inconceivable: A Womans Triumph Over Despair and Statistics) and Sami S. David (Making Babies: A Proven 3-Month Program for Maximum Fertility)? Or do you move on to in vitro fertilization?

title: Maintainer of City Watershed Fatally Shot, Officials Say
description: New Yorkers seldom stop to think that the water they use comes from reservoirs in the forests and wooded hills that stretch from Westchester County to the Catskills, or of the workers who keep it flowing, and safe. But early Monday morning, something happened to remind them.

title: Finnish Soul Is Reflected in Goalies
description: The duel at 178 feet between Antti Niemi and Tuukka Rask took place last month in California, with the fateful shot heard halfway around the world in Finland, long known for skiing, saunas, sunless winters and cellphones, and increasingly gaining notice for its puck stoppers.

title: At Four Seasons, Picasso Tapestry Hangs on the Edge of Eviction
description: For more than half a century, it has hung in the hallway of the Four Seasons Restaurant on Park Avenue, an immense work by one of the greatest artists of the 20th century. But Picassos curtain is coming down  and that might just destroy it.

title: When Loud Music Turned Deadly
description: This video tells the story of a black teenager in Florida who was killed by a white man after an argument over loud music. The slain youths father shares his loss.

title: Dissecting a Frog: How to Write a Humor Piece
description: Analyzing humor, as E.B. White famously said, is like dissecting a frog; few people are interested and the frog dies of it. Nonetheless, writing humor is a highly logical exercise  fit idea X into form Y for humorous result Z  and can therefore be broken down in ways that more slippery kinds of prose tend to resist.

title: Born While Floods Surge
description: Yolando was born during the worst of typhoon Haiyan. He lives with his family in a region devastated by the storm.

title: Dont Ask Your Doctor About Low T
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  A FUNNY thing has happened in the United States over the last few decades. Mens average testosterone levels have been dropping by at least 1 percent a year, according to a 2006 study in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism.

title: Detroit Turns Bankruptcy Into Challenge of Banks
description: Detroits bankruptcy is rapidly shaping up as a battle of Wall Street vs. Main Street, at least as far as the citys creditors are concerned.

title: Lawmaker Says Colleges Are Misleading on Aid Letter
description: Many top colleges are misleading applicants about the paperwork needed to seek financial aid, possibly violating federal law and costing students extra money, a congressman said on Monday.

title: Seahawks-Broncos Super Bowl TV Ratings Top 111 Million
description: The game was hardly an edge-of-the-seat thriller, but in the end the pull of the Super Bowl was all that mattered: A record 111.5 million viewers watched Foxs coverage of the Seattle Seahawks dismantling of the Denver Broncos, the Nielsen company reported on Monday.

title: Puppy Love Warms Hearts; Diversity Draws Mixed Response
description: THE annual flood of data after the Super Bowl indicates that the commercials during the game that did best among consumers on television, online and in social media were feel-good spots meant to be uplifting, inspirational, nostalgic or patriotic. And by almost all accounts, the spot that was discussed, liked and shared most was Puppy Love, a warm, emotional tale created by the Anomaly agency that Budweiser brought to viewers late in the fourth quarter.

title: Super Bowl Again Proves Bigger Than the Game Itself
description: The Super Bowl can be a great game or a bad game, a dramatic struggle or a laugher. And viewership hardly wavers.

title: Closing Arguments in Martoma Trial
description: Mathew Martoma, a former top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, pursued a canary in a coal mine to give him an illegal sneak preview of the results of a clinical Alzheimers drug trial, a prosecutor said on Monday in closing remarks for the governments closely watched insider trading case.

title: Hoffmans Heroin Points to Surge in Grim Trade
description: Detectives found dozens of small packages in the West Village apartment where Philip Seymour Hoffman, the actor, died on Sunday. Most were branded, some with purple letters spelling out Ace of Spades, others bearing the mark of an ace of hearts. At least five were empty, and in the trash.

title: Love, Death and Sochi
description: There are few moments sweeter, more humbling or more thrilling than telling someone you love how you feel.

title: Karzai Arranged Secret Contacts With the Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has been engaged in secret contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace agreement without the involvement of his American and Western allies, further corroding already strained relations with the United States.

title: What Machines Cant Do
description: Were clearly heading into an age of brilliant technology. Computers are already impressively good at guiding driverless cars and beating humans at chess and Jeopardy. As Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology point out in their book The Second Machine Age, computers are increasingly going to be able to perform important parts of even mostly cognitive jobs, like picking stocks, diagnosing diseases and granting parole.

title: Collegiate Womens Bowling Gains in Popularity
description: Bowl season has a completely different meaning to Dawn Gugliaro.

title: Second U.S. Bribery Trial Begins for Brooklyn Assemblyman
description: In October 2010, William F. Boyland Jr., a state assemblyman from Brooklyn, shared fine cuts of meat, wine and whiskey with two businessmen who were trying to buy Mr. Boylands political influence.

title: Olson and Boies, Legal Duo, Seek Role in 2 Cases on Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, the star legal duo who defied skeptics by successfully challenging Californias ban on same-sex marriage, are seeking to play a central role in the next round of marriage cases that appear to be on a fast track to the high court. But in doing so, they have touched off a debate over who gets the coveted job of arguing what could be a landmark gay rights decision.

title: When Loud Music Turned Deadly
description: This Op-Doc video tells the story of how a black 17-year-old, Jordan Davis, was killed by a 45-year-old white man, Michael Dunn, now charged with first-degree murder. The shooting took place at a gas station in Jacksonville, Fla., the day after Thanksgiving in 2012. It followed an argument in which Mr. Dunn complained about loud hip-hop music playing in Mr. Daviss friends car. Mr. Dunn has claimed he fired in self-defense after seeing a gun, which the police never found. Two lives, two outcomes, both tragic. Jury selection begins this week.

title: Too Many Sorry Excuses for Apology
description: It seems that just about every day a chief executive, politician or other prominent figure is apologizing for something.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 4, 2014
description: Nothing says hard-core like being cast out by Al Qaeda.

title: The Gun Report, 1 Year Later
description: It has been a year since my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I started publishing The Gun Report, an effort to use my blog to aggregate daily gun violence in America. Our methodology is pretty simple: We do a Google News search each weekday morning for the previous days shootings and then list them. Most days, we have been finding between 20 and 30 shootings; on Mondays, when we also add the weekends violence, the number is usually well over 100.

title: Bill Would Put Face on Anonymous Attack Ads
description: One campaign advertisement mailed to voters homes last fall suggested that a candidate for New York City comptroller deserved to be behind bars. Another highlighted accusations of sexual harassment against a City Council candidate. In a Russian-speaking enclave of Brooklyn, a robocall accused a Council hopeful of having once been an agent for the K.G.B.

title: Calling for an Apology Cease-Fire
description: In 1976, Elton John sang the memorable phrase Sorry seems to be the hardest word. Well, sorry has become one of the easiest and most convenient  and therefore least meaningful  words there is.

title: Firearms Toll Among the Young
description: The world at large heard instantly about the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., where 20 youngsters were murdered in 2012 in a terrifying spree of gunfire. Far less noticed but no less horrific is the unending toll from the more routine bursts of gunfire that each day send an average of 20 American children and adolescents to hospitals, many of them for long-term treatment.

title: A Chill on Speech
description: The New York Legislature is moving to pass a bill that would bar state financing for academic groups that have taken official action to boycott higher-education institutions in Israel. The initiative, which last week passed the State Senate, is now pending before the Assembly. It should be voted down by lawmakers, or, if they prove feckless, Gov. Andrew Cuomo should veto it.

title: Democracy in Thailand, Interrupted
description: These are dark days in Thailand, where an election on Sunday was disrupted by protesters whose demands for a suspension of democracy could lead to greater chaos. The countrys constitutional monarchy has faced coups and street protests in the past, but it has been a model of relative stability and development in Southeast Asia, a region known for its autocratic and brutal governments. As an American treaty ally, Thailand has been critically important in helping to reduce regional tensions and provided balance to the growing military assertiveness of China by championing trade and economic integration partly through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. On Sunday, protesters disrupted the vote by blocking the distribution of ballot boxes to polling places in about 11 percent of the countrys electoral districts. Because Thailands Constitution requires that 95 percent of parliamentary seats be filled before a new government can be formed, the disruption means the country will remain in limbo for months as election authorities try to conduct elections in those districts where protesters prevented a vote from taking place. A gun battle between protesters and government supporters left seven people injured on Saturday, a day before the elections.

title: The Mayor and the Unions
description: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, this is the month that the civic conversation shifts from lofty goals and progressive agenda setting  and, lets hope, snow plowing  to the gloomier and more combative subject of money.

title: They Often Elicit Blessings
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  One of the things I admire about young David Steinberg (calling him young probably grates on his nerves, but Im old enough to be his mother so I claim that right) is his enthusiasm for pushing the constructing envelope in what I consider to be a very productive way. Many beginning constructors find it enough to develop a simple, relatively tight theme and be done with it. Not Mr. Steinberg. He goes for the tough stuff and then tightens it up even more.

title: Parks Department Takes a Seat Behind Nonprofit Conservancies
description: Somewhere along the way, New York City lost its faith in its ability to run a parks department.

title: Move to Red Bulls Gets Convey Close to Home
description: One of the Red Bulls new players has a familiarity with the teams second-year coach, Mike Petke, that comes more from dynamic interchanges on the soccer field than from pedestrian chalk-talks after training.

title: Immigrant Youth Leaders Signal They May Be Open to a G.O.P. Compromise
description: WASHINGTON  Despite a defiant tone, immigrant youth leaders gathered here on Monday gave signs that they could consider supporting a Republican compromise proposal offering a path to citizenship for young people but not for other immigrants in the country illegally.

title: The Other Super Bowl Contest: Twitter vs. Facebook
description: From the start of the Super Bowl on Sunday, it was obvious that it was a one-sided match-up: the Seattle Seahawks quickly took the lead, leaving the Denver Broncos further and further behind in every quarter.

title: A Long Goodbye for a Lost Railroad
description: JIANGMEN, China  It has been decades since a train has passed through the old Beijie train station in southern China. On a recent winter morning, the only sign of activity came from a group of architecture students busy with their sketch pads.

title: The Casual Couture of the Average American
Corrections: February 4, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Championship Built in Carrolls Image
description: Pete Carroll bounded through the front doors of the Sheraton Times Square Hotel a little after 8 a.m. Monday. It was 10 hours after his Seattle Seahawks won Super Bowl XLVIII, so he had ample time to rest. He just didnt.

title: De Blasio Says New York Learned From Past Storm Mistakes
description: Grappling with the first of three snowstorms expected to hit New York City in a week, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday that his administration had learned from its mistakes and had already made changes to speed snow removal.

title: In Talk of Economy, Obama Turns to Opportunity Over Inequality
description: WASHINGTON  Like so many political fights, the one between President Obama and Republicans over income inequality has become a battle over language. Is it about inequality of incomes or of opportunity? On this question, the president and his party have moved in Republicans  and voters  direction.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 3, 2014
With New App, Facebook Aims to Make Its Users Feeds Newsier
description: Mark Zuckerberg dreams of a day when Facebooks computers would know you and your habits so well that it would deliver exactly the information you want to see  what he calls the best personalized newspaper in the world.

title: While Asking for Help, Detroit Sells a Comeback
description: DETROIT  Consider this public relations challenge, perhaps not seen since the Edsel: At the same time that beleaguered Detroit is emphasizing its desperate need for financial support, it is pitching itself as the city of the future.

title: Video of Journalists Arrest in Egypt Seen as Threat to Media
description: CAIRO  A leaked video of the arrest of two journalists offered a cinematic close-up on Monday of the new military-backed governments crackdown on dissent: slow-moving footage of a hotel room full of telecommunications equipment set to the thumping, sinister score of the recent superhero movie Thor: The Dark World.

title: Dispute Over Italian Marines Prompts Bickering in Indian Court, but No Resolution
description: NEW DELHI  With black-robed lawyers crammed into a courtroom, Indias Supreme Court refused on Monday to resolve a major international dispute that a top Italian diplomat warned could soon damage ties.

title: De Blasio Takes a Comedic Break on The Daily Show
description: He bragged about hanging Che Guevara posters in his office, announced plans to flood the Upper East Side with biblical insects, and declared that the horses of Central Park were being waterboarded in their stables.

title: Toyota Is Reported With Most Recalls in 2013
description: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013. The cars and trucks from Toyota and its Lexus brand were among the almost 22 million vehicles recalled last year in 632 recalls, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That figure compares with nearly 16.4 million vehicles recalled in 2012 and is the highest number since 2004, when recalled vehicles hit 30.8 million. The Chrysler Group ranked second, with almost 4.7 million vehicles recalled in 36 actions; and Honda and its Acura brand were third, with 15 recalls involving almost 2.8 million vehicles.

title: As Kidd Hits Stride, Nets Keep Improving by Nipping Sixers
description: Nets Coach Jason Kidd walked into a pregame news conference at Barclays Center on Dec. 3 with a sobering bit of information: He was relieving his top assistant, Lawrence Frank, of a majority of his coaching duties.

title: Former Aide to Christie Invokes Fifth Amendment Right
description: A former top aide to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey revealed Monday that she would not hand over documents in response to a subpoena from a legislative panel investigating the controversial closing of lanes at the George Washington Bridge last fall, citing her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

title: Trading Captain Isnt a Rarity in the N.H.L., and Usually Isnt a Productive Move
description: The uncertainty over the future of the Rangers captain, Ryan Callahan, continued Monday, with fans wondering whether he would be dealt before the trade deadline on March 5 or the Olympic roster freeze on Friday.

title: Jean Babile, Rebel of World Ballet, Dies at 90
description: Jean Babile, who gained instant stardom in French ballet as the violent chair-throwing youth in Roland Petits Le Jeune Homme et la Mort (The Young Man and Death) in 1946, and who remained international dances great rebel, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 90.

title: Falling to Bucks, the Knicks Continue a Pattern of Not Having One
description: MILWAUKEE  The fourth-quarter scenes played out in a way that could only make Knicks Coach Mike Woodson shudder. Amare Stoudamire dribbled into a lane crowded with Milwaukee Bucks and lost the ball. Out of the pack came Milwaukee forward Giannis Antetokounmpo, his long limbs churning upcourt on the way to a dunk that pushed the Bucks lead to 10.

title: Potent Pro-Israel Group Finds Its Momentum Blunted
description: WASHINGTON  The last time the nations most potent pro-Israel lobbying group lost a major showdown with the White House was when President Ronald Reagan agreed to sell Awacs surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia over the groups bitter objections.

title: Study Finds Changes in Brains of Hockey Players Who Had Concussions
description: Hockey players who sustained concussions during a recent season experienced acute microstructural changes in their brains, according to a series of studies published in the Journal of Neurosurgery on Tuesday.

title: How L.B.J. Pushed Through Kennedys Tax Cut
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Word of the Day | carapace
description: carapace\ker--pas, ka-r-\ noun

title: Study Puts Exonerations at Record Level in U.S.
description: The number of exonerations in the United States of those wrongly convicted of a crime increased to a record 87 during 2013, and of that number, nearly one in five had initially pleaded guilty to charges filed against them, according to a report to be released on Tuesday as part of a project led by two university law schools.

title: Mets Sign Farnsworth
description: The Mets continued to fill out their bullpen, announcing that they had signed Kyle Farnsworth to a minor league deal, with an invitation to spring training. Farnsworth, 37, had a 4.70 earned run average in 48 games last season, which he split between Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay.

title: Indian Groups Question Public Child-Welfare Practices
description: DENVER  Several prominent Native American groups on Monday called for the Justice Department to investigate the treatment of Indian children in public child-welfare systems and private adoptions.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) RUST AND BONE (2012) Ali (Matthias Schoenaerts), a former prizefighter fleeing with his young son (Armand Verdure) from a bad situation, arrives in Antibes, on the Cte dAzur. At a club where he works as a bouncer, he meets Stephanie (Marion Cotillard, above, with Mr. Schoenaerts), a trainer for a Sea World-like amusement park. Then she loses her legs in an accident with a killer whale and calls him, thinking he might help rouse her from her despair. A plot summary of Rust and Bone might suggest a maudlin, therapeutic fable of healing, and in many ways  or, lets say, in hindsight  the movie is just that, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But its conventional, sentimental essence (which is overtly revealed only at the end) is effectively complicated, indeed almost undone, by the jagged textures of the filmmaking and the naturalistic intensity of the performances. He added: The removal of Ms. Cotillards legs  including in scenes in which she wears a bathing suit or nothing  is surely one of the most impressive special-effects feats of the year, and a reminder that digital cinema is not all about accessorizing wizards, monsters and superheroes. But the greater marvel is Ms. Cotillard herself, an actress of limitless bravery and supernatural poise, who is both beauty and beast. Mr. Schoenaerts is her perfect foil and complement, as large and coarse as she is small and delicate, and also as tender as she is tough.

title: Adult Swim, No. 1 With Younger Adults, Is Expanding
description: The big developments in late-night television are not all happening on NBC this week. Adult Swim, the network that is, in many ways, the new force in late night, has some significant news, too: It is expanding again.

title: Stevie Nicks, Just Following Her Muse
description: During her 40-year career as a member of Fleetwood Mac and a solo artist, the singer-songwriter Stevie Nicks has made more than 40 Top 50 hits and sold over 140 million albums. In Your Dreams, a documentary film about the making of her 2011 album of the same name, was recently released on DVD. Now 65, Ms. Nicks called from a rented house in Phoenix, her hometown. A condensed and edited version of our conversation follows.

title: A Competition for Converts in Arunachal Pradesh
description: ITANAGAR, Arunachal Pradesh  Though the event they advertised had passed a month earlier, the neon-colored posters remained, clinging to the state capitals walls, lampposts and storefronts. On them were invitations to Indigenous Faith Day celebrations on Dec. 1, with slogans like Culture without faith is body without soul, and, more pointedly, Imitation of alien faith is slavery.

title: Foursquare Checks In With Microsoft and Gets $15 Million to Revitalize Itself
description: On Tuesday, Foursquare, the location-sharing application, announced a data licensing partnership and $15 million investment from Microsoft.

title: Profit Drops for BP, but Still Beats Analysts Forecasts
description: LONDON  BP, the British oil giant, on Tuesday joined other oil companies including Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil in reporting lower profit for the fourth quarter as production declined and the companys refineries struggled to make money.

title: Revamping and Tax Gain Help UBS Beat Estimates
description: Updated, 7:30 p.m. | The Swiss bank UBS reported higher-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday as a far-reaching revamping plan started to pay off and it benefited from a tax gain.

title: Test Yourself | History, Feb. 4
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Middle Class Is Steadily Eroding. Just Ask the Business World.
description: Nelson D. Schwartz writes about economic trends in the article The Middle Class Is Steadily Eroding. Just Ask the Business World.

title: In Rapid Turnaround, Toyota Is on Track to Post Record Earnings
description: TOKYO  While the American automakers have made drastic comebacks since the recession, no car company has had a bigger revival than Toyota.

title: Outsourced Cancer Research, by Spacecraft
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  A cancer research lab on the outskirts of Cambridge seems like an unlikely place to find innovations in gaming.

title: Can Marriage Cure Poverty?
description: Imagine a late-night television commercial aimed at Washingtons wonks: Tired of your same old tax credits and grant proposals? Ever dreamed of a policy tool that improved childrens health, bolstered income and eradicated poverty  all without costing the government a penny? Then, a smash cut to a wedding scene.

title: In the Bronx, 20 Kids and Counting
description: One of the first things Stephen Reiss noticed about Eshey Scarborough-Harriss office were the photos she had of her children. There were a lot. More than a dozen.

title: If You Were Governor of Your State, How Would You Spend a Budget Surplus?
description: We have become so used to hearing news about layoffs and spending cuts over the past several years that you may not remember what its like to have a government surplus  but thats exactly whats happening in many states. Politicians now have to figure out what to do with that extra money.

title: Times Minute | Karzai and the Taliban
description: Also on the Minute, a sharp increase in heroin overdose deaths in New York City and a man in India goes all out for his 100th birthday celebration.

title: Times Minute | Karzai and the Taliban
description: In the Video

title: New York Today: A Slushy Interlude, Then More Snow
description: Updated 10:10 a.m.

title: For a Select Few, the Transformative Power of Facebookfor Better or Worse
description: On Tuesday, Facebook turns 10. Over the last decade, it has grown from a website coded in a dorm room to a Silicon Valley giant. It has been at the center of privacy and security backlashes and controversies  some short and others lasting  over new policies and one redesign after another.

title: Rights Group Releases Video of LGBT Attacks in Russia
description: With just days left until the start on Friday of the Sochi Winter Olympics, Human Rights Watch released a video on Tuesday that highlights the disturbing violence and discrimination that gay, lesbian, transgender and bisexual people face in Russia.

title: Photographer Shifts from Automotive Espionage to Fine Art
description: CHANDLER, ARIZ.  Brenda Priddy has become known around the world for her automotive spy photography. In her line of work, she stalks heavily camouflaged prototype vehicles being driven in secret  or so the engineers at the wheel have thought.

title: The Censorship Pendulum
description: BEIJING  IF you want to understand the current state of self-expression in China, the best indicator must be the line Sorry, the text has been deleted.

title: Democracy in Thailand
description: Different visions are pulling the country in different directions.

title: When Plan A Doesnt Work
description: Three years ago, I had an idea for a technology company. I noticed that the daily deal sites like Groupon and LivingSocial were starting to wane, and I thought I had a better model. I mocked up some designs, built a PowerPoint deck, and took the concept to investors. After a year of pitching, I raised the money, hired a team, and set about building the product, which we called Posse.

title: Beating the Curse of the Ninth
description: LONDON  Two years ago when Peter Maxwell Davies  doyen of British composers and Master of the Queens Music  produced a Ninth Symphony he was asked, repeatedly, if he shouldnt be worried about the Curse of the Ninth: a long-cherished myth of classical music claiming that if you manage to write nine symphonies you probably wont live to complete a 10th.

title: Venture Capital Firm Focused on the Midwest Raises a $250 Million Fund
description: Mark D. Kvamme, a former partner at the venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, considers himself a Silicon Valley guy through and through, having grown up in the region and spent his professional life there.

title: Veteran Banker to Lead Citigroups British Business
description: LONDON  James Bardrick, a veteran banker in London, has been named head of Citigroups business in Britain.

title: Close but Not Quite
description: A slightly unusual word choice can enliven a story. But we should make sure we know what our slightly unusual word actually means.

title: Where White Means Diversity
description: A FEDERAL COURT DECISION concerning competition between Marylands predominantly white public universities and its predominantly black ones has turned the spotlight on diversification of historically black colleges.

title: Hard Times at Howard U.
description: IT COULD BE SAID that Dr. Wayne A.I. Frederick, acting president of Howard University, was to the manner born.
