On his birth 42 years ago in Port of Spain, Trinidad, his mother had already determined he would follow in the footsteps of the man she admired most: Eric Williams, who before leading Trinidad and Tobago to independence from Britain had taught at Howard.

title: Spike Jonze Lives a 5-Year Relationship in 1 Day
description: LOS ANGELES  Spike Jonze, who won the Writers Guild Award for best original screenplay for Her over the weekend, has a slightly unusual writer-director process: he spends a long time in the edit room, as much as a year, tweaking the script continually as he goes. But in one way, Her appeared on screen as originally written: the flashbacks between Joaquin Phoenixs character, Theodore Twombly, and his ex-wife, played by Rooney Mara. Those scenes flesh out his romantic life before he falls for his computer operating system, voiced by Scarlett Johansson.

title: Playing on de Blasios Softball Team
description: Dear Diary:

title: Hold the Apologies
description: What does saying sorry mean when its tossed around with the frequency of a Justin Bieber scandal? asks Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column. Almost every day, some prominent figure  a chief executive, a politician, an athlete  is apologizing for something  to say nothing of the average person. Are we in the midst of an apology crisis? To hear Dov Seidman talk about it, the answer is an emphatic yes. And in fact, Mr. Seidman is so sure that our mea culpas have become meaningless that he called for an apology cease-fire in front of several dozen chief executives and politicians at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Remembering to Pray
description: Sometimes, toward end of day, I jog on a beach nearby on Mobile Bay. As the sun is sinking I look out at the pelicans wheeling in the sky, the fishermen on Fairhope Pier casting their nets, sailboats and channel markers changing to silhouette.

title: The Moment | Back to the Land
description: Theres a handcrafted earthiness to urban dressing this season.

title: Microsoft Names New Chief; Gates Becomes Adviser
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft on Tuesday announced that Satya Nadella was its next leader, betting on a longtime engineering executive to help the company keep better pace with changes in technology.

title: After 2 Years in Moscow, U.S. Envoy Is Resigning
description: MOSCOW  The United States ambassador to Russia announced Tuesday that he would resign after the Winter Olympics, set to begin in Sochi this week, ending a stormy two-year tenure during which relations between the two countries were at their lowest ebb since the end of the Cold War.

title: Lenovo Shares Tumble in Wake of Companys Deal Spree
description: After taking off for the Chinese New Year holiday, shareholders in Lenovo appear to be having some cold feet about the computer makers recent deal spree.

title: In Our Pages: February 5
description: 1914: Military Revolt Occurs in Peru

title: 6th India Art Fair Reports Strong Sales
description: NEW DELHI  On the heels of Christies successful auction in India, the sixth edition of the India Art Fair demonstrated that demand in the countrys art market remains strong.

title: ARM Reports Loss as Sales of High-End Smartphones Slow
description: LONDON  In the latest sign that the market for high-end smartphones is stalling, ARM Holdings, the British semiconductor designer, reported on Tuesday a net loss for its fourth quarter as royalties from its chip designs continued to falter.

title: Market for Patents Was Softer in 2013, Firms Say
description: Technology companies have for years been stockpiling patents as an aggressive defense against lawsuits. But patent prices and transfers were down significantly in 2013, according to data from a patent brokerage company and an intellectual property valuation and investment firm.

title: The Embarrassing Debt Ceiling Ritual
description: Jack Lew, the Treasury secretary, must be tired of this embarrassing ritual by now. Every few months, he has to notify Congress that the entirely unnecessary borrowing limit that lawmakers have insisted on imposing must be raised yet again. Then he has to wait while Republicans contort themselves to keep the government out of default while trying to persuade the hard right that they really hate doing so.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Names Satya Nadella Its New Chief
description: Microsoft on Tuesday announced that Satya Nadella would be its next leader, betting on a longtime engineering executive to help the company keep better pace with changes in technology, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: The Booming Blog Says Goodbye
description: The Booming blog, as now configured, is coming to an end.

title: Brisk Business in Big Law Firms Hiring Other Firms Partners, Study Finds
description: The countrys biggest law firms are hiring other firms partners at a rapid pace, a new study has found. Lawyers specializing in corporate work are the hottest commodities, an annual tally by the legal journal American Lawyer showed.

title: U.S. Push to Export Dirty Fossil Fuels Parallels Past Action on Tobacco
description: I encourage you to read How the U.S. Exports Global Warming, a fine feature by Tim Dickinson in Rolling Stone showing how the United States, flush with coal, oil and the dirty tar sands byproduct petroleum coke, is working hard, from the White House down, to become a big exporter of carbon. Heres the nut paragraph, which draws an apt parallel to the history of tobacco regulation and trade:

title: How Does the Classic Marriage Plot Stand Up in 2014?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Dana Stevens discuss whether the classic marriage plot  desire, courtship, happily ever after  stand up in 2014?

title: Amid Ethics Inquiry, South Jersey Democrat Is Giving Up House Seat for a New Job
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Robert E. Andrews announced on Tuesday that he would resign from Congress after more than two decades, but said it had nothing to do with a bleak outlook for Democratic chances of retaking the House or with an ethics investigation into alleged misuse of his campaign funds.

title: Minnesotas Olympic Hockey Cradle (Pop. 1,781)
description: WARROAD, Minn.  This time, no royal titles were conferred, like King and Queen of the Frosty Festival, which T. J. Oshie and Gigi Marvin were crowned at Warroad High School in 2005.

title: Signs of Progress in UBS Investment Bank Overhaul
description: More than a year ago, UBS pledged to overhaul its investment bank after a prominent trading loss and a rate-rigging scandal. Those efforts appeared to be bearing fruit, based on the banks latest earnings report released Tuesday.

title: Sphinx Organization to Join With IMG Artists in Aiding Student Musicians
description: The Sphinx Organization, an organization based in Detroit that offers classical music training to minority students, announced a partnership with the management agency IMG Artists on Tuesday, in which Sphinxs orchestras would perform at festivals and other events run by IMG, and IMGs artists would collaborate with Sphinx. Aaron P. Dworkin, the violinist who founded Sphinx in 1996 and has built it into a national program that runs competitions and sends touring ensembles around the country, described the agreement as a relationship unlike the usual arrangement between managers and artists.

title: Moderate Me Me Me Blogging
description: So Noah Smith has a piece about how moderate yours truly really is. Its almost completely right, except that I wish Noah would stop saying that my views on monetary policy in a liquidity trap derive from Eggertsson/Woodford; its a fine paper, but they were following me, not the other way around. Also, Arcade Fires My body is a cage isnt a cover of Peter Gabriel; he was covering them.

title: For Adults Only
description: The cheeky British artist Sarah Lucas returns to New York with a solo exhibition at the Gladstone Gallery.

title: Facebook, by the Numbers
description: Started at Harvard in 2004 as a way for college students to connect with each other, Facebook over 10 years has evolved into a global icon.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Health Care for Profit
Initial Autopsy Shows Arunachal Pradesh Student Had Head Injuries, Uncle Says
description: NEW DELHI  Initial autopsy results show that Nido Tania, an 18-year-old student from the northeast who was allegedly beaten by shopkeepers in south Delhi last week, had head injuries and brain swelling before he died, Mr. Tanias uncle told India Ink on Tuesday.

title: More Than a Dozen Killed in Attacks in Baghdad Area
description: BAGHDAD  Two rockets slammed into the zone in Baghdad where diplomatic and government offices are located, and a wave of bombings struck across the rest of the city on Tuesday, killing more than a dozen people, according to security sources.

title: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force
description: WASHINGTON  A Congressional Budget Office analysis released Tuesday predicted that the Affordable Care Act would shrink the work force by the equivalent of more than two million full-time positions and recharged the political debate over the health care law, providing Republican opponents fresh lines of attack and putting Democrats on the defensive.

title: Times Minute | Microsoft's New CEO
description: Also on the Minute, Facebook turns 10 and a fight club for flies.

title: Times Minute | Microsofts New C.E.O.
description: In the Video

title: For Restaurants, an Arcane Water Rule Is Going Away
description: A local regulation on drinking, on the books even longer than Prohibition was, has been flouted so routinely that when its repeal goes into effect this month most New Yorkers will probably not even notice.

title: Cate Blanchett Loves Santa Barbara (and Heres Why)
description: The Santa Barbara International Film Festival, which began last week and runs through Sunday, is not shy about announcing its intentions to the Oscar crowd, touting itself as a must-stop for front-runners on the awards-season fast track.

title: Wheelies: The Ram On Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Today in Small Business: Spying on Employees
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: At Bouley Botanical, Planters Overflow
description: Outside, there was a marrow-freezing snowstorm. But inside, at the corner of Church and White Streets in TriBeCa, windows burst forth with green, midsummer-like vegetation. This is Bouley Botanical, the latest enterprise/experiment from the chef David Bouley.

title: Time Inc. to Cut 500 Jobs Ahead of Spinoff
description: Time Inc., the magazine giant with brands including People, Sports Illustrated and Fortune, began a new round of layoffs on Tuesday as part of a companywide restructuring that will result in the loss of about 500 jobs, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: James J. Gallagher Dies at 87; Educator Focused on Disabled and Gifted
description: James J. Gallagher, an authority on child development whose work expanded educational opportunities for disabled and gifted children nationwide, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 87.

title: Evaporating Unemployment
description: Before the recession, in December 2007, about 63 percent of American adults had jobs. Six years later, in December 2013, less than 59 percent of adults had jobs.

title: Image of the Day: February 4
Britain Says India Did Not Follow Its Advice in 1984 Army Raid
description: LONDON  Britain sent a military officer to advise India before Indian forces stormed the Golden Temple in Amritsar in 1984, leaving hundreds dead, but the advice was largely ignored and had little impact on the bloody outcome, the British government said on Tuesday.

title: Designer Seed Thought to Be Latest Target by Chinese
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The case of the missing corn seeds first broke in May 2011 when a manager at a DuPont research farm in east-central Iowa noticed a man on his knees, digging up the field. When confronted, the man, Mo Hailong, who was with his colleague Wang Lei, appeared flushed. Mr. Mo told the manager that he worked for the University of Iowa and was traveling to a conference nearby. When the manager paused to answered his cellphone, the two men sped off in a car, racing through a ditch to get away, federal authorities said.

title: Fraud in Army Recruiting Bonus Program May Cost Nearly $100 Million
description: WASHINGTON  An Army program meant to increase the number of recruits during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars devolved into an illegal free-for-all that could cost taxpayers close to $100 million, military investigators say, describing new details of what they called a long-running scheme among National Guard recruiters that went undetected for years.

title: Mr. Fremantles Adventure
description: In early 1864, printers in New York and Mobile, Ala. began to publish one of the most unusual books of the Civil War: the diary of a British officer, Lt. Colonel Arthur Fremantle, who had spent three months observing the war, on both sides. Though he began his tour with a pro-Union bias on account of his opposition to slavery, Fremantle traveled extensively through the South. Entering through Mexico, he crossed the Rio Grande on April 7, 1863, and left New York to return to Britain 14 weeks later. His insights into the Confederacy, though at times myopic, especially on the question of slavery, offer one of the best single sources on life in the wartime South.

title: Scenes From Hockeytown USA
description: Images from the tiny town of Warroad, Minn., the home of two indoor ice rinks and eight Olympic hockey players.

title: California Teacher Accused of Sexual Abuse in YouTube Video Is Arrested
description: A former California teacher and school administrator is expected to be arraigned Thursday on 16 felony charges of sexual assault after a former student confronted her over the telephone and then posted a video recording of the conversation on YouTube, according to a statement from the district attorneys office in Riverside, Calif.

title: Bookshelf | Portraits of the Hudson Valleys Creative Community
description: When Pete Seeger died last week, folk music lost one of its greatest pioneers, but so, too, did the Hudson Valley. Seeger had called the bucolic area just north of New York City home since the late 40s, when he spent $1,700 for 17 acres in Beacon. It was from his house there that Seeger began, in the 60s, his crusade to clean up the polluted Hudson River via his environmental nonprofit, the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater. Seeger was inspired artistically throughout his lifetime by the force of the mighty, meandering river, and it was Seeger that the British graphic designer Nick Hand initially had in mind when he decided, in the spring of 2012, to log about 550 miles biking through the region to interview and photograph members of its artisan community. The results are compiled in his new and lovely little book, Conversations on the Hudson (Princeton Architectural Press).

title: In London: Three Plays, Double Standards
description: LONDON  The exorcists job is far from over, it seems. More than a century after they were first conjured, the title figures of Ibsens Ghosts, those remnants of corrosive societal traditions, are still clinging to us like leeches.

title: Christies Cancels Sale of Joan Miro Works Owned by Portugal
description: MADRID  On Tuesday, the auction house Christies canceled a London sale of a collection of 85 works by the Catalan artist Joan Mir, owned by Portugal.

title: A Portable Music Player That May Outdo Some Home Systems
description: Who needs a $2,000 iPod?

title: At Microsoft, a Step Forward as Founders Step Back
description: Microsofts founding fathers are finally receding into the middle distance. Satya Nadellas experience makes him a solid choice to succeed the longtime chief executive, Steven Ballmer. Better still, he will have greater room to maneuver as Bill Gates steps down as chairman. Mr. Nadella will need to grapple with his predecessors bad decisions, like the Nokia deal, and hes unlikely to pursue a breakup. But he can focus on what the company does best.

title: Team Harry vs. Team Ron
description: J. K. Rowlings admission that Hermione Granger should not have ended up with Ron Weasley at the end of the Harry Potter series has sent shock waves through the lives of people heavily invested in the lives of fictional adolescent wizards.

title: British Insurer Names R.B.S.s Former Chief as Its C.E.O.
description: LONDON  The British insurer RSA Group said on Tuesday that it had tapped the former chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland as its top executive two months after the insurer announced a huge hole in its balance sheet.

title: Obamacare and the Decline of Work
description: The headlines forthe new Congressional Budget Office report on the health care lawemphasize the botched roll-outs potential impact on enrollment, but this strikes me as quite possibly the bigger deal:

title: Same Old Stadium, Same Winning Approach for the As
description: Frustration is useless, so the Oakland Athletics insist they do not feel it. This is hard to believe, but maybe it is part of the reason that, as the game keeps evolving, the As remain one step ahead.

title: Westchester Leader Moves Toward a Bid for Governor
description: ALBANY  Nine months before Election Day, New York Republicans have inched closer to finding a potential candidate for governor, with word that Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, has formed an exploratory committee.

title: Dont Look for de Blasio in the St. Patricks Day Parade
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio says he wont be marching in the St. Patricks Day Parade because its organizers dont allow Irish gays and lesbians to march behind banners, signs, flags or other symbols that proclaim gay identity and pride.

title: Russia Says Syria Will Export Chemicals by March 1
description: Seeking to mollify international officials impatient with Syria for missing deadlines to destroy its chemical weapons, Russia said on Tuesday that the Syrian government planned to send a large shipment out of the country this month and to export its entire stockpile by March 1.

title: L.A. Dance Project Finds a New Home at Ace Hotel
description: The L.A. Dance Project, started in 2012 by the former New York City Ballet dancer Benjamin Millepied, has a new home. Its the Theater at Ace Hotel, a 1600-seat space in downtown Los Angeles that occupies the ground floor of a new boutique hotel created in in a 1927 building. The company will have its first performances there on Feb. 20, with Justin Pecks Murder Ballads, a new work by Hiroaki Umeda, and Mr. Millepieds Reflections.

title: The Seeds of a New Generation
description: John D. Jackson lives in the heart of the Corn Belt, where most of the corn has nothing to do with sweet kernels on the cob. His farm in Southern Illinois typically grows field corn, the high-starch variety that is turned into ethanol and cattle feed. He also works as a logistics manager for Archer Daniels Midland, the agricultural giant that produces the other big artifact of this crop: high fructose corn syrup.

title: Obama Announces Pledges of $750 Million for Student Technology
description: ADELPHI, Md.  Business leaders have pledged more than $750 million as part of a White House initiative to strengthen access to technology for 99 percent of students within five years, President Obama announced on Tuesday.

title: Video: Filming Dallas Buyers Club
description: Dallas Buyers Club came away empty-handed from the Writers Guild Awards over the weekend, but the film, including its screenplay, is still very much in contention at the Oscars. The Baggers colleague Mekado Murphy spoke with the director, Jean-Marc Valle, about his filmmaking approach, which could be summed up in a phrase: let the shots breathe.

title: Regulator Compares Currency Investigation to Libor Case
description: LONDON Expect more bad news from banks about accusations of manipulation in the huge foreign exchange market.

title: What, Us Worry?
description: Reading the latest Pew Research Center report on global attitudes toward aging made me think of Mad magazine.

title: The Best Time to Talk to Your Children About the Next National Tragedy? Now
description: The best time to think about how youll tackle difficult subjects with your children is before the need arises.

title: Paying the Rent on Time Can Enhance Your Credit Report
description: If youre a young person just starting out in the working world, you may not have much of a credit history, especially if you dont have student loans or have never had a credit card.

title: The Gun Report: February 4, 2014
Target Vows to Speed Anti-Fraud Technology
description: WASHINGTON  A top executive of Target told a Senate committee on Tuesday that the company was accelerating plans to adopt a technology widely used in Europe but rare in the United States that reduces potential for credit card fraud, and lawmakers from both parties called on other businesses to do the same.

title: Food Matters | Hot Dog!
description: From restaurants to bicycle-pushed carts, purveyors all over Paris are embracing the humble hot dog, elevating it to something original and unexpectedly stylish. At both of its 10th Arrondissement locations, Hutch Hotdog House serves all-chicken sausages blanketed with onion jam, homemade pickles and chili sauce. Custom-made franks, flavored mustards and Raclette give le chien chaud a gourmet twist at Little Fernand near the Porte Saint-Denis, while the organic all-beef dog entices an otherwise demure crowd at the new cocktail den Glass. Vegetarians can also get in on the action at Le Tricycle, a traveling cart specializing in meat-free dogs named after rappers (the Nate and the Snoop).

title: Aston Martin Starts Recall Anew After Finding Counterfeit Material in Repair Pedal Assembly
description: After discovering that a supplier in China had used counterfeit material, Aston Martin said it would re-do a 5,000-vehicle recall issued because the accelerator pedal assembly could break. The automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of the do-over in a report posted on the agencys website.

title: Activist Investor Takes Aim at Helen of Troy
description: Updated, 2:07 p.m. |

title: An Unusual Partnership to Tackle Stubborn Diseases
description: The National Institutes of Health, 10 large drug companies and seven nonprofit organizations announced  an unconventional partnership on Tuesday intended to speed up development of drugs to treat Alzheimers disease, Type 2 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

title: Christies Other Congestion Problem
description: Adding to his troubles over the monster traffic jams that his aides deliberately caused at the George Washington Bridge last year, New Jerseys Governor Chris Christie is now facing more bad press about gridlock in his state.The problem, as more than 33,000 football fans are still grousing about days later, is that New Jerseys transit system wasnt really ready for the Super Bowl on Sunday night.

title: Senate Passes Long-Stalled Farm Bill, With Clear Winners and Losers
description: WASHINGTON  No one was happier than Danny Murphy, a Mississippi soybean farmer with 1,500 acres, when the Senate on Tuesday passed a farm bill that expanded crop insurance and other benefits for agribusiness. Its a relief, Mr. Murphy said.

title: Navy Opens Inquiry Into Cheating in Reactor Training
description: WASHINGTON  The Navy said Tuesday that it had begun an investigation into whether senior enlisted sailors training on nuclear reactors had been cheating on written tests, adding to the list of recent military cheating scandals.

title: Familiar Hotel Brands Expand in China
description: Chinese travelers are the biggest spenders when it comes to international tourism, according to the United Nations World Tourism Organization, and American hotels are pulling out all the stops to win them over, putting teakettles in the guest rooms, congee rice porridge on the menus and Mandarin speakers on staff.

title: Hotel Review: W Singapore
description: Rates

title: Drama League Fellowship to Support Female Writer-Directors
description: The Drama League, a New York organization that provides training and financial support to theater artists, is establishing a new fellowship for female writer-directors who are creating original work, league members announced on Monday night at their annual gala. The fellowship is named for Beatrice Terry, an alumna of the organizations Directors Project who was an assistant or associate director on several Broadway shows including the Tony Award-winning musicals Spring Awakening and Memphis. Ms. Terry died in 2012 from cancer at the age of 52.

title: His-and-Hers Jams, a New Cocktail Menu at the Dead Rabbit and More
description: To Savor: Macarons Arrive in SoHo, With a Little Company

title: For Motorola Mobility, Third Place Was Far From Enough
description: New data from ComScore, the market research company, makes one thing very clear: In the brutal smartphone market, being No. 3 is not something to brag about.

title: Easy Sheet Pan Chicken
description: Melissa Clark makes an entire family meal (crunchy chicken with broccoli rabe and sweet potatoes) on two simple sheet pans.

title: Behold, the Sturdy Sheet Pan
description: Of all the fancy kitchen equipment in my prodigious collection  the copper gratin dishes, the pressurized siphon, the multifunctional immersion blender  its the humble sheet pans I reach for most often.

title: In Yearlong Clash Over Herbalife, Innuendo Trumps Clarity
description: William A. Ackman, the founder of the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, announced his big short on Herbalife more than a year ago, and many are still unsure whether hes right or wrong. You might think that is a problem, but for some of Herbalifes investors, the truth doesnt appear to matter much as they have been profiting from the wild swings in the stock price.

title: Christopher Sieber Joins the Cast of Matilda
description: The Tony-nominated actor Christopher Sieber will return to Broadway to play the evil headmistress Agatha Trunchbull in Matilda the Musical, the shows producers have announced. Mr. Sieber is to make his debut as the character on March 18.

title: Annisa
description: Anita Los Greenwich Village restaurant earns a third star.

title: U.S. Spy Chief Says Assad Has Strengthened His Hold on Power
description: WASHINGTON  The countrys top intelligence official said Tuesday that President Bashar al-Assads hold on power in Syria had strengthened over the past year, and that he had benefited from a deal to abandon his chemical weapons arsenal.

title: S.&P. Lowers Puerto Rico Debt to Junk Status
description: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | Standard & Poors downgraded the debt of Puerto Rico to junk status on Tuesday, intensifying a cash squeeze for the commonwealth, whose financial condition is of outsize importance to the rest of the United States because its debt is widely held by individual investors through mutual funds.

title: 200 Prompts for Argumentative Writing
Developer From Peru Has Eye on Detroit
description: DETROIT  It was late Friday afternoon before Labor Day weekend when Fernando Palazuelo reached the head of the line at the tax collection window of the treasurers office in Wayne County, Mich.

title: Bodega Negra Opens a Branch in New York
description: Headliner

title: How Many Non-Combatants Are Killed by Drones?
description: Adam Schiff, a Democratic congressman from California, urged the nations intelligence leaders today to get behind an important idea: The Obama administration, he said, should publish an annual report on American drone strikes, showing how many combatants and especially how many non-combatants are killed by unmanned aircraft each year.

title: Michael Kors Is Now a Billionaire
description: A high-flying stock price has made Michael Kors rich. Just how rich? On Tuesday, the clothing designer became a billionaire.

title: Hearing Its Own Drummer
description: I THINK THE NEWS is out that Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has become overrun by glassy condos and slapped-up townhomes harboring gentlemen with archaic facial hair patterns sustained by 10-course tasting menus festooned with twigs. But it was still jarring, and not in an artisanal-jam kind of way, to glimpse Chanel and Prada placards looming in an opticians window just outside the Bedford Avenue L stop, that culturally freighted crossroads of the new youthquake. So SoHo, so soon.

title: Listen Up | Singer-Songwriter Jenny Lewiss Perfect New Single for Girls
description: The love-it-or-hate-it HBO series Girls, now in its third season, has had its share of memorable musical moments. The buried 90s treasure Steal My Sunshine by Len made a hilarious comeback during a scene in Chris ODowds characters luxury condo and Hannah all but launched the Swedish duo Icona Pops career when she let loose to their dance-floor anthem I Love It. This season, the Girls music team commissioned Jenny Lewis, the L.A.-based singer-songwriter and former frontwoman of the defunct L.A. indie band Rilo Kiley, to write asingle, Completely Not Me the crown jewel of the shows new soundtrack album (which also includes tunes from Father John Misty, Lily Allen, Beck, Cat Power and others), out next week from Atlantic Records.

title: On the Horizon: Bicentenary of Norways Constitution Day; New Languages From the Crowd
description: Bicentenary This year marks the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Norwegian Constitution at Eidsvoll, on May 17, 1814. Within Norway, the bicentenary is being celebrated with events throughout the year. In January, Queen Sonja visited the Norwegian Folk Museum to open, 1814-The Game for Denmark and Norway, an exhibit that details the countries struggles for independence during the Year of Miracles. Visitors can also tour Eidsvoll House, which has been restored to look like as it might have when the constitution was signed there. The house opens Feb. 16, and tours run all year.

title: Rethinking Blogs at The New York Times
description: After we moved our article pages to a new framework and platform, we did the same with our blogs. Scott Taylor, senior software engineer on the Blogs team, wrote about it. Below is an excerpt from a longer post on Scotts personal blog.

title: Former Rwandan Intelligence Chief Goes on Trial for 1994 Genocide
description: PARIS  In an unprecedented step, a French court opened a genocide trial on Tuesday against a former Rwandan intelligence chief in the first of what could be several prosecutions of former officials and others who fled Rwanda after the 1994 slaughter there.

title: L. Stephen Hill
description: Mr. Hill, 50, is a founder and principal of Goldstein, Hill & West Architects, with Alan Goldstein and David West. The firm, which is based in New York and was founded in 2009, has focused mainly on residential design. The partners have worked on numerous projects, including Silver Towers, One Riverside Park and the Aldyn.

title: Vignettes From a Much-Lauded Career
description: It wasnt so long ago that the gifted, indefatigably prolific theater composer Michael John LaChiusa was regarded as a theatrical wunderkind destined to be a future king of Broadway. It hasnt turned out that way. Mr. LaChiusa, 51, has had his successes but no blockbusters. A major impediment has been his refusal (or inability) to write the kind of snugly packaged pop tunes that are Broadways bread and butter. To which I say, more power to him; the form needs composers as talented as Mr. LaChiusa, who have the courage to sacrifice commerciality and go their own way.

title: The Needles in the Monumental N.S.A. Haystack
description: The saga of Edward J. Snowden, the man whose leaked documents revealed the Orwellian dimensions of the National Security Agency, reads like a le Carr novel crossed with something by Kafka  at least it does in Luke Hardings new book, The Snowden Files.

title: Typing Into PDF Forms
description: Q. Why is it possible to type into some PDF forms and not in others? Is there any way to fill out all PDF forms on the computer without having to print them out?

title: Japan Is a Land of Rising Hopes for Ski Jumping
description: NAYORO, Japan  The sound of cicadas and the smell of pine trees in the thick summer air were interrupted by the whoosh of ski jumpers in bodysuits hurling themselves off the 90-meter hill here in the northern reaches of Japan.

title: With Technologys Aid, Banks Squeeze Their Branches Into Smaller Locations
description: As machines do more, bank branches shrink.

title: Keeping Her Passport Handy
description: Anita Lo has been the chef of Annisa since it opened almost 14 years ago, and summing up her style has not gotten any easier. Even she, when naming the cookbook she wrote with Charlotte Druckman, defined her style by what it is not. The title is Cooking Without Borders.

title: A Blend of Folk and Filigree, Raucous and Dreamy
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra, led by its music director, Yannick Nzet-Sguin, paid a memorable visit to Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, four months after its scheduled performance at the halls opening gala was canceled because of a strike by stagehands. But there were no audible hisses when those stagehands wheeled out the Steinway grand for the programs piano concerto.

title: Teaching Just Wasnt Right for Him, Head of Mexican Drug Cartel Says
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, 2:35 p.m. | In an interview with Britains Channel 4 News broadcast last week, Servando Gmez, the head of Mexicos feared Knights Templar drug cartel, reflected on his transition from schoolteacher to organized crime boss. Teaching, he said, was an honest job, but for me, with my hyperactive nature and aspirations, it wasnt satisfying.

title: Netflix Signs for a Third Season of House of Cards
description: Even before the second season becomes available to viewers, producers of the web-streaming series House of Cards have completed a deal with Netflix for a third season of 13 episodes.

title: Colleagues Work Part of Alfred Schnittkes Anniversary Party
description: Many artists have works they disdain later in their careers, pieces created before their mature voice had emerged. For the 82-year-old Russian composer Sofia Gubaidulina, her Fairytale Poem is one such score.

title: Affordability in Kensington, Brooklyn
description: Deirdre Lehn became aware of Kensingtons neighborliness as soon as she attended an open house. We went to the open houses, and all the neighbors would come by, and folks were chatting with us and inviting us to come by for coffee, Ms. Lehn said. These were, like, people we didnt know.

title: MoMAs Proposal for Sculpture Garden Pleases and Riles
description: Peace and quiet can be hard to come by in the middle of Manhattan. Maybe, if the ice ever melts, you might balance a lunch burrito on your lap in the sunken plaza outside the McGraw-Hill Building. Or park yourself in a hotel lobby and pretend to be a guest.

title: Philippine Leader Sounds Alarm on China
description: MANILA  President Benigno S. Aquino III called on Tuesday for nations around the world to do more to support the Philippines in resisting Chinas assertive claims to the seas near his country, drawing a comparison to the Wests failure to support Czechoslovakia against Hitlers demands for Czech land in 1938.

title: New Inquiry on Sri Lanka Points to Possible War Crimes
description: GENEVA  Senior Sri Lankan government officials and military officers may bear criminal responsibility for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during an offensive near the end of the islands civil war, according to a new investigation that backs calls for an international inquiry into those events.

title: Threes a Trend | Luxe Sweatpants
description: Chalk it up to anincreasingly casual workplace culture, the rise of the urban freelancer or the advent of the couch-to-dinner weekend wardrobe. Whatever the case, the old-school sweatpant, made modern with a slim cut and more refined fabrics, is now being heralded as the new khaki. Luxe versions of the stretch-waist pants are showing up on runways and in presentations in both Europe and New York, where the mens shows continue this week. For his fall/winter 2014 collection, Michael Kors explained that he blended New York City polish with the laid-back attitude of California, and that he did away almost entirely with structured waistbands and belt loops. Made with double-faced cashmere or a more office-appropriate glen plaid, the newly refined track pant was the linchpin of Korss relaxed, elegant wardrobe. Meanwhile, Ralph Lauren introduced more sportswear styles under its Purple Label than ever before. A luxurious cashmere-knit jogging-style pant paired with a matching crew-neck sweater and trim topcoat stood in stark contrast to the nipped-waist suits that are at the heart of the tailored line, yet looked no less natty. And at Bottega Veneta, Tomas Maier paired belted coats, lightly tailored jackets and suede bombers with numerous iterations of the pull-on pant, from corduroy to cashmere, to signify his belief in this new trouser alternative.

title: More Space for the Living and the Dead
description: A serendipitous juxtaposition of programming on PBS on Wednesday night reminds us just how long humans have been trying to squeeze more space out of urban environments. The ancient Romans knew something we apparently dont: If you build downward for people who dont much care about the view rather than upward for billionaires who do, you dont have to worry about how to wash the windows.

title: A Dancers Rare Grace Survives a Horrible Fate
description: As you watch grainy kinescope footage of dancers in a mirrored studio executing a pas de deux in the documentary biography Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq, it is almost as though you are beholding mythological deities who have alighted briefly on the earth. Here today, gone tomorrow, they are like rare birds, seldom glimpsed, who remind us of the evanescence of all things, most of all physical beauty and the casual grace of youth. Therein lies a primal attraction of ballet: its evocation of the ecstatic moment is as fleeting as it is haunting.

title: Health Law Goals Face Antitrust Hurdles
description: With the midterm elections fast coming into focus, politics in Washington will remain consumed by health care for months to come.

title: Jay and Dave, With Jerry in the Middle
description: The comic Jerry Seinfeld is a friend to both Jay Leno and David Letterman and has had them both on his web series, "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee"

title: AT&T Becomes First Major Advertiser to Protest Russias Antigay Law
description: AT&T has become the first major advertiser to come out against a measure outlawing homosexual propaganda that has led to protests aimed at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, as well as the first to urge others involved with the Olympic Games to do the same.

title: Circadian Clocks May Be Tuned to Vibrations, Too
description: In nature, the rising and setting of the sun help set an animals circadian clock, a part of the brain that regulates sleep and wakefulness. Fluctuations of light tell the body when to release melatonin, for example, or lower body temperature.

title: N.E.A. Funds Benefit Both Rich and Poor, Study Finds
description: Ever since the late 1980s, when the performance artist Karen Finley started playing around with yams and chocolate, the National Endowment for the Arts has come under fire from some conservative lawmakers. Back then the agency was castigated for giving grants to provocative artists like Ms. Finley, whom some critics called obscene.

title: On Silver Screen, a Bit of Gold
description: As the Sochi Olympics will remind the world again, there is a huge amount of human drama in the skiing, skating and snowboarding that seize the worlds attention every four years.

title: De Blasio to Skip St. Patricks Day Parade; Cites Exclusion of Gay Groups
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Tuesday that he would not march in the St. Patricks Day Parade in Manhattan next month, citing the events longstanding tensions with gay and lesbian groups.

title: Times Minute | Army Recruitment Scam
description: Also on the Minute, a territorial dispute in the South China Sea and the effect of the Affordable Care Act on the full-time work force.

title: The Ballad of Leno and Letterman, Told by Seinfeld
description: The link between the careers of Jay Leno and David Letterman is long and deep, and their personal relationship has often been fractious, sometimes warm, certainly competitive.

title: Morgan Stanley Reaches $1.25 Billion Mortgage Settlement
description: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $1.25 billion to the Federal Housing Finance Agency to resolve claims that it sold shoddy mortgage securities to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

title: U.N. Report Details Abuse of Children in Syrian War
description: UNITED NATIONS  United Nations investigators say in a new report that children in Syria have been sexually abused in government detention, recruited to fight with the opposition, tortured and used as civilian shields.

title: President of BAM Will Leave Next Year
description: When Karen Brooks Hopkins first arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music more than three decades ago, it was considered a pioneering outpost for avant-garde theater, music and dance. Housed in a single Beaux-Arts building in what was then a gritty neighborhood, it struggled to attract theatergoers, some of whom would tell Ms. Hopkins they were more likely to travel to London than to Brooklyn to see a play.

title: Polls Find Security Is Americans Top Olympic Concern
description: Just ahead of the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics on Friday, a plurality of Americans say it was a bad decision to hold the Games in Russia, with security concerns the top reason, a new Pew Research Center poll found.

title: Tanaquil Le Clercq as Muse: Onstage, in Photographs and in a New Film
description: A couple of years ago, the magazine published a photo essay about Mildred and Richard Loving, the couple whose case led to the Supreme Courts striking down miscegenation laws in 1967. The pictures appeared at the same time as an HBO documentary about the Lovings directed by Nancy Buirski. Now Buirskis next documentary, Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq, is coming out. It opens tomorrow at the Film Society of Lincoln Center; later this monththe Berlin International Film Festival will screen it as an Official Selection.

description: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan.

description: There was a pitcher in Japan in the 1950s and 60s named Kazuhisa Inao who was so good that the popular saying at the time was God, Buddha, Inao, in deference to the pitchers almost otherworldly talent.

title: With New App, Photos Become a Travel Guide
description: Applying snap judgments to snapshots, the new Jetpac City Guides for iPhones analyzes Instagram photos for commonalities to come up with top-10 lists of things like bars women love and coffee shops with popular latte art in 6,000 cities worldwide.

title: With New Chief, Microsofts New Mantra Is Innovation, Over and Over
description: You might remember a now-famous scene with Steven A. Ballmer, then the chief executive of Microsoft, walking on stage at a conference in 2006, sweat staining his armpits and chest while he passionately bellowed, Developers! Developers! Developers! Developers! Developers!

description: Recent Sale

title: 3 Companies Fined for Mislabeling Crude Oil in Rail Transit
description: Federal regulators said on Tuesday that they had fined three companies for mislabeling the type of crude oil they were transporting. The penalties  a total of $93,000  were the first from surprise inspections begun after since a series of accidents in the last year underscored the hazard of transporting highly flammable oil by rail.

title: Welcome Relief for Homeowners, Until the Tax Bill Arrives
description: Come tax time, JPMorgan Chase will be able to write off the $1.5 billion in debt relief it must give homeowners to satisfy the terms of a recent settlement.

title: Pakistani Side Fails to Show Up at Taliban Peace Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani government representatives failed to appear on Tuesday for the scheduled start of peace talks with the Taliban, forcing the postponement of the talks and drawing a sharp rebuke from the militants representatives.

description: To the Editor:

description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  It was a harrowing trip across the finish line, a rag-doll maneuver of somersaults and twisted limbs and a face-plant into the snow. Finish, the tall plastic marker read, with the skiers body wrapped around its base.

title: Smoking in Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Say No
description: President Obama indicated in his State of the Union address last week that he will exercise his admittedly limited executive powers in this year of action. Though most of the mild proposals he made are welcome, one still wonders why he doesnt say no more often. Two examples where this would be useful are the farm bill and the proposed extension of the Keystone XL pipeline, both of which will reach his office for decisions soon  the farm bill, perhaps, as you read this. (The Senate passed the bill Tuesday afternoon, so its next stop is Obamas desk.)

title: WellPoint, a Onetime Critic of Health Law, May Yet Profit
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In the midst of the sweeping transformation taking place in health insurance, the company that served as an illustration of why an overhaul was necessary could end up benefiting most from the new federal health care law.

title: Tennessee Governor Urges 2 Free Years of Community College and Technical School
description: Public colleges have sharply raised their prices since the 1990s in the face of declining state support, but a plan by Tennessees governor to make two years of community college and technical school free for all students represents a striking reversal of that trend.

title: The Third Intifada
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  For a while now Ive wondered why theres been no Third Intifada. That is, no third Palestinian uprising in the West Bank, the first of which helped to spur the Oslo peace process and the second of which  with more live ammunition from the Israeli side and suicide bombings from the Palestinian side  led to the breakdown of Oslo. You get many explanations from Palestinians: theyre too poor, too divided, too tired or that they realize these uprisings, in the end, did them more harm than good, especially the second. But being here, its obvious that a Third Intifada is underway. Its the one that Israel always feared most  not an intifada with stones or suicide bombers, but one propelled by nonviolent resistance and economic boycott.

title: In Texting Era, Crisis Hotlines Put Help at Youths Fingertips
description: The conversation began abruptly, with the anonymous teenager getting straight to the point: She had just told her family that she was really a boy trapped in a female body. Now my family hates me, she told a crisis counselor.

title: Republicans Spar on Leaks and Surveillance, Underscoring Partisan Shake-up
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Tuesday offered sharply divergent views about secret government surveillance programs and the leaks that made them public, underscoring the unsettled nature of a political debate that has scrambled the usual partisan lines.

title: German Paper Says U.S. Kept Tabs on Leader
description: BERLIN  American intelligence services monitored former Chancellor Gerhard Schrder beginning in 2002 and perhaps earlier, a leading German newspaper reported on Tuesday. Mr. Schrder, a Social Democrat, openly opposed the Bush administrations developing plans to go to war in Iraq.

title: Often Overlooked, Mancuso Is Prepared for Her Fourth Olympics
description: Which American woman has won the most Olympic ski racing medals?

Michael Bastian: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

description: Few figures in American literature have suffered as strangely divided an afterlife as Robert Frost.

description: SEATTLE  Bill Gates is back in the building at Microsoft.

title: The Two Silicon Valleys: One of Haves, One of Have-Nots
description: Silicon Valley is booming. Job growth is so strong that the recession is a distant memory. Average incomes are up, and the levitation of technology stocks and a pipeline of initial public offerings promise more wealth to come.

title: Long After Soviet Fall, Russian Pairs Climb Back Up
description: When, as a teenager, Maxim Trankov moved in 1999 from the Ural Mountains to St. Petersburg, he had great ambition as a Russian pairs skater but little money for food or an apartment.

title: Schools Official Investigating Teacher Exchanged Explicit Texts With Her, Report Finds
description: A detective for the New York City Education Department who was checking into accusations of misconduct by a teacher in Coney Island, Brooklyn, instead engaged in a sexually explicit phone relationship with her, according to a report released on Tuesday.

title: An Investigation Into a Sexual Text Messaging Relationship in the Education Department
description: The report says a man investigating allegations of misconduct by a teacher had a sexually explicit text messaging relationship with the teacher.

title: An Aggressive Climate Initiative
description: The Obama administration announced on Monday a proposed Environmental Protection Agency regulation to reduce the nations carbon pollution.

title: Where N.S.A. Kept Watch in Cold War, Artists Now Find Refuge
description: BERLIN  Before Christopher McLarren, a United States Army veteran, takes a tour group up the dark stairs to the highest reaches of the former Field Station Berlin, a crumbling Cold War listening post, he warns the participants to stick together and watch where they step.

title: On Top of Devil's Mountain
description: Teufelsberg, or Devils Mountain, includes an abandoned Cold War N.S.A. listening post in Berlin that has evolved into a de facto art installation.

title: Google Gives Eric Schmidt $100 Million in Stock
description: Google said on Tuesday that it gave its chairman, Eric E. Schmidt, $100 million in restricted stock units  and for good measure, added $6 million in cash to be awarded on Valentines Day.

title: Saving Ukraine
description: The United States and Europe may finally be ready to put some real emergency aid on the table as part of an effort to resolve the political crisis in Ukraine and to tie the country more closely to the West. Without such an offer of financial support, Russia will continue to have leverage to bully Ukraine into its geopolitical orbit. The standoff over economic policy and whether Ukraine will ally with Europe or Russia is more than two months old and has led to violent protests in which at least six people were killed.

title: Lawyers in Terrorism Case Seek Access to 9/11 Suspect
description: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, might not seem like the ideal witness to present at trial.

title: Overselling Testosterone, Dangerously
description: A large study has found substantial risks in prescribing testosterone to middle-age and older men for a variety of ailments. One part of the study found that testosterone doubled the risk of cardiovascular disease in more than 7,000 men who were 65 years old or older, essentially confirming findings in previous studies. The other part found that testosterone almost tripled the risk of heart attacks in a group of more than 48,000 middle-age men with previous histories of heart disease. The harm in both cases occurred within 90 days of receiving the prescription.

title: Title for the Seahawks Is a Triumph for the Profile of Yoga
description: The Seahawks Super Bowl victory sent happy repercussions through the expected constituencies  namely, Seahawks fans, the anti-Manning crowd, proponents of the color green  but it also lit up a community not usually excited about football: yogis.

title: Freeing Workers From the Insurance Trap
description: The Congressional Budget Office estimated on Tuesday that the Affordable Care Act will reduce the number of full-time workers by 2.5 million over the next decade. That is mostly a good thing, a liberating result of the law. Of course, Republicans immediately tried to brand the findings as devastating and stark evidence of President Obamas health care reform as a failure and a job killer. It is no such thing.

title: High School Maniacal
description: WASHINGTON  High school never ends.

title: On the Luge, Safety Built Into Swerves
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  On the day that the Winter Olympics opened in Vancouver, British Columbia, four years ago, a luger named Nodar Kumaritashvili was killed on a training run. Traveling almost 90 miles per hour at Whistler Sliding Centre, Kumaritashvili, a 21-year-old from the Republic of Georgia, lost control of his sled near the bottom of the course and was thrown from the track. He died after striking a pole.

title: U.S. Representative to Syrian Opposition Is Retiring
description: WASHINGTON  The United States top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, is planning to retire from the State Department and is expected to leave his post soon, department officials said on Tuesday.

title: Warming to Women on the Ice
description: On the ice, the teenage hockey player Anna Shokhina is like a grandmaster hunched over a chessboard, able to see several moves ahead through her curtain bangs. Introduced to the sport at 5 by a coach who proffered a stick and a pair of skates and invited her to join his boys team, Shokhina was blind in the beginning.

title: On Connecticut Ice, a Proving Ground for Olympic Hopefuls
description: As ice hockey hotbeds in the United States go, the three Ms  Michigan, Massachusetts and Minnesota  lead the way. Maine, upstate New York and North Dakota also have been prominent feeder spots.

description: Administrivial Will Shortz Follow Up! If you missed the Will Shortz interview on MSNBC, you can watch it here.

description: SOCHI, Russia  One of my neighbors who doesnt follow the news stopped me a few days before I flew to the Winter Olympics. She was excited to hear that I was going to Russia, and told me how lucky I was.

title: A British Doctors Death in Syria, and His Mothers Quest for Justice
description: GENEVA  Determined to find her son, Fatima Khan flew to Damascus from Britain last summer, traveling alone for the first time in her 57 years. A surgeon, he had disappeared months before while treating patients in war-ravaged northern Syria.

title: E.P.A. Staff Struggling to Create Pollution Rule
description: WASHINGTON  In marathon meetings and tense all-day drafting sessions, dozens of lawyers, economists and engineers at the Environmental Protection Agency are struggling to create what is certain to be a divisive but potentially historic centerpiece of President Obamas climate change legacy.

title: Amid Trade Rumors, Callahan Propels Rangers
description: The Rangers rolled to their fourth straight victory Tuesday with a smooth 5-1 demolition of the Colorado Avalanche at Madison Square Garden, making it all the more striking that they would consider trading Ryan Callahan.

title: Government Said to Undervalue Coal Leases
description: DENVER  The federal coal leasing program run by the Bureau of Land Management operates without sufficient oversight or a consistent means of ensuring that fair prices are paid for the leases, a report released on Tuesday said.

title: Four People Arrested as Part of Inquiry Into Hoffmans Death
description: Four people were arrested in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday evening with more than 350 bags of heroin as part of the investigation into the death of the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, a law enforcement official said.

title: Teachers Push for Back Pay May Pinch New York City
description: As New Yorks 152 municipal unions line up to press Mayor Bill de Blasio for raises and back pay, his administration and the powerful teachers union are reaching the final stages of a largely overlooked, drawn-out battle that could prove enormously expensive to the city  potentially putting at risk its ability to balance the budget.

title: A Diverse Landscape
description: The crest of the Caucasus divides Europe and Asia. The region is home to dozens of ethnic groups.

title: Slovene Skier Tries to Shake a Puzzling Cold Spell
description: KRANJSKA GORA, Slovenia  Alpine skiing has long been the sport that best defined tiny Slovenia, whether it was during its years as part of Yugoslavia or in the go-go years after independence in 1991.

title: Dont Know These Olympic Athletes? You Will
description: Although the Olympics sometimes crown established stars, they are just as often a coming-out party for athletes who emerge as national heroes with unexpected performances. And the title of breakthrough star of the Games is often judged through a nationalistic lens. In 2002, Americans were thrilled by Sarah Hughess unexpected figure skating gold medal; Croatians were stunned by Janica Kostelics three Alpine golds; and China celebrated its first Winter Games gold, by the short-track speedskater Yang Yang. Here are some of the candidates to emerge as the darlings of their nations in Sochi, Russia.

title: Interview With President Aquino
description: President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines called for nations around the world to support his country in resisting China. He also talked about the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan.

description: Detectives were investigating the death of a 2-year-old girl who was found at her familys home in Queens late Monday with broken ribs and bruising around her mouth.

description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Given the way their season has unfolded, it seemed almost safe to assume that the Knicks, after winning four of their previous five games, would somehow find a way to lose to theworst team in the N.B.A.

title: A Call to Ignore Exam Results When Evaluating Educators
description: A year after a switch to new standardized tests for public school students caused passing rates to plummet, leaders of both political parties in the New York Legislature on Tuesday called on the state to back away from plans to use those exams to grade teachers.

description: ATHENS  The verdict set crowds of police officers cheering.

description: PARIS  Defying a popes explicit instructions is not a widespread habit among Roman Catholic cardinals, especially when the pope in question is immensely popular, on the verge of sainthood and no longer able to object.

title: Is That a Luge in Times Square?
description: In an imagined New York City Winter Olympics, many of Manhattans iconic settings might be taken over by tracks, jumps and ski slopes.

title: Russia Blocks Several Activists From Olympics, Even as Spectators
description: SOCHI, Russia  The Russian hosts of the 2014 Winter Games made clear long ago they would brook no political protests at the Olympics, and now, it seems, they are having second thoughts about allowing dissidents even to attend as spectators.

title: California: Officers Faulted in Mistaken Shooting
description: Eight Los Angeles police officers violated Police Department policy when they fired on two unarmed women in a pickup truck last February during the hunt for Christopher Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer accused of killing four people, a civilian oversight board said Tuesday. Police Chief Charlie Beck will determine how to discipline the eight, who have been removed from field duty since the episode. Chief Beck said actions could range from extensive retraining to termination. The women were delivering newspapers when officers mistook their truck for Mr. Dorners vehicle, and fired more than 100 rounds. Last year the city agreed to pay them $4.2 million. Chief Beck said that although he sympathized with the officers, he could not excuse their decision to open fire. This was a tragic cascade of circumstance that led to an inaccurate conclusion by the officers, he said.

title: Assembly Withdraws Bill to Limit Anti-Israel Boycotts
description: Legislation intended to limit academic groups protests against Israel was abruptly withdrawn from consideration by the New York State Assembly after a chorus of educators and legal groups denounced it as a bold assault on academic freedom.

title: Old Tensions Resurface in Debate Over U.S. Role in Post-2014 Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama brought his top Afghanistan commanders to the Oval Office on Tuesday to discuss the way forward in a war he is determined to end by the end of the year, even as he finds himself stymied by an unreliable partner and an uncertain future.

title: Free Trade Disagreement
description: The Obama administrations negotiations over the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation trade agreement, have become a test of the compatibility of globalization with the increasing expectation among democratized populations of transparency in government.

title: Fight Awaits de Blasio on Opening Upper East Side Trash Transfer Site
description: Among the many pressing issues Mayor Bill de Blasio will contend with in the coming four years is one that will be waiting practically outside his door.

title: In the Scripted World of Diplomacy, a Burst of Tweets
description: WASHINGTON  On his first anniversary as secretary of state on Tuesday, John Kerry celebrated by reactivating his Twitter handle. It only took a year but @StateDept finally let me have my own @Twitter account, Mr. Kerry tweeted with the hashtag #JKTweetsAgain, as if to suggest he had been held hostage for the last year without a BlackBerry.

title: Cases of New Deadly Bird Flu Surge in China, Experts Say
description: Cases of the new H7N9 avian influenza in China are surging alarmingly, flu experts warned this week.

title: A Pianist With a Goal Taps Mozart and Chopin
description: When last we saw the star pianist Lang Lang, it was at the Grammy Awards on Jan. 26, jamming with Metallica on its power ballad One, to loud and muddled effect. In the first half of Mr. Langs recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, Mozart was about as awkward a match for this pianists considerable talents as metal had been.

description: This winters frigid temperatures could be having one desirable side effect. They may be revving up your metabolism.

title: Protest Aside, Postal Service Is Taking Next Step to Sell Grand Property in the Bronx
description: For four decades, Ella Michael has walked through the doors of the Bronx General Post Office to stock up on stamps and ship holiday presents to family and friends in Georgia and South Carolina. For a while in the 1980s, she came with letters for her son who was serving in the United States Army in Germany.
