description: Animal rights workers in Sochi, Russia, are rescuing stray dogs from exterminators hired by the government. They hope athletes and fans visiting the Olympics will adopt them.

title: New York City Woman Is Charged in Killing of Daughter, 2
description: The mother of a 2-year-old girl has been charged with second-degree murder in what the authorities described as a pattern of abuse that culminated in the toddlers death this week, the Queens district attorney attorneys office said on Wednesday.

title: Racing to Save the Stray Dogs of Sochi
description: SOCHI, Russia  A dog shelter backed by a Russian billionaire is engaged in a frantic last-ditch effort to save hundreds of strays facing a death sentence before the Winter Olympics begin here.

title: One From Berlin
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  This 15 x 16 puzzle by Joe Krozel grew on me. I dont always do this, but I started in the northwest and was a bit taken aback by the entries at 1 Across and 4 Down (BANG and GASHED, respectively). With all the news stories of shootings and other types of violence, I personally found the opening of Mr. Krozels puzzle disturbing.

title: Months Later, Sniper Attack at Power Hub Still a Mystery
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A mysterious and sophisticated sniper attack last year on a Silicon Valley power substation has underscored concerns about the vulnerability of the countrys electrical grid and prompted debate over whether it was an act of terrorism.

title: Veronica Beard: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: In the Breath Between Winter Storms, Officials Scramble to Find More Salt
description: As the latest winter storm bore down on New York City, officials faced with dwindling mounds of salt contacted the state and got an emergency shipment of 2,000 tons. New York State also deployed dozens of trucks to deliver salt from upstate to Long Island towns that are running short. And fielding requests from municipalities, New Jerseys transportation commissioner called the head of a major supplier, International Salt, to urge the quickest possible delivery.

title: Live (Streaming) From Russia
description: NBCs moneyed grip on the Olympics means that it has traveled a technological path that no other network has. It has shown the Games entirely on broadcast television. It has added multiple cable networks. Now, it is live-streaming virtually every event to an ecosystem increasingly populated by tablets and smartphones.

title: Subdued Send-Off, but Jay Leno Is Exiting on Top
description: When Jack Paar left the Tonight show in 1962, he passed through a set of curtains and the camera zoomed in on a card that read: No More to Come. Three decades later, Johnny Carson had Bette Midler serenade him on his penultimate show, then sat and spoke directly to his fans in his emotional finale, watched by 42 million viewers.

title: Chill Seattle Savors Its Super Bowl Moment in the Sun
description: SEATTLE  Drivers here often smile and wave at one another for no obvious reason. A study last year found that Washington residents were less likely than people elsewhere to swear at strangers. For many, Seattle chill sums up the conflicted local soul: polite but cool.

title: Time and Luck Run Out as $1 Million Lottery Prize Goes Unclaimed in the Bronx
description: The lottery sign is proudly taped to the window of a discount beauty supply store in the Bronx, reminding customers that one of their own became a millionaire overnight.

title: VFiles: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Broadway Dims Lights for Hoffman
description: Broadway theaters dimmed their marquee lights for one minute Wednesday in memory of the acclaimed screen and stage actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, who died on Sunday, apparently of a drug overdose.

title: A Complicated Actor, Philip Seymour Hoffman, in His Last Days
description: A father with his children in a Greenwich Village playground. A disheveled man hovering around the lone A.T.M. in a grocery store, withdrawing the exact sum of $200, over and over, for an hour. A guy texting his buddy to invite him over to watch the Knicks game at his apartment.

title: Cycling Study Says Hearts Race With the Riders
description: It should be pretty clear that professional athletes are better at sports than you. It turns out, though, they may be better looking, too.

title: Corrections: February 6, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Con Ed Asks Harlem to Conserve Power
description: Con Edison has asked electricity customers in Harlem to avoid using nonessential appliances like washers, dryers, dishwashers and extra lights because of problems with electric cables in the area.

title: With Felton a Step Slow, the Knicks Allow the Blazers to Run Away
description: The Knicks had a third-quarter lead against one of the N.B.A.s premier teams Wednesday night when Raymond Felton was slowed by a screen along the 3-point arc. He trailed the Portland Trail Blazers Damian Lillard for the rest of the play, relegated to the role of spectator as Lillard drove the lane before passing to Nicolas Batum for a layup.

title: Temporary Insanity
description: For eight days in February and then again in September, more than 100,000 characters descend on New York City for the womens fashion shows. Traffic grinds to a halt. Requests on Uber, the luxury car-service app, spike 40 percent. Its harder to get a seat at certain restaurants, like Carbone or NoMad, than it is a front-row perch at Marc Jacobs. And there are enough crazed street-style peacocks clomping around and #NYFW selfies getting snapped to make the whole scene feel like some endless Kardashian nightmare. But its also serious business. The shows bring in an estimated $860 million for the city, more than the projected earnings of the U.S. Open, the New York City Marathon or the Super Bowl. Not bad for an event that began in 1941, when the International Ladies Garment Workers Union invited 30 journalists to attend a few designers showrooms. Here, a brief look into the harrowing and often hysterical week that kicks off every new fashion season.

title: Shiny Shades of Cerulean
description: A bevy of shiny accessories in steely shades of blue are brightening up winters drab look. Monochromatic watches and jewelry, like David Yurmans classic cable bracelet made anew with icy-blue aluminum, add modest pops of the eye-catching hues. But its the highly reflective sunglasses, shoes and bags that really make a statement. Saint Laurents teal duffle and sapphire high-tops scream space-age fashion while a pair of ombr Gucci shades are too attention-grabbing to hide behind.

title: Europeans Undermining Trade Negotiations
description: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Word of the Day | incursion
description: incursion \in-kr-zhn\ noun

title: Jets Hire Assistant
description: The Jets filled the lone remaining vacancy on their coaching staff by hiring Thomas McGaughey as their special-teams coach. McGaughey, 40, spent the last three seasons as the special-teams coach at Louisiana State. McGaughey was the Giants assistant special-teams coordinator for four seasons and has also coached in the N.F.L. in Kansas City, Houston and Denver.

title: Football Fans Fill the Seattle Streets
description: The scene at the Seahawks championship parade.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) WINTER OLYMPICS Coverage of the 2014 Games from Sochi, Russia, begins with the mens and pairs short programs in the inaugural figure skating team contest, which combines results in mens, womens, pairs and ice-dancing competition. Of the 10 competing teams, Canada, Russia and the United States are favored. (Above, a member of the Russian team, Yevgeny Plushenko.) Other segments feature womens moguls in freestyle skiing and mens and womens slopestyle snowboarding. Shaun White has announced that he will drop out of the first-time slopestyle event.

title: An American in Madras Traces Career of Unlikely Pioneer in Tamil-Language Films
description: As a college student in what is now known as Mumbai, the Indian filmmaker Karan Bali watched the 1947 Hindi classic Meera, a remake of the 1945 Tamil-language film of the same name, and loved it. However, it was not until in 2004, while researching an article for his portal on Indian cinema, Upperstall, that he discovered the director of both films was an American, Ellis R. Dungan.

title: Legal Costs Hurt Credit Suisse Profit
description: Updated, 7:15 p.m. | Credit Suisse said on Thursday that weakness in its investment bank and money set aside to cover legal costs weighed on its fourth-quarter results, contributing to a small profit increase for the Swiss bank.

title: After Losses, Yet Another Overhaul for Sony
description: TOKYO  After failing to turn around two of its most troubled consumer electronics businesses, Sony is pushing them aside.

title: Members of Russian Punk Band Get Warm Greeting in Brooklyn
description: Newly freed by the Russian authorities, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, one of two members of the punk band Pussy Riot jailed for their political activism, had a message for the crowd at a fund-raising concert in Brooklyn on Wednesday.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 6, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | An Olympics in the Shadow of a War Zone
description: In An Olympics in the Shadow of a War Zone, Steven Lee Myers writes about the challenges of holding the Winter Games in such a volatile region.

title: In Jaipur, New Feminists Are Born
description: The womens rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem are keeping a diary of their travels throughout India as they meet the countrys young feminists, writers and thought leaders. In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem take part in the Jaipur Literature Festival.

title: Looted, but Not Lost: An African Artists Life Work
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic  Bangui has been a looters paradise for weeks now. Despite French and African Union peacekeepers, Christians have gone on a rampage burning Muslim homes and businesses in revenge for almost a year of Muslim Seleka rule of scorched earth and terror. Except now, with no rule of law, the looting has crossed religious boundaries and rampaging mobs sack their own neighborhoods.

title: Does a More Equal Marriage Mean Less Sex?
description: Not long ago, I was at a dinner party with several couples in their 40s, all married except for my boyfriend and me. The mood was jovial until, over dessert, one guest made an offhand joke about Internet porn.

title: Will You Be Watching the Sochi Olympics?
description: Never before has the pre-Olympic chatter been less about the athletes or the sports, Juliet Macur writes in a piece for Wednesdays special Sochi 2014  section. Not only are there serious concerns about terrorism, but many are also outraged about Russian legislation that seems to discriminate against gay athletes and visitors.

title: European Hardship Hurts Vodafones Sales
description: LONDON  Vodafone reported weak quarterly sales figures on Thursday, confirming that the British cellphone carrier was still suffering from Europes financial problems.

title: Egypts Despair, and Its Hope
description: CAIRO  Last month, on the third anniversary of the revolution of Jan. 25 that led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, millions of Egyptians came out onto the streets carrying Egyptian flags and pictures of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the army leader whom they considered their hero for siding with the will of the people and overthrowing the Muslim Brotherhood government in June. At the same time, supporters of the Brotherhoods deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, continued their confrontations with the police, which resulted in 49 deaths and scores of injuries.

title: New York Today: Beware of Widespread Black Ice
description: Updated 10:29 a.m.

title: Times Minute | Saving Sochi's Stray Dogs
description: Also on the Minute, the American Idol finalist Clay Aiken announces his bid for Congress and Broadway dims its lights for Philip Seymour Hoffman.

title: Times Minute | Saving Sochis Stray Dogs
description: In the Video

title: North Korea, Citing U.S. Bomber Training Run, May Cancel Reunions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Thursday threatened to cancel reunions of families separated by the Korean War, accusing the United States of flying nuclear-capable B-52 bombers on a training mission over the Korean Peninsula.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Return of the Stomach Bug
description: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a 70-year-old woman who has severe gastrointestinal symptoms that return four years later?

title: As 2 Go Free, Brooklyn Conviction Challenges Keep Pouring In
description: Their wrists uncuffed, their ankles unchained, Antonio Yarbough and Sharrif Wilson walked out of a Brooklyn courtroom Thursday afternoon, free after more than two decades in prison for three murders they did not commit.

title: Finnish Group Offers to Buy Pohjola Bank for $4.6 Billion
description: The Finnish financial company OP-Pohjola Group said on Thursday that it had offered to buy the shares it does not already own in Pohjola Bank for about 3.4 billion euros, or about $4.6 billion.

title: In Japan, a Beloved Deaf Composer Appears to Be None of the Above
description: TOKYO  He was celebrated as a prolific musical genius whose compositions appeared in popular video games and the competition routine of a top figure skater in the coming Sochi Olympics. His deafness won him praise as Japans modern-day Beethoven.

title: Democrats Aim for a 2014 More Like 2012 and 2008
description: WASHINGTON  The Democrats plan to hold on to their narrow Senate majority goes by the name Bannock Street project. It runs through 10 states, includes a $60 million investment and requires more than 4,000 paid staff members. And the effort will need all of that  and perhaps more  to achieve its goal, which is nothing short of changing the character of the electorate in a midterm cycle.

title: When Identity Theft Hits Home
description: When I first heard about the extensive Target hack in December, I sighed in mild irritation. Sure, the breachs size and scope was shocking, but these things have become so common I just assumed Id receive a new card in the mail and that would be the end of it.

title: A Social Network Thats Just for College Students
description: Start-Up: Blend.

title: British Rate Still at 0.5% As Growth Stays Slow
description: LONDON  The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low as Britains economic recovery continues at a slow pace.

title: Downhill Is Already Causing Concern
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The Olympic mens downhill course begins with a descent so steep that skiers quickly reach 90 miles an hour. A subsequent jump catapults racers almost the length of a football field.

title: Poetry Pairing | American Income
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features American Income by Afaa Michael Weaver and Reflections on the Road to Yale by Travis Reginal.

title: India Looks to Expand Visa-on-Arrival Program to 180 Countries
description: NEW DELHI  India said it would seek to expand its visa-on-arrival program to tourists from 180 countries, including the United States and China, to encourage more people to visit the country.

title: Glassdoor, a Jobs Website, Hires a Finance Chief
description: Glassdoor, the jobs listings website that lets employees rate their bosses, has hired a chief financial officer, potentially setting up an initial public offering of the company down the line.

title: Shaun Whites Absence Looms Over Slopestyle Qualifying
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  In snowboarding, it is extremely difficult to be the defending Olympic gold medalist in halfpipe and hold similar expectations in slopestyle. Shaun White knows this better than anyone  almost.

title: Europes Central Bank, Defying Doomsayers, Holds Rate Steady
description: PARIS  The European Central Banks president, Mario Draghi, is taking a wait-and-see approach as the threat of deflation hangs over the euro zone and the regions unemployment remains stubbornly high.

title: A Doll Who Pulls Her Own Strings
description: When Nora Helmer, the heroine of Ibsens A Dolls House, left her family, slamming the door as she departed, the sound shook the theater and the world. People left the theater, night after night, pale with excitement, arguing, quarreling, challenging, an early critic remarked of that 1879 play. Many theater companies considered the ending so shocking, they changed it.

title: Toying With Ideas Outside the Manual
description: When I was young I lacked the patience and fine-motor skills to do much with Lego, but I spent a lot of time with friends whose bedrooms and basements bristled with elaborate, snapped-together spaceships and skyscrapers. There was always something of a gap between the care and imagination that went into the constructions and what you did with them after the building was done. Those intricate structures became, like just about everything else, stages for car crashes and action-figure duels. Now and then there would be a pause for an argument about who was the bad guy and what the rules were, and then the battle would resume until it was time for a snack.

title: Swiss Firm Mercuria in Talks to Buy JPMorgans Commodities Unit
description: LONDON  The Mercuria Energy Group, a fast-growing energy and commodities trading company, is in exclusive talks to acquire the physical commodities business of JPMorgan Chase, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: Times Co. Reports Slower Decline in Ads
description: The New York Times Company said on Thursday that it added digital subscribers and slowed its declines in print and digital advertising revenue during the fourth quarter of 2013, a year of transition for the company.

title: Daily Report: After Years in Philanthropy, a Different Gates Returns to Microsoft
description: The last time Bill Gates played an active role at Microsoft, as chief software architect, he witnessed the company muffing its earliest efforts to become a major player in search, smartphones and tablet computers, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: K.K.R. Profit More Than Doubled in Fourth Quarter
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Thursday that its fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, as rising markets helped deliver big gains on its investments.

title: Picking a Flavor of Linux
description: Q. I want to install Linux on an old PC to get a few more years out of it, but I dont know which version to use. What is the difference between Ubuntu and Mint for a new user and are there any free guides to using either?

title: Video: Matthew McConaughey, Chest-Thumper
description: Once a big screen heartthrob, Matthew McConaughey doesnt necessarily want to play the hero anymore.

title: Seeking an Unbiased Jury
description: Dear Diary:

title: Fraternity Life, Islamic Style
description: SHORTLY BEFORE SUNUP, a dozen or so students at the University of California, San Diego, stumbled dutifully out of bed. They ironed their collared shirts, knotted their ties and piled into their cars. Their destination was the Islamic Center of San Diego, where they were to be initiated into the countrys first Muslim fraternity, Alpha Lambda Mu, named for three letters that start several chapters of the Quran: Alif Laam Meem.

title: Americas First Muslim Fraternity
description: A glimpse into the beginnings of Alif Laam Meem on the campus of the University of Texas, Dallas.

title: A Shrug at Puerto Ricos Debt Downgrade
description: Standard & Poors lowered Puerto Ricos credit rating to junk status on Tuesday, but on Wednesday, the market responded with barely a flinch. While prices of some of the islands bonds traded lower, there was nothing close to the kind of mass sell-off that might indicate a panic, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook.

title: Designing a Dream Daytime Wedding
description: One of the things that has always struck me about weddings, these very special days, is how run of the mill they can sometimes feel. When it came time,at 40, to organize my own wedding, I realized that I wanted to do things a little differently, and that I needed to avoid the bridal market in order to keep things personal and on-budget. In the end, this approach to creating a meaningful and memorable day did cost less, and everyone in attendance felt truly spoiled.

title: Christy Wyatt of Good Technology, on Minding the Details
description: This interview with Christy Wyatt, chief executive of Good Technology, a provider of mobile security solutions, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Jamaican Bobsledders Are Back, With Fans Help
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  When Winston Watts put on his helmet to begin Jamaicas first trip down an Olympic bobsled track in 12 years, he was surprised by what he felt in his eyes. It was not tears of emotion; no, this substance was grittier and chalkier. After a moment, he figured it out: He had protein powder dribbling down his face.

title: Rise in Profit for G.M., but Europe Unit Falters
description: DETROIT  General Motors on Thursday reported its 16th consecutive profitable quarter  but consistent losses in its troubled European division continued to hurt its results.

title: Labor Supply and the Meaning of Life
description: I had some fun (for weird econonerd values of fun) yesterday thinking through the interesting possibility that our pre-Obamacare health system created a reverse notch that induced some people to work too much. But I think I should step back and talk about the broader issue here.

title: The Start of New York Fashion Week
description: Good morning, New York. Your Fashion Week is here. Today is the first official day of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, though devoted showgoers have been hoofing through slush and snow for the better part of two days to reach earlier presentations. (As I note in todays Thursday Styles article on the fashion diaspora, New York Fashion Week is expanding in both time and geography.)

title: Austerity Memories
description: Ryan Cooper writes about possibilities for a deal that actually does something to boost the economy. He suggests that with the deficit obsession fading, Democrats can go back to the old formula of spending increases in return for tax cuts  the formula that gave us, for example, the Childrens Health Insurance Program in the late 1990s.

title: In Our Pages: February 7
description: 1939: Ban on Game Called Love

title: From a Forgotten Box, a Ray of Light
description: This story begins in 1973 with a man in Wales tidying up the mess in his garage and discovering a box of daguerreotypes. Uncertain whether to throw it out, he waited until his brother-in law asked advice from a friend who was a photographer and documentary filmmaker. The friend, Noel Chanan, strongly advised him to hold tight onto a box that must be brimful of history.

title: Student Contest | Write an Editorial on an Issue That Matters to You
description: Update | Feb. 5, 2015: We have announced our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest.

title: Rachel Kushner: By the Book
description: The author of The Flamethrowers and Telex From Cuba steers clear of books with ugly covers. And those that are touted as sweeping, tender or universal.

title: Stradivarius Is Recovered Unharmed After Theft
description: A Stradivarius violin stolen last month from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra has been recovered seemingly unharmed, the authorities in Milwaukee announced on Thursday.

title: Sugary Foods Increase Heart Risks
description: Eating sugary foods, researchers have found, increases the risk of dying from heart disease.

title: Clothes and Character: The Grandmaster
description: Updated, 12:00 p.m. | The Grandmaster, is the director Wong Kar-wais combined biopic and action film about the rise of one of kung fus masters, Ip Man, who would later go on to train Bruce Lee. The films stars, Tony Leung (Ip Man) and Ziyi Zhang (who plays Gong Er, a rival and, of course, love interest), went through several years of intense martial-arts training for the film.

title: AOL Reports Solid Revenue, but Patch Weighs on Profit
description: AOL, the Internet portal-turned-media company, reported strong revenue for the fourth quarter of 2013 on Thursday, but costs related to Patch, its struggling hyperlocal news service, cut into its profits.

title: What Does a School Crossing Guard Do?
description: Bring up the subject of school crossing guards in New York City, and plenty of parents will have something spirited to say: Ours is awesome! She holds my daughters hand! Or perhaps: Ours is useless! The other day I saw her texting while kids crossed the street alone!

title: Concern at Westchester Art House as Heavyweight Rival, Sundance, Plans Theater
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.  Even during film awards season, there have not been many theaters where residents of Westchester County could see quirky independent or foreign contenders like Nebraska, Philomena or Inside Llewyn Davis. Until the last few years, there has often been just one such dependable locale, the 12-year-old nonprofit Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville, the countys only true art house.

title: A Vegan-Focused Valentines Weekend
description: Not sure what to give your vegan sweetie for Valentines? The historic Windward House Bed and Breakfast in Camden, Me., which emphasizes locally sourced food and environmentally friendly products, is offering a weekend getaway free of animal products.

title: Image of the Day: February 6
Sony Turns to Investment Firm With a Taste for Unloved Assets
description: For its latest restructuring, Sony has turned to a private equity firm that specializes in buying unloved assets from Japanese electronics giants.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: Five designers discuss their work on recent book covers: first concepts that didnt make the final cut, and then the cover as published.

title: Imagining a New York City Flag for the 21st Century
description: Everyone knows the old joke about what has four wheels and flies. The answer, of course: a garbage truck. But whats blue, white and orange, festooned with beavers, flour barrels, the blades of a windmill, a sailor, an Indian and an eagle? And flies, too?

title: Russian Biathlon Coach Had Suspicions, Too
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Wolfgang Pichler, a prominent coach of the Russian biathlon team, said he knew that at least one Russian athlete was doping as far back as November, more than two months before she and another Russian biathlete were suspended for doping violations.

title: Government Demands for Data About Twitter Users Continue to Grow
description: As Twitter gets bigger, governments around the world are increasingly seeking information about its 241 million users and their accounts, the social networking company said Thursday as it released fourth semiannual transparency report.

title: Gravitys Score, Playing Soon in Space?
description: From the start, Alfonso Cuarn and his son and collaborator, Jons, knew that sound would be a major part of Gravity.

title: Profit Tumbles at Fox, but Cable Makes Gains
description: LOS ANGELES  Higher costs for sports television, an advertising dip at local TV stations, crumbling ratings for The X Factor and lackluster movie releases sent quarterly profit tumbling at 21st Century Fox.

title: Magazines Gain in Digital Sales but Newsstand Revenue Continues to Fall
description: Magazine circulation declined slightly in the last six months of 2013, according to new figures released Thursday by the Alliance for Audited Media, as big declines in single-copy newsstand sales offset gains in digital editions.

title: Scholarly Editions of Mozart Librettos Going Online
description: If youve always wanted to have the Mozart operas at your fingertips  in scholarly editions, no less  here is a start: the Mozarteum Foundation Salzburg has put the first installment of its Mozart libretto project online, and it turns out that the librettos are only the gateway: as you read along, you can click on a speaker icon, which will not only give you access to an audio recording of the relevant section of the opera but will also put a full orchestral and vocal score on your screen.

title: Vodafones Investment Case Will Involve Deal-Making
description: Vodafone is starting to look healthier as a standalone company.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: shivering as exercise, CVS and peanut allergies. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Excerpt: 'Little Me'
description: Rachel York and Christian Borle sing I Love You from the Encores! production of the musical Little Me, at City Center.

title: Original Review: Little Me
description: Howard Taubmans 1962 review of the Broadway musical at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: Religious Freedom Is a Tenet of Foreign Policy, Obama Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday scolded China, Iran, North Korea and other countries known for repressing religious minorities and declared that promoting freedom of faith around the world was a central goal of American foreign policy.

title: Caribbean Newcomers Dip Their Toes in the Snow
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  When Dominica, a tiny Caribbean nation, makes its Winter Olympic debut on Friday, the cross-country skier carrying its flag at the opening ceremony will be a wealthy former investment fund manager from Staten Island who never tried cross-country skiing until after his 30th birthday.

title: Times Minute | Tracking Your Face
description: Also on the Minute, a peak at The Times online library of Olympic tricks and an interview with Oscar nominee Matthew McConaughey.

title: Popular Web Series About Struggling Actors Gets New Season Start Date
description: Fans of the web series Submissions Only, which takes a humorous yet gimlet-eyed look at the life of the struggling New York actor, have been eagerly awaiting the release of the third season. One has only to read the comments on YouTube, below the trailer for the new season, to get a sense of the level of anticipation in this particular demographic.

title: Times Minute | Tracking Your Face
description: In the Video

title: BCBG Max Azria: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Oprah Winfrey Eyes night, Mother for Broadway Debut
description: Oprah Winfrey is in talks to make her Broadway debut in a revival of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play night, Mother, starring opposite Tony-Award winner Audra McDonald as a mother struggling to stop her daughter from killing herself, according to two theater executives familiar with the plans.

title: State Regulator Halts Deal Between Wells Fargo and Loan Servicer
description: Updated, 4:12 p.m. | A New York State regulator has dealt a blow to Ocwen Financial by halting the transfer of about $39 billion in servicing rights to the company from Wells Fargo.

title: Boehner Doubts Immigration Bill Will Pass in 2014
description: WASHINGTON  The yearlong effort to overhaul the nations immigration laws, which had the support of President Obama, Republican leaders and much of American business and labor, was seriously imperiled on Thursday when Speaker John A. Boehner conceded that it was unlikely he could pass a bill.

title: No Sex, Please, Were on Medicare
description: What could be more likely to draw international headlines, and jokes on late-night talk shows, than a government report that includes both an alleged waste of Medicare money and erectile dysfunction?

title: European Lawmakers Try to Spur Market for Carbon-Emission Credits
description: LONDON  European Union lawmakers moved on Thursday to support the blocs system for trading carbon-emission permits, hoping to revive Europes flagging effort to take a market-incentives approach to reducing greenhouse gases.

title: After Boeing 787 Is Diverted, Air India Looks Into Software Problem
description: MUMBAI, India  In the latest in a string of technical problems involving the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, a software glitch has caused an Air India flight to divert from its course and make an emergency landing in Malaysia.

title: A Triumph for Putin, if Not for the Rest of a Sagging Russia
description: MOSCOW  After President Vladimir V. Putin delivered Russias successful pitch to host the Winter Olympic Games in Sochi  in English and a smattering of French, no less  he declared it an international validation of the Russia that had emerged from the ruins of the Soviet Union.

title: Today in Small Business: An Epic Local Commercial Goes Viral
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Richard Chai  Love: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Cooper-Hewitt Museum Gets a $10 Million Donation
description: The Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York has been on a hot streak. In October, it received $5 million from the city to help with its $79 million renovation. On Thursday, the museum announced a $10 million donation from the Morton and Barbara Mandel Family Foundation  the largest in this arts institutions history.

title: Words of Praise for the Citys Sanitation Chief
description: It was always a rather thankless position, but with the addition of social media and tweeted complaints of unplowed streets amplifying New Yorks renowned impatience, the position of sanitation commissioner comes with a new job requirement: extra thick skin.

title: Russia Claims U.S. Is Meddling Over Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The tense Russian-American jockeying over the fate of Ukraine escalated on Thursday as a Kremlin official accused Washington of crudely interfering in the former Soviet republic, while the Obama administration blamed Moscow for spreading an intercepted private conversation between two American diplomats.

title: No Comment Necessary: Pity the One Percent
description: In late January, Tom Perkins, a venture capitalist, called attention to the parallels between Nazi Germanys war on its one percent, namely its Jews and the progressive war on the American one percent, namely the rich.

title: How to Identify a Stradivarius
description: Christopher Reuning, a rare-instrument dealer in Boston, explained how an expert would identify the Stradivarius stolen in late January from the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra.

title: Illustrating a Sexless but Equal Marriage
description: This weeks cover story by Lori Gottlieb asks what female empowerment means for the sex lives of modern married couples. While many partnerships these days are so-called peer marriages, in which both spouses work full-time as well as share household and parenting duties, the twist is that those apparently appealing dynamics may have a negative impact on a couples sex life.

title: Creatures of the Wind: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Wheelies: The Sorry, Ferrari Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Fashion Week Parties: Kickoff
description: AmFAR kicked off New York Fashion Week, Details celebrated its March issue and VFiles partied late.

title: Laurenne Ross on Downhill Practice
description: The American downhill skier Laurenne Ross talks about the womens racing course in Sochi, Russia.

title: Green Mountains Deal With Coke Fails to Dent SodaStream
description: When Green Mountain Coffee Roasters announced an investment from the Coca-Cola Company on Wednesday, many investors assumed that SodaStream, the D.I.Y.-soft-drink darling, would suffer.

title: Restaurant Report: Serge et le Phoque in Hong Kong
description: Two stars of the Paris dining scene now have a pied--terre in Hong Kong. Last August, Fred Peneau, formerly the business partner of Iaki Aizpitarte at Le Chateaubriand, and the chef Christophe Pel joined with the interior designer Charles Pelletier to open Serge et le Phoque, a contemporary French restaurant in the heart of the Wan Chai district. (The restaurant was named both after and by Mr. Peneaus young son, Serge, who thought that le Phoque, French for the seal, would be a good companion to Le Dauphin, or the dolphin, another of Mr. Peneaus ventures.)

title: In Cambodias Capital, an Infusion of Flavor
description: As Phnom Penhs traffic roared nearby on a recent late afternoon, George and William Norbert-Munns were busy decorating. Amid piles of rubble and cement bags, the brothers mapped their vision for the dark, compact space  solid timber banquette seating, chocolate-hued walls, large windows  that would transform it into a sleek gastro pub.

title: Hotels With History in Goa, India
description: Half an hour before our plane touched ground in Goa, a crew member announced that we would be turning around and flying back to Mumbai. It was the middle of monsoon season, and the rain and lightning had grown so heavy, the pilot no longer thought it safe to land. Im not sure what metrics led the flight crew to change their minds, because heavy rain and lightning are exactly what we lurched through when, moments later, our plane began its jarring descent to Indias good-time state.

title: Ex-SAC Trader Convicted of Securities Fraud
description: Mathew Martoma had been on his way to being another American success story. Today, he is the eighth person who once worked for the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen to be convicted of insider trading.

title: The Gun Report: February 6, 2014
description: Curtis Reeves, the 71-year-old retired police captain who shot and killed a man who was texting in a Florida movie theater on Jan. 13, attended his bail hearing yesterday, and more details about the shooting came to light.

title: Rules of Style | Eduns Danielle Sherman on Surviving Fashion Week
description: After under-the-radar stints at the Row (which she co-founded with her childhood friends Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen) and as the head of design for T by Alexander Wang, Danielle Sherman shot into the spotlight when the LVMH brand Edun hired her to take the reins last season. Design is in the L.A. natives blood: Her grandparents ran the Swinging London label the Dollyrocker, and her father has a soccer-shoe company. Now, shes reinventing the Africa-focused brand with a modern, easygoing take on luxury  and even shot the spring ad campaign herself (an avid photographer, she also happens to be engaged to the lensman-about-town Todd Selby).

title: Where Lincoln Sat, Transfixed by Todd
description: An unprepossessing 1830s couch that witnessed the 1840 courtship of Abraham Lincoln and Mary Todd is returning to one of her relatives parlors with its chipped mahogany trim and torn upholstery repaired.

title: A Catalog of Cancer Genes Thats Done, or Just a Start
description: Cancer is a disease of genes gone wrong. When certain genes mutate, they make cells behave in odd ways. The cells divide swiftly, they hide from the immune system that could kill them and they gain the nourishment they need to develop into tumors.

title: North of Tokyo, Exploring the Sacred and Scenic
description: To the right of the path, a fast-rushing river, blue and white, sped through a secluded gorge, breaking into rapids over dark rocks and tumbling over the occasional waterfall. To the left, a long line of timeworn Buddhist statues sat with their backs to a steep wooded bank, inviting passers-by to share their contemplation.

title: Answer to Puerto Ricos Debt Woes? Its Complicated
description: Puerto Rico is in something of a jam at the moment.

title: Legislation Merging Russias 2 Top Courts Stokes Worries
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday signed legislation merging Russias two top courts in a controversial decision seen by many as meant to consolidate the Kremlins power over the countrys judicial system.

title: Senate Fails to Pass Three-Month Extension of Jobless Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate failed to move forward on a three-month extension of assistance for the long-term unemployed on Thursday, leaving it unlikely that Congress would approve the measure soon while undercutting a key aspect of President Obamas economic recovery plan.

title: A Certain Meanness of Argument, A Certain Superiority of Fact
description: I wrote yesterday about my frustration with the various liberal responses to the Congressional Budget Offices take on Obamacare and workforce participation, but this piece, from the sensible-centrist Ron Fournier, is actually much more exasperating:

title: Fossil Fuel, Naked
description: Which is to say Coal, Bare.

title: New Cord for Electric Vehicles Offers Charge-Anywhere Versatility
description: Range anxiety and limited charging infrastructure are among the reasons some consumers dont consider buying an electric vehicle. Those two concerns are related, because if theres no place to charge an E.V., that affects the distance a driver can travel.

title: Ideas to Make Retirement Possible
description: Who killed pensions? Can they be resurrected?

title: U.S. Points to Russia as Diplomats Private Call Is Posted on Web
description: WASHINGTON  After months of taking grief for snooping on foreign leaders, the Obama administration found itself on the other side on Thursday after a private telephone call between two American diplomats appeared on the Internet in a breach that the White House tied to Russia.

title: Rachel Comey: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Ethics Panel to Review Lawmakers Spending
description: WASHINGTON  The House Ethics Committee said Thursday that it would conduct a preliminary investigation into the campaign finances of Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington, the Houses highest-ranking Republican woman, who just last week delivered her partys response to the State of the Union address.

title: Broadcaster Releases Gay Mountain Video for Olympics in Sochi
description: A television broadcaster in Britain is celebrating the opening of the Winter Olympics in Sochi with a change in its corporate logo to rainbow colors, and a promotional advertisement that it will air on Friday to applaud the gay and straight athletes who are taking part.

title: Syrian City to Receive Aid, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The Syrian government appeared to take a small step to ease the plight of civilians by agreeing to provide humanitarian access to the city of Homs, which has been under siege for over a year, American and United Nations officials said on Thursday.

title: Should Doctors Wait Longer Before Intervening in Births?
description: Having a baby  the actual, in-labor, taking-that-baby-from- womb-to-world stage  takes time. As much as many of us feel that the lack of an easy mechanism to complete that process is something of a human design flaw, most women will labor for hours during delivery. How many hours depends on a range of natural factors (first births, for example, tend to take longer). It depends, too, on the willingness of any attending clinicians to let labor continue before intervening with oxytocin, forceps, vacuum or a cesarean.

title: Romance at Arms Length
description: IN Spike Jonzes mesmerizing new movie Her, a man falls in love with a sultry-voiced computer operating system whose presence in the film is so lifelike you have to keep reminding yourself she doesnt actually exist. To make it easier for the audience to believe that a computer might be able to mimic human thought, emotion and speech so convincingly, Mr. Jonze sets his story in the not-so-distant future.

title: The Age of Small Things
description: Dodge Gallery

title: Robert Bechtle
description: Gladstone Gallery

title: Illinois Tool Works Sells Packaging Unit to Carlyle Group
description: Updated, 4:40 p.m. | Illinois Tool Works has agreed to sell its industrial packaging unit to the Carlyle Group for $3.2 billion, the companies announced on Thursday.

title: The Wayland Rudd Collection
description: Winkleman Gallery

title: Living With Cancer: An Artists View
description: Every time I sign a consent form, I wonder how informed I really am. Do physicians  can physicians convey the consequences of their treatments to cancer patients? Or is this where artists step in?

title: Lori Ellison
description: McKenzie Fine Art Inc.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Bright Eyes at Creatures of the Wind
description: You couldnt help but notice that flash of electric-blue liner peeking out from under models eyes at Creatures of the Wind this morning. But its reason for being there? Not entirely obvious. Its actually a lighting effect more than anything else, revealed the makeup artist James Boehmer. We pulled colors from the collection and eventually landed on this metallic blue since it gives the eyes a lit-from-within effect, and looks great on everyone. To achieve the special-effects illusion, Boehmer traced a superfine streak of Nars Larger Than Life Long-Wear Eyeliner in Khao San Road on the waterline  that innermost part of the lower lid  so it would catch the light, he explained, and shock the whites of the eyes so they stood out more. The finished result was a bit ethereal, a bit punk and definitely pretty, even if that wasnt the point.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: In the latest installment of Before and After, book designers discuss recent examples of their work: early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

title: Hayley Tompkins: Space Kitchen
description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: If Natures a Generous Benefactor, a Girl Cant Help Sharing Her Gifts
description: If it is possible to leer sweetly, then thats what theyre doing this weekend at City Center, where a likable if long-winded production of Little Me is running through Sunday. The Encores! concert revival of this 1962 musical manages to wipe the smirk off the face of a show about the rise and rise of a woman whose greatest assets are her mammary glands.

title: Duckie Brown: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: A Check With No Name

title: Finnish Goalies Mask Runs Afoul of I.O.C. Rules
description: SOCHI, Russia  On her Olympic mask, the Finnish goaltender Noora Raty included the words Hakkaa paalle, which loosely translates to Cut them down. It is a battle cry with roots that go back four centuries, to the Thirty Years War, and it has become the national team mantra, something the players recite before every game.

title: Anatomy: 'The Broken Circle Breakdown'
description: Felix van Groeningen narrates a musical sequence from "The Broken Circle Breakdown."

title: For Top Chef, a New Season of Cruises
description: The Bravo television show Top Chef may repeat the basic concept each season, but the actual show is quite different every time nonetheless. It follows, then, that rather than simply reproduce Top Chef: The Cruise, a Celebrity Cruises charter that set sail last spring, allowing cruisers to fraternize with former contestants on the competition show, the network and the cruise line have partnered on a new venture in 2014.

title: Olympic Dreams, Financial Reality
description: The 2014 Olympics in Sochi are estimated to be the most expensive yet. While host cities hope the games will bring in a profit, they have more often than not created long-term economic burdens.

title: The Olympics: A Costly Feel-Good Moment
description: Even before the Olympic torch reached Sochi on Wednesday  after a 39,000-mile journey, the longest in the history of the Games  another Olympic record had already been shattered: the cost of the Games.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of The Broken Circle Breakdown
description: The Belgian drama The Broken Circle Breakdown follows the relationship that develops between a tattoo artist (Veerle Baetens) and a bluegrass musician (Johan Heldenbergh). The film was nominated for an Academy Award in the foreign-language category and is also available on demand this week. In this video, the director Felix van Groeningen narrates a scene from the film, where the two leads share a musical moment. They perform the song The Boy Who Wouldnt Hoe Corn, first as a couple in their bedroom, then transitioning to a band rehearsal and finally in front of an audience onstage. Mr. Van Groeningen discusses some of his ideas behind the sequence.

title: Letters: My Life in Middlemarch
description: Glorious George

title: Correcting the Film Version of a Sensational Story
description: There is intrinsic power in escape stories; consider films like Papillon or Escape From Alcatraz. With Riding the Midnight Express With Billy Hayes, the writer Billy Hayes tells his own. Its been presented before: in Midnight Express, his 1976 memoir about five years he spent imprisoned in Turkey for trying to smuggle hashish, and in the 1978 movie adaptation. But as he makes clear in this one-man show, the movie omits much of his ordeal, and what it does present has, shall we say, a high degree of historical revisionism.

title: The Ringing Sounds of Dallas Buyers Club
description: Gravity had a score that had to transcend the soundless void of space. Dallas Buyers Club, set in the 1980s in Texas, when there was no shortage of crescendo-ed pop songs and drifting ballads to set the scene, had almost no score at all.

title: Excerpt: 'Bronx Bombers'
description: A scene from the new Broadway play about the New York Yankees.

title: Its Space Is No Object
description: The kitchen measures 3 feet by 5 feet and has no oven, only a few induction burners and a sandwich press. There is barely room for the two men in black aprons (the chef, Andrew DAmbrosi, and his sous-chef, Anthony Mongeluzzi) who toil, heads bowed, behind a long glass case filled with gleaming slabs of raw fish.

title: Looking Beyond the Canonical Masterpieces
description: Leon Botstein, the conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, is right. Classical music has far too long been in thrall to the cult of the masterpiece, the idea that the arts exist more or less solely for the purpose of identifying and codifying a canon of great works.

title: Skating at Home, Plushenko Has Already Won
description: SOCHI, Russia  On Thursday night, the first great Russian star competed at the first Russian Winter Olympics. The eager crowd was disappointingly small at the Iceberg Skating Palace, but Evgeni Plushenko never needed a big audience. He could put on a show in a phone booth.

title: Coal-Flavored Water
description: The recent waste leak from an old coal-fired power plant in North Carolina should serve as a wakeup call to federal officials who have been far too slow and timid about regulating the disposal of coal ash.

title: Cordial and Friendly Session as Pakistan and Taliban Open Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani government officials and Taliban representatives made their first formal contact on Thursday, each side handing the other a wish list as they began talks to end a debilitating conflict that has ravaged the country for years.

title: Off-the-Field Fumbles and Passes
description: Traditionally, and in no particular order, Super Bowl Sunday tends to result in hangovers, gambling losses and chatter about the commercials. But what about romance? Can the big game inspire big love? The answer appears to be yes; at least according to the personal ads on Craigslist. The following poems about the erotic possibilities of the Super Bowl were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: A Fashion Meet-and-Greet With the Mayor
description: The fashion industry and New York Mayor Bill de Blasio are officially in the getting-to-know-you phase of their relationship.

title: A Sentimental Education
description: Recent studies suggest that reading literature may make us smarter and more empathic, even more civic-minded. But what can literature tell us about love? Writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love  and a few that led them memorably astray.

title: Costello Tagliapietra: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: De Blasio Appoints Chirlane McCray, His Wife, to Lead Nonprofit Group
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has at times teased his appointees about their diminutive statures, or in one case, an eye patch. But he had not, before Thursday, flirtatiously pinched a prominent official while announcing her new role. Or kissed her twice  on the lips  or given her a high-five.

title: White Pine Trees Provide Canopy and Carpet
description: There are few places on earth as silent or as fragrant as a grove of white pines. Showering down from above, the trees soft needles form a springy, thick carpet suffused with the bracing smell of pine resin. Mature pine groves have been accurately described as cathedral-like, the trees spires forming a dense canopy that effectively blocks out direct light and much ambient noise. Tangibly mysterious places, groves of pines frequently shelter wintering wildlife like owls and small mammals. Winter seems to be just a little more forgiving under the pine boughs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kosovo and Elsewhere
description: Photos form Kosovo, South Africa, Jerusalem and South Sudan.

title: Classic Lensman, Using Full Palette
description: Perhaps the greatest revelation provided by Capa in Color is not that Robert Capa, best known as a war photographer, shot in color film. It is that he shot in color frequently, honing his technical facility and trying to get the work published in magazines that began printing color photographs in the late 1930s. In letters, wall texts and magazine layouts displayed in this exhibition at the International Center of Photography, however, you sense Capas enthusiasm for color bumping up against various conventions and commercial demands.

title: How Ben Horowitz Avoided an Options Backdating Scandal
description: Just by listening to his favorite rappers, Ben Horowitz has absorbed many tales of run-ins and near run-ins with the law. But the prominent Silicon Valley investor also lived one of his own.

title: Second Shot
description: There comes a moment in every novelists career when she sloughs off the weight of the past  the conventions and obsessions, the stylistic fallbacks and linguistic tics, the influence of early masters  and ventures into new territory, breaking free into a marriage of tone and style, of plot and characterization, thats utterly her own. Anna Quindlens marvelous romantic comedy of manners is just such a book.

title: Seeing the Show With Their Ears
description: I DONT know why you people have to go to the movies, the man had barked. You wont get anything out of it anyway.

title: Postapocalyptic Survival Stories
description: Like a high-minded Choose Your Own Adventure tale or a feature-length scenario from the holodeck of Star Trek, the risible After the Dark posits a number of postapocalyptic survival stories. Why choose one end of the world when you can safely have several by presenting them as lesson plans in a classroom?

title: A Martian View of Our Pale Dot
description: Talk about small is beautiful.

title: Ralph Kiner, Slugger Who Became a Voice of the Mets, Dies at 91
description: Ralph Kiner, baseballs vastly undersung slugger, who belted more home runs than anyone else over his 10-year career but whose achievements in the batters box were obscured by his decades in the broadcast booth, where he was one of the games most recognizable personalities, died on Thursday at home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 91.

title: Twitters Stock Crashes Back to Reality
description: Twitters stock plunged on Thursday, dropping 24 percent to close at $50.05 a share, after a fourth-quarter earnings report on Wednesday showed significant declines in usage and a slowdown in the growth of the new users.

title: Artists on Artists | Richard Tuttle on Frederic Remington, Purveyor of Wild West Nostalgia
description: The Post-Minimalist sculptor Richard Tuttle is known for transforming humble materials like cloth, wire and plastic bags into something unexpected and new. Whether hes nailing a bit of frayed rope to a wall or using a doormat, lumber and Kraft paper to build an Arp-like construction on the floor, he always creates work that is anti-monumental and abstract, as evidenced by Looking for the Map, at Pace Gallery on East 57th Street (Feb. 7  March 15), which showcases 11 studies for his installation next October at Tate Moderns Turbine Hall.

title: When a Form Is Given Its Room to Play
description: Something old, something new, nothing borrowed and not enough color. A variation on the venerable bridal dress code pretty much sums up the Museum of Modern Arts latest foray into its photography collection, A World of Its Own: Photographic Practices in the Studio. In turn, the title of this fabulous yet irritating survey offers its own variation  on the name of Virginia Woolfs famous essay about female independence, A Room of Ones Own  but the show itself, which opens on Saturday, dazzles but often seems slow and repetitive.

title: Repaying Home Equity Loans
description: Borrowers who opened home-equity lines of credit at the height of the housing bubble should brace for stiff increases in their monthly payments.

title: At Wellesley, Debate Over a Statue in Briefs
description: BOSTON  When Sruthi Narayanan, a Wellesley College senior, first saw a nearly naked man who appeared to be stumbling on campus, she assumed he was a drunk, about to be arrested.

title: One-Acts From Young Playwrights
description: Here in the 21st century, the Miser would have expected the two young gentlemen sharing his abode to be leagues beyond the analog board games that enriched the Misers childhood. Yet their Christmas lists included throwbacks like Battleship and Monopoly. There is obviously some lingering appeal to those flat, rectangular-boxed ensembles of cheap cardboard and plastic.

title: Multiple Exposures, Looking Both Ways
description: PHILADELPHIA  In Michael Snows 45-minute film Wavelength (1967), the camera gradually zooms in on a wall in his studio. Wavelength is a classic of experimental cinema, but it ends with a photograph and might, in a way, be one. That interpretation is encouraged, at any rate, by Michael Snow: Photo-Centric, an engaging survey of his photography at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Mapping Clintons Trajectory
description: Many people who worked with Hillary Rodham Clinton, from low-level aides in the State Department up to President Obama, found themselves liking her more with each interaction, even if they had been worked over, the authors of H R C write. They quote a member of Defense Secretary Robert M. Gatess inner circle, who somewhat patronizingly describes it as traversing the stages of Hillary: You know, you first dread the prospect of working with her, then you sort of begrudgingly begin to respect her, then you outright respect her and her incredible work ethic. You know, shes inexhaustible, shes tough-minded, and then you come to actually start to like her, and you just cant believe it, but you actually like this person, and shes charming and shes funny and shes interesting and shes inquisitive and shes engaging.

title: Writing Was on the Wall, and Some Still Remains
description: Some of my most vivid memories from occasional visits to New York in the late 1970s and early 80s are of the graffiti-covered trains roaring through the citys subway system. With their giant, pneumatic, spray-painted letters spelling names like Crash and Daze against apocalyptic backgrounds, those unauthorized moving murals amazed me. I thought they were beautiful and inspiring.

title: A-Team Tracks Nazi Plunder
description: And here we thought that George Clooney was this eras Cary Grant even if, with his squinty smile and no-sweat insouciance, hes really closer to Clark Gable. As it turns out, Mr. Clooney seems to have been harboring a desire to tap into his inner Gregory Peck  noble, stolid, dull  as he does in The Monuments Men, which he both directed and stars in. It was Peck who led the team of World War II Allied saboteurs in The Guns of Navarone, one of those men-on-a-mission movies, a subgenre that includes everything from The Dirty Dozen to the Oceans Eleven trilogy, which starred Mr. Clooney in a fizzier, less sanctimonious mode.

title: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Senate Confirms One of Its Own as Ambassador to China
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted 96 to 0 on Thursday to confirm Senator Max Baucus as the new ambassador to China.

description: Freestyle skiing, figure skating, and a new sport  slopestyle snowboarding  on the first day of competition at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics.

title: Olympic-ish Sport for Tyros Like Us
description: THE Winter Olympic Games are here, which means its time once again for couch-dwelling Americans not only to become instant experts in sports they barely knew existed, but also to ponder going out and trying them.

title: Bryan Greenberg at Richard Chai
description: It was quite the heartthrob lineup at Richard Chais fall 2014 show at Lincoln Center on Thursday morning. Seatmates Zachary Quinto, Bryan Greenberg and Joe Jonas (the latter doing no press), slid into their front-row assignments a few minutes after 11 a.m. Perhaps Mr. Greenberg, dressed in a dark leather jacket with quilting details, was in familiar territory, having once worked in the fashion industry  well, on screen anyway.

description: A few weeks before his arrest at Kennedy Airport, Charles Shrem was standing behind the Manhattan bar he invested in with some of his Bitcoin fortune, buzzing about his big plans for the virtual currency and himself.

description: Today Speaker John Boehner cast doubt on the possibility of the House passing immigration legislation this year, probably dashing whatever slim hopes there were for a deal.

title: Samuragochis Work, Now in Question
description: Mamoru Samuragochi, who won fame for overcoming deafness to write music, confessed many of his best-known works were ghostwritten. Then his ghostwriter said he was not actually deaf, either.

title: Tome: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

description: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

title: New York Fashion Week: BCBG Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Did Mother, Maybe, Not Know Best?
description: After two decades of saying I would never get married, I did. I changed my mind one Sunday while sitting at my desk in front of my computer, as happily unmarried as ever.

title: Giving and Forgiving
description: My wife and I are dear friends with a couple we cherish. At our sons bar mitzvah last October, they approached my wife and told her they had forgotten their gift and would get it to us. When they came to dinner two weeks later, they had forgotten it again. We have seen them several times since, but the topic no longer comes up. We accept that they are never giving a gift; we love them anyway. Still, after every evening together, my wife points out the elephant in the room: Still no gift. How do we get past this, so its no longer on our minds? Should we say something?

title: Eichmanns Rabbi Gazes Backward
description: Perhaps the most haunting and enduring feature of Shoah, Claude Lanzmanns nine-and-a-half-hour documentary  the closest thing to a definitive cinematic work on the Nazis mass murder of European Jews we are likely to have  is its dogged commitment to the present tense. Filmed mostly in the 1970s in some of the places where the killing was planned and carried out, Shoah, released in 1985, relies on face-to-face, after-the-fact testimony rather than archival footage or dramatic reconstruction. It is thus simultaneously about the imperative to remember and the inadequacy of memory. A masterpiece of historical detective work, the film is also a philosophical exploration of a gap that has only grown wider in the years since its release.

title: This Is Your Captain Singing
description: Singing careers tend to follow a pattern: early study, conservatory, a young artists program, smaller parts, larger ones, little-known companies, famous ones. A soprano who does the Third Norn in Wagners Gtterdmmerung might, if shes lucky, eventually graduate to Brnnhilde.

title: Theater Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Ex-Brokerage Executives Charged With Fraud
description: The owner and two executives of the WJB Capital Group were arrested on Thursday and charged with defrauding at least 15 investors out of more than $11 million during the waning days of their now-defunct brokerage company.

title: Romantic Intensity, Replete With Trills and Flourishes
description: Even by the reliably high standards of the Young Concert Artists series, which has been promoting gifted young musicians since 1961, the performance on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall by the Ukrainian violinist Aleksey Semenenko proved particularly rewarding.

title: Fashion Sketches and Cartwheel Practice With Betsey Johnson
description: When Betsey Johnson, the celebrated fashion designer who, at 71, still does cartwheels on the runway, has a show in the works, as she does on Feb. 12 for Fashion Week 2014 at Lincoln Center, her Sundays are overwhelmed by casting calls for models and by the sudden need for decorative detail like, say, gold lam rose petals. Im in a total panic, with adrenaline and excitement, said Ms. Johnson, who filed for bankruptcy in 2012 and was later bought out by her friend and fellow designer Steve Madden. On a more typical Sunday  my day of nothing  she is happy to do little more than kick around her neighborhood, the Upper East Side, or look after her granddaughters, Layla, 7, and Ella, 5, who live in her apartment building with Ms. Johnsons daughter, Lulu.

title: What I Love | Sarabeth Levine
description: The co-owner of the restaurants that bear her name lives with her husband on the Upper West Side.

title: Where the Real Sarabeth Dines
description: Be prepared to ditch the brogues or stilettos before setting foot in Sarabeth Levines immaculate (and she wants to keep it that way) two-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side.

title: Comedy Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Threads in the Tapestry, Dark, Bright and Scratchy
description: In recent years, the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, which originated as a conductorless period-instrument ensemble in 1987, has ventured beyond its original brief with well-received interpretations of 19th-century works, often in collaboration with noted conductors. Its performance of the complete Brandenburg Concertos by Bach at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday marked a return to its core mission. But the concert had a subdued quality in which fine solos could not make up for the overall lackluster sound and uneven performance.

title: Movie Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: After a Bad Breakup, Anything Goes
description: Under its contemporary facade of buzzing cellphones and potty-mouthed insults, Bryan Poysers Love & Air Sex is a traditional romantic comedy that is desperate to please. Although the main characters, in their 20s and early 30s, communicate mostly via text message, often in sexually graphic detail, they are the same vulnerable relationship seekers they have always been but with extra mileage on their pedometers.

title: Words Spoken and Sung in Service of Freedom
description: The most powerful performance at Bringing Human Rights Home, a benefit concert for Amnesty International at Barclays Center on Wednesday night, didnt need drums or electric guitars.

title: Jazz Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: As Seen on TV, a Medical Mystery Involving Hip Implants Is Solved
description: By a strange coincidence, two leading medical journals on Thursday published case studies of the same arcane medical mystery. In one, doctors solved the riddle only after the patient, a middle-aged woman, got so sick she had to have a heart transplant. But in the other, a physician who teaches at the University of Marburg in Germany found the clues in Season 7, Episode 11, of the Fox television show House.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: What to Look For in Fridays Jobs Report
description: Did hiring pick up in January, or are we in for a repeat of Decembers disappointing jobs report?

title: Facebook and Football
description: The digital clench has never been stronger. This week, 10 years since the founding of Facebook, some new numbers showed just how much the social network produced in Mark Zuckerbergs Harvard dorm has changed us all. Can I share?

title: Veteran Actors To Dress Up For Casa Valentina
description: An lineup of theater veterans, including Reed Birney (Picnic), John Cullum (The Scottsboro Boys), Patrick Page (Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark), and Larry Pine (The Designated Mourner), will be among the ensemble cast in Harvey Fiersteins new Broadway play Casa Valentina this spring, the producers announced on Thursday.

title: Now Theyll Love Me, a Twin Sister Schemes
description: In The Pretty One, Jene LaMarques first feature, Zoe Kazan plays identical twins of contrasting temperament. Audrey, alluded to in the title, has a cute haircut, fashionable clothes and an exciting life in a city that might be Los Angeles. (The film is too coy to be specific about such things.) Her sister, Laurel, mousy and odd, lives with their widowed father (John Carroll Lynch) in a rambling house in a quirky town where she helps him paint copies of famous artworks.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Feb. 7-13
description: Art

title: There Can Be Frightening Things in the Canadian Woods
description: The Qubcois director Denis Ct throws a tight frame around his characters in Vic + Flo Saw a Bear, nearly boxing them in. That makes sense for this funny-eccentric, funny-scary story of two female ex-cons who having once been holed up together in prison are now holed up in a house in the deep woods. Theres a once-upon- a-time feel to both the location and the movie, which had its premiere at the 2013 Berlin International Film Festival, where it won an award. The title may sound like a childrens book and the bear may be metaphoric, but make no mistake: This is a story with surprisingly great, big teeth.

title: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 7-13
description: Fantasias Big Bon Voyage Party

title: At Coach, Boots for the Polar Vortex
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Spare Times for Feb. 7-13
description: ATHENA FILM FESTIVAL (Friday through Sunday) This annual festival celebrating strong women in film started on Thursday and continues with screenings, discussions and other events at Barnard College, 3009 Broadway, between 116th and 120th Streets, Morningside Heights.

title: New Yorkers: John Youngaitis
description: Following in his fathers footsteps, John Youngaitis runs a storefront taxidermy studio in Middle Village, Queens.

title: How to Stop Heroin Deaths
description: PHILIP SEYMOUR HOFFMAN, who died of an apparent heroin overdose on Sunday, was just one of hundreds of New Yorkers who fall victim to this drug each year. Heroin-related deaths increased 84 percent from 2010 to 2012 in New York City and occur at a higher rate  52 percent  than overdose deaths involving any other substance.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: A Taxidermist Is a Keeper of a Quiet Zoo
description: Wrapped in his white cloth apron, John Youngaitis resembles a neighborhood butcher.

title: A Play for Justice in South Korea
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Shopping for a Bra With Betsey Johnson
description: How do I look with breasts? asked Betsey Johnson, holding a push-up bra clasped over her shirt in a Victorias Secret showroom. I took several photos in quick succession, suspecting that it would not be long before security asked me to stop.

title: West Bank: U.N. Staff Ends Strike
description: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, the body that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees, announced Thursday that a two-month strike by its 4,500 employees in the West Bank had ended. The strike, over pay and other issues, kept more than 50,000 children out of school, closed down free health services and raised tensions in the volatile refugee camps. The United Nations agency said in a statement that its director of operations in the West Bank and a representative of the areas staff union had signed a document outlining measures to improve conditions for the staff, without elaborating. The statement praised the government of the Palestinian Authority for its mediation efforts and said the agency was looking forward to the immediate resumption of all services.

title: Italy: Toxic Waste Law Enacted
description: In the first strong legislative response to the dumping crisis in the southern region of Campania, President Giorgio Napolitano signed an emergency law on Thursday to tackle environmental crimes and the damage produced by the illegal dumping or burning of waste. Under the new law, burning garbage without authorization is a crime punishable by up to five years in prison. In the vast area north of Naples where the Camorra mafia has buried toxic waste for decades, health and environmental authorities will have to carry out tests on the agricultural fields to measure the toxicity levels in the soil. Parliament allocated about $676 million for the cleanup, and police officers or soldiers will conduct antidumping patrols. The law includes measures to clean up the environmental damage produced by a steel plant in the southern city of Taranto.

title: Highlights From Our Social Feeds at NYFW, Day 1
France: Seized Ivory Destroyed
description: In an effort to deter poachers and traffickers, France publicly destroyed a stock of about three tons of confiscated ivory from the tusks of African elephants on Thursday, making it the first European country to take such a step. The ivory was crushed in a large machine at a ceremony at the foot of the Eiffel Tower presided over by Environment Minister Philippe Martin. The impounded ivory included 698 elephant tusks that the police had confiscated and stockpiled since the 1990s. The operation was part of President Franois Hollandes plan to send a clear and precise message against poachers, traffickers and buyers and to show the French governments solidarity to African countries, the Environment Ministry said. The United States and China, ivorys biggest market, have also destroyed seized ivory to help stem the illicit trade that endangers the survival of the elephants.

title: Dreamscapes of a Nightmarish Conflict
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

description: New York

title: When Should Countries Boycott the Olympics?
Carla Ciffoni Transforms Backstage at Richard Chai Love
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Carla Ciffoni before (left) and after (right) makeup by Romy Soleimani and hair by Kevin Ryan.

title: Officers and Office Workers Find an Oasis in National Grid Caf
description: It looked like a casting call for Law & Order: SVU. Packs of police officers sat at long, white tables, chatting about arrests, ballistic tests and vacation time. Nearby, two fire dispatchers hurriedly ate meatloaf and pastrami while checking their phones. Other diners seemed to be standard-issue office workers, eating brown-bag lunches and drinking cups of coffee.

title: A Woman and Her Tortoise on Quest for Family
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Muchelney Under Water
description: Dozens of homes are flooded and much of the west coast of England and Wales are under fresh flood alerts.

title: Accustomed to Floods, but Nothing Like This, in Southern England
description: MUCHELNEY, England  The village of Muchelney has become an island. Cars stand idle; locals canoe across the flooded plain or take a police boat down the road-turned-river connecting them to what they now call the mainland. About halfway, a silver sedan bobs in the water, its roof barely protruding. It has been there for five weeks.

title: Letting the Kids in on the Charitable Giving Conversation
description: Money is one of the most powerful tools we have to teach children the values and virtues we want them to adopt. Given how many of our own values are wrapped up in charitable giving, it makes sense to bring the kids in on some of the decision making.

title: Why, Yes, This Is Going to Hurt
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Uterine Surgical Technique Is Linked to Abnormal Growths and Cancer Spread
description: Concerns are increasing among doctors about the safety of a procedure performed on tens of thousands of women a year in the United States who undergo surgery to remove fibroid tumors from the uterus, or to remove the entire uterus.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: The New York Times movie critics on Vic + Flo Saw a Bear, The Lego Movie and The Last of the Unjust.

title: Iran Delivers Surprise, Money, to Jewish Hospital
description: TEHRAN  The brother of Irans president walked into Tehrans only Jewish hospital on Thursday, delivering a surprise donation along with the message that the Health Ministry would give more attention to hospitals that traditionally serve Christian and Jewish Iranians.

title: Theres a Dark Cloud Over Our Sport
