description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  When Don Catlin, the former head of the U.C.L.A. Olympic Analytical Laboratory, heard that three biathletes had tested positive for a nonspecific substance about a week before the Olympics, I could hear him sigh over the phone.

title: Motion Is Filed to Silence Prosecutor in Sept. 11 Case
description: WASHINGTON  The defense team lawyers for one of the five Guantnamo Bay detainees charged with aiding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are seeking to muzzle the chief military commissions prosecutor, saying that his comments defending the tribunals system  including in a recent 60 Minutes interview  are unethical and that they are undermining their clients right to a fair trial.

title: Mad Daddy on a Mission
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Caribbean Islands Agree to Swap Diesel Power for Renewable Sources
description: Several Caribbean nations committed on Thursday to start replacing diesel generators, the most common means of producing electricity on islands, with renewable sources like wind, solar or the earths heat.

title: Richard Hayman, a Pops Concert Figure in St. Louis and Boston, Dies at 93
description: Richard Hayman, who began his career as a harmonica player and went on to become the conductor of pops concerts in St. Louis and the arranger of pops concerts in Boston, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
description: The Obama administration penalized nearly three dozen companies and individuals in eight countries on Thursday, accusing them of evading Iranian sanctions. It was the administrations most extensive enforcement action to target Iran since a temporary international agreement on that countrys disputed nuclear program was completed in November and put into effect last month.

title: Death in the Afternoon, Then Drinks
description: Between the fetid Gowanus Canal and the South Brooklyn Casket Company lies the Morbid Anatomy Library and Museum. Two thousand books, whose titles include Corpses, Coffins and Crypts and Stuffed Animals and Pickled Heads, share 200 square feet with inert squirrels, a fetal possum, a human skeleton and about 25 live visitors on any given Saturday afternoon.

title: Skating Close to the Edge, Again, on the Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON  Here they go again.

title: The Buried Treasure Is the Psychedelic Kind
description: Opens on Friday.

title: In Excellence Push, A&M Welcomes 9 New Research Fellows
description: Nine internationally renowned researchers from various fields will be welcomed on Friday as fellows of the Texas A&M University Institute for Advanced Study, part of a group that administrators have nicknamed the Genius Corps.

title: A Jumbled Journey Through a Curious Marketplace
description: Opens on Friday in New York, Los Angeles and Toronto.

title: Trying to Weigh the Value of Voter Guides
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: Rene Ricard, Art Arbiter With Wildean Wit, Dies at 67
description: Ive never worked a day in my life, Rene Ricard, then 32, wrote in an essay for The New York Times Op-Ed page in 1978. If I did it would probably ruin my career, which at the moment is something of a cross between a butterfly and a lap dog.

title: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

title: Fingers Crossed, Marketers Count on Olympic Gold
description: THE many marketers spending an estimated $1 billion to sponsor and advertise during the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, are keeping their fingers crossed that the multiple issues threatening to overshadow the Winter Games  whether security, human rights, stray dogs or ramshackle accommodations  will not repel American consumers.

title: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 9-15
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Theyre Single, and Creeps. The Women, Too.
New York State Agrees to Cut Toll for Verrazano Bridge
description: For years, and especially in election years, New York Citys political elite has cast an occasional eye toward the transit-deficient hinterland of Staten Island.

title: Health, Work, Lies
description: On Wednesday, Douglas Elmendorf, the director of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, said the obvious: losing your job and choosing to work less arent the same thing. If you lose your job, you suffer immense personal and financial hardship. If, on the other hand, you choose to work less and spend more time with your family, we dont sympathize. We say congratulations.

title: Long-Haul Expansion by a Norwegian Carrier Upsets U.S. Airlines
description: Flying doesnt come cheaply these days, particularly on long-haul flights across the Atlantic.

title: Invasion Remarks Fuel a Heated Debate in a G.O.P. Race
description: On immigration policy, there are no major differences between the Republican candidates running for lieutenant governor in Texas.

title: Guatemala Court Rules to Curb Crusader
description: MEXICO CITY  Guatemalan politics were thrown into disarray on Thursday after the countrys highest court ruled that the crusading attorney general, Claudia Paz y Paz, must step down in May, seven months before her four-year term was to end.

title: F.D.A. Tightens Rules on Infant Formula
description: The Food and Drug Administration updated safety requirements for producers of infant formula. The changes require companies to tighten their quality control procedures and reporting requirements. They also require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens like salmonella. Most companies already meet those standards, but the rule will give the agency more control over enforcing them. The rule will also ensure that infant formula contains all federally required nutrients. The changes will be open to public comment for 45 days.

title: Todd Snyder: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Events in Westchester for Feb. 9-15
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Odd: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Lugers Name Matches the One on His Waistband
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Bruno Banani is a German mens underwear company. The brand, which features styles with colorful names like Booty Bass, Rusty Iron and Blockbuster (it can come as a G-string), is well known in Europe for its unusual marketing campaigns. The company has sent its garments underwater to the Bermuda Triangle, and in 1998, Russian astronauts wore the underwear aboard a space station.

title: Other Peoples Views
description: Lets say youre turning 40 and you realize you want to leave accounting and become a hip-hop artist. People will say youre having a pathetic midlife crisis, but should you do it anyway?

title: In Royal Drama, Spain Sees Its Reality Reflected
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Once upon a time, Spains Princess Cristina and her husband lived a life of royal splendor. Ensconced in a hillside mansion with a saltwater swimming pool outside Barcelona, they jaunted off to sailing regattas and charity balls with the Spanish elite.

title: Events on Long Island for Feb. 9-15
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: A Bellows Painting Moves From Virginia to London
description: In 1920, students at what was then the Randolph-Macon Womans College in Lynchburg, Va., raised $2,500 to buy George Bellowss Men of the Docks, a 1912 painting of workers milling around an ocean liner docked at the Brooklyn waterfront. It became the centerpiece of the colleges Maier Museum of Art.

title: Brain-Dead, a Canadian Woman Remains a Silent Partner Awaiting Birth
description: OTTAWA  Nearly six weeks after a pregnant Canadian woman was declared brain-dead, she remains on life support in Victoria, British Columbia, because of her familys hope that her fetus will mature enough to be delivered. The decision by Robyn Bensons family to try to deliver her child has drawn growing attention in Canada, largely because of a series of moving blog posts by her husband, Dylan Benson.

title: Counting Cars in a Comic Pileup
description: Coming soon to your iPhone (if youre so inclined): the 70-millimeter Ultra Panavision Hollywood roadshow.

title: Huge Leak of Coal Ash Slows at North Carolina Power Plant
description: A massive leak of toxic coal ash from a retired North Carolina power plant into a neighboring river dwindled on Thursday, utility officials said, but hundreds of workers had yet to seal the breach in a drainage pipe where the leak was detected more than four days ago.

title: Three Sensational Deaths and Two Notable Lives
description: The manhunt evoked the Lindbergh kidnapping case; the debate over the insanity defense echoed Harry K. Thaws trial for shooting Stanford White; the principal actors included Thomas Dewey and the defense lawyer Samuel Leibowitz. The triple murder on Beekman Place in 1937 by Robert George Irwin has been largely forgotten, but it captivated America for months.

title: A Moving Glass Box Conquers Uneven Terrain at a Subway Station
description: The first subway line of New York, the No. 1, burst from the ground at a place in Upper Manhattan called Fort George Hill around March 1904, having traveled two miles north, from around 158th Street, through solid rock.

title: Past Fictions, a Lack of Trust and No Deal in SAC Case
description: The guilty verdict on Thursday against the former SAC trader Mathew Martoma only deepens a mystery about the case: Given the overwhelming evidence against him, why did he fight the charges of insider trading, risking a lengthy prison term, rather than make a deal with the government to cooperate in return for leniency?

title: The Homogeneous Federal Bench
description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, in a dissent from a 2007 Supreme Court decision that made it harder for women to sue employers for pay discrimination, suggested that the courts majority was not in tune with the realities of the workplace. Her background as general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, where she had co-founded the Womens Rights Project in 1972, surely informed her thinking. Unfortunately, that kind of experience is both less common and more controversial on the federal bench today. If she were being considered for a seat on the court these days, Justice Ginsburg told an audience in 2011, my A.C.L.U. connection would probably disqualify me.

title: Taking Tobacco Off the Shelves
description: CVS Caremark, the giant drugstore chain, deserves a big round of applause for deciding to phase out the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products at its more than 7,600 stores by Oct. 1. The decision will cost the company a substantial amount of money but will place CVS where it and other pharmacy chains belong  on the side of customer health and against a product that still kills 480,000 Americans a year.

title: Taking Stand, Nagin Defends Acts as Mayor in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  C. Ray Nagin took the stand in his federal corruption trial on Thursday, and under both the genial guidance of his defense lawyer and the unyielding press of a federal prosecutor, defended his conduct as the onetime mayor of this city and insisted he never received bribes for awarding contracts.

title: Amid Flow of Leaks, Turkey Moves to Crimp Internet
description: ISTANBUL  Shortly after an audio recording in which Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is said to be heard talking about easing zoning laws for a construction tycoon in exchange for two villas for his family, SoundCloud, the file-sharing site where it was leaked last month, was suddenly unavailable to Internet users in Turkey.

title: A Spotlight on Mr. Putins Russia
description: The Olympic Games that open in Sochi, Russia, on Friday are intended to be the fulfillment of President Vladimir Putins quest for prestige and power on the world stage. But the reality of Mr. Putin and the Russia he leads conflicts starkly with Olympic ideals and fundamental human rights. There is no way to ignore the dark side  the soul-crushing repression, the cruel new antigay and blasphemy laws and the corrupt legal system in which political dissidents are sentenced to lengthy terms on false charges.

title: Malaprops Were Part of the Charm of Kiner, an Enduring Met
description: Ralph Kiner had not called many Mets games in the past few years. He did not want to travel much. He was usually at afternoon games for a few innings, maybe 12 or 15 times a season.

title: Environmental Groups Denounce Arrests of Ecologists Near Olympic Sites
description: SOCHI, Russia  The initial brunt of a police crackdown on protesters at the Winter Olympics  originally expected to target gay rights groups  has instead fallen on environmental activists.

title: Behind Retreat on Immigration, a Complicated Political Interplay
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner would sorely like to help engineer an overhaul of immigration policy to bolster his legacy, help his party politically and address a difficult social and economic problem. He just cannot seem to persuade other Republicans, who see the immigration debate as a major threat to their drive to win the Senate and increase their House majority in November.

title: Mother Pleads Not Guilty in Death of 2-Year-Old
description: On Jan. 23, Ashley Diaz stood in Queens Family Court with her five children, ages 2 to 10, as a judge reviewed her efforts in parenting classes and therapy sessions mandated by the court after an abuse and neglect investigation two years ago.

title: On Blog, an Ex-Christie Ally Showed Approach to Politics
description: As Wally Edge, political blogger, David Wildstein was so anonymous that when he sold his company, the buyer did not know his real name.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 6, 2014
Designers Carve a Fashion Runway at the Games
description: Beyond the thrilling victories and agonizing defeats, the Olympics are a 16-day fashion show, even for fans blithely unaware that the United States Alpine skiing uniforms are meant to evoke the nations flag reflected in the water off Fort McHenry the morning after the British bombardment, 200 years ago, that inspired The Star-Spangled Banner.

title: If You Stage It, They Will Come
description: Talk about your fantasy baseball team. Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, for starters. Plus Mickey Mantle and Joe DiMaggio. Add the catcher Elston Howard, the first black player on the New York Yankees roster, and throw in the teams current captain, Derek Jeter.

title: Fourth-Brightest Star in the Sky
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I struggled with this 66-worder by Ned White, but I wound up liking the struggle. I believe thats why we have Friday puzzles, right? To both stretch your limits and entertain.

title: Energy Role Is Lifting Democrat in Louisiana
description: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, is set to become chairwoman next week of the Senate Energy Committee, a powerful position that gives her jurisdiction over the oil and gas industry that fuels her states economy  and which will be a major source of contributions to Ms. Landrieus tough re-election campaign this fall.

title: Twitter Q. and A. on Olympic Preparations
description: A day before the 2014 Winter Olympics begin in Sochi, Russia, David Herszenhorn, a Times correspondent based in Moscow, answered readers questions via Twitter on preparations for the Games. He discussed the importance of security concerns, current U.S.-Russian relations and how those abroad could help Sochis threatened stray dogs.

title: Bench Empty, the Lakers Are Saved by a Technicality
description: There were 3 minutes 32 seconds remaining in the Lakers game against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Wednesday when Los Angeles center Robert Sacre committed his sixth foul. Would the Lakers, who at the time had only five healthy players, be forced to play four on five?

title: Abundance of Snow, Headache to Many, Is a Boon for Hundreds Without Jobs
description: Nadji Colon never saw snow until he arrived in the Bronx in his late 20s from his homeland, Puerto Rico. He found it slushy and unpleasant to pick his way through.

title: In Hong Kong, an Unexploded Bomb Forces Evacuations
description: Hong Kong residents have a lot to contend with. Soaring real estate prices. High pollution levels. Political meddling from mainland China. And, in at least one pricey neighborhood famous for its racetrack, unexploded American ordnance from World War II.

title: Trial Brings New Scrutiny of Self-Defense Laws
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Nearly seven months after a jury acquitted George Zimmerman, whose shooting of an unarmed black teenager made him synonymous with Floridas so-called Stand Your Ground law, the states latest drama involving a fatal burst of gunfire and a claim of self-defense began to play out Thursday in a courtroom here.

title: The Cohen Connections
description: The top hedge fund SAC Capital agreed to plead guilty to insider trading and pay a record $1.2 billion fine. At least eight current or former SAC employees have been convicted or pleaded guilty to insider trading.

title: New Hampshire: Deal Reached on Medicaid Expansion
description: State senators saidThursdaythat they had reached a bipartisan deal on a framework to expand Medicaid to about 50,000 low-income adults. Under the agreement, the state will use federal money to buy private insurance, similar to a method adopted last year in Iowa and Arkansas. Last year, the New Hampshire House passed a bill to expand Medicaid, but the Senate failed to agree on expansion. The House voted again to expand Medicaid in January. The new deal will be drafted into a bill, which will probably be voted on in March. Gov. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, praised the deal during her State of the State addresson Thursday.

title: Power Failures Are Still Widespread After Storm
description: More than 500,000 people in Pennsylvania and Maryland went a second day without electricity on Thursday as utilities scrambled to restore power after heavy ice felled trees and damaged electrical equipment. Utility companies in Pennsylvania said that about 446,000 customers had no power on Thursday afternoon, a day after a storm knocked out electricity to about 800,000 people. In Maryland, utilities said about 50,000 customers remained in the dark. The companies said most customers would have their lights back by Friday night.

title: Vasil Bilak, 96, Dies; Czech Communist Encouraged 1968 Soviet Invasion
description: Vasil Bilak, a former Communist leader in Czechoslovakia who in 1968 encouraged the Soviet Union to invade his country to halt efforts for change that he saw as a threat to socialism, died on Thursday in Bratislava, Slovakias capital. He was 96.

title: Streak Over, Rangers Focus Turns to Penguins, Then Sochi
description: The Rangers drive for a fifth straight victory stalled at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night as they fell to the Edmonton Oilers, 2-1, on Nail Yakupovs goal with 1 minute 38 seconds to play.

title: In Trail Blazers, Woodson Sees a Lot to Like
description: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson has had an aggravating season that could soon cost him his job. But amid everything that is going wrong with his team, he has found time to admire how the Portland Trail Blazers go about their business.

title: Nets Keep Noses in Front Despite Fight From Depleted Spurs
description: The San Antonio Spurs had just 10 players dressed to meet the Nets on Thursday night, and before the evening was done, two of them had blood dripping from their broken noses. They were absurdly depleted, seemingly reduced to a B-list squad. But it hardly mattered.

title: Past, Future or Alien?
description: Im a huge sci-fi nerd, the curator Ginger Shulick says, and Ive been wanting to do an overtly sci-fi-themed show. So she did. The exhibition, titled Future/Past, opens today at the Reverse gallery in Brooklyn and features works by a handful of global artists, some of them clearly speculative-fiction buffs themselves. You cant really tell if things are from the past, or if theyre alien or futuristic, explains Shulick. I like to present works that raise more questions than leave you with answers.

title: California Bill Would Require Antitheft Technology for Cellphones
description: A smartphone is sleek, compact and valuable, which makes it a perfect target for a thief. Californian lawmakers want to require cellphone companies to fix that problem.

title: The Challenges of Running Responsible Supply Chains
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

title: Word of the Day | apolitical
description: apolitical \a-p-li-ti-kl\ adjective

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance (Before Sunset) in Paris that began nine years before that (Before Sunrise) in Vienna, Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke, above, with Ms. Delpy) are now in Greece, at the end of a summer vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and the son (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick) he left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with his son. Celine sees his question as a demand to make it happen. And so they will fight about this and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women  throughout the course of a day. Before Sunrise, Before Sunset and Before Midnight are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. Celine and Jesse can get on your nerves almost as much as they get on each others, Mr. Scott added. We have known them, and they have known each other, for a long time now, but we dont know, from one moment to the next, what their future will be, or what it is that keeps them going. That kind of uncertainty, a scary fact of life, is something most movies avoid. We prefer the magical thinking of neat endings, tidy plots and clear character arcs. Before Midnight is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect.

title: Mark McMorris on Slopestyle
description: Snowboardings slopestyle event has been dominated recently by Mark McMorris, a 20-year-old from the flat plains of Saskatchewan, Canada.

title: Ban on Liquids for Carry-Ons on Direct U.S.-Russia Flights
description: Passengers on nonstop flights between the United States and Russia have been prohibited from packing liquids, gels, aerosols or powders in their carry-on bags during the Winter Olympic Games in Sochi under a new directive issued by the United States Transportation Security Administration.

title: Woodson Shows Frustration
description: A day after the Knicks lost their third straight game, Coach Mike Woodson reiterated that he felt the team was capable of making the playoffs. But he also showed some frustration.

title: Corrections: February 7, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Report Says North Korea Is Improving Missile Capabilities
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has made progress in expanding its main satellite launch site, apparently to accommodate larger rockets that outside analysts said the country was developing for its intercontinental ballistic missile program, an American research institute reported Thursday.

title: That Old Guy? Hes Retired Now, Right?
description: Johnny Carsons departure from the Tonight show in 1992 was an abdication. Jay Lenos last show, on Thursday, was closer to a retirement party  a bittersweet send-off for a loyal executive pushed out after 22 years.

title: Amid Raft of Chinese Financial Numbers, One to Watch Carefully
description: Chinas slowing growth and sputtering industrial output have helped fuel a global fall in stock prices this year. Economists are divided on whether ballooning debt in the worlds second-biggest economy will trigger a full-blown financial crisis or whether China, as it has time and again, will manage to defy the pessimists and continue to outgrow its neighbors.

title: A Homegrown Comic Con Highlights Growth in Local Comics Market
description: MUMBAI In 2011, a group of comic book lovers in Delhi found it was too expensive to travel to the Comic Con fan conventions overseas and decided to hold their own event at home in the Indian capital.

title: Criticizing the Vatican
description: The United Nations this week released a report sharply critical of the Vaticans response to child abuse.

title: Petition to Nullify Thai Election Is Rejected in Setback for Opposition
description: BANGKOK  A petition to nullify Thailands general election was rejected Friday on procedural grounds by the countrys ombudsman, a setback for the opposition Democrat Party, which is allied with protesters trying to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

title: Stranded Travelers Start Riot at Airport
description: Holiday travel stress became too much for some of the 2,000 stranded passengers at an airport in central China, with some passengers smashing computers and causing a riot, the Global Times newspaper has reported.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 7, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Steel Maker ArcelorMittal Narrows Its Net Loss
description: LONDON  Not long after Lakshmi Mittal formed ArcelorMittal through the takeover of Arcelor in 2006, the financial crisis dragged global demand for steel sharply down, hitting the companys European base particularly hard. ArcelorMittal, the worlds largest steel maker, has been on the ropes ever since, running losses in some years and struggling with an outsize debt burden.

title: Indonesia Grants Parole to Australian Woman in Drug Case
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian government on Friday granted parole to an Australian woman whose conviction in 2005 for smuggling drugs into the Indonesian resort island of Bali caused a diplomatic row between the two nations and public outrage in her home country.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Teaching Creativity
description: In Learning to Think Outside the Box, Laura Pappano writes about how and why creativity has become an academic discipline. Use the article and the related slide show of student projects, above, to answer the questions below.

title: Alex Webb Looks Back in Black-and-White
description: Alex Webb was a 23-year-old photographer in 1976 when he put his belongings in a New York darkroom and headed south in his beat-up Volvo, which doubled as his bedroom. His experiences led his meanderings, and he occasionally picked up assignments that financed his work.

title: What Are Five Everyday Problems That Bother You, and What Can You Do About Them?
description: Do you hate it when you go into a public bathroom stall and the lock wont work? How about when businesses you need close too early, or when umbrellas are more hindrance than help? What are some everyday problems, small or large, that really annoy you?

title: Fashion Week Preview: Day 2
description: Fashion Week officially began Thursday  for proof, look no further than the legions mugging for street-style photographers in front of Lincoln Center  but Friday is the day when the action really revs up.

title: Times Minute | Russian Olympic Fashion
description: Also on the Minute, Oprah Winfrey eyes the Broadway stage and the colorful life of the longtime Mets announcer Ralph Kiner.

title: Times Minute | Russian Olympic Fashion
description: In the Video

title: New York Today: Wisdom of the Groundhog
description: Updated, 11:01 a.m.

title: In Signing Farm Bill, Obama Extols Rural Growth
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  President Obama signed the $956 billion farm bill on Friday at Michigan State University, where he extolled the benefits of a thriving agricultural sector for the nations overall economy.

title: Supporters Call for Investigation Into Death of Chinese Activists Father
description: Chinese human rights lawyers have raised questions about the death of an activists father who fell from a government building while under detention in late January. The authorities have told family members that Xue Fushun committed suicide by jumping from the fourth story of a procurators office building in the city of Qufu in the northeastern province of Shandong.

title: Report Finds Growth in Agriculture Economy
description: The Council of Economic Advisers released a report on Friday highlighting the growth in the agriculture economy as President Obama is set to sign the farm bill.

title: The End of Snow?
description: OVER the next two weeks, hundreds of millions of people will watch Americans like Ted Ligety and Mikaela Shiffrin ski for gold on the downhill alpine course. Television crews will pan across epic vistas of the rugged Caucasus Mountains, draped with brilliant white ski slopes. What viewers might not see is the 16 million cubic feet of snow that was stored under insulated blankets last year to make sure those slopes remained white, or the hundreds of snow-making guns that have been running around the clock to keep them that way.

title: Without Scotland, Premier Says, Britain Would Be Less Great
description: LONDON  Marking the formal beginning of the British governments campaign to preserve the United Kingdom, Prime Minister David Cameron made an emotional plea to Scots to vote in September to remain in the union, saying on Friday that without Scotland, Britain would be deeply diminished.

title: A New Vision for Prince Igor at the Met
description: It is common in contemporary opera for a director to update the setting of a story and impose some interpretive concept on a piece. Most directors do not go so far, however, as to reorder scenes, tweak the plot, excise whole ensembles and interpolate musical numbers from a different score.

title: A Hotelier Corrects His Testimony on the Impact of the Affordable Care Act
description: Last week, The Agenda reported on a House committee hearing that examined a provision in the Affordable Care Act that requires companies with at least 50 employees to offer health insurance to any employee who works at least 30 hours a week. It appeared that a bill to raise that threshold to 40 hours, the Save American Workers Act, could be on a fast track to debate by the full House, and on Tuesday the legislation took a big step forward when it passed out of the Ways and Means Committee.

title: Highlights: The Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony
description: The New York Times covered the Winter Olympics opening ceremony from inside of Fisht Olympic Stadium in Sochi  live as it happened, not on tape delay.

title: A Virtual Airline, a Real Crash
description: Europe is full of small upstart airlines, andManx2, which served eight destinations in Britain and Ireland, certainly seemed to be one of them.Its planes were emblazoned with its name. The flight attendants said, Welcome aboard this Manx2 flight. Even the headrests and pilots ties advertised the airline.

title: A Guilty Verdict for Former SAC Trader
description: FORMER SAC TRADER CONVICTED OF INSIDER TRADING | A federal jury in Manhattan found Mathew Martoma guilty on Thursday of insider trading , culminating a case that prosecutors had never thought would go to trial in the first place. The case may be the last criminal case to emerge from a decade-long investigation of Steven A. Cohen and his SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Martoma, who is married and has three young children, is expected to face a prison sentence of seven to 10 years.

title: British Regulator Hires Former Goldman and UBS Executive
description: LONDON  The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said Friday that it had hired a former managing director at Goldman Sachs and UBS as an adviser in its division that supervises wholesale banking and investment management.

title: U.S. Issues Penalties Over Violations of Iran Sanctions
description: The Obama administration penalized nearly three dozen companies and individuals in eight countries on Thursday, accusing them of evading Iranian sanctions. It was the administrations most extensive enforcement action to target Iran since a temporary international agreement on that countrys disputed nuclear program was completed in November and put into effect last month.

title: Talking to Children About Consent
description: HAVING THAT TALK with your child  the one about sex, babies and putting some distance between those two things  can be daunting. Now, a string of high-profile sexual assaults on campuses has put the topic of consent on the table. Debra Herbenick, a sexual health educator at the Kinsey Institute at Indiana University, discusses the kinds of conversations parents should have with their children about sexual misconduct.

title: Making Consent Cool
description: IN 1993, when Antioch College introduced its ask first policy  mandating that students solicit permission for every intimate advance, including kissing  the policy was widely derided.

title: Stepping Up to Stop Sexual Assault
description: BYSTANDER INTERVENTION is so easy to grasp, even by the most inexperienced college freshman, that the program may well be the best hope for reducing sexual assaults on campuses. Mostly it is common sense: If a drunk young man at a party is pawing a drunk young woman, then someone nearby (the bystander) needs to step in (intervene) and get one of them out of there. Of course, that can be tricky at times.

title: Syria Says It Will Stay in Peace Talks as Homs Evacuation Begins
description: ISTANBUL  The Syrian government announced on Friday that it would participate in next round of Geneva peace talks aimed at ending the countrys civil war, as civilians trapped in a rebel-controlled part of Homs, one of the conflicts urban epicenters, began trickling out under a deal negotiated by the United Nations.

title: If Cineastes Could Pick the Oscar Winners
description: In the run-up to the Oscars, prognosticators trip over themselves to divine the Academys choices  rather than, as cineastes might hope, showcase the most deserving performers and filmmakers of the year.

title: Homeless and Too Tired for Food
description: Dear Diary:

title: Payroll Data Shows a Lag in Wages, Not Just Hiring
description: For the more than 10 million Americans who are out of work, finding a job is hard. For the 145 million or so who are employed, getting a raise is even harder.

title: Biden Shows Interest in Another Presidential Run
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said in an interview broadcast on Friday that he would run for president if no one else can fight for the domestic, economic and foreign policy issues he cares about and said he would decide by mid-2015.

title: Apollo Profit Fell 36% in Fourth Quarter
description: Apollo Global Management was a big seller of its holdings last year, but that wasnt enough to lift the private equity giants profit for the final three months of 2013.

title: Desperate for Clean Air, Delhi Residents Experiment with Solutions
description: NEW DELHI  For some worried expatriates and Indians, the battle to keep pollution out of their homes and their lungs started well before renewed media coverage in the past weeks unofficially crowned New Delhi as the worlds most polluted city.

title: Teenagers in The Times | January 2014
description: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson Teaching With Teenagers in The Times.

title: Objects | Temptation Arises
description: Introducing clutches and sandals so elegantly modern and quietly sexy that they seem downright practical.

title: Now, the Sentencing for Martoma
description: The impressive streak of 79 insider trading convictions won by the United States attorneys office in Manhattan now includes Mathew Martoma, who dealt directly with the hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen. But the verdict is unlikely to bring prosecutors any closer to what is apparently their aim: to bring criminal charges against Mr. Cohen.

title: Second-Order Journalism
description: Dave Weigel looks at the disastrous initial media handling of the CBO report  CBOghazi, hah!  and addresses one of my pet peeves: reporting that skips right past the actual policy issues to speculation about how they will play politically. I think of this as second-order reporting, and its almost always a bad thing.

title: Car Seats Save Lives but Are Still Underused
description: More than 9,000 children under 12 died in motor vehicle accidents from 2002 to 2011, in many cases because they were not properly restrained in child seats or seatbelts.

title: Mixed Messages in the Employment Data
description: It is generally wise to take individual jobs reports with a grain of salt. The data, as the economists say, are noisy  imperfect estimates subject to revision. But the jobs report for January might need an extra few shakes of the shaker.

title: For the Sake of Argument: Writing Persuasively to Craft Short, Evidence-Based Editorials
description: Overview | How can writing change peoples worldview? How can it influence public opinion? How can it lead to meaningful action?

title: Sticky Situations
description: David Glasner has a thoughtful post about wage stickiness, a favorite topic of mine. And he is partially right in suggesting that there has been a bit of a role reversal regarding the role of sticky wages in recessions: Keynes asserted that wage flexibility would not help, but Keyness self-proclaimed heirs ended up putting downward nominal wage rigidity at the core of their analysis. By the way, this didnt start with the New Keynesians; way back in the 1940s Franco Modigliani had already taught us to think that everything depended on M/w, the ratio of the money supply to the wage rate.

title: Rewards Program Tries Bitcoin
description: PointsHound, a website that rewards travel reservations with frequent-flier miles and hotel points, is using the virtual currency Bitcoinin its payout system.

title: Leaked Recordings Lay Bare E.U. and U.S. Divisions in Goals for Ukraine
description: BERLIN  Really Pretty Stupid was the headline chosen by the august Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung on Friday to describe an editorial on the latest eruption between the United States and Europe, this time over who should take the lead in trying to calm the crisis in Ukraine, and how to do it.

title: The North Carolina Story
description: Ive just praised Dave Weigel for his take on CBOghazi, the media debacle over health reform and employment. Let me now give an example of how even someone as good and skeptical as Weigel can be (slightly) taken in by right-wing spin. In another fine piece on the health-employment link, Weigel mentions states with falling unemployment, including North Carolina  and appropriately is skeptical about claims for NCs success. But not skeptical enough! In his footnote he writes:

title: 36 Hours in Yangon, Myanmar
description: Its Myanmars moment, and the countrys major city, Yangon (formerly Rangoon), is hoping to become Southeast Asias next boomtown. Diplomatic missions, business delegations and tourists have filled Yangons hotels since the countrys military government began transferring power to civilian leaders in 2011. The spotlight continues this year as Myanmar, also known as Burma, takes on the chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. For now, though, as the road map for laws and reforms is being drawn, the city remains in a kind of urban time warp, still awaiting a much-needed capital infusion to fuel what it hopes to be its renaissance. Golden pagodas, colonial-era buildings, traditional shop houses and moldering jazz-age mansions form a low-rise fabric unique to Asia, the whole stitched together by tree-lined avenues swarming with buses and cars. While ethnic and religious tensions simmer along Myanmars borderlands, including in remote Rakhine State, where there have been recent outbreaks of religious violence, Yangon is far from these areas. Still, time will tell whether the city will reclaim its former status as a cosmopolitan capital.

title: Deep Inside Baz Luhrmanns Creative Chaos
description: Baz Luhrmann likes to say that his life is a circus run like an army, and to step into his boudoir is to begin to understand what he means. After noon on a Friday, the 51-year-old auteur is sitting up in bed, his lower half under the covers, silver hair and black T-shirt rumpled from sleep. His wife and frequent creative collaborator, Catherine Martin, known to everyone as C. M., lies curled beside him atop a flax-colored linen duvet. Four assistants occupy chairs around them, all holding laptops. Each of the young people who gather under Luhrmanns big top has a fantastical back story, at least in his telling. One went to Eton and speaks perfect Chinese; another has a grandpappy who created a little firm called the C.I.A. All have areas of concentration  communications, for example, or moving Baz through time and geography  and all have been trained in the Bazmark way, which means that they carry portable tape recorders to capture his directives and strive always to anticipate his needs. Judging by their alert posture at this moment, something momentous is about to happen. The impish ringmaster is having a vision.

title: Winter Superpower Gets Its Turn as Olympic Host
description: SOCHI, Russia  That the organizers here spent a record $50 billion  capital improvements and alleged baksheesh included  and did not quite get a finished product is difficult to fathom.

title: All of the Pleasure. None of the Guilt.
description: A friend of mine made a resolution once: No more guilty pleasures. I assumed at first that he meant he would no longer indulge in, you know, the usual cultural indulgences: those movies, books, TV shows, albums, et cetera, that are unabashedly enjoyable (like Miley Cyruss Wrecking Ball) but that also confer a patina of guilt to the self-conscious cultural consumer even as hes enjoying them (like Miley Cyruss Wrecking Ball).

title: Cecily Strong Is Being Serious
description: Youre younger than Saturday Night Live itself. Were you a comedy nerd as a kid? Totally. I grew up on S.N.L., doing all the sketches on the playground. A friend and I would play these Chicago newscasters that were actually just impressions of the Bears Superfans. Two 11-year-old girls with fake mustaches  we were joke stealers already.

title: Pilgrims Progress
description: In A.D. 441, St. Patrick, Irelands patron saint, climbed the third-highest mountain in County Mayo and, according to legend, spent 40 days and nights fasting and praying at its summit. Modern pilgrims inspired by his example still flock to what is now known as Croagh Patrick. The Rev. Charlie McDonnell, a local priest, says that 50 years ago, most climbed the mountain on Reek Sunday, the last Sunday in July. But now, people visit the site every day. Some climb for spiritual reasons, barefoot and clutching rosary beads (Mass is celebrated frequently at the peak), others for their physical health. Even before St. Patricks famous ascent, the mountain was a pagan holy spot. Patrick claimed the mountain for Christianity, Father McDonnell says. But we welcome everybody to the mountain. It is a sacred place. Julie Bosman

title: Reply All: The 1.26.14 Issue
description: PLANET HILLARY

title: Sochi vs. Sacha Baron Cohen
description: Steven Yeun shares his characters Michigan background; assessing veteran rom-com duos.

title: The Business-Dinner Spy
description: We recently had a teamwork dinner with the head of our division. One of my employees placed his iPhone on the table and recorded the discussion without anyone else knowing. The next day he transcribed what everybody said as a way to hold management accountable for things wed talked about working on. Was he obliged to get our permission in advance for the recording? NAME WITHHELD, SALT LAKE CITY

title: Who Made That Planetarium?
description: Late in 1924 there appeared something new under the sun, an apparatus that shows every object in the sky that is visible to the unaided eye, and in a most realistic manner, wrote the scientist and educator Clyde Fisher a decade after the opening of the worlds first projection planetarium in Munich. It matters not whether the audience be made up of children or adults, professional people or laymen, the emotional experience is always the same. When the light is gradually diminished bringing on the darkness of night in the dome, and the stars are turned on, the audience gasps audibly in surprise at the breathtaking beauty of it.

title: U.S. Factory Report May Not Be as Dire as It Looks
description: WORLD markets, already nervous over possibly fragile emerging-market economies, tumbled early this week after a survey of manufacturers in the United States showed a surprising drop in the proportion of companies saying their business was improving. On Monday, the Standard & Poors 500-stock index fell more than 2 percent, suffering its worst day since last June.

title: As Knicks Fall Back, Amare Stoudemire Finds New Vigor
description: The loss was only seconds old when Amare Stoudemire, a towel draped around his neck, approached Giannis Antetokounmpo for a congratulatory handshake and some unsolicited advice.

title: In the Eye of the Beholder
description: This week we turn our gaze to love stories, a subject that brought together one of the odder but more distinguished pairings in the Book Reviews history. In 1988, in his review of Gabriel Garca Mrquezs Love in the Time of Cholera, Thomas Pynchon judged that Garca Mrquez wrote with impassioned control, out of a maniacal serenity. Calling the book shining and heartbreaking, he added it to the ranks of novels that can return our worn souls to us.

title: The Body Politic
description: It was six yards square and extravagantly swathed in purple and gold, from its velvet headboard and valance to its voluminous damask curtains. The Virgin Queen took it with her when she moved from one royal residence to the next, chased by winter drafts and the inevitable buildup of noisome effluvia emanating from the rudimentary sanitation of her privy. As Anna Whitelocks The Queens Bed proves, there is still a new and fascinating vantage from which to consider Elizabeth I. While most historians of the period dissect the body politic, Whitelock doesnt waste time in the halls of Parliament. Instead, she hastens straight to the boudoir of the queen who chose celibacy as a means of wielding power.

title: Mash Notes
description: The Modern Love column in this newspaper is a guilty pleasure for the many and a source of bitter rejection for the few: Over the past nine years only some 350 columns have been published out of 50,000 submissions. Imagine the countless Sunday brunches over which the previous nights bad date / marital sex problem / unanswered Match.com posting was miserably rehashed, only to be transformed into the most glittering of silver linings: By God, this would make a fantastic Modern Love piece! And then  the flurry of typing, the excited phone calls to friends, the pinching-myself byline  the other shoe drops.

title: GoPro to Go Public
description: Updated, 11:32 a.m. | GoPro, the video camera maker favored by extreme athletes and everyday adventurers, said on Friday that it planned to go public.

title: Bridled Vows
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: Scenes From a Marriage
description: Visitors to the White House who seek out the well-known portraits of Jacqueline Kennedy and Nancy Reagan  eerie, El Greco-like elongations executed by Aaron Shikler  are sometimes surprised to have their attention arrested by Henriette Wyeth Hurds rendering of the far-less-chronicled Pat Nixon. The picture was created several years after the Nixons abrupt departure from Washington, and only for the sake of the subjects daughters. The painted Mrs. Nixon seems stricken, ready to brim with tears. If the portrait could speak, it would most likely say what she herself did after the helicopter lifted off from the South Lawn on Aug. 9, 1974: Its so sad. Its so sad.

title: Passages
description: Is the sexual self an essential thing  immutable? Or can the complex matrix of desire change? These questions are fundamental to ideas of behavior and morality. I find myself with a foot in both worlds, willing to argue either point of view. The theme of Sex After . . .   how womens sexual lives shift over time  is a significant one, rich with possibility.

title: Love in the Time of Neuroscience
description: In The Devils Dictionary, Ambrose Bierce defined love as a temporary insanity curable by marriage. Enter Sue Johnson, a clinical psychologist and couples therapist who says that relationships are a basic human need and that a stable, loving relationship is the absolute cornerstone of human happiness and general well-being. To repair ailing partnerships, she has developed a new approach in marriage counseling called Emotionally Focused Therapy, or EFT, which she introduces in her new book, Love Sense.

title: French Kisses
description: Ill be gone soon, Gore Vidal told me, not long before he died. Then Edmund White can be king. Queen bee, perhaps?

title: Le Mariage
description: Elizabeth Patterson Bonaparte was an American celebrity, Carol Berkin declares. Indeed, she was perhaps the first of her era. The extraordinary story told in this slim volume goes some way toward justifying that extravagant claim.

title: Oops, There Goes Another Fall on the Ice
description: Conditions in New York City are prime for the antics of Buster Keaton and other masters of the pratfall. But as any number of orthopedists and emergency room doctors in the city can attest, most people do not share Keatons grace.

title: A High-Water Mark for Women, in Retrospect
description: During the worst part of the credit crisis, women had more paid jobs than men for the first time, the Labor Department now says.

title: Blythe Masters of JPMorgan Is Said to Decline Advisory Post
description: Updated, 7:13 p.m. |

title: A Conversation on Tobacco and Coal Exports and Moral Responsibility
description: I sent my recent post on exports of life-shortening tobacco and dirty fossil fuels to a variety of climate and energy scientists and analysts and the result was an interesting email conversation that is excerpted below.

title: Correspondence Course
description: How rewarding to perch on the shoulder of a character Barbara Pym might have conjured  a late bloomer who possesses brickish stoicism and brews tea on an Aga. So when the British author Deborah McKinlay takes us to the depths of the English countryside, in a house that was an advertisement for the English countryside, we recognize that a Lively voice   la Penelope, that is  will be reporting with wry detachment and affection.

title: You Must Remember This
description: Michele Zackheims books, like treasure hunts, send their narrators scuttling after hidden gems. In Violettes Embrace, an artist travels to Paris to unearth secrets about the writer Violette Leduc. In Einsteins Daughter, Zackheim herself goes abroad to investigate the mysterious fate of the scientists illegitimate daughter. And in her new novel, Last Train to Paris, an elderly New York journalist named Rose digs through an old trunk of papers that holds reminders of her past life and lost love.

title: Still in Thrall
description: Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again. You can probably hear the late Joan Fontaines clipped Anglo-American voice declaiming that line in Alfred Hitchcocks Rebecca, the voice of a young woman recalling the strange, wearying and totally dysfunctional secrets that once lay in wait for her.

title: Inside the List
description: LAffaire: Some thriller writers pick a topic and stick with it, more or less: John Grisham writes about lawyers, Brad Thor writes about government agents. Then theres Robert Harris. Hes hit the list with novels about imperial Rome and World War II, a contemporary political drama, an alternative history in which the Nazis have won the war and a financial thriller about a computer that goes rogue, Kubrick style.

title: Recovering From Surgery, Wendy Whelan Postpones National Dance Tour
description: Wendy Whelan, the longtime New York City Ballet star who has been making a critically acclaimed foray into modern dance, announced Friday that she was postponing a national tour this spring because she needs more time to heal from hip surgery.

title: Editors Choice
description: ALL JOY AND NO FUN: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood,  by Jennifer Senior. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Examining, with bracing honesty and authentic wisdom, what it means to be a parent, Senior presents both interviews and research.

title: Paperback Row
description: MISSING OUT: In Praise of the Unlived Life,  by Adam Phillips. (Picador, $15.) One of Britains foremost psychoanalysts explores the alternative lives we could be leading but for some reason are not. Drawing on his own clinical experience and the works of Shakespeare and Freud, D. W. Winnicott and William James, Phillips encourages us to live, as gratifyingly as possible, the life we have, rather than be haunted by the myth of our potential.

title: Sidestepping the Risk of a Privacy Breach
description: This week, we reached the inevitable point in the controversy over the credit and debit card breaches where grim-faced retail executives from Target and Neiman Marcus, industry experts and consumer advocates turned up in Washington. They raised their hands and delivered well-rehearsed statements to our elected representatives.

title: Video Reviews of The Lego Movie, The Last of the Unjust and Vic + Flo Saw a Bear
description: In this weeks video, Times movie critics share their thoughts on the Canadian drama Vic + Flo Saw a Bear, the animated Lego Movie and The Last of the Unjust, a documentary. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Romance
description: THE LUCKIEST LADY IN LONDON

title: Image of the Day: February 7
Postal Service Reports a Decline in Losses
description: WASHINGTON  Aggressive cost cutting and increased revenue from its packing and shipping business helped the Postal Service stem its losses in the first quarter of its fiscal year, which ended Dec. 31.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A Sentimental Education
description: This week, Daniel Jones talks about Love Illuminated; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Parul Sehgal, an editor at the Book Review, discusses the Love Stories issue; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: A Sentimental Education
description: This week, Daniel Jones and Parul Sehgal.

title: New York Fashion Week: Duckie Brown Mens Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

title: 64th Berlinale Kicks Off With Premiere of The Grand Budapest Hotel
description: BERLIN  The 64th annual Berlin Film Festival opened here on Thursday evening with the gala world premiere of Wes Andersons The Grand Budapest Hotel, a tender, urbane caper movie set in an imaginary world of interwar Eastern Europe starring Ralph Fiennes and inspired by the Austrian writer Stefan Zweig (1881-1942) and the films of Ernst Lubitsch (1892-1947).

title: Visvim: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: In Our Pages: February 8
description: 1889: Great Fire on the Thames

title: Entering the Era of Private and Semi-Anonymous Apps
description: Todays Web-enabled gadgets should come with a digital Miranda warning. Anything you say or do online, from a status update to a selfie, can and will be used as evidence against you on the Internet.

title: I Was a Tonya Harding Look-Alike
description: In 1994, I looked exactly like Tonya Harding. Would you have agreed? Doesnt matter. Because the ultimate decision rested with an expert team of celebrity-look-alike judges assembled by Geraldo Rivera. Lets put it this way: Twenty years ago, one Tonya did bring home the gold; it is cheap plastic and somewhere in my childrens dress-up box. And it symbolizes the era of my life that, if Olympic judges scored for weirdness, would nail a perfect 6.0.

title: Hamptons House: Make Mine New
description: In the Hamptons, where million-dollar vacation homes are snapped up like flea-market finds and $10 million spec homes are in such high demand that their developers could moonlight as fortunetellers were they not so busy building more, buying new has become not only the fashion but the first choice. Buying vintage tends to spawn repair and renovation headaches; choosing turnkey promises convenience and five-star amenities.

title: New York Fashion Week: Todd Snyder Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Times Minute | Another Weak Jobs Report
description: Also on the Minute, Putin's Olympic hopes and a look at the origins of modern planetariums.

title: Semifinals  Semifinal, Run 1
description: Snowboarding, Mens Slopestyle, Semifinals Semifinal, Run 1

title: Times Minute | Another Weak Jobs Report
description: In the Video

title: Boycotting Israel and the First Amendment
description: Common sense, and maybe a renewed appreciation for first principles, seems to be stymying dangerous legislation that would undermine free speech in a misguided attempt to appear pro-Israel.

title: Highlights From the Chicago Auto Show
description: With the Detroit auto show already growing smaller in the rearview mirror, the next big show of the 2014 season is underway in Chicago. The noticeably confident Detroit automakers may have received most of the attention at the show in their hometown, but this week, on the other side of Lake Michigan, the spotlight was on foreign manufacturers.

title: Employments Decline, for Men of All Ages
description: Men who graduated from high school between 1982 and 1986 were victims of bad timing. They entered their prime working years during a period of slow growth. By January 1994, only 83.3 percent of men 25 to 29 years old were working.

title: River of Fundament | Matthew Barney
description: Matthew Barney's latest film was inspired by the mythology of ancient Egypt as imagined by Norman Mailer's historical novel, Ancient Evenings.

title: One-Wok Meals
description: Last week my impulse purchases at the farmers market included a lush bunch of red chard and a beautiful bunch of golden beets with the greens attached. Normally I use these vegetables in Mediterranean dishes  you have seen many of them in Recipes for Health  but I was craving stir-fries.

title: Helmets: Because Their Thick Skulls Arent Thick Enough
description: If you make your kids wear helmets when theyre sledding and ice skating, not only will they better resemble all the gnarliest lugers and hockey players in the coming Olympics, but also, more important, youll be helping to change the culture. And, most importantly, my children will therefore be less mad at me about having to wear them.

title: Keeping Swindlers Out of Your Bank and Brokerage Accounts
description: Data breaches at Target and Neiman Marcus were certainly scary. Personal information from tens of millions of people fell into the hands of cybercriminals.

title: Today in Small Business: The Harlem Renaissance
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small business owners today.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Think Back: Olympics Meet Politics
description: From Berlin in 1936 to Sochi in 2014, the Olympic Games are not just an athletic stage but a political one, The Timess Sam Tanenhaus explains.

title: The Effect Crowdfunding Has on Venerable Nonprofits Raises Concern
description: THE ads ran for years. The global charity Save the Children  asked for a monthly donation, and in return, a few times a year the donors received a photo and handwritten note or drawing from children in impoverished places like Haiti.

title: Movie Review: Vic + Flow Saw a Bear
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Vic + Flo Saw a Bear.

title: Sexy Beast
description: Summoning Norman Mailer, Egyptian mythology, an oboe-playing porn star and one dead cow, Matthew Barney creates River of Fundament, a baroque and no less baffling art-world spectacle.

title: Paul Taylor Dance Company to Begin Lincoln Center Run With $6 Tickets
description: It is the greatest bargain in modern dance: the Paul Taylor Dance Company is celebrating its 60th anniversary with a special performance at Lincoln Center at which all tickets will be only $6  less than the cost of a childs or seniors movie ticket in Manhattan.

title: Book Review Podcast: A Sentimental Education
description: As part of the Love Stories issue of The New York Times Book Review, writers in a variety of genres share the books that taught them about love  and a few that led them memorably astray. Hilary Mantel writes:

title: Too Much Winter, and Not Nearly Enough Propane
description: EASTABOGA, Ala.  In the midst of one of the great natural gas drilling booms in the nations history, millions of Americans are struggling with a problem that is chilling their bones.

title: Senate Seat of Baucus Is Filled in Montana
description: DENVER  The Democratic governor of Montana appointed the lieutenant governor on Friday to fill the Senate seat left open by the departure of Senator Max Baucus, a move Democrats hope will improve their chances of retaining the seat in what is expected to be a fiercely fought election this November.

title: Deception Foils Attempt to Hijack Turkish Jet to Sochi
description: ISTANBUL  A passenger aboard a commercial airline flight from Ukraine to Turkey tried to hijack it to Sochi, Russia, on Friday after the Winter Olympics started. He threatened to set off a bomb with a cellphone if his demands were not met, but the crew fooled him  and the other passengers  into thinking the plane had landed in Sochi when it was actually in Istanbul, passengers and the authorities said.

title: Emma Oak Transforms Backstage at Creatures of the Wind
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Emma Oak before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Boehmer and hair by Odile Gilbert.

title: David Cameron's Plea for Scotland
description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain made a plea to the people of Scotland to choose to remain part of the United Kingdom.

title: Movie Review: 'The Last of the Unjust'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Last of the Unjust.

title: Gathering to Mourn Philip Seymour Hoffman
description: Celebrities and locals gathered at the funeral in Manhattan.

title: Peter Som: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Young Thug as Vocal Stylist
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Young Thug and the hip-hop tradition of irreducible voices.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1
description: Berluti opened Madison Avenue flagship; Target collaborated with Peter Pilotto; Vince toasted IPO; Todd Snyder hosted after party.

title: Tightrope for a Bad Boy Made Good
description: What happens to the outlaw after he is embraced by the mainstream? Its a recurring question in American culture, from Huckleberry Finn to Kurt Cobain. Eric Churchs fourth studio album, The Outsiders, is the follow-up to Chief, from 2011, which took him to No. 1 on the country charts and won the Country Music Associations album of the year award. The new record, which EMI Nashville will release on Tuesday, represents a reaffirmation of his independent spirit in the face of an increasingly homogenized Nashville sound.

title: Popcast: Young Thug as Vocal Stylist
description: Black Portland, the new mixtape by the Atlanta rapper Young Thug and Bloody Jay, is full of southern cadence, trap beats, rhymes about cars and women, and mid-oughts Lil Wayne spaciness. But its more full of something else: Young Thugs voice, which goes high and low, very young and very old. It sings and growls and yelps and moans and wobbles and articulates words or leaves them half-formed.

title: Caught Between Cutie and the Boxer
description: In an Oscar field dominated by films that address weighty questions of international politics, Zachary Heinzerlings Cutie and the Boxer is a bit of an outlier in the feature documentary category. Much of the film was shot in a messy apartment-cum-studio in Brooklyn, and it focuses not on upheaval or genocide but on Ushio and Noriko Shinohara, a pair of Japanese artists who are also husband and wife.

title: Movie Review: 'The Lego Movie'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Lego Movie.

title: A White-Shoe Firm Unbuttons
description: Eliot and John W. Cross were the perfect patrician designers, brothers born into a family with plenty of money and social standing. They put their Ivy League and Beaux-Arts connections into play in 1907, and quickly gained a practice in discreet townhouses, clubs, country houses and jewel-like banks, all shown in the luxuriously illustrated monograph on their work, New York Transformed  The Architecture of Cross & Cross, by Peter Pennoyer and Anne Walker (Monacelli Press, 2014).

title: On Amazon, Pilots  and Potential  on View
Why Europes Job Picture Looks Different
description: A theme often heard on this side of the Atlantic about the worlds Great Recession and its faltering recovery is how American policy has been more effective than Europes, which has been hitched to an expensive currency and shackled to a set of austere economic policies that served nobody but Germany.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Stomach Bug Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 70-year-old woman with 10 days of gastrointestinal distress that was just like an episode she had had four years earlier.

title: Wheelies: The Carrot and Stick Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Meeting That Couples Often Find Daunting
description: With Valentines Day just ahead, now may be a good time to consider some of the more difficult things we do for love. Meeting the future in-laws is among the most daunting of those tasks, and since many of these meetings occur in the winter months, often a chilly one, too.

title: Asphalt Orchestra Aims to Record Its Interpretation of a Pixies Album
description: The Alarm Will Sound orchestrations of the Beatles Revolution 9 and works by Aphex Twin and the Shaggs have long been among the most surprising scores to turn up in a classical music ensembles programming. But they may soon have company:Asphalt Orchestra, a quirkily eclectic 12-piece wind, brass and percussion ensemble that performs as a post-modernist marching band, is hoping to record its own version of Surfer Rosa, the Pixies influential debut album, released in 1988.

title: Coke and Einhorn Take Opposite Sides of Green Mountain Bet
description: Betraying its renowned jingle, Coca-Cola is singing in perfect disharmony with David Einhorn. To feel good paying nearly $1.3 billion for a minority stake in Green Mountain Coffee, the beverage giant must have answered some nagging questions posed by the hedge fund manager a few years ago. Investors seem to figure that Coke did its due diligence. Procter & Gamble and Hewlett-Packard have shown just how much that can matter.

title: Coming to Trafalgar Square: An Unusual Horse and a Giant Thumb
description: LONDON A skeletal, riderless horse by Hans Haacke and a giant thumb by David Shrigley are the winning proposals for 2015 and 2016 for the Fourth Plinth commissions in Trafalgar Square. The annual award, funded by the mayor of London and chosen by a commissioning group, allows artists to propose a sculpture for the vacant plinth, built in 1841 to carry an equestrian statue of King William IV but left vacant until 1998, when this project began.

title: Portrait of an Army Family
description: Some give some, and some give more. Some have no clue to what theyre really fighting for, Kristin Pruett sang at her home piano in Boise, Idaho, recently. She tape-recorded her holiday tribute to the family of veterans shed married into, and put it online with photos.

title: Once Youre On the No-Fly List, Its Hard to Get Off
description: Rahinah Ibrahims nine-year journey to clear her name with the U.S. government may be nearing an end.

title: Big Moments on Campus
description: Jack Begg, supervisor of news research at The Times, traces the nations history through its centers of learning.

title: Final Decisions
description: CONGRATULATIONS. Youve been accepted to more than one college. Now comes the hard part: deciding which to go to. Make a mistake and you could be repeating the whole application process again next year  to transfer out.

title: The Man With Nerves Like Sewer Pipes
description: OVER THE LAST 33 YEARS, E. Gordon Gee has presided over an astounding five universities  Ohio State, Vanderbilt, Brown, West Virginia (twice) and Colorado. But Dr. Gee, 70, has a habit of getting in trouble  comparing his job at Ohio State to running the Polish Army, calling the fathers at Notre Dame holy on Sunday, but holy hell the rest of the week. He has come under fire for his high compensation (he made nearly $2 million at Ohio State) and his high-flying expense account. (His response: If hes not worth it, fire him.) Still, Dr. Gee, named Time magazines top college president in 2009, is a constant presence on state and national policy commissions. He is finishing a book on the politics of higher education, and after stepping down at Ohio State on July 1, hes back in office  last month, he became interim president of West Virginia University, where he served as president in the 1980s.

title: Love, Actually
description: I RECENTLY OVERHEARD two students talking in a dining hall at the university where I teach. Yeah, I might get married, too, one confided. But not until Im at least 30 and have a career. Then she grinned. Until then? Im going to party it up.

title: Adderall and Academics
description: PRO BASEBALL PLAYERS and cyclists have nothing on college students come exam time, when the demand for performance-enhancing stimulants, from Red Bull to Adderall, skyrockets.

title: Sponsored by the Letter B
description: GRADE INFLATION has returned as a hot point at the nations top colleges (or maybe they just have darn good students).

title: Investing (More) in Daughters
description: TO THE LIST of expenses that make raising a girl pricey  clothes, makeup, smartphones  add one more item: education.

title: Doctoral Cachet
description: WHAT DO Ph.D.s have in common with car mechanics? We knew you were wondering. So we asked.

title: Dancing With the Book Carts
description: WHAT SPORT demands the precision of synchronized swimming and the book smarts of a librarian?

title: A Look at Koreas Culture From the Bathhouse
description: My friend Arcadia Kim has three children and a Harvard business degree, but when she tried to negotiate on our behalf with the lady in charge of exfoliation at the Dragonhill Spa in Seoul, she did not stand a chance.

title: Feasts for the Eyes, and the Palate, in Xian, China
description: On the Muslim Street in the Chinese city of Xian stands a bronze tableau in honor of street food. There, on a crowded lane packed with stalls selling Islamic-Chinese cuisine  lamb dumplings, mutton soup, pancakes and mung bean noodles  tourists can pose with statues of a soup seller and his customers. Its a photo opportunity that brings together Xians two most famous tourist drawing cards: life-size human replicas and superb dumplings.

title: Puerto Ricos Second Cut to Junk Debt
description: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | Moodys Investors Service downgraded Puerto Ricos general-obligation debt to junk status on Friday, intensifying a cash squeeze on the island and prompting some residents to blame hard-nosed creditors for their mounting troubles.

title: Lacking a House, a Senator Is Renewing His Ties in Kansas
description: DODGE CITY, Kan.  It is hard to find anyone who has seen Senator Pat Roberts here at the redbrick house on a golf course that his voter registration lists as his home. Across town at the Inn Pancake House on Wyatt Earp Boulevard, breakfast regulars say the Republican senator is a virtual stranger.

title: Tanya Taylor: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Weekend Reading: Sochi Olympics vs. Wall St.
description: If you prefer CNBC to NBC Sports, check out DealBooks alternative programming guide to the Winter Olympics.

title: Prepaid Debit Cards May Augment Bank Accounts
description: PREPAID debit cards are often thought of as an alternative for people who cant qualify for traditional checking accounts, since you typically dont have to undergo a credit check to get a prepaid card.

title: A Policy Response to Job Market Weakness
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: U.S. Charging Coal Companies Too Little for Land, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Some coal mining companies are paying lower-than-market rates to lease land from the federal government, while also enjoying low royalty rates, increasing their profits at the expense of taxpayers, investigators for the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee have found.

title: Big Ticket | A Grand-Scale Restoration Yields $51 Million
description: An imposing Upper East Side mansion that underwent a flamboyant renovation after being gutted by a fire in 2006 and was rumored to be available for $52 million in 2009 has sold, quietly, for $51 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Monochromatic, but Many Folds
description: The British artist David Musgrave had his first solo show at Luhring Augustine in 2009, and now that gallery is mounting another, with new work that includes drawing, sculpture and digital animation. This time around, Mr. Musgrave has worked in a larger format for some of his drawings, whose subjects resemble discarded sheets of board or paper that have been torn, creased, faded, stained or scored with a blade, the gallery said.

title: Excerpt: Prince Igor at the Met
description: Ildar Abdrazakov sings the title role in this scene from a recent dress rehearsal.

title: Relationship Repair for Valentines Day
description: For those whose Facebook relationship status reads its complicated, the Wolcott Hotel in New York may have an appropriate Valentines Day getaway package. Taking a practical approach to the holiday, the Wolcott is offering an On the Mend deal this month aimed at couples who want some big city amusements while sorting out a troubled relationship.

title: A Steady Hand in Uncertain Times
description: The great Bernard Haitink, who turns 85 on March 4 and is celebrating his 60th season as a conductor, is a fixer, with a gift for swooping in at troubled times for major ensembles. He steadied the Chicago Symphony Orchestra before Riccardo Mutis arrival as music director in 2010; he was also the principal guest conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra from 1995 to 2004, then played a key role in recent years as it faced a future without James Levine.

title: Farewell Jet to a Long Career
description: What City Ballet fan doesnt love Jenifer Ringer, and who wont be sad to learn that she is retiring from the company? Gentle, lyrical, romantic and, above all, able to infuse her dancing with a rare warmth and humanity, Ms. Ringer, with her oval face, dark hair and eyes, looks like every little girls idea of a ballerina. She was picked out as particularly promising soon after joining City Ballet at 17, in 1990, and promoted to soloist by 1995. But at 23, she left City Ballet, plagued by depression, injury and weight issues.

title: Singing Jazz for Lovers
description: Valentines Day has become a red-letter day for elite jazz singers in Manhattan. This Friday, options include Dianne Reeves, who has a new release suited to the occasion, at the Rose Theater; Gregory Porter, who just won the Grammy for best jazz vocal album, at Town Hall; and Tierney Sutton, a polished songbook interpreter, at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola.

title: Tax on Austrian 'Champagne' Has High Society Fuming
description: VIENNA  Just when it seemed that Austria was surviving Europes financial crisis unscathed, austerity has hit  in the form of a tax on sekt, the countrys version of Champagne.

title: Immigrants Tale, Without Clichs
description: One of last years quiet surprises was Mother of George, a film by Andrew Dosunmu about a Nigerian couple in Brooklyn who, as the story begins, are being wed in a ceremony full of echoes from their homeland. But the opening joy gives way to stresses as the couple (played by Danai Gurira of The Walking Dead and Isaach De Bankol) have trouble conceiving the child they are expected to produce.

title: Sex and ... O.K., Just Sex
description: As soon as a buxom blonde squeaks down a stripper pole, its pretty evident that there will be nothing remotely ladylike about this ladies night out. In Jenny McCarthys Dirty Sexy Funny, on Friday night at 11 on Epix, Ms. McCarthy  her gift for raunch on full display  tackles the plight of the modern woman with backup from the comedians Justine Marino, Tammy Pescatelli, Lynne Koplitz, Paula Bel and Tiffany Haddish.

title: 70s Photorealism: Revived and Still Relevant
description: Photorealism was one of the major movements in American art of the early 1970s. A natural offshoot of Pop Art and heir to one-man movements like Edward Hopper, photorealist paintings depicted the postwar American landscape, highlighting Vietnam War pessimism and the plight of working-class people in the recession-era 70s. The gritty realism of these painters mirrored the films of directors like Barbara Kopple, John Cassavetes or Robert Altman, or the minimalist fiction of Raymond Carver and Jayne Anne Phillips.

title: Crossing Class Lines for Love, Again
description: Attention, Downton Abbey fans: Lady Sybil Crawley is alive and well and living in New York. Or at least someone uncannily like her. In the film Winters Tale, opening Friday, Jessica Brown Findlay, her ravishing tresses and plummy vowels intact, portrays Beverly Penn, the high-spirited consumptive daughter of an early-20th-century mogul.
