title: Fashion Week Morning Report: Past, Present and Future
description: New York Fashion Week is approaching its midpoint. A full weekend of shows behind us, several big guns are still to come, among them the one-namers (Marc, Donna, Calvin, Ralph, Tommy) and the spectacle-mongers (Thom Browne springs to mind). What does Monday have in store?

title: New York Today: Another Slippery Commute
description: Updated 10:14 a.m.

title: Forgotten by the Games
description: A lavish construction project for the Olympics has made life harder for residents of Akhshtyr, a small, barren village in the mountains above Sochi.

title: Microsoft Loses a Number to Try to Gain a Future
description: On Monday, Microsoft is officially releasing and pricing a new version of its Excel spreadsheet program. Excel is a cornerstone of Microsofts software sales to businesses, so it matters a great deal to the companys future.

title: A Farewell to the Maruti 800, Humble King of Indias Roads
description: NEW DELHI  After more than 30 years of production, Maruti Suzuki, one of the biggest car manufacturers in India, said late last week that it would no longer make its iconic model, the Maruti 800. After selling almost 3 million worldwide, declining sales and stricter emissions standards have convinced the companys owners, nostalgic themselves, to let go.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Lori Gottlieb on the Sex Lives in Peer Marriages
description: Lori Gottlieb wrote this weeks cover story about what a peer marriage can do to a couples sex life. A contributing editor for The Atlantic and a psychotherapist in Los Angeles, Gottlieb is the author of Marry Him: The Case for Settling for Mr. Good Enough. She wrote about the business of psychotherapy in the Nov. 25, 2012, issue of the magazine.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 10, 2014
description: Update: Feb. 11, 2014

title: Introducing an Alternative to Performance Reviews
description: In my last two posts I have talked about the problems with performance reviews and suggested an alternative I call performance coaching.This post describes how you can put into effect and use the program.

title: Barclays Says It Will Miss Pretax Profit Forecasts for 2013
description: LONDON  The British lender Barclays said Monday that it would report 2013 adjusted profit before tax of 5.2 billion pounds, or about $8.5 billion, below analysts expectations.

title: Daily Report: Tech I.P.O.s Cloaked in Secrecy Becoming the New Normal
description: Choosing to file confidentially for an initial public offering is fast becoming the norm for young technology companies, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced report. On Friday, GoPro, the video camera maker favored by extreme athletes and everyday adventurers, became the latest to file such a secret I.P.O.

title: Alibaba Seeks Control of AutoNavi, a Chinese Mapping Company
description: Alibaba, the Chinese Internet giant, offered on Monday to buy the 72 percent of AutoNavi Holdings that it did not already own, in an all-cash bid that values AutoNavi, a mapping software company, at about $1.58 billion.

title: As Second Round of Syrian Talks Begins, U.N.s Mediator Steps Cautiously
description: GENEVA  Representatives of Syrias government and opposition on Monday opened a second round in the fragile peace process as humanitarian agencies continued to evacuate civilians from the besieged Old City of Homs under a cease-fire that was negotiated in the first round.

title: Nepal Picks New Premier, Putting End to Stalemate
description: NEW DELHI  After years of deadlock, Nepals Parliament on Monday elected Sushil Koirala, a longtime democracy activist who was involved in a famous 1973 Nepali plane hijacking, as the countrys new prime minister.

title: A Chinese Officials Job Plea to JPMorgans Chief
description: CHINESE OFFICIAL MADE JOB PLEA TO JPMORGANS CHIEF | In yet another potential setback for JPMorgan Chase, a confidential email shows a top Chinese insurance regulator directly asked Jamie Dimon, JPMorgans chairman and chief executive, for a favor to hire a young job applicant, a family friend of the regulator. Interviews, and the previously unreported email, show that Mr. Dimon met the applicant at a meeting in 2012, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The meeting came as JPMorgan was seeking lucrative work from Chinese insurance companies.

title: Plenty of Spills and Fewer Thrills on Bumpy Ride
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The condition of the Olympic halfpipe was widely criticized Monday, the last day of training before the high-profile competitions Tuesday and Wednesday. Some even suggested that the contests be postponed for a day or two, until conditions improved.

title: Brits Off Broadway to Feature Mini-Festival of Ayckbourn Plays
description: The tireless playwright Alan Ayckbourn has had several works presented in New York during the annual Brits Off Broadway festival, most recently Neighbourhood Watch in 2011. This year he will be back with several more: a new work with a war-on-terror theme, a revival from 1992 and a double bill of short farces.

title: Autopsy of Arunachal Pradesh Student Confirms Assault Caused Death, Uncle Says
description: NEW DELHI  The final autopsy report of Nido Tania, the 18-year-old from Arunachal Pradesh who died after an altercation with shopkeepers in south Delhi, confirmed that injuries suffered during an assault caused his death, Mr. Tanias uncle said Monday.

title: Swiss Vote Seen as Challenge to European Integration
description: LONDON  European officials warned Switzerland on Monday that it would pay a steep price for its vote to limit the flow of workers across its borders, but many also acknowledged that far-right parties were beginning to reshape politics and policy across the Continent.

And amid the deluge of supportive texts she receives, there are often pictures of Gov. Chris Christie sitting on the George Washington Bridge. She chuckles but doesnt reply.

title: Why Do You Care How Much Other People Work?
description: The brouhaha over the CBO report  I dont want to call it a debate, because that would suggest that people on both sides are making sense, or even listening  continues. But there is a massive lack of clarity. This is, no doubt, in large part because incoherence serves the interests of some parties. But I think theres also some genuine intellectual confusion that might, for a few players at least, actually be reduced by careful analysis.

His meditation on how that can happen involves a useful take on what happened to the profession in the decades that preceded the 2008 crisis, and a very interesting take on the current state of affairs (DSGE is dynamic stochastic general equilibrium  basically, the particular form of modeling that is more or less the only thing one can publish in journals these days):

title: Californias Physician Directories Removed Because of Errors
description: LOS ANGELES  The California health care exchange has taken down its physician directories, amid continuing complaints from doctors and patients alike that the lists of doctors and hospitals included in each insurance plan were error-riddled and unreliable.

title: A Big Pot of Simmered Pintos
description: This pot of beans was Step 1 for the other Recipes for Health this week. If I know that Im going to use these beans for a Mexican dinner I season them with cilantro and, if I can find it, epazote. If I want Italian or Provenal flavors I make a bouquet garni with bay leaf, thyme, parsley, maybe sage, and most definitely a Parmesan rind. This week, since I am using my beans as a starting off point for other dishes, I season them only with onion, garlic, bay leaf and salt. The dishes that will follow throughout the week will introduce more flavors.

title: Suicide Bomb Trainer in Iraq Accidentally Blows Up His Class
description: BAGHDAD  If there were such a thing, it would probably be rule No. 1 in the teaching manual for instructors of aspiring suicide bombers: Dont give lessons with live explosives.

title: Pasta e Fagiole
description: This is a classic Italian bean and pasta soup. If you have already made a pot of beans using a pound of beans, and want to use it for this soup, just use half the beans but all of the broth as directed in Step 1.

title: Vegetarian Chili With Winter Vegetables
description: I have made several versions of vegetarian chili; in some the beans take center stage, others are just as focused on vegetables. This thick, satisfying chili is equally focused on both. I particularly like the way the sweet flavor and comforting, creamy texture of the winter squash plays against the spicy flavors in the chili.

title: Bruschetta With Smashed Beans, Sage and Kale
description: This is comfort food  a generous spoonful of thick beans seasoned with fresh sage on top of a substantial slice of garlic toast. To make a meal of it I top the beans with seasoned greens and a little Parmesan.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Ballet Rehearsal Buns at Diane von Furstenberg
description: With show venues spread far and wide this season, theres a certain athleticism involved in leaping around the city. On Diane von Furstenbergs runway in Tribeca yesterday, the relative endurance of the day fit in well with the designers theme. The collection was inspired by Russian ballerinas, the hairstylist Orlando Pita said backstage. So naturally hair was whisked up into a bun. But Pita noted an important distinction: Diane wanted the models to look like they were in rehearsal, rather than in performance. Conveying that sense of unfinished, dashed-off elegance came down to misting BioSilk Dry Clean Shampoo on fine hair for body or rubbing BioSilk Silk Gel Medium Hold on thicker strands for control, and piling everything up into a high ponytail. The length of the tail was then twisted and wrapped around the base, and slightly spread out with the fingers to create a wide, round shape secured with a cupful of bobby pins. But just when the bun began to look too stage-ready, Pita pulled this last step: The trick is to put finishing spray on your brush and comb back the hair vertically, he said, demonstrating the technique around the crown. This makes it look like someone has taken her fingers and combed her hair up. It lent a subtle rawness, which did seem quite en pointe.

title: Tostadas With Beans, Cabbage and Avocado
description: Beans are traditionally fried in lard, but I use a small amount of grapeseed or sunflower oil instead, and rely on the broth from the beans for flavor. This is a great buffet dish for a Mexican dinner party. I prefer to toast the tortillas using the microwave method, but you can also deep-fry them.

title: Finally, a Way to Make a Selfie Statue
description: In this, the Age of the Selfie, it figurines: You can now get yourself made into a tiny statue, using a three-dimensional printer and a common household gaming device.

title: Two Founding Members of Pussy Riot Respond to Criticism
description: Hours before they departed the United States, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina, founding members of Pussy Riot, responded sharply to a letter that other members of that Russian activist collective had posted online  and sent to journalists. The letter disparaged some of the behavior of Ms. Alyokhina and Ms. Tolokonnikova, who are now advocating for prison reform, as unbecoming of the radical feminist group, which became known across the world after its members were arrested for performing a protest song in a Moscow cathedral in 2012.

title: Kagan Says Her Path to Supreme Court Was Made Smoother by Ginsburgs

title: An Economist Answers Questions About Online Dating
description: Paul Oyer, an economist at Stanfords Graduate School of Business, is the author of Everything I Ever Needed to Know About Economics I Learned From Online Dating, published last month by Harvard Business Review Press. Through his own experience, Mr. Oyer became intrigued by the economics at work in the online dating marketplace. His book explores how knowledge of economic concepts can help narrow Cupids aim. Mr. Oyers personal strategy turned out to be a winning one: he met his current partner online.

title: A Conversation With: Leena Gita Reghunath, Editorial Manager at The Caravan Magazine
description: NEW DELHI  From 2006 to 2008, a series of bomb attacks hit civilian targets around India, the deadliest of which was on Feb. 18, 2007, when 68 people died on a train traveling to Pakistan. Swami Aseemanand, a former activist with the influential Hindu nationalist group Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or R.S.S., has been charged with plotting five of these attacks, which collectively killed 119 people.

title: Judges Weigh Evidence in Case Against Congolese Rebel

The Art Directors Guild also announced its winners for production design in movies, and they were: Gravity, for fantasy film; The Great Gatsby, for period film; and Her, which despite being set in the near future, won in the contemporary category. (The future is closer than we think.) All three are nominees at the Oscars as well, so its bound to be a close race.

title: Flooding and Landslides in Burundi Kill Dozens
description: At least 60 people were killed and dozens injured in Burundi after heavy rains caused flooding and landslides in the small, landlocked African country, a government spokesman, Willy Nyamitwe, said on Monday. Harimenshi Hermes, a spokesman for the police, said that thousands more had been displaced because of damage to their homes. Many houses in the suburbs were destroyed by the rain, said Beatrice Nibogora, an information officer for the United Nations in Burundi. Many of the victims are children, and the houses collapsed on them. The government said it would organize burials for the dead and treatment for the injured. Torrential rains began on Sunday night and continued into Monday morning, causing power failures and cutting off roadways around Burundis capital, Bujumbura. The city sits on the shore of Lake Tanganyika near the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Hot Chocolate With a Kick

title: Tiny Plants Loss May Have Doomed Mammoths
description: A 50,000 year analysis of Arctic vegetation history reveals that a change in diet may have led to the demise of the woolly mammoth, the woolly rhinoceros and other large animals, according to a study in the journal Nature. About 10,000 years ago in the Arctic steppe, grasslands began to replace forbs, a flowery plant cover. Animals may have relied on forbs as a source of protein.

title: Drug Shortages Continue to Vex Doctors

title: Weekend Gun Report: February 7-9, 2014
description: In light of the start of the Florida trial ofMichael Dunn, who is accused of shooting an unarmed 17-year-old to death at a gas station, ThinkProgress reported last week that at least 26 children and teens have died in Stand Your Ground cases across the state. Dunn reportedly plans to invoke Stand Your Ground, which states that a person who feels he is in danger may be justified in the use of deadly force, and some are asking whether laws such as these, which have proliferated in at least 20 states, empower people to shoot first and ask questions later.

description: The life of a heroin addict is not the same as it was 20 years ago, and the biggest reason is what some doctors call heroin lite: prescription opiates. These medications are more available than ever, and reliably whet an appetite that, once formed, never entirely fades.

title: Seeking the Keys to Longevity in What Makes Olga Run?
description: No one would mistake Olga Kotelko for one of the Olympians competing in Sochi, Russia, but at age 94, she holds more world records than most: 26, to be exact, including age-group bests in the high jump, the hammer throw and the 200-meter run. Not bad for someone who took up track and field at age 77.

title: Laurie Anderson Performances Planned for Spoleto Festival USA Are Canceled
description: Laurie Andersons Language of the Future, a work she performed at the River to River Festival in New York in June, was to have had three performances at the Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., this spring. But Nigel Redden, the festivals general director, announced on Monday that the performances, which had been scheduled for June 4, 5 and 7, had been canceled due to unforeseen circumstances. The festival would not elaborate, and a call to Ms. Andersons studio in New York was not returned. Mr. Redden, in a statement, said that the festival would not offer a substitution for Ms. Andersons work.

title: Spain Seeks to Curb Law Allowing Judges to Pursue Cases Globally
description: MADRID  For nearly two decades, Spanish judges have been the provocateurs of international criminal law, pursuing human rights cases against Argentine military officers, Israeli defense officials or American soldiers in Iraq. Most famously, a Spanish judge opened the case that led to the arrest of the former dictator of Chile, Augusto Pinochet.

title: That Six-Serving Bar of Marijuana Chocolate? My Son Ate It
description: Just a week after leaving Boston for a summer internship in California, our 21-year-old son landed in an emergency room and was put on a suicide watch. Im going to ruin the suspense and tell you what happened: His roommate told him to help himself to the food in the fridge, and he ate a marijuana-laced chocolate bar meant to be consumed as six servings.

title: A Patients-Eye-View of Nurses
description: Last June, the month he turned 90, Dr. Arnold S. Relman, the eminent former medical educator and editor, fell down a flight of stairs at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He cracked his skull and broke three vertebrae in his neck and more bones in his face.

title: Mind Over Matter, Battling a Bandersnatch
description: Like Clark Kent and Peter Parker, the 11-year-old Bruce Wong is a sweet guy who inhabits the dweebier end of the social spectrum. His big sister, Violet, implores him to stop being such a nerd.

title: Strollers Are the Latest Airport Amenity
description: Families flying with very young children can now take advantage of a growing trend: A number of airports are providing loaner strollers to ease the stress of traveling.

title: Next Reading for Big City Book Club
description: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and remarkably he did not demand that we read his own, newly published memoir, Little Failure, about his upbringing as a Russian migr in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected Bright Lights, Big City, Jay McInerneys touchstone novel of the hedonistic 80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m. To join the club and receive regular email updates, visit: nytimes.com/marketing/bigcitybookclub.

title: Do Some Drugs Become Dangerous After Expiration?
description: Q. Are there drugs that turn into toxic substances as they age?

title: Bundle of Joy, Confusion and Doubt
description: CHICAGO  The sobering themes of Luna Gale, the new play by Rebecca Gilman having its premiere at the Goodman Theater here, have a sad, strange currency. Ms. Gilmans drama, about a fight over the fate of a baby in jeopardy, concerns itself with two pathologies that have been much in the news: sexual abuse within a family and the corrosive effects of drug addiction. (I probably dont need to explain why those problems have been screaming from the headlines lately.)

title: A Question for Yellen
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: On Ski Jumping: Jessica Jerome
description: Its a great feeling because you can just float, says Jessica Jerome of the United States, who will be competing in the first womens ski jumping competition at an Olympics.

title: Avoiding a Pillow Fight With New Zealand Customs
description: UNTIL two years ago, I had never been to New York City, and Im 52 years old. So I guess its fair to say that I never thought Id be a frequent business traveler. Im the C.E.O. and inventor of My Pillow, and when I started the company I was really hoping that I would begin to travel for business. That would mean we were doing well.

description: New York

description: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of The Tipping Point and Outliers. (1)

title: Furious Bosnians Shut Down Central Sarajevo
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  Bosnias most widespread antigovernment protests in almost two decades shut down the center of Sarajevo and affected five other cities on Monday, as demonstrators vented their anger at politicians whom they view as self-serving and corrupt.

description: LONDON  As flood warnings move down the River Thames, and closer to the capital, the political tide is rising, too.

description: There are too many camels in the Bible, out of time and out of place.

description: The pop singer Carly Rae Jepsen (Call Me Maybe) and the television actress Fran Drescher (The Nanny) scored only modestly at the Broadway box office last week for their first performances in Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella, according to data released Monday by the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers.

description: My young friend had just finished the last months of his medical training. He had faced down many multiple-choice tests and triumphed over them all.

description: The pileup at the ratings finish line Sunday night resembled the cross-country skiing events in Sochi, as a host of popular shows duked it out for ratings supremacy. Skaters and skiers were potent; but so, too, were zombies.

title: Debating Evolution and Dealing With Climate Change
description: Last Tuesdays debate between Bill Nye the Science Guy and Ken Ham, president of the Creation Museum, whipped up a Sharknado-like frenzy online. Five hundred thousand viewers and seemingly all of Twitter followed the event live, which pitted evolution against creationism. Some called it a modern-day Scopes monkey trial, others a waste of time. The video has more than a million views on YouTube.

title: Movie Star Points Way to Sanity, Maybe
description: The Good Luck of Right Now is only the second nominally adult novel by Matthew Quick, whose attention-getting first was The Silver Linings Playbook. Mr. Quicks other books have been categorized as young adult fiction, though, in his hands, the two genres are not that different. Among the adult aspects of this new book are the degrees of its characters dysfunctionality, the jokey fact that one of them can barely complete a word without inserting an obscenity in the middle of it, and that it takes the epistolary form of a series of letters to Dear Mr. Richard Gere.

title: New York Fashion Week: Diane Von Furstenberg Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Movie Date Night Can Double as Therapy
description: One of the great divides in male-female relationships is the chick flick  movies like Terms of Endearment and The Notebook that often leave women in tears and men bored. But now, a fascinating new study shows that sappy relationship movies made in Hollywood can actually help strengthen relationships in the real world.

title: The Science of Ice Skating
description: Science is aiming to help ice skaters meet the sports physical challenges without sacrificing their health.

title: Job Growth Slumps. Employment Surges.
description: More people have gone to work during the past three months than at any time in decades.

title: Riders Cautious of Halfpipe Conditions
description: Snowboarders Kelly Clark, Hannah Teeter and Peetu Piiroinen gave their impressions of the halfpipe conditions in Sochi.

title: Further Delays for Employers in Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced on Monday that it would postpone enforcement of a federal requirement for medium-size employers to provide health insurance to employees and allow larger employers more flexibility in how they provide coverage.

title: Aging the Stars, a Man-Made Extinction, Being Cold While Globally Warming
description: Stellar archaeologists go on the hunt for the oldest stars in our galactic neighborhood; Elizabeth Kolbert talks about her new book, The Sixth Extinction; the weather outside your window  no matter how cold and icy  does not change the reality of a warming climate.

title: Sorting iPad Apps by Name
description: Q. Is there any way that user-installed apps on an iPad can be sorted alphabetically?

title: Suit Will Seek State Money Promised to Schools in 2007
description: New York State has shortchanged the entire public school system by billions of dollars, ignoring an agreement that followed a landmark court ruling in 2006, according to a lawsuit to be filed Tuesday by an education advocacy group.

title: Labor Battle at Kellogg Plant in Memphis Drags On
description: MEMPHIS  Its 11 a.m. and a bone-chilling 18 degrees as Joey Watts, wearing a picket sign that says Locked Out, trudges across an overpass overlooking the cereal factory, which has a big neon sign spelling out Kelloggs in its red signature logo.

title: Poor Nations Seek New Hepatitis C Drug
description: Now that wealthy nations have a simple pill regimen that can cure hepatitis C, calls are mounting from representatives of poor nations for the same drugs.

title: Tommy Hilfigers Colorful Clogs
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: The Grandpas of Hockey
description: SOCHI, Russia  Old Men Winter will descend on the Sochi Games this week, leaving the mens ice hockey tournament with a dusting of gray. The 12-team competition features five players in their 40s, including Petr Nedved of the Czech Republic and Sandis Ozolinsh of Latvia, who bumped into each other in the athletes village the other day at that soda fountain of youth, McDonalds.

title: Fourth Place: Just Missing a Medal
description: It just wasnt my night, said Shaun White as he joined a group of athletes who barely missed a medal by finishing fourth.

title: Sometimes, Even the Young Know When to Slow Down
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has a hit ensemble on its hands with the remarkable Danish String Quartet. This season the group began a three-year residency with the societys CMS Two program for outstanding younger performers. Having played to acclaim last fall at the Kaplan Penthouse, the ensemble gave its first performance at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. Demand was so great for this sold-out concert that an encore event of the same program was added for Monday night at the Rose Studio.

title: Alarm and Anger Over Britains Lack of Preparation Flood Social Media and the Web
description: Video and other images shared online highlighted just how dire the flooding has become in England. Rivers are bursting their banks, railroad tracks are swamped and thousands of people have been stranded by flooding, particularly in southern England, over the past month.

title: Fond Farewell to a Ballerina Who Mixes Warmth and Technique
description: A double bill of Jerome Robbinss Dances at a Gathering and George Balanchines Union Jack might seem an odd choice of program for a ballerinas farewell performance. Rather than star vehicles, these ballets are ensemble works: 10 fairly equal dancers share the first; an army of more than 70 floods the second. And yet at the David H. Koch Theater on Sunday afternoon, the program succeeded in displaying some of the finest qualities of Jenifer Ringer in her final show with New York City Ballet.

description: Thomas M. Rutledge seems like a man on a mission. The U.S. cable operator he runs, Charter Communications, is preparing a slate of replacement directors for larger rival Time Warner Cable, the target of his $60 billion hostile bid. He may also have roped in Comcast to alleviate financial worries about the plan to take over his former employer.

description: The bookseller Barnes & Noble laid off employees in its Nook device unit on Monday, the latest sign of the companys difficulties in executing its digital strategy.

description: The cacophony rises as the voices of the three women overlap: the first singing, the second talking into a microphone, the third speaking directly to the spectators while she moves among them. Eventually, the singer has had enough.

description: A new National Hot Rod Association drag racing season opened pretty much the same way the 2013 season ended: John Force, the serial Funny Car champion, again outran Father Time.

description: After harsh criticism for the slow response to the ice and snow that paralyzed the Atlanta metropolitan area for days last month, Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia issued a state of emergency on Monday, a day before a winter storm was expected to hit.

description: The Giant Magellan Telescope, when built, will have a resolving power 10 times greater than the Hubble Space Telescope.

description: SUN KIL MOON

title: Blending Moorish Tradition With a Do-It-Yourself Credo
description: What you heard foremost in 75 Dollar Bills Saturday night show at Troost in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was Che Chens guitar: a cut-rate Japanese model sketching looped figures inside old Arabic modes, pushing jagged sound through a small amplifier.

title: A Mutable Feast
description: BOSTON  Ernest Hemingway was a hoarder. His own prose style may have been spare and economical, but he was unable to part with the words, printed or written, of just about anyone else. According to his fourth wife, Mary, he was incapable of throwing away anything but magazine wrappers and three-year old newspapers. A trove of some 2,500 documents collected and preserved at Finca Viga, Hemingways farm outside Havana, and now digitized and newly available at the Hemingway Collection in the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum here, includes diaries, letters, lists, telegrams, insurance policies, bank statements, passports, tickets to bullfights and the Longchamp racecourse in Paris, a brochure from a swimming pool filter company, a page of his son Patricks homework and seemingly every Christmas card Hemingway ever received.

title: The Archaeology of the Stars
description: Four years ago, Anna Frebel, a young astronomer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, found an ancient star in a neighboring galaxy whose chemical composition proved nearly identical to some unusual stars on the outskirts of our own galaxy, which are older than the Milky Way itself.

title: Lawsuit Challenges Governments $13 Billion Deal With JPMorgan
description: With a record $13 billion sticker price, the settlement deal between JPMorgan Chase and the government captured the attention of Wall Street and Washington late last year.

title: The iPhone and Its Ilk as Museum Exhibits for Future Generations
description: Putting an iPhone on display in an art museum is an easy, if still unusual, decision to make. Preserving an iPhone in such a way that museum-goers of the 22nd century will be able to appreciate its form and its function, as well as its role in cultural history, becomes somewhat trickier.

title: Attack of the Flappy Bird Clones
description: Legend has it that Pablo Picasso once said, Good artists borrow, great artists steal.

title: On Top of Croagh Patrick
description: This past weekends Look featured photographs taken last year by Kenneth O Halloran of some of the thousands of people who climbed Croagh Patrick in Ireland on Reek Sunday, the last Sunday in July. Tradition holds that St. Patrick spent 40 days andnights at the top of the mountain in A.D. 441, and it remains one of many pilgrimage sites still visited annually throughout Ireland.

description: Last week, HTC signaled that it might develop a wearable device and release it this year.

description: LIKE many financial activities, wealth management has become increasingly automated, although it is inherently more complicated than a bot that searches the Internet or simply stores portfolios.

title: John Maynard Keyness Own Portfolio Not Too Dismal
description: WHEN it comes to John Maynard Keynes and his economic theories, the economist has long been a lightning rod as tall as the Empire State Building. Yet examining his investment success is another matter, and far less prickly.

title: Even Among the Richest of the Rich, Fortunes Diverge
description: WASHINGTON  YES, we know the economic fortunes of the 99 percent and 1 percent have diverged over the last three or four decades. But the fortunes of the 1 percent and the 0.1 percent, or the 0.01 percent, or the 0.001 percent, have diverged even more. Economists have taken to calling it fractal inequality. It is not just that the rich have pulled away from the average American. It is that the richer you are, the more you have pulled away.

title: Tinkering Too Much With an E.T.F. Might Not Pay
description: LOW cost, simplicity and ease of trading have attracted investors to exchange-traded funds. Many investment managers are being drawn to E.T.F.s, too, and are building portfolios substantially or even entirely from them instead of using elaborate combinations of mutual funds and individual securities.

title: Whats in Store for 2014? Heres What to Watch
description: FOR investors, this year is off to a mixed start. Stock market indexes maintained their gains from last year before dropping. Treasury bonds continued their losing streak in the weeks after the Federal Reserve announced that it was reducing its bond-buying program  until the stock sell-off caused people to buy bonds. Interest in emerging markets has dropped.

description: AS the financial crisis consumed Wall Street in 2008, James Corl left his job as chief investment officer of the money manager Cohen & Steers, where he was a well-compensated real estate stock investor, and struck out on his own.

description: SARA ROWBOTHAM CORNELL named her Boston-based digital media company in honor of her parents longtime vacation house, Blue Blinds, which she inherited. A watercolor of the 1870s-era New Hampshire farmhouse hangs in her own home.

description: THE municipal bond market has been judged lately more by its failures than its successes, and the judgment has been harsh.

title: Family Foundations Let Affluent Leave a Legacy
description: STEPHANIE Cordes, a graduate of the University of California, Santa Barbara, has a present from her father, Ron, that she treasures. Its a handmade pink scrapbook, titled, 5 Life Lessons From Dad.

title: Prosecutor Questions Ex-Judges Memory
description: It is rare enough for a judge to come forward years after a trial and testify that he convicted someone because of his personal bias against white people.

title: Russia and China Skip Security Council Meeting on Humanitarian Aid to Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  The morning after an aid convoy came under fire when it tried to reach a besieged Syrian city, a meeting here on a draft resolution that would force all parties in the bloody conflict to allow access for humanitarian organizations fell apart when representatives from Russia and China failed to show up, United Nations Security Council diplomats said.

title: Journalist Struck by Flare During Rio Protest Is Declared Brain-Dead
description: Health officials in Rio de Janeiro announced on Monday that Santiago Andrade, a Brazilian cameraman who had been wounded by an explosive device while covering clashes between protesters and the police, was clinically brain-dead, the newspaper Folha de S.Paulo reported.

title: House Republicans Seek to Trade Debt Deal for Repeal on Military Pensions
description: WASHINGTON  The House is likely to vote Wednesday on a plan to extend the governments borrowing authority into 2015 in exchange for reversing a cut to the pensions of working-age military veterans that Congress approved just two months ago to try to trim the budget deficit.

title: Did Anyone Look at That Ad?
description: For years, the advertising industry has been struggling to address a nagging problem: Who is actually looking at those ads on a webpage or embedded in a video?

title: False Alarm Over Suspicious Substance at Wydens Senate Office
description: The United States Capitol Police investigated a suspicious substance found in the office of Senator Ron Wyden on Monday evening, and less than an hour later announced in an email, All tests are negative, and the area is now open.

title: Tortoises in Oscar Race
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  As Oscar nominees met for their annual luncheon here on Monday, no film stood taller than Fox Searchlights 12 Years a Slave, with nine nominations and the No. 1 spot in a running poll of awards handicappers, who have pegged it as the years likely best picture.

title: Reactions to Woody Allen and Dylan Farrow
Backstage Beauty Report | Sporty 3-D Hair at 3.1 Phillip Lim
description: Hairstyles captured in fashion photography look amazing  but those coifs need only hold up for a few shutter clicks. Backstage at 3.1 Phillip Lim this afternoon, hair pro Paul Hanlon whipped models manes into tousled, sporty-slick styles reminiscent of Bruce Webers O Rio de Janeiro book from the 80s, but with a durability that would allow the dos to withstand the rigors of the runway (and several hours worth of afterparties). When you see those pictures, somebodys gone in and done the hair, and its a moment. This is 3-D, the models are walking and moving, and you dont want anything to fall out, Hanlon explained. Perhaps that was his full-disclosure reason for applying what he admitted was an excessive amount of styling fixers: He first brushed through volumizing mousse for body, then massaged on a root booster to help form a pompadourish flip. Next he saturated strands, section by section, in Moroccanoil Treatment Light to create a wet, separated texture all over, and combed Moroccanoil Intense Curl Cream through on the front before pulling the hair tight on the sides and high on the top. To finish, Hanlon doused it all with hair spray. The maximalist approach went over well, creating a modern vibe that model Maggie Jablonski described as punk, but artistic and beachy. The only drawback: how to wash out all that product? Just follow Jablonskis directive: Stand and watch it melt away in the shower.

title: Court Rejects Apple Appeal in E-Book Case
description: The court-appointed monitor in the Apple e-book price-fixing case can get back to work.

title: Anti-Defamation Leagues Director to Retire After Leading Group for 27 Years
description: Abraham H. Foxman, a Holocaust survivor whose 50-year tenure battling anti-Semitism made him one of the visible and influential leaders of the American Jewish community, announced on Monday that he will retire next year as national director of the Anti-Defamation League.

title: Use Force to Save Starving Syrians
description: DENVER  THE Syrian people are starving. According to the United Nations, about 800,000 civilians are currently under siege. In areas around the cities of Homs, Aleppo and Deir Ezzor and in parts of the capital, Damascus, no food, medical supplies or humanitarian aid can get in, and people cant get out. Many have already died under these starvation sieges and hundreds of thousands teeter on the brink, subsisting on grass and weeds. In Damascus, a cleric has ruled that under these conditions, Muslims are permitted to eat normally forbidden animals like cats, dogs and donkeys.

title: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Days 3, 4 and 5
description: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

title: K.K.R. to Close 2 Mutual Funds
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is closing two mutual funds less than two years after it started them, a setback for the private equity giant as it looks to attract smaller investors.

title: Security Staff Getting Its Old Name Back
description: WASHINGTON  For the clubby, overworked group of White House national security officials who toil in the basement of the West Wing, one small perk had always been the title: You were a member of the N.S.C. staff, working for the presidents National Security Council, which deals with foreign policy hot spots around the globe.

title: Shockers Pursue Perfection One Victory at a Time
description: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa  There isnt much to the visiting coaches office at the University of Northern Iowas McLeod Center, a big room with concrete-block walls and a couple of block-style couches and chairs. Wichita State Coach Gregg Marshall, his gold print tie undone and dark gray suit coat discarded, claimed one couch Saturday night while the rest of his staff fussed with suitcases, hustling for a charter flight home.

title: John J. Cali, a Leader in New Jersey Real Estate, Dies at 95
description: John J. Cali, the co-founder of a family business that became one of the nations largest real estate investment trusts, died on Feb. 1 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 95.

title: In Arkansas, Private Option Medicaid Plan Could Be Derailed
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Last year, the Republicans who control this states Legislature devised a politically palatable way to expand Medicaid under President Obamas health care law. They won permission to use federal expansion funds to buy private insurance for as many as 250,000 poor people instead of adding them to traditional Medicaid, which conservatives disparage as a broken entitlement program.

title: To Go Further, Speedskaters Had to Let Go of Their Wheels
description: SOCHI, Russia  Rollerblading is back.

title: Hyundai Sends Luxury Model to Challenge Europes Auto Stalwarts
description: TOKYO  Hows this for a marketing challenge? Selling a South Korean luxury sedan in Europe  the home turf of Audi, BMW, Mercedes and other gilded marques.

title: Winter Storms Cause Havoc for Fliers
description: Like millions of travelers this winter, Billy Bauer has felt the full effects of the nations cold weather.

title: What Is Addiction?
The American Precariat
description: When foreign visitors used to describe American culture, they generally settled on different versions of one trait: energy. Whether driven by crass motivations or spiritual ones, Americans, visitors agreed, worked more frantically, moved more and switched jobs more than just about anybody else on earth.

title: Pirate Radio Gives Voice to Syrian Opposition
description: ISTANBUL  The engineer gave the cue that the station was on the air, and the keyboard player began a mournful tune. Then the nights guest joined in, his rich baritone filling the small rooftop studio here as it was being broadcast by pirate transmitters in pockets across Syria, his war-torn home.

title: Erik Blegvad, Childrens Book Artist With a Subversive Wit, Dies at 90
description: Erik Blegvad, a prolific childrens book artist renowned for illustrations whose fine-grained propriety could barely conceal the deep subversive wit at their core, died on Jan. 14 in London. He was 90.

title: G.M. Reveals C.E.O.s Pay Details to Counter Gender-Bias Criticism
description: Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, will earn as much as $14.4 million in compensation during her first year on the job, the company said on Monday.

title: New Plan by Islamic Center Developer: Rebuild a Synagogue
description: Sharif El-Gamal, the developer whose plans for a $100 million Islamic prayer and community center near the World Trade Center collapsed amid a national controversy three years ago, is back.

title: Memories of Home as Hollande Visits United States
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama welcomed President Franois Hollande of France to the United States on Monday, deferring for a day the customary ruffles and flourishes of a state visit to squire him to the mountaintop estate of an American president long identified with France.

title: Chief of Harlem Childrens Program Will Step Aside
description: Geoffrey Canada, whose block-by-block approach to tackling poverty inspired a movement in urban education, attracting millions of dollars from Wall Street and endorsements from celebrities like Oprah Winfrey, said on Monday that he would step down as chief executive of the Harlem Childrens Zone.

title: Dogged by Data Theft
description: What is stopping us from moving to this kind of technology? asked a perplexed Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat from Minnesota. It was last Tuesday, and the Senate Judiciary Committee, on which Klobuchar sits, was holding a hearing about the recent breaches of Target and Neiman Marcus in which the data from tens of millions of credit and debit cards were stolen.

title: Gay Rights and the Justice Department
description: Since the Supreme Court struck down the provision in the Defense of Marriage Act denying federal benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples, the Justice Department has been helping federal agencies change their practices. Now the department is adjusting its own policies and programs, bringing significant advances for gay couples and American justice.

title: Waiting for Clemency From Cuomo
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y.  Years end, when winds rake the brown hills and snowflakes powder treetops, used to bring a nervous hope to Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women, a maximum-security prison here.

title: Revelations by AOL Boss Raise Fears Over Privacy
description: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, apologized last weekend for publicly revealing sensitive health care details about two employees to explain why the online media giant had decided to cut benefits. He even reinstated the benefits after a backlash.

title: Canadians Continue Domination of Moguls
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  For the Canadian ski team, success seems to come in twos.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 10, 2014
The Lost Art of the Condolence Letter
description: It was the summer of writing condolence notes. In the span of three weeks, two crushing losses: one a cherished friend, brutally taken by cancer, the other, a close friends father, dying in a freak accident. A few months later, another close friends father, after a long illness.

title: Philadelphia School Chief Faces Down Budget Cuts and Crises
description: PHILADELPHIA  William R. Hite Jr., superintendent of schools here in one of the nations poorest cities, is known as a man who prefers collaboration to confrontation, but he has spent the academic year taking no prisoners. He laid off almost 4,000 workers to close a $304 million budget gap and threatened to keep school doors locked until officials found stopgap money to ensure what he considered a basic level of security for students. He says he was just warming up.

title: AOL Chiefs Words Leads to a Study in Im Sorry
description: Was Tim Armstrongs apology authentic?

title: Thom Browne: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Army Auditors Shock and Awe
description: War profiteering is presumably as old as warfare. But the costly fraud that Army officials recently disclosed to Senate investigators seems especially shameful. It took place on the home front and corrupted a supposedly legitimate special program to increase the number of recruits during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. More than 1,200 people are under investigation, including 200 military officers, for allegedly defrauding a program that paid cash bounties for drawing enlistees into service.

title: The State of Mr. de Blasios City
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in his first State of the City address on Monday, talked about inequality, about hard times in the Gilded City, about the ladder up to the good life stretching farther and farther out of reach.

title: Paul Ash, Who Made Music Store a Chain, Dies at 84
description: Sam Ash preferred playing the violin to being an entrepreneur, and he said no when his sons, Jerome and Paul, asked him to expand beyond his single musical instrument store in Brooklyn. But five years after Sam died in 1956, the sons opened the familys first branch store, in Hempstead, N.Y. It was just the beginning.

title: The Message From Homs
description: In the last four days, at least 800 people  mostly women, children and the elderly  have been evacuated from Homs, one of Syrias most embattled cities in what was an important, yet pathetically incomplete, humanitarian pause in the fighting. Brokered by the United Nations, the pause has been extended until Wednesday, giving more civilians a chance to escape the relentless bombardment and deprivation.

title: During Olympics, Minor League Teams Gladly Borrow Vacated N.H.L. Ice
description: WASHINGTON  The next hockey player to step onto the Verizon Center ice, on Feb. 23, will not be Alex Ovechkin or John Carlson or anyone else whom fans of the home team, the Washington Capitals, are used to seeing.

title: U.S. Debates Drone Strike on American Terrorism Suspect in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is debating whether to authorize a lethal strike against an American citizen living in Pakistan who some believe is actively plotting terrorist attacks, according to current and former government officials.

title: Billy Reid: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Patrik Ervell: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Court Gives California More Time to Ease Prison Crowding
description: LOS ANGELES  In what amounts to a legal and political victory for Gov. Jerry Brown, a panel of three federal judges ruled on Monday that California can have two more years to reduce severe overcrowding in state prisons, a decision that gives the governor time to pursue a strategy of using rehabilitation programs to reduce head counts.

title: In N.F.L., Its Now Question of Ability, Not Orientation
description: A bunch of Antonio Garays former N.F.L. teammates sent him text messages Sunday night. A top college football player, Michael Sam, had announced that he was gay; had Garay seen?

title: Trimmings NYFW, Days 3 and 4
description: From liquid gold boots to shearling clutches, these are the standout accessories from Alexander Wang, Prabal Gurung, Opening Ceremony and more.

title: In West Bank Settlements, Israeli Jobs Are Double-Edged Sword
description: MISHOR ADUMIM INDUSTRIAL ZONE, West Bank  The personal conflict that thousands of Palestinians face working for Israeli companies in the occupied West Bank is particularly stark for Hassan Jalaita, who for 18 years has repaired Israeli Army jeeps at the Zarfati garage here.

title: New Storm Has South Bracing for the Worst
description: ATLANTA  This time no one is taking any chances.

title: On Rented 787, Tanaka Makes Entrance That Is So Yankees
description: A Japan Airlines Boeing 787 Dreamliner, capable of carrying nearly 200 people up to 7,850 nautical miles, touched down at Kennedy International Airport on Sunday afternoon with only six passengers, including an ace pitcher, his pop star wife, a personal manager and a toy poodle named Haru.

title: Environmental Group Proposes Options for Breached Pond at Jamaica Bay in Queens
description: On the shore of West Pond, a 45-acre freshwater body at the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, a small sign proclaims, Without freshwater this refuge would be a very different place.

title: Heroins Small-Town Toll, and a Mothers Grief
description: HUDSON, Wis.  Karen Hale averts her eyes when she drives past the Super 8 motel in this picturesque riverfront town where her 21-year-old daughter, Alysa Ivy, died of an overdose last May. She has contemplated asking the medical examiner, now a friend, to accompany her there so she could lie on the bed in Room 223 where her childs body was found.

title: Extensive Enumeration
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Oh, right. I almost forgot. Time to pre-treat all the stains on the website. Its LAUNDRY day.

title: A Line of Defense Against the Theft of Personal Data
description: The pattern with credit- and debit-card breaches tends to go something like this: A company like Target or Neiman Marcus announces that thieves may have stolen your card numbers or other information, then the company offers a year of credit-monitoring. But the chastened keeper of your personal data rarely if ever offers to pay for the most potent protection of all: A security freeze on the files that the three big credit bureaus keep on you.

title: Ban Sought on Microbeads in Beauty Items
description: Lawmakers in Albany could make New York the first state to outlaw the tiny plastic beads used in personal care products like facial scrubs and toothpastes.

title: Looking Their Best for Westminster
description: Pirata is a small, happy, 2-year-old Portuguese Podengo Pequeno, a little hound who looks like a terrier and who once hopped atop a co-owners refrigerator and tore open a sleeve of Ritz crackers.

title: Zero + Maria Cornejo: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Impatience Has Its Reward: Books Are Rolled Out Faster
description: Annihilation, the chilling first novel of a trilogy by Jeff VanderMeer that was released last week, tells the story of a scientific expedition to a mysterious place called Area X that has been cut off from the rest of the world.

title: What to Watch from Sochi: February 10
description: SKI JUMPING The womens competition is making its Olympic debut largely because of the efforts of competitors like the Americans Jessica Jerome and Lindsey Van, who were at the center of the long legal struggle to have it added to the Games program. Another American, Sarah Hendrickson, is the reigning world champion, and she usually would have been the obvious favorite. But Hendrickson, 19, is coming back from a serious knee injury and has not competed since August. Hendrickson struggled in practice and qualifying for the normal hill, and now a different teenager, 17-year-old Sara Takanashi of Japan, is the leading contender to win the gold. NBCSN, 1:30 p.m.

title: Jury Weighs Whether Former Mayor Tried to Help New Orleans or Himself
description: NEW ORLEANS  After hearing six and a half days of testimony in the federal corruption case of C. Ray Nagin, a jury will now have to determine whether Mr. Nagin was doing his honest best to help a rebuilding city or was a politician on the take.

title: Robert E. Cooke, Pediatrician Who Helped Create Head Start, Dies at 93
description: Dr. Robert E. Cooke, a pediatrician who helped Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson create major initiatives to benefit children, including Head Start, died on Feb. 2 at his home in Oak Bluffs, Mass., on Marthas Vineyard. He was 93.

title: Cuomo Says Education Boards Plan Dilutes Teacher Reviews
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo attacked state education officials on Monday for what he saw as an attempt to water down a new teacher evaluation system that was one of his earliest legislative triumphs.

title: Zac Posen: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Bosnians Share Images of Fresh Protests
description: Updated, Tuesday, 11:48 a.m. | As my colleague Alison Smale reports from Sarajevo, antigovernment protesters returned to the streets in Bosnia on Monday, driven by anger at a dysfunctional political systems inability to address an economic crisis.

title: 18 New Subpoenas Authorized in Lane Closing Inquiry
description: The New Jersey legislative committee investigating the controversial lane closings at the George Washington Bridge authorized 18 new subpoenas Monday, including one seeking records that will show who was aboard state police helicopters during the four days of the closings in September.

title: Clinton Scandal of 90s Resurfaces With Papers
description: It has been more than 16 years since the Monica Lewinsky sex scandal. The 22-year-old White House intern is now a low-profile 40-year-old. The once-embattled President Bill Clinton has assumed a postpresidential role as global philanthropist and the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is now a former senator, a former secretary of state, and a potential 2016 presidential candidate.

title: The Westminster Kennel Club Takes Over Manhattan
description: The focus of the sports world is on the Sochi Olympics these days, but a canine competition going on in Manhattan is equally intense.

title: Donna Karan: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Highlights From Our Social Feeds at NYFW, Day 5
Majority of Americans Favor Ties With Cuba, Poll Finds
description: After more than a half-century of official United States hostility toward Cuba punctuated by a comprehensive trade embargo, a majority of Americans  and an even greater majority of Floridians, home to this countrys largest Cuban-American population  now favor normalizing relations or engaging more directly with the Cuban government, according to a nonpartisan survey.

title: Seattle Gets Its Own Tech Bus Protest
description: SEATTLE  This citys technology scene, though vibrant, is significantly smaller than that of its cousin to the south, the San Francisco Bay Area. So, too, it seems, are Seattles anti-gentrification protests.

title: U.S. Reaches Out to Indian Opposition Leader It Once Rebuked
description: NEW DELHI  The United States has requested a meeting with Narendra Modi, a candidate for prime minister of India, signaling an attempt to establish a relationship after a chill that dates to 2005, when the American government imposed a visa ban to rebuke him for his role in religious riots in his home state.

title: A State Dinner With a French Flair
description: WASHINGTON  Tuesday is the first state dinner of President Obamas second term, honoring President Franois Hollande of France. Come for the intrigue and stay for Mary J. Blige and the cotton candy.

title: Hopelessly Devoted
description: Conjuring a hillside of wild sweet pea or a garden of sun-kissed roses, five classic new fragrances that are soft enough to make ones own.

title: The Perfume Diaries
description: A life lived as a series of love affairs with scents might sound flighty or hard to please  but the science of smell and memory explains this kind of promiscuity.

title: Donovan and Ray Davies to Join Songwriters Hall of Fame
description: The Songwriters Hall of Fame is expected to announce on Tuesday that its 2014 class of inductees will include Donovan, Ray Davies, Graham Gouldman, Mark James and Jim Weatherly. They will be formally inducted in a ceremony in New York on June 12.

title: An Economic Milestone
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Word of the Day | raiment
description: raiment \ra-mnt\ noun

title: A Leading Chinese Economist Warns of a Difficult Year and Dead Companies
description: Sounding warnings that could have been made 20 or even 30 years ago, one of Chinas most renowned economists said the countrys economy faces a very difficult year as it continues confronting a host of problems that have intensified over the past decade.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) BUTCH CASSIDY & THE SUNDANCE KID Long before Paul Newman and Robert Redford immortalized them, Robert Leroy Parker (better known as Butch Cassidy) and Harry Alonzo Longabaugh (the Sundance Kid) captured the countrys attention in the 1890s with their train and bank robberies. But who were they? And how did they manage to pull off spectacular holdups while eluding Pinkerton security forces, only to ride off into the sunset and die in a shootout in Bolivia? In this latest installment in The Wild West series presented by American Experience, the director John Maggio follows the men as they formed the Wild Bunch, rode the Outlaw Trail finding work as ranch hands, and escaped to South America.

title: UBS Suspends 2 Bankers in China Hiring Investigation
description: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | UBS has suspended two staff members, including its top capital markets banker in Asia, as the Swiss bank investigates its hiring of the daughter of the chairman of a Chinese chemicals company that is considering a $1 billion share sale the bank has sought a role in.

title: Corrections: February 11, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Uttar Pradesh Festival Honors Unsung Feminists from Regions Past
description: LUCKNOW, Uttar Pradesh  Lucknow, the capital of Uttar Pradesh, was buzzing with activity in recent days as Sanatkada, a well-known nonprofit in the city for women has been hosting its annual handicrafts festival, where vendors from across India come to sell their goods.

title: LOral Begins to Untangle Its Bonds With Nestl
description: PARIS  When Liliane Bettencourt sold nearly a third of the cosmetics maker LOral to Nestl 40 years ago, she did so because she feared that French Socialists would nationalize the company.

title: Test Yourself | History, Feb. 11
description: Take the Quiz

description: SOCHI, Russia  The International Olympic Committee has reinstated the Indian Olympic Association, officials said Tuesday, the first time a countrys governing body has been reinstated during a Games.

title: Barclays to Cut 12,000 Jobs in Face of Steep Losses
description: Updated, 8:26 p.m. | LONDON  Barclays said on Tuesday that it would cut as many 12,000 jobs this year, or about 8 percent of its work force, as part of a painful restructuring that began a year ago.

title: 6 Qs About the News | N.F.L. Prospect Michael Sam Proudly Says What Teammates Knew: Hes Gay
description: In N.F.L. Prospect Michael Sam Proudly Says What Teammates Knew: Hes Gay, John Branch writes about the defensive lineman who could become the first openly gay player in the N.F.L.

title: American Lugers Annoyed by Groups Gay Rights Video
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  There was a ripple of discontent over a gay rights issue at the Sochi Games on Tuesday, but it had nothing to do with Russia.

title: How Credit-Card Debt Can Help the Poor
description: Last October, Jeffrey Shavers, a hotel maintenance worker in Chicago, took out an extremely unusual $300 loan. Shavers might have liked to use the money to visit his daughter, a college student in New Orleans, or to buy his 10-year-old son a new bike. But he couldnt, because Shavers never actually saw the money. The cash went into a locked savings account that he couldnt access. Its like an abstract $300, he explained.

title: African-American History, From Family Albums to Museum Walls
description: Although the photographer Hugh Bell had been part of The Family of Man exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art, he later realized inclusivity went only so far when he called to pitch a story to an editor at Esquire.

title: Is It Unethical for a Zoo to Kill a Healthy Giraffe?
description: This weekend a Danish zoo euthanized a healthy 2-year-old giraffe. Bengt Holst, the zoos scientific director, explained, We dont do it to be cruel; we do it to ensure a healthy population. But many animal rights activists, who mounted a furious last-minute campaign to save the giraffe, angrily protested the killing.

title: R.B.S. Names New Head of British Retail Bank
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Tuesday that it had picked one of its own as the new head of its retail bank in Britain.

title: Banking While Russian
description: IT was the quintessential immigrant moment. Two weeks after my family and I had arrived in New York, a friend drove me to Costco. Half an hour later, at the cash register, I was hidden from view by the pyramid of diapers, napkins and other paper products in the shopping cart. My friend laughed and snapped a picture, promising to post it online with the caption, Masha comes to America.

title: At Norths Suggestion, Koreas Open Dialogue
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North and South Korea on Wednesday started their highest-level government dialogue since the Norths nuclear test last year prompted fears of armed conflict on the divided Korean Peninsula.

title: New York Today: Greenmarket Blues
description: Updated 11:45 a.m.

title: China and Taiwan Hold First Direct Talks Since 49
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Representatives of Taiwan and China held their first official talks on Tuesday since the end of Chinas civil war in 1949, a meeting expected to produce few concrete results but one that was a symbolic development in the easing of the two sides longtime rivalry.

title: Times Minute | Sochi's Halfpipe Problems
description: Also on the Minute, a personal conflict for Palestinians employed by Israeli companies in the occupied West Bank and a collection of Ernest Hemingway papers goes digital.

title: Fashion Week Morning Report: Globe-Trotters
description: Hers was the label that launched a thousand flats. Tory Burch leads off Tuesday of New York Fashion Week with a 9 a.m. show at Lincoln Centers Avery Fisher Hall. Ms. Burch first struck retail gold with her medallion-bearing Revas, but she has since found hit after hit (and expanded to store after store after store worldwide). For spring, she went as far afield as her collection  in this case, poolside, Franco-American style, channeling Romy Schneider in the 1969 film La Piscine. Next up? Only Ms. Burch knows. Wherever first-class travel can take her, one supposes.

title: Times Minute | Sochis Halfpipe Problems
description: In the Video

title: Shaun Whites Run Ends With a Thud Instead of a Gold
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Shaun White stood at the top of the halfpipe, the last contestant of the competition, needing a near-perfect run to capture his third consecutive gold medal at the Winter Olympics. He has built an empire on such moments.

title: Shirley Temple Black, Hollywoods Biggest Little Star, Dies at 85
description: Shirley Temple Black, who as a dimpled, precocious and determined little girl in the 1930s sang and tap-danced her way to a height of Hollywood stardom and worldwide fame that no other child has reached, died on Monday night at her home in Woodside, Calif. She was 85.

title: Hollandes United States Visit
description: President Hollande of France is invited to a state dinner at the White House.

title: Seeking a Spoiler-Free Sochi Olympics
description: The yawning time difference between Sochi, Russia, and the United States has presented a challenge for people who want to watch NBCs nightly Olympics coverage: avoiding spoilers. Even just grazing on your favorite websites and social media platforms can lead to discovering the outcome of an event before it hits TV, possibly deflating some of the joy in the drama.

title: From Paul McCartney to Thakoon
description: Liz Goldwyn, a writer and filmmaker (and recent Sunday Styles cover subject), was at the Thakoon show on Sunday, unfashionably early and sitting by herself on a bench in the middle of the room, waiting for her seatmates Taylor Schilling, of Orange Is the New Black, and Caitlin FitzGerald, of Masters of Sex, to show up.

title: There Is No Free Shipping
description: Shipping stuff is a big part of my operation, so its with some bemusement that Ive watched the efforts of Amazon to hide the costs (and challenges) of delivery from customers.

title: Private Equity Deal Makers See Increased Competition
description: BOSTON  Competition is heating up in the world of private equity.

title: Cries of Death to America as Iranians Celebrate 35th Anniversary of Revolution
description: TEHRAN  Mixing exhortations of death to America with admonishments to children about healthy teeth and gums, Iran celebrated the 35th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution on Tuesday, and the state news media said millions had exuberantly participated.

title: Bank of England to Investigate Foreign Exchange Manipulation Claims
description: LONDON  The Bank of England is taking the allegations that it indirectly condoned foreign exchange market manipulation very seriously and is working with lawyers to investigate the claims, Andrew Bailey, a central bank executive, said Tuesday.

title: Examining AOLs Apology
description: APOLOGY WATCH: AOL EDITION | Last week, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Dov Seidman started Apology Watch on DealBook to track apologies and follow up on what companies, institutions and individuals have done post-apology. And then, almost on cue, a highly publicized case study arrived courtesy of Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, Mr. Sorkin writes in this weeks DealBook column.

title: Is There a Role For Wildlife Trade in Fighting Wildlife Trafficking?
description: An important two-day meeting is under way in London exploring fresh approaches to stemming the booming illegal trade in rare wildlife. The meeting, International Wildlife Trafficking: Solutions to a Global Crisis, was organized by the Royal Zoological Society, Wildlife Conservation Society and other groups. You can read the agenda here and dip in to watch a live video stream here:

title: Such and Such
description: A colleague notes that we frequently stumble with the phrase as such.

title: Randall of U.S. Falls Short in Cross-Country Sprint
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Kikkan Randall, considered to have the best chance of any American at the Sochi Olympics to win a cross-country medal, surprisingly failed to advance from her quarterfinal heat in the womens sprint on Tuesday.

title: Mallinckrodt to Buy San Diego Biopharmaceutical Firm for $1.3 Billion
description: LONDON  Mallinckrodt, an Irish specialty pharmaceutical company, said Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Cadence Pharmaceuticals for about $1.3 billion in cash.

title: Attack on Movie Theater in Pakistan Kills 11
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A grenade attack on a movie theater killed 11 people and injured 25 in the northern Pakistani city of Peshawar on Tuesday, police and hospital officials said. It was the second such attack in Peshawar, the capital of the restive Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province, this month.

title: Penguin Withdraws Book by American Scholar of Hinduism to Settle Lawsuit
description: BANGALORE  Penguin Books India, a unit of Penguin Random House, has agreed to withdraw and destroy all copies of a 2009 book on Hinduism by an American scholar to settle a lawsuit by a Hindu nationalist group that had objected to the books portrayal of the religion.

title: Competing for Generosity
description: Dear Diary:

title: Yellen Sets a Familiar Direction for the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the new chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, told a House committee on Tuesday that she strongly supported and planned to continue the policies adopted under her predecessor, Ben S. Bernanke.

title: Arrests in New York and Italy Thwart Mob Drug Scheme, Authorities Say
description: The mobsters, from the Calabria region of Italy, wanted a foothold in the underworld of New York City and thought their success smuggling drugs into Europe would serve them well on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Artworks Removed From Austria Home of German Who Holds Huge Trove
description: BERLIN  For several days last November, reporters in Salzburg, Austria, staked out 9 Carl-Storch-Strasse, a rundown house in an elegant neighborhood identified as the home of Cornelius Gurlitt by a small metal plate on the door. Reports that the German authorities had confiscated a trove of 1,280 artworks, some of them suspected of having been traded or looted during the Nazi era, from Mr. Gurlitts apartment in Munich had set off a global outcry and deep curiosity.

title: Stripe and Square Face Complexity Abroad
description: LONDON  International users now generate the majority of traffic for the social media giants Facebook and Twitter, and fast-growing tech companies like Airbnb, the online property rental service, have expanded rapidly into non-American markets to ward off local competitors.

title: New York Fashion Week: 3.1 Phillip Lim Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: One View of Merrill Lynchs Fall
description: In late 2001, Winthrop H. Smith Jr., a senior Merrill Lynch executive and son of one of the firms founding partners, walked into the office of his just-appointed boss, E. Stanley ONeal, ready to accept a new job he was being offered.

title: Holder Urges States to Lift Bans on Felons Voting
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. called Tuesday for the repeal of laws that prohibit millions of felons from voting, underscoring the Obama administrations determination to elevate issues of criminal justice and race in the presidents second term and create a lasting civil rights legacy.

title: Daily Report: Software Error Shakes Bitcoin Exchange
description: What was once the worlds largest Bitcoin exchange, Mt. Gox, appeared near collapse on Monday, the latest symbol of the woes facing early players in the world of virtual currencies, Nathaniel Popper reports.
