title: Yellens Testimony to House Committee
description: Janet Yellen, the newly installed chief of the Federal Reserve, made her first appearance before a congressional panel in that role as she testified before the House Financial Services Committee. Times correspondents covered the appearance in a live blog here.

title: House Approves Higher Debt Limit Without Condition
description: WASHINGTON  Ending three years of brinkmanship in which the threat of a devastating default on the nations debt was used to wring conservative concessions from President Obama, the House on Tuesday voted to raise the governments borrowing limit until March 2015, without any conditions.

title: Islamic Extremists Slaughter 15 Soldiers in Northern Iraqi City
description: BAGHDAD  Fighters from a Sunni extremist group attacked an army unit in a northern Iraqi city on Tuesday, killing 15 soldiers in a rampage of beheadings, shootings and a hanging, security officials said.

title: Highlights of the Westminster Dog Show
description: The field of nearly 3,000 dogs at the 138th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show got whittled to one best in show at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, as Sky, a 5-year-old wire fox terrier, took the crown.

title: Food Matters | A Pilgrimage to a Plate
description: With his Michelin-starred restaurant, In De Wulf, Kobe Desramaults is the latest innovative chef to turn nowhere  here, a remote corner of Belgium  into a culinary somewhere.

title: Finance Magnates Among Top Donors in 2013
description: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the private equity giant Carlyle Group, is a fan of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. So much so, in fact, that he donated $50 million to the center last year. His total donations of $121.7 million ranked No. 21 on The Chronicle of Philanthropys 2013 list of top American donors.

title: Military Plane Crash in Algeria Leaves Scores Dead
description: PARIS  An Algerian military plane crashed in a mountainous area of northeastern Algeria on Tuesday, and by nightfall rescuers had recovered at least 77 bodies and one survivor, according to Algerian National Television.

title: A.B.A. Nominates New Jersey Lawyer as President
description: The American Bar Association, the 400,000-member group that establishes standards for law schools and formulates codes of conduct and ethics for lawyers, has nominated Paulette Brown as its president.

title: La Quintas I.P.O. Filing Continues Blackstones Selling Spree
description: With La Quinta Holdings moving toward an initial public offering, its parent, the Blackstone Group, has shown that its still an eager seller.

title: Karen O, Inspired by The Jerk
description: If there were a prize for most indie recording at the Oscars, Karen Os Moon Song, featured in the film Her, would probably take it: she recorded it in her downtown Manhattan apartment, at her dining room table, as a demo for the actors to use. It was entirely off the cuff. The first thing you hear on the track, she said, is the sirens going off on Lafayette Street, from the nearby firehouse.

title: Inequality and Indignity
description: In the aftermath of the CBO report, the initial botched reporting and political interpretation, and the subsequent backlash, conservatives have had two choices. They can stay with the lies about job destruction  and many have; or they can talk about the work disincentives and claim that they are a terrible thing.

title: Every Dog Has Its Getaway
description: Does Fido deserve some pampering?

title: Donna Karan: Three Decades in Fashion
description: With Rita Ora spilling out of a black wrap dress and Katie Holmes in a chiffon skirt and leather top that was as sleek as a rain-soaked Manhattan street, Donna Karan celebrated 30 years of serving women with meaningful fashion.

title: When Marijuana Looks Like Candy, Not Drugs
description: This is not what I thought marijuana looked like.

title: The Great Civil War Escape
description: Thomas Rose could see the Union troops approaching from the east. After five days of torturous travel on foot, he was about to make good his escape from Richmonds infamous Libby Prison. Awaiting the arrival of his comrades, he noticed three soldiers to his rear. Assuming they were a federal vanguard, he rose to greet them, only to find himself recaptured. After wrestling a musket from one of his captors and firing it into the air, Rose ran toward the approaching Yankees. A dozen rebel soldiers quickly knocked him to the ground and bound him for return to Richmond, ending the short-lived escape of one of the masterminds of the Civil Wars most celebrated prison break.

title: Chasing Gold (and Jeans That Fit)
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  There was no way to ask the question without sounding slightly creepy, but the downhill skier Jan Hudec kindly answered it with cheerful Canadian candor. Yes, I have an enormous butt, he said.

title: Thomas Frank, Author and Historian, Will Join Salon
description: Salon Media Group said Tuesday that it was hiring Thomas Frank, the historian and author best known for his book Whats the Matter With Kansas, to write feature articles every Sunday as well as weigh in on current events as warranted.

title: Fitch Cuts Puerto Ricos Debt to Junk
description: Fitch Ratings lowered Puerto Ricos debt to junk status on Tuesday, becoming the last of the top three ratings agencies to downgrade the financially struggling island.

title: Do We Really Need Negative Book Reviews?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Zo Heller discuss whether bad books should be written about or ignored.

title: Alibabas Online Land Grab
description: Alibabas purchase of AutoNavi is a land grab, in two senses.

title: New Round of Syria Talks Off to a Slow Start
description: GENEVA  Face-to-face peace talks between the Syrian government and opposition representatives here failed to make progress on Tuesday, both sides said, each making statements indicating that they were still talking past each other in this new round of discussions.

title: Anna Kendrick at Carolina Herrera
description: Monday mornings usually take some easing in, but not for the Fashion Week herd, which continued to swarm runway spaces, battle for taxis and pick its way around icy sidewalks. Among the crowd at Lincoln Center for the Carolina Herrera show at 10 a.m. was the actress Anna Kendrick, who was seated next to Emmy Rossum and across the runway from Tina Fey.

title: J. Crew: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: A Lighthouse in Winter
description: I occasionally try to step back from the nonstop flow of environmental news to consider the beautiful basics that too often hide in plain sight on a busy planet. Ive explored thecycles of life on a farmand four seasons in a patch of woodsin my part of the Hudson Valley.On Facebook, Ive been enjoying an extraordinary photographic journal chronicling hour-by-hour changes in light and weather on the Hudson River around the Rondout Creek Lighthouse at Kingston, N.Y. The images are taken byCarolyn Marks Blackwood, an award-winningfilm producerand photographer whose home and studio are perched on a ledge in Rhinecliff, on the opposite bank.

title: The Dirty Martini Cleans Up Well
description: In this age of the aspirational cocktail, when bar menus can read like manifestoes or museum catalogs, certain drink orders are guaranteed to ignite the spleen of the serious bartender. Among them: the mojito (a lot of labor, particularly if customers ask for seven, which they often do); the Cosmopolitan (Sex and the City ended a while back); the vodka Red Bull (take your bad decisions outside); and the Bloody Mary, if ordered at night (seriously?).

title: Badgley Mischka: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Tory Burch: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Delhi Chief Minister Accuses Reliance Industries Chairman and Government Officials of Collusion
description: NEW DELHI  Arvind Kejriwal, the chief minister of Delhi, on Tuesday ordered the filing of a criminal complaint against Mukesh Ambani, the richest businessman in India, and the petroleum and natural gas minister, M. Veerappa Moily, to look into whether the two men and others colluded to keep gas prices high.

title: Image of the Day: February 11
Parochial Modern
description: Below-the-knee pleated skirts  when contrasted with boxy shirts and sporty accessories  are the breakout stars of the new fashion season.

title: Volatility in Market, and Losses, Close a Fund at Brevan Howard
description: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | The upheaval in emerging markets has buried its first high-flying fund.

title: Times Minute | Olympic Derrires
description: Also on the Minute, Janet Yellen offers her first public testimony as the Federal Reserve's new chairwoman and Shirley Temple remembered.

title: Times Minute | Olympic Derrires
description: In the Video

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 11
description: Mens snowboard halfpipe, womens ski jump and downhill and more curling on the sixth day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

title: John Mack Calls for an End to Beating Up on Wall St. C.E.O.s
description: JPMorgan Chase touched off a round of criticism when it disclosed that it would give its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, a big raise for 2013, a year in which the bank paid billions to resolve legal problems. But another Wall Street titan came to Mr. Dimons defense on Tuesday.

title: Rare Afghan Polio Case Tied to Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A 3-year-old girl in Kabul has contracted polio, the first confirmed case in the capital in 12 years, health officials said Tuesday.

title: New York Fashion Week: Ovadia & Sons Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

title: Eye Infection Forces Costas to Step Aside From Olympics Coverage
description: The infection in Bob Costass left eye appeared Thursday and spread to his right eye Sunday. When he woke up Tuesday in Sochi, Russia, with his eyes swollen and crusted shut, he told NBC that he could not host that nights prime-time Olympics broadcast.

title: Pops Prairie Woman Finds a Jazz Home on Broadway
description: Few would dispute that the Canadian singer-songwriter K. D. Lang has one of the great pop singing voices of our time. But in recent years, Ms. Lang, now 52, has retreated from the spotlight. On Tuesday, in a bold career move, she is replacing Fantasia Barrino in the jazz revue After Midnight  set in the Cotton Club in Harlem in the early 1930s  singing four songs with Wynton Marsaliss Jazz at Lincoln Center All-Stars.

title: New York States Top Judge Permits Early Bar Exam in Exchange for Pro Bono Work
description: In an effort to bolster the number of lawyers for the poor, New York States top judge has cleared the way for law students to take the bar exam early in return for devoting their last semester to pro bono work.

title: Yellen Speaks to Congress
description: Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, delivered her opening statement to Congress.

title: Online Exhibit Tracks Books Saved by the Real-Life Monuments Men
description: The role of the Allied armies Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives section in saving thousands of European art masterpieces from Nazi plunder is getting a big Hollywood hurrah, thanks to the film The Monuments Men.

title: Today in Small Business: Million-Dollar Tweets
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

title: Giffords to Write Book on Gun Violence
description: Gabrielle Giffords, the former Arizona congresswoman, has written a book with her husband, Mark Kelly, addressing the issue of gun violence, her publisher said on Tuesday. Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, previously released Ms. Giffordss memoir in 2011, also co-written with her husband.

title: Parents Are Poor Judges of Childrens Weight
description: Many parents apparently believe their children are leaner than they actually are.

title: Hilary Mantel Portrait to Be Displayed at British Library
description: You might think, given Britains long and celebrated literary history, that portraits of British authors would have found their way into the British Library while those writers were still alive. But you would be wrong, at least for the next few days. On Feb. 24, a portrait of Hilary Mantel, painted by Nick Lord, will become the first painting of a living author to be displayed at the museum.

title: Arcade Fire Gets Inside Spike Jonzes Brain
description: Like Karen O, the members of Arcade Fire have long known and collaborated with Spike Jonze. They worked on his last movie, Where the Wild Things Are, and he directed a short film for their album The Suburbs (and a live video for their song Afterlife at the YouTube Awards). So even though the band, based in Montreal, was busy working on its latest record, Reflektor, the musicians were eager to help Mr. Jonze with Her.

title: Goldman Sachs Adds Five to Management Committee
description: Goldman Sachs has added five executives to the firms influential management committee, a group of Goldman insiders that has the ear of the banks top brass.

title: Detainees Sentenced in Seconds in Streamline Justice on Border
description: TUCSON  My record is 30 minutes, Magistrate Judge Bernardo P. Velasco of Federal District Court here said one afternoon, describing the speed with which he had sealed the fates of 70 migrants caught sneaking into the country. Each of the accused had 25 seconds, give or take, to hear the charges against him, enter a plea and receive a sentence.

title: With Christie Under Fire, Republican Governors Have Big Fund-Raising Month
description: The Republican Governors Association announced on Wednesday that it had set a January record for fund-raising, seeking to refute suggestions that the troubles of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have scared away the groups donors.

title: Former New York Cultural Commissioner Takes Fellowship at Southern Methodist University
description: Kate D. Levin, New York Citys former cultural affairs commissioner, has been appointed the first fellow at Southern Methodist Universitys arts research center in Dallas, the university announced on Tuesday.

title: Modified Corn a Step Closer to Approval in Europe
description: LONDON  After 13 years, six scientific opinions and two legal challenges, an insect-resistant type of corn is on the verge of being approved by the European Union. It would be only the third genetically modified crop to be authorized for cultivation in the 28-nation bloc.

title: The Gun Report: February 11, 2014
description: This weekend, motorists in Beaumont, Tex., were treated to a peculiar sight: a man in a banana costume toting an AK-47 and a drum magazine with a 50-round capacity. He was promoting the grand opening of a nearby gun shop, Golden Triangle Tactical. Police let the 18-year-old go with a citation for violating a city ordinance which prohibits soliciting alongside roadways.

title: The Debt Ceiling Is Now Pointless
description: After Speaker John Boehner announced this morning that he would let a clean increase of the debt ceiling pass with mostly Democratic votes, I imagined what the country would be like if he let all bills come to a majority vote, instead of just those bills Republicans approve.

title: Obama Welcomes Hollande to the U.S.
description: President Obama and his French counterpart, President Franois Hollande, held a joint news conference to discuss a continuing alliance.

title: Shelby Cobra Coupe Becomes the First Federally Registered Historic Car
description: A 1964 Shelby Cobra Daytona Coupe has become the first vehicle recorded under a federal program to identify and preserve important engineering marvels, the Historic Vehicle Association annouced last month.

title: Vera Wang: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: New York Fashion Week: Theory Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

title: Get Ready for a Long Proxy Fight Over Time Warner Cable
description: The battle has begun.

title: Appeals Court Allows Challenges by Detainees at Guantnamo Prison
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that judges had the power to oversee complaints by detainees about the conditions of their confinement at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The ruling was a defeat for the Obama administration and may open the door to new lawsuits by the remaining 155 Guantnamo inmates.

title: U.S. Center for Russian Studies to Shut Moscow Office
description: MOSCOW  The Kennan Institute, a research center co-founded by George F. Kennan, the seminal Cold War theorist, that has fostered the study of Russia and the former Soviet Union since 1974, will shutter its office in Moscow this spring.

title: On This Red Carpet, Aging Is Desirable
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  You know something has shifted in Hollywood when well-known actresses in their 40s dare to show up at the AARP awards. Reminding a youth-obsessed town that time marches on? Career suicide, or at least it used to be.

title: Vail Dance Festival Announces Lineup
description: The American Ballet Theater principal Herman Cornejo will be the artist in residence at the 2014 Vail International Dance Festival, performing with the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company. The festival, which runs from July 27 to Aug. 9 in Vail, Colo., and is led by Damian Woetzel, will also feature the return of Wendy Whelan, bringing her Restless Creature project; a collaboration between the Taiwanese modern dancer Fang-Yi Sheu and the classical Indian dancer Shantala Shivalingappa; and new works by the Memphis jooker Lil Buck, and the contemporary dance choreographers Brian Brooks and Matthew Neenan.

title: WWS 472, Economics of the Welfare State, Class 2: Health Care
description: Notes here (pdf).

title: German Wins First Womens Ski Jump
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  It took 90 years for women to earn the right to ski jump in the Winter Games and just a day to crown their first Olympic champion.

title: Steve Reich Is Awarded $550,000 Prize by Spanish Foundation
description: The composer Steve Reich has won the 2013 BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award for contemporary composition, Mr. Reichs publisher, Boosey & Hawkes, announced on Tuesday. The award, which is given by a foundation associated with a Spanish financial services group, carries a cash prize of 400,000 euros (about $550,000), and is to be presented at a ceremony in June.

title: Rodarte: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: In Paris, a Worldly Good Deal
description: Savvy travelers know that location is everything, so its likely that Jules Verne, the world-roving French author of the celebrated 1873 adventure novel Around the World in Eighty Days, would be impressed by the 25-room Htel du Continent on the Rue du Mont-Thabor in Paris, newly renovated just in time for Paris Fashion Week. Its tucked away right in the heart of the city in the stylish First Arrondissement on a charming back street that runs parallel to the boutique-lined Rue Saint-Honor  and its only steps from the Louvre, the Tuileries Garden, the Place Vendme and the Place de la Concorde too.

title: Mark McNairy New Amsterdam: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 5
description: Barneys toasted transgender campaign; Galore celebrated new issue; Purple held its seasonal bash.

title: Midnight at the Museum, Breakfast at the Vatican
description: How about breakfast at the Vatican Museums before they open?

title: Why Norovirus Crops Up on Cruises
description: It has not been the best season for cruise ships. By the time the Explorer of the Seas docked at Bayonne, N.J., late last month, more than 600 passengers and crew members were sick to their stomachs; the Caribbean Princess arrived in Houston the same day after an outbreak sickened at least 192 people onboard.

title: In Letters, a Literary Force Lets Readers In
description: When The Paris Review finally got around to interviewing Malcolm Cowley in 1982, when he was 84, among the first questions the magazine posed was this: Do you regret not having concentrated more fully on your poetry? Cowley said yes. His problem, he added, was the essentially middle-class feeling that I had to support myself.

title: Executions Are Suspended by Governor in Washington
description: The governor of Washington, Jay Inslee, announced Tuesday that no executions would take place in the state while he remained in office, despite the fact that the death penalty was legal there.

title: Social Media Dispatches: Death and Destruction in Central African Republic
description: Witnesses have been documenting the violence in the Central African Republic over the past few days, with relentless slaughter and traces of entire communities wiped out as thousands of Muslims fled their homes to escape retaliatory attacks.

title: Back Home, Sense of Pride in Michael Sam
description: Michael Sam, a defensive end at Missouri who will enter the N.F.L. draft, announced Sunday that he was gay. People in his hometown of Hitchcock, Tex., and on his college team voiced their support.

title: Before Coming Out, a Hard Time Growing Up
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.  Michael Sam was the loud country boy who wore a tank top and a cowboy hat. He was the smooth-singing baritone who could irritate his coaches and crack up his teammates with his improvised songs.

title: President Obama Speaks on Syria
description: President Obama answered a question from Mark Landler, a White House Correspondent for The New York Times, about the ongoing crisis in Syria and about putting pressure on the Assad regime.

title: The Song Doesnt Remain the Same
description: In January the U.S. military and I celebrated our 42nd anniversary. Sort of. I am one of those modern soldiers with commitment issues. I enlisted in the Air Force Jan. 31, 1972.

title: A Cooking Class, an Herb Book and a Special Cod
description: To Learn: A Culinary Exchange in the Kitchen

title: New York Fashion Week: Billy Reid Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Rebecca Smeyne.

title: Goldman Handed Out Cosmetic Mirrors and Nail Files at Womens Coding Event
description: Updated, 8:43 p.m. | Goldman Sachs was the biggest sponsor of a Harvard event last weekend aimed at women interested in computer science. But the Wall Street banks conference swag at the event was found off-putting by at least one attendee.

title: A Mad Den of Beasts, Maniacally Cackling
description: The seven women of LeeSaar the Company are a sleek pack. In Grass and Jackals, which had its New York premiere on Saturday in the troupes debut performance at the Joyce Theater, they are sheathed in black bodysuits. Under thick black slabs of painted-on eyebrows, their eyes gaze out with the look of animals encountered in the wild: now sanguinely alert, now spooked. Then they smile like contestants in a beauty pageant, a different kind of watched beast.

title: The 13-Page Preschool Application
description: Holding a 13-page form from the pile on our dining room table, I called out across our apartment, trying to get my husbands attention. This preschool application asked for not only an essay about my 23-month-old daughter, but also a reference letter, both mine and my husbands credentials, and whether we were trustees at any major institutions. But it was the line where I was supposed to write my email address that really made me palpitate.

title: A World Unprepared, Again, for Rising Interest Rates
description: MEXICO CITY  I was living in So Paulo in 1997 when, out of the blue, an investment banker I knew in London called to ask about Brazilian cocktails. He didnt want one. He needed a name for a potential economic crisis, in the vein of Mexicos Tequila affair in 1994 and Thailands Tom Yum Kung debacle, which was unfolding at the time.

title: Hugh Jackman to Host the Tony Awards
description: Hugh Jackman will once again host the Tony Awards ceremony, which will be held on June 8 at Radio City Music Hall, the producers of the event announced on Tuesday. (Mr. Jackman made his own announcement via Instagram). A top Broadway box-office draw in the shows Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway, A Steady Rain and The Boy From Oz, Mr. Jackman will follow Neil Patrick Harris, who hosted the awards for the past three seasons. Mr. Harris may be a Tony nominee himself this year in his role as the lead character in the coming Broadway production of Hedwig and the Angry Inch.

title: Diesel Black Gold: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: What Makes Older People Happy
description: Every year, my husband and I wonder what kind of birthday gift to give his dad, now 86 years old. The newest gadget, which may be admired but almost surely will be put in a drawer? Something much more ordinary, like one of the cardigan sweaters he wears day in and day out?

title: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | History, Geography and Social Studies
description: Updated: Feb. 13

title: Living in Bedford Park, the Bronx
description: Affordable home prices, interesting prewar housing and good transportation draw buyers to the neighborhood.

title: Attention Priced-Out Shoppers
description: As Brooklyn neighborhoods grow more expensive and the citys affordability frontier shifts to the Bronx, Bedford Park, in the north-central section of the borough, could become prime territory, being both stable and financially within reach.

title: LOrals Deal With Nestl Puts Zaoui Brothers Back in Spotlight
description: LOrals deal to buy back 8 percent of itself from Nestl has been a long time coming, with a number of big names involved.

title: Why Cant You Find That Wine?
description: Often plaintive and occasionally hostile, the missives arrive regularly by email, snail mail and phone: You have an uncanny ability to discuss wines that are difficult if not impossible to find, one California reader wrote in June.

title: New York Fashion Week: Donna Karan Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Democrats and Republicans Unite Against Phone Calls on Airplanes
description: Congress may be deeply divided along partisan lines on most important national issues, but it turns out there is one thing Republicans and Democrats do agree on: restricting cellphone calls on planes.

title: Yankees Newest Star Welcomes Biggest Stage
description: Nobody sells hope like the Yankees. Nobody has such easy access to it. With their money and their marquee, they are a magnetic draw to an overseas sensation like Masahiro Tanaka, who buttoned up a No. 19 pinstriped jersey on Tuesday, tugged on that famous navy blue cap and proclaimed, in English, Im very happy to be a Yankee.

title: Yellen and the Labor Market
description: In her first testimony as Fed chair, Janet Yellen said  as we all hoped and expected she would  that she doesnt believe that the conventional unemployment rate gives a good picture of the amount of labor market slack. She mentioned, in particular, the high level of long-term unemployment and the large number of involuntary part-time workers.

title: Hows Your Ballot Looking?
description: With less than three weeks to go until the Academy Award for best picture is revealed, New York Times readers are in synch with many Oscar prognosticators  sort of. Everyone seems to agree that theres more than one front-runner. But how many leaders are there?

title: On an Adventure, Feeling All Right
description: Bob Marley made plenty of music that lends itself to a feel-good kids show.

description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession, Class 4
description: Slides here (pdf). For those following, Class 3 basically covered the material posted here for the snowed-out class 2, with some brief discussion of the Great Moderation folded in  it turned out that this topic was kind of thin anyway.

title: Jazzing Things Up, on Piano and on Vocals, as She Has for Decades
description: Call it an early sign of spring in an especially punishing winter. The aptly nicknamed first lady of jazz piano, Barbara Carroll, opened her return engagement to Birdland on Saturday evening with a vigorous performance of Lets Face the Music and Dance.

title: Gatti Cancels Carnegie Hall Appearances
description: Updated, Feb. 14 Daniele Gatti, a conductor with a growing international career, has canceled two planned Carnegie Hall appearances with the Vienna Philharmonic  and the rest of his engagements for the next two months  citing inflamed tendons in his shoulders, Carnegie Hall announced.

title: Developer Takes a New Look at Downtown New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN  A firm that once turned up its nose at this collegiate city now wants to build a $360 million mixed-use development on a downtown parking lot.

title: Wheelies: The ADAC Sings the Blues Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Fashion Trend: Bigger Showrooms and Smaller Offices
description: With smartphones replacing landlines and online calendars doing the work of assistants, it often seems as if the modern office has moved permanently into cyberspace.

title: A Performer Hews to the Shadows for Schubert Songs of Anguish and Joy
description: Wolfgang Holzmair did not so much perform for the audience assembled on Sunday evening at the Frick Collection as permit it to observe him.

title: Loves Details Translated
description: Amanda Majeskis concert on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall finally hit its stride when it began to feel like a cabaret show. Polished and sly, Ms. Majeski, a young American soprano, closed the program with the four songs that Britten wrote in the late 1930s for the singer and actress Hedli Anderson, to wry poems by Auden.

title: Chicane Opens in SoHo
description: Headliner

title: Corvex Adds Zell to Nominees for CommonWealth Board
description: Corvex Management has stepped up its fight against CommonWealth REIT, a real estate investment concern, by adding a boldface name to its slate of board nominees.

title: Go West to Sample the World
description: WHEN I ASKED a friend to meet me for dinner at a food court near the Javits Convention Center, he acted as if I had suggested we fill a fanny pack with Hot Pockets and eat them on the back of a bus.

title: Obama on Iranian Sanctions
description: President Obama spoke about the state of sanctions against Iran, and the businesses that do not comply.

title: Feeling Economic Pressure, Kazakhstan Takes Sudden Action
description: Kazakhstan joined a growing list of emerging economies under pressure as its central bank moved to devalue the countrys currency on Tuesday.

title: Doubts Start to Arise at Camp Scared Straight
description: SEATTLE  A potent premise fails to deliver the goods in A Great Wilderness, the frustratingly limp new drama by the talented Samuel D. Hunter (A Bright New Boise, The Whale), having its premiere here at Seattle Repertory Theater.

title: New York Fashion Week: Rodarte Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Anna Moller.

title: On the Horizon: A Winter Tournament Waged in Snow
description: On Feb. 22, as the Olympics wind to a close, more than 150 teams will meet at the foot of a 1,300-foot volcanic dome, in Sobetso, Japan, to splatter each other with snowballs at the 26th annual Showa-Shinzan International Yukigassen (Snow Battle).

title: Filling Club Spaces With Dance Beats and Arena-Size Sound
description: Oversize glasses, check. Asymmetrical haircut, check. Arm-pumping, climb-on-the-D.J.-desk enthusiasm, check. Lasers, check. And most of all: bass, check.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, South Sudan and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

title: Obama Greets Frances Leader, but Warns Against Doing Business With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  With the French president looking on, President Obama vowed on Tuesday to come down on companies that evade sanctions against Iran like a ton of bricks. He spoke a week after a delegation of French corporate executives traveled to Tehran looking for business opportunities amid diplomatic efforts to reach a nuclear deal.

title: Antisurveillance Campaign Adds Itself to Washingtons Datebook
description: The antisurveillance crowd is trying to get onto the governments radar. And though its a busy Tuesday in the nations capital, they seem to be having some success, repurposing an effective 2012 campaign to stop two Internet-related laws. But this time, instead of trying to block measures, a coalition of civil liberties groups and technology companies is flooding social media with calls to pass legislation that would limit the surveillance powers of the National Security Agency.

title: Karen Elson at Tory Burch
description: The morning rush hour didnt wait for the Fashion Week faces who dotted Tory Burchs 9 a.m. show on Tuesday. Anna Kendrick and Q-Tip made it minutes before the first model strutted the runway. Ditto the model Karen Elson, who later attended Rodartes Star Wars themed spectacle and has had quite the last few days, on the catwalk and off.

title: Three Men Leap Forward at City Ballet
description: Sara Mearns, a glory of New York City Ballet for several seasons, has recently brought a newly adult quality to her roles. But what consort has been worthy of her? An answer has at last emerged: Zachary Catazaro, who after Christmas danced in a couple of Nutcrackers as Cavalier to the Sugar Plum Fairy of Ms. Mearns and went on to partner her in other works. Their shared look of beauty, glamour, maturity and authority induced awe.

title: S.E.C.s Review of Stock Trading Will See Some of Its Own Work
description: There are now at least 58 stock exchanges in the United States, many of them dark pools where the trades can be made anonymously. With institutional investors claiming they are outgunned by high-frequency traders, and individual investors adrift in fragmented markets, its no wonder that Mary Jo White, the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is moving to review and overhaul how stocks are traded. The issue is that the S.E.C. may have created the problem it is now hoping to solve.

title: Graco Recalls Car Seats Over Faulty Buckle
description: Graco Childrens Products is recalling almost 3.8 million car seats because faulty buckles can make it hard to free the child in an emergency, the company said on Tuesday.

title: Build Your Own Chaos
description: What is the best way to play with Lego bricks? From youth, we have been able to dabble with a choice: conformity versus creativity.

title: Sochi Video Notebook: Shaun White
description: The snowboarder spoke about his legacy after finishing fourth in the mens halfpipe final in Sochi.

title: Art Matters | Old and New Worlds Collide Around Mexico Citys Zona Maco
description: While tradition is big in Mexico City, bureaucratic efficiency is not. This past weekend marked the 11th edition of the Zona Maco art fair, which this year switched its dates surreptitiously from April to February, risking administrative upheaval in todays ever-more-scheduled and globalized art world. Though Zona Maco proclaims itself Latin Americas most important fair, international gallerists and collectors seem to return not out of obligation, but because of the adventures and the pleasures its host city has to offer.

title: Exploring Black Americans Opinions of Same-Sex Marriage
description: Perched precariously at the intersection of race, religion and sexual identity, The New Black, Yoruba Richens calm and nuanced exploration of African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage, balances crude filmmaking with sophisticated insights.

title: Beside the Flash of Gold, a Shadow
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The athletes willingly accept the risks in winter sports in which yesterdays jaw-dropping trick too quickly becomes the new normal.

title: Less Redemption, More Tears
description: The existential battle that rages through RoboCop, a nicely cast, respectable remake of the wittily corrosive 1987 Paul Verhoeven film, is less the struggle between man and machine than between the originals pop nihilism and the bottom-line commercialism driving this new vehicle. Once again, an ordinary man, a Detroit cop, Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman), is transformed by corporate interests into a cyborg after being critically wounded in the line of duty. And, as before, the reanimated creature walks and talks like a latter-day Frankensteins monster, his recognizably human parts encased in an artificial carapace, although this version also mixes in tears with the bullets.

title: Long-Term Care Insurance Priced by Gender
description: Deciding to buy long-term-care insurance is a big financial commitment  even more so if you are a woman.

title: Dow Chemical Formally Rebuffs Breakup Proposal
description: Dow Chemical said on Tuesday that it saw no value in pursuing a significant breakup, dealing a setback to a hedge fund manager who encouraged the company to split its petrochemicals and specialty chemicals businesses.

description: One of the largest and most meticulous studies of mammography ever done, involving 90,000 women and lasting a quarter-century, has added powerful new doubts about the value of the screening test for women of any age.

title: Putin Ally Claims Not to See Racism in Fake Image of Obama Craving Banana on Her Twitter Feed
description: Last Updated, 8:39 p.m. | One day after she apologized for a digitally altered image of President Obama posted on her Twitter feed, the Russian official who helped light the Olympic caldron to open the Sochi Games told the BBC that she had no idea why the fake photograph was racist.

title: Marty Plissner, 87, Is Dead; Led Political Coverage at CBS
description: Marty Plissner, a longtime political director for CBS News who helped expand the role of television in covering elections, died on Feb. 6 in Washington. He was 87.

title: Samvir Sidhu
description: Mr. Sidhu, 30, who goes by Sam, is the managing principal of Megalith Capital, which recently moved its headquarters to New York from Philadelphia. The company specializes in multifamily developments. Its current projects include a condominium conversion in TriBeCa, as well as a condo conversion and rental development in Dumbo, Brooklyn.

title: U.N. Court, on Appeal, Acquits 2 Rwandans in 1994 Genocide
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Twenty years after the small African nation of Rwanda descended into a frenzy of killing, a special United Nations court announced Tuesday that two high-ranking Rwandan officers convicted of taking part in the 1994 genocide had been acquitted on appeal.

title: Matsuzaka Says Tanakas Biggest Adjustment May Be to Life in the U.S.
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  About an hour before Masahiro Tanaka was officially introduced on Tuesday as a Yankee, as the next great Japanese import, Daisuke Matsuzaka was asked what advice he would give Tanaka. Essentially, what was his experience like?

title: Remembering Shirley Temple Black

title: A Grizzly Answer for Obesity
description: PULLMAN, Wash.  CLINICALLY speaking, about 1.5 billion people worldwide are overweight. According to the World Health Organization, more than 10 percent of the worlds adults are obese, arguably making them the largest patient population in existence. We can debate the causes, but the long-term consequences of obesity  diabetes, heart disease, cancer  place huge burdens on our society. Public health campaigns have made little impression on this spreading medical crisis.

title: Atlantic Media Executive Heads to Byron Trotts Firm
description: Byron D. Trott, the former Goldman Sachs rain-maker known for having the ear of Warren E. Buffett, isnt known for being a regular presence in the press. But his firms newest managing director just happens to be a longtime media executive.

title: Barbies Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue Causes a Stir Online
description: TWO familiar brands that have for decades been the targets of complaints about their depictions of women have joined forces for a promotional campaign that tells critics they are proudly unapologetic about who they are.

title: U.S. Military Denounces Afghanistans Planned Release of More Prisoners
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American military officials in Afghanistan complained on Tuesday that Afghan authorities had ordered the release of more prisoners whom the Americans consider to be dangerous insurgents, and said their release would violate agreements between the Afghan and American governments.

title: A Debate in New York Over the Name of a Sea Between Japan and the Koreas
description: If all politics were truly local, Brooklynites might be lobbying to rename the estuary that separates them from Manhattan. After all, it is only the East River if you happen to be a Manhattanite.

title: In Skating, Its All About Mind Games
description: SOCHI, Russia  Figure skating is the only Winter Olympic sport in which a competitor is so alone for so many minutes, so isolated in a contained space, accompanied only by thoughts that can be as quivery as tired legs.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Fairytale Lips at Rodarte
description: The innocence of childhood, glimpsed through the hazy filter of nostalgia, imparted a wistful, weirdly beautiful element to the makeup at Rodarte this afternoon. Backstage, the makeup artist James Kaliardos described the inspiration as the time when you sort of romanticize things like movies and fairytales that stick with you, and affect the way you see beauty. The Rodarte princess, however, is all grown up and has a dark side to her as well. Providing that much-needed edge: a pair of iridescent lip colors done in rich shades of mauve and lavender. Kate and Laura are so into makeup, and the subtle differences in color, Kaliardos said about the Mulleavy sisters, noting that they spent hours deciding on the final palette. The models skin tones largely dictated which of the two shades they would wear, but the application technique was the same: Kaliardos lined the mouth with either Nars Velvet Lip Liner Pencil in El Agua (a deep rose, to be released in the fall) or Nars Eyeliner in Mambo, a reddish brown, and then filled in the lips with a corresponding hue (Nars Lipstick in Dominique Audacious and Deborah Audacious, respectively; both available in the fall). Lastly, he topped everything off with a custom blend of glitter  rose and gold mixed into a base of lipstick and gloss  packed on the mouth with a small makeup brush for precision. (Note to those at home: Surgical tape helps to catch any sparkle fallout on your skin).

title: Police Say Christie Copter Didnt Fly Over Bridge
description: The New Jersey State Police released a statement on Tuesday saying that none of the three helicopter flights that carried Gov. Chris Christie during the controversial lane closings at the George Washington Bridge in September flew over or near the bridge or Fort Lee, N.J.

title: What Is America All About?
description: CALL me obtuse, but I was surprised when President Obama, running for re-election two summers ago, declared that Costco is representative of what America is all about. It is? More than the Marshall Plan or the Bill of Rights? Or Walmart?

title: Olympic Hockey Is the Same, Except for This and That
description: The mens hockey tournament in Sochi, Russia, which begins Wednesday, will feature more than 140 N.H.L. players. But Olympic hockey, governed by the International Ice Hockey Federation, is not quite the same as N.H.L. hockey. Here are some of the differences:

title: Wage Premium From College Is Said to Be Up
description: The millennials  born after 1980  are the best-educated generation in history. By early adulthood, a third have college degrees, and those degrees help them earn more than ever before. So scholars at the Pew Research Center were puzzled when they found that the median, inflation-adjusted income of 25- to 32-year-olds had changed very little since 1965.

title: Food Co-ops in Gentrifying Areas Find They Arent to Every Taste
description: A group of local teenagers was abuzz over the price of a single candy bar at the new Bushwick Food Co-op: $3.10, plus tax.

title: Nuclear Issue in Limbo as Indecision Grips Japan
description: TOKYO  Several industrialized countries have turned their backs on nuclear power as a result of the Fukushima nuclear disaster, including one that has already begun permanently shutting functioning plants. That country is not Japan.

title: New York Officials Stall Plans to Tweak Teacher Evaluations
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos ire at state education officials has cowed them into backing off a plan, for now, to tinker with a new teacher evaluation system.

title: U.S. Targets Buyers of China-Bound Luxury Cars
description: Michael A. Downs, a businessman in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., says he is simply looking to profit from the growing demand in China for cars from the likes of Mercedes, BMW and Range Rover.

description: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Chick-fil-A Commits to Stop Sales of Poultry Raised With Antibiotics
description: Chick-fil-A said on Tuesday that within five years it would no longer sell products containing meat from chickens raised with antibiotics.

title: Restoring a Pairs Skating Dynasty
description: SOCHI, Russia  As pairs skating began Tuesday, the elderly couple walked to their seats at Iceberg Skating Palace, inconspicuous even in a section reserved for honored guests.

title: Oscar de la Renta: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Tiger Population Grows in India, as Does Fear After Attacks
description: NEW DELHI  No one has lived long enough to describe the tiger in detail, but some things about her are known. She traverses great stretches of land in a day and is comfortable wandering deep into human territory. After killing her first three or four people, she began to eat her victims  starting rump-first, one expert said, as she would a deer.

title: A Repentant Rebel Addresses New York Abolitionists
description: Henry Ward Beecher, the best known minister in the United States, took the platform in his beloved Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn sometime after 8 p. m. on Feb. 10, 1864. Under Beechers guidance the members of Plymouth Church stood as the most committed abolitionist flock in New York and even throughout the nation. On this night Beecher deferred to Brooklyns mayor, A. M. Wood, who introduced the evenings speaker, E. W. Gantt, late a General in the rebel army. Gantt took the stage in the beautiful hall. Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims had occupied this building at the beginning of 1850 and while the exterior was not especially prepossessing, with its simple brick facade, the sanctuary looked very elegant. The hall, with a seating capacity of more than 2,500, boasted the largest pipe organ in the United States at the time. White pews trimmed in stained hardwood filled the floor and balcony, with the pews set in an oval, giving the space a theater-in-the-round sense rather than that of a cathedral or Puritan meeting house.

title: New York Fashion Week Street Style: Day 6
description: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

title: Israels Big Question
description: Ive written a series of columns from Israel in the past two weeks because I believe that if Secretary of State John Kerry brings his peace mission to a head and presents the parties with a clear framework for an agreement, Israel and the Jewish people will face one of the most critical choices in their history. And when they do, all hell could break loose in Israel. It is important to understand why.

title: Iouri Podladtchikovs Winning Halfpipe Run
description: The Swiss snowboarder laid down the cleanest, most technical combination of tricks in the mens halfpipe.

title: Demonizing Gays in Africa
description: As acceptance of gays and lesbians has grown in the United States and Europe, intolerance and persecution has been rising in other parts of the world. African nations are leaders in this cruel and dehumanizing trend.

title: State Dinner Guest List for Hollande Is Impressive, if Minus One
description: WASHINGTON  In the end, the White House solved the most delicate protocol issue of Tuesdays state dinner for President Franois Hollande of France in a dignified but creative way.

title: Medicaid Expansion, Red-State Style
description: Some 20 states have refused to expand their Medicaid programs to cover uninsured low-income people, an important element of the health reform law. Now several states that had been opposed, mostly for ideological reasons, are seeking to cover newly eligible Medicaid beneficiaries through private insurance.

title: State Dinners Through the Years
description: A look at several White House state dinners, a tradition dating to 1874 and President Ulysses S. Grant.

title: The Day the Internet Didnt Fight Back
description: Updated: This post now includes comment from Senator Dianne Feinsteins office and a protest organizer. |

title: 6 Million Americans Without a Voice
description: The right to vote is the foundation of any democracy, yet nearly six million Americans are denied that right, in many cases for life, because they have been convicted of a crime. Some states disenfranchise more than 7 percent of their adult citizens.

title: Sky, Wire Fox Terrier and Veteran Show Dog, Wins at Westminster
description: A bloodhound named Nathan stole the crowds heart Tuesday night at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Each time a camera caught his droopy-faced countenance, or a judge came within a few feet of him, his fans at Madison Square Garden erupted. They were nuts about Nathan, who was unfazed by the commotion.

title: Christie Ridicules Democrats for Emphasizing Income Inequality
description: CHICAGO  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey delivered an unexpectedly blistering broadside on Tuesday against the Democratic Partys growing emphasis on income inequality, warning that the movement would drive America toward mediocrity and portraying its leaders, like Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, as local liberals unlikely to ignite a national cause.

title: For Women, a More Complicated Choice on Mammograms
description: For women who dutifully keep their mammogram appointments year after year, the latest results from a long-term trial in Canada, which found no difference in death rates from breast cancer among women who had regular mammograms and those who did not, are bound to sow confusion, perhaps even anger.

title: Panel Wont Change Naproxen Labels
description: A panel convened by the Food and Drug Administration concluded that naproxen, the active ingredient in Aleve, did not pose a lower risk of cardiovascular problems than ibuprofen and similar pain drugs. The panel voted 16 to 9 on Tuesday not to change warning labels on naproxen, a broadly used anti-inflammatory pain medication, to say that it is less risky. Naproxen, which is widely used to treat arthritis pain, had been found in some studies included in a large analysis published last year in The Lancet to carry a lower risk for heart problems than others in its class. A large clinical trial comparing a number of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, including naproxen and ibuprofen, is nearing completion, and some participants said they expected that the results would allow for more definitive conclusions on naproxen.

title: Rival Industries Sweet-Talk the Public
description: WASHINGTON  The corn refinery and sugar industries, bitter rivals in the manufacture of billions of dollars worth of sweeteners for sodas and other high-calorie foods, covertly funded dueling nonprofit groups in Washington in a multiyear effort to grab market share, while also stoking fears among consumers about possible health risks, court records made public in a federal lawsuit between the two parties show.

title: Union Drive Doesnt Bother Management, but G.O.P. Fumes
description: As workers at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., prepare to vote this week on whether to join the United Automobile Workers, they are facing unusual pressure from the states Republican legislators to reject the union.

title: Cubas Reward for the Dutiful: Gated Housing
description: HAVANA  In the splendid neighborhoods of this dilapidated city, old mansions are being upgraded with imported tile. Businessmen go out for sushi and drive home in plush Audis. Now, hoping to keep up, the government is erecting something special for its own: a housing development called Project Granma, featuring hundreds of comfortable apartments in a gated complex set to have its own movie theater and schools.

title: Practice Is the Only Place Knicks Cant Beat Themselves
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Coach Mike Woodson called a timeout. His team was trailing by 3 points with 5.7 seconds left, so he broke out his whiteboard and drew up a play for a game-tying shot. On the ensuing inbounds play, his plan vaporized like a plume of talcum powder. A swarm of defenders quickly converged on Beno Udrih, who failed to squeeze off a jumper before the buzzer sounded.

title: On the Lookout for Falling Ice Amid Manhattans Towers
description: In a season that has been miserable with snow, ice and slush  and with another wintry blast on the way  New Yorkers have gotten used to looking down to avoid danger on frozen streets.

title: Creators Still in Demand on Health Care Website
description: WASHINGTON  After denigrating the work of CGI and replacing it as the largest contractor on the federal health care website, the Obama administration is negotiating with the company to extend its work on the project for a few months.

description: New York

title: In London, an Auction of Arte Povera Yields Rich Results
description: LONDON  In Christies salesroom here on Tuesday night, a crowd heavily laced with Italian- and French-speaking collectors and dealers came to watch and to bid on Eyes Wide Open: An Italian Vision, a private collection of primarily Italian art.

title: Spy Chief Says Snowden Took Advantage of Perfect Storm of Security Lapses
description: WASHINGTON  The director of national intelligence acknowledged Tuesday that nearly a year after the contractor Edward J. Snowden scraped highly classified documents from the National Security Agencys networks, the technology was not yet fully in place to prevent another insider from stealing top-secret data on a similarly large scale.

title: What to Watch from Sochi: February 12
description: ALPINE SKIING In the absence of Lindsey Vonn, the womens downhill is the latest chapter of the rivalry between Maria Hfl-Riesch and Julia Mancuso. Hfl-Riesch won the super combined Monday, but Mancuso had the best time in the downhill portion of the event. NBC, 8 p.m.

Grace and Athleticism as Pairs Take to Ice

title: At the End of a Soire
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This was a nice change of mid-week pace by Peter A. Collins. Of course, the first things you probably noticed when you looked at the grid were the three Ts. What do you think? Are they a hint to what we will find as we solve the puzzle, or is the pattern just a red herring?

title: Highlights From Our Social Feeds at NYFW, Day 6
An Italian Monastery Becomes a Fashion Destination for Brides in a Frugal Era
description: CASCIA, Italy  The seamstress gently fastened the ivory-colored silk-covered buttons of the lace corset. She took out the embroidered veil and laid it over the bride-to-bes long black hair. Girlfriends and family members watched in silence, their eyes glistening.

title: Christian School Faulted for Halting Abuse Study
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  For decades, students at Bob Jones University who sought counseling for sexual abuse were told not to report it because turning in an abuser from a fundamentalist Christian community would damage Jesus Christ. Administrators called victims liars and sinners.

title: Discoveries From Two Explorers
description: Have carabiner, will travel. The invitation to Tommy Hilfigers show came affixed to a little metal clasp, the sort mountaineers use to fasten their ropes. If you needed clearer indication that Mr. Hilfiger was on an outdoorsy lark, two steps into his show space at the Park Avenue Armory on Monday provided it. He had erected a towering range of snow-capped peaks. If you cant take the editors to the slopes ...

title: Budget Puzzle for Mayor: What to Do With a Surplus That May Top $3 Billion
description: A rosier-than-expected financial picture has left Mayor Bill de Blasio with an unanticipated predicament as he releases his first preliminary New York budget on Wednesday: how to hide a surplus that could easily exceed $3 billion.

title: Trendspotting: Trading Pelts
description: There was something impressive this week about the handful of insiders who seemed to draw on an uncanny fashion sixth sense.

title: Britain: Thames Flooding Causes Cameron to Skip Middle East Visit
description: Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday canceled a trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories, which would have been his first to the region as prime minister, to deal with extraordinary flooding in England. In the Thames Valley, which currently faces the most severe flood warnings, about 1,000 homes have been evacuated, and 1,600 military personnel had been deployed. The prime minister spent the last two days touring a number of villages, even as questions arose over whether the floods were his Katrina moment, a reference to the American governments response to the hurricane that hit New Orleans in 2005.

title: Florida Mans Fiance Contradicts Parts of His Testimony in Killing of Teenager
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  At times teary, his feet shackled, Michael Dunn, the man accused of fatally shooting a black teenager in November 2012 during an argument over loud music, took the witness stand on Tuesday and told the jury he pulled the trigger repeatedly only to save his own life.

title: Cuomo Rejects Another Plan by de Blasio: Minimum Wage
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio profess to be the closest of friends. But that did not stop the governor on Tuesday from summarily swatting away one of the mayors major policy proposals  again.

title: A War Over Sweetener Market Share
description: Documents made public as a result of a lawsuit between the sugar industry and the corn refiners association  which supply billions of dollars a year worth of sweeteners to sodas and other processed foods  have provided a rare behind-the-scenes look at how two giant players enlisted academics and nonprofits as they fought a fierce battle for market share.

title: Japanese Composer Says His Hearing Loss Is Partly Faked
description: TOKYO  Making his first public statement since admitting last week that a ghostwriter had written his best-known compositions, the man once hailed as Japans deaf musical genius said Wednesday that he had also at least partly faked his own hearing loss.

title: Facing Jail Time, Until a Lawyer With Survival Skills Helped Her Find Her Way
description: The .22-caliber pistol was in her waistband, not only unlicensed but defaced, its serial number scratched or sanded off. She had not been to school in at least six months. Sitting in a detention cell in December 2010 at age 17, Jessica Williams of East Harlem realized she had been caught cold and was about to be cooked: a year in jail on a Class D felony, and then lifetime membership in the Rikers Island Alumni Association. Reality didnt hit me until I was in Rikers Island, and thought, Oh my God, this is not my life, Ms. Williams said this week.

title: Liquid-Cooled Supercomputers, to Trim the Power Bill
description: TOKYO  Dropping a home computer into a vat of liquid would wreck it.

title: Mayors Call Did Not Prompt Pastors Release, Police Say
description: A Brooklyn pastor with close ties to Mayor Bill de Blasio was arrested and then released in an unusual turn of events that included a call from the mayor to a top police commander late Monday. But the mayors office and the police both said Tuesday that Mr. de Blasios call came after a precinct commander had already decided to release the clergyman.

title: Canada: Healthy Baby Is Delivered by Woman Declared Brain-Dead
description: A child was born over the weekend to a Canadian woman declared brain-dead after a cerebral hemorrhage on Dec. 28. Robyn Benson was 22 weeks pregnant when she was declared brain-dead in Victoria, British Columbia. But at the request of her husband, Dylan Benson, she was maintained on life support in a hospital intensive care unit and removed from life support shortly after giving birth. The case drew wide notice in Canada because of blog posts by Mr. Benson, who announced the birth on Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 12, 2014
description: It may not look good, but it does everything the law requires.

title: In Governors Races This Year, Lessons for 2016
description: MADISON, Wis.  Three years after stripping public employee unions of the right to collectively bargain, Gov. Scott Walker began this election year by introducing workers who had found jobs since he took office. A dozen stood with him in the State Capitol, dressed for the workplace: a nursing assistant, an accountant, a maintenance technician at Milwaukee Valve.

title: Hospitals Plan to Expand Angers Many in Park Slope, Brooklyn
description: As Brooklyn residents in Bedford-Stuyvesant and Cobble Hill clamor to keep their flailing community hospitals open, a different kind of opposition has arisen in Park Slope, where the financially robust New York Methodist Hospital is embroiled in a battle over its plan to open an outpatient care center next to its main campus in the heart of the neighborhood.

description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  One by one, the competitors took flight Tuesday at the first Olympic womens ski jumping event, and there was no way Blair Tomten could hold back tears.

description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged Tuesday in connection with the death of her 2-year-old son, the latest in a string of suspicious child deaths in New York City investigated by the police.

title: Queens Man Charged in Murder of Rap Stars Associate
description: A 35-year-old man has been charged with killing a longtime associate of the rapper 50 Cent and wounding three other men last month when he opened fire on a sport utility vehicle as a group of men drove through the snowy streets of Queens, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: Bratton Replacing 2 Leaders at New York Police Dept.
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton notified two powerful police chiefs on Tuesday that he planned to replace them as part of his efforts to change the New York Police Department, according to several people familiar with the discussions.

A New Halfpipe King
description: Shaun White finished fourth in the mens finals, ceding the Olympic gold to someone else  Iouri Podladtchikov of Switzerland  for the first time since 2002.

title: Whatever Happened to Every Man a King?
description: A passionate group of labor economists has taken up a cause championed 40 years ago by Senator Russell Long of Louisiana: to turn every worker into a capitalist.

title: Rights Group Details Kidnapping and Torture of Eritrean Refugees
description: CAIRO  Security officers in Egypt and Sudan have at times colluded with traffickers who kidnap and torture Eritrean refugees in order to extort money from the refugees relatives, according to a report released on Tuesday by Human Rights Watch.

title: Proposed Hong Kong Tax Directed at Mainland Chinese Raises Alarms
description: Hong Kong residents concerned about mainland Chinas growing influence on their territory found yet another reason for alarm recently, with a report saying that a substantial increase in tourism last year was propelled by mainland Chinese  who accounted for 70 percent of the 54 million visitors in 2013.

title: Salvadoran Who Told of Survival at Sea Flies Home
description: MEXICO CITY  A Salvadoran man who told the authorities he spent 13 months adrift in the Pacific Ocean before washing ashore in the Marshall Islands returned home to El Salvador on Tuesday, but seemed too overwhelmed to talk about his experiences.

title: Nancy Holt, Outdoor Artist, Dies at 75
description: Nancy Holt, a pioneer in the land-art movement of the 1960s and 70s and the creator of one of the eras most poetic works  Sun Tunnels, four huge concrete culverts set in the Utah desert to align with the sun on summer and winter solstices  died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 75.

title: Demoralization Is Not a Policy Achievement
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Why Vitamins May Be Bad for Your Workout
description: Many people take vitamins as part of their daily fitness regimens, having heard that antioxidants aid physical recovery and amplify the impact of workouts. But in another example of science undercutting deeply held assumptions, several new experiments find that antioxidant supplements may actually reduce the benefits of training.

title: 2 Lawmakers Urge Fed to Change Its Enforcement Procedures
description: Two prominent members of Congress, troubled by an enforcement action that the Federal Reserve imposed on large banks last year, are pressing for a big change in the way that Fed approves its crackdowns.

description: inopportune \()in--pr-tn, -tyn\ adjective

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Lincolns Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) TOM JONES (1963) In this 31 Days of Oscar presentation, Albert Finney stars as an 18th-century English foundling turned Casanova in Tony Richardsons Academy Award-winning adaptation of the classic novel by Henry Fielding. Susannah York (above, with Mr. Finney) is Sophie, the passionate daughter of the blue-blooded Squire Western (Hugh Griffith) and the woman Tom hopes to wed  though her father has other plans. Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the film surely one of the wildest, bawdiest and funniest comedies that a refreshingly agile filmmaker has ever brought to the screen.

title: Nebraska City Votes to Keep Rule Aimed at Illegal Immigrants
description: Residents of a small city in Nebraska voted on Tuesday to keep a controversial measure they approved in 2010 to ban illegal immigrants from renting homes.

title: Toyota Recalls Newest Priuses Over Software
description: TOKYO  Toyota Motor is recalling all of the 1.9 million newest-generation Prius vehicles it has sold worldwide because of a programming error that could cause their gas-electric hybrid systems to shut down, the automaker said Wednesday.

title: First Tie for Alpine Gold, Though Not Precisely
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  A tie is not uncommon in most sports. Without it there would be no overtime, no extra innings and no sudden death. But a tie for the gold medal in an Alpine Olympic event had never occurred before Wednesdays womens downhill at the Sochi Games.

title: Nanjing Meeting Leads to Pledge of Cross-Strait Communications
description: The chief outcome of Tuesdays meeting between officials of Taiwan and mainland China was an agreement to set up a mechanism for regular communications between the two sides, which have previously relied on quasi-official bodies. Those organizations, Taiwans Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainlands Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will continue to operate alongside whatever official lines of communication are established, the Chinese state news agency Xinhua reported.

title: Mayoral Victory in San Diego Offers Some Hope to Californias Struggling G.O.P.
description: SAN DIEGO  The election of a Republican city councilman to become San Diegos mayor became a rare bright spot for a party that has been eclipsed at the state level in California.

description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale said on Wednesday that it had swung to a profit in the fourth quarter, as it booked fewer one-time items than it did a year earlier.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 12, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | If the World Is Really Warming Up, How Come It Is So Darned Cold?
description: In Freezing Out the Bigger Picture, Justin Gillis writes about the difference between climate and weather.

title: Can Wendy Davis Have It All?
description: One sunny Friday morning in late January, Wendy Davis took me on a two-hour tour of the life she led just a decade or so ago, back when she was a city councilwoman and the world knew nothing of her or the pink running shoes she wore during her epic filibuster, or her ambition to be elected this November as a Democratic governor in the deeply Republican state of Texas, or the way her parenting has become a point of debate in whether shes a suitable candidate for that office. We were in Fort Worth, where Davis, who is a state senator, has lived for about 35 of her 50 years, most in utter obscurity. When she joined the City Council in 1999, she was only the third-most-prominent Wendy Davis in town (the other two were socialites), and to the extent that community leaders knew her at all, it was as the wife of Jeff Davis, an attorney and former city councilman, whose civic passions would spark her own. Once that fire was lit, everything would later change for her  for her marriage, for her city, for Texas and, who knows, perhaps even for a national Democratic Party in search of a post-Obama non-Hillary superstar.

title: Freeing Vegetables From Side-Dish Purgatory
description: Imagine this: Your dinner guests are seated around the table, waiting for you to parade out the main course. You triumphantly carry it in on a platter. Oohs and ahs ensue.

title: Finding the Subject in the Shadows
description: Gabriella Demczuk, 22, was born in Stockholm, was raised mostly in Baltimore and graduated from George Washington University. She has worked for NPR and The Hill, a congressional newspaper, and photographs regularly for The New York Times as the photography intern at The Timess Washington Bureau. Her Turning Point conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

title: Is Hookup Culture Leaving Your Generation Unhappy and Unprepared for Love?
description: Its almost Valentines Day, and articles about trends in love and romance have been in The Times all week, including one from Education Life about how young people need to learn how to love.

title: Former Czech Prime Minister Charged With Bribery
description: PARIS  Petr Necas, the former prime minister of the Czech Republic forced to resign last summer over a corruption scandal, has been charged with bribery, the Czech media reported late Tuesday.

description: PARK CITY, Utah  Ted Ligety was losing races by seven seconds. And that was just to the other 11-year-olds in his towns ski club.

title: New York Fashion Week Morning Report: Home Stretch
description: Were closing in on the end. New York Fashion week ends on Thursday; weve so far made it through five (official) days. Of course, NYFW days are to normal days as dog years are to their masters. Ask anyone whos had a full schedule of shows: Odds are, theyll tell you theyre on at least Day 35.

title: Free Press Groups Warn of Chinas Influence on Hong Kong and Taiwan Media
description: Updated, 8:16 a.m. ET | Press freedom in Hong Kong and Taiwan, which have long been known for their boisterous news media, is under increasing pressure from China, as news outlets curtail coverage that might anger government officials or trigger businesses to pull advertising, the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists said in a new report published on Wednesday.

title: Bank of England Shifts on Factors That Could Prompt a Rate Increase
description: LONDON  The Bank of England on Wednesday abandoned its six-month-old strategy of pledging to consider raising interest rates only when unemployment falls to 7 percent, saying it would now take a number of factors into account.

title: Identity Theft Hits Home: The Aftermath
description: Its been about two weeks since I discovered I was a victim of identity theft. It has not been a lot of fun.

title: Leaning In Can Be Uncomfortable
description: I hate to admit it, but the life of a female tech entrepreneur is different.

title: A Year Before Cricket World Cup, Indian Selectors Crack the Whip
description: NEW DELHI  On Tuesday afternoon, as the Indian cricket team for the Asia Cup, a four-team tournament that includes Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh, was announced, it was revealed that two key players  batsman Suresh Raina and bowler Ishant Sharma  had been dropped.

title: Security Forces in Egypt Detain Employee of American Embassy
description: CAIRO  Security forces have detained an Egyptian employee of the United States Embassy who worked as a liaison to the Muslim Brotherhood, Egyptian news reports said Wednesday, stirring fears of pressure on Western diplomats who communicate with the Islamist opposition.

title: A Twist in Charters Pursuit of a Cable Deal
description: CHARTERS BID FOR TIME WARNER CABLE HEATS UP | Charter Communications on Tuesday played its latest move in its pursuit of Time Warner Cable, nominating 13 directors to its targets board. Now, as Time Warner Cables annual meeting approaches, shareholders will have to decide whether they want to force in a new board that would be more receptive to a deal with Charter, David Gelles writes in DealBook. Charter proposed to acquire Time Warner Cable for $132.50 a share last month, but Time Warner Cable maintains that Charters bid undervalues the cable operator.

title: Bullish on Boyish
description: In 2004, as Jimmy Fallon was leaving Saturday Night Live after a six-year run creating sketch characters and sharing the Weekend Update desk with Tina Fey, Lorne Michaels floated an idea.

title: Take My Bro, Please
description: For a gross-out movie, Someone Marry Barry has a respectable number of genuinely funny moments. Over all, its still kind of crass and lowbrow, showing a particular obsession with flatulence, but theres a good-heartedness to it that somehow overrides your gut instinct to stop watching.

title: Q. and A. | His Influence More Pervasive Than Ever, Boy George Stages a Comeback
description: After years of tabloid-documented drug addictions and run-ins with the law, Boy George at last has his feet on solid ground. The 52-year-old singer  born George ODowd and sober for the past five years  was one of the biggest pop stars of the 80s, when he and his band, Culture Club, scored chart-topping hits with Karma Chameleon and Do You Really Want To Hurt Me. More importantly, George openly blurred the boundaries of sexuality in the era of AIDS, serving as a trailblazer for gay rights  and for the avant-garde personas of countless pop stars since.

title: Evaluating the Dearth of Female Hedge Fund Managers
description: Whitney Tilson is the managing partner of the hedge fund firm Kase Capital Management, which he founded more than 15 years ago. Mr. Tilson is also the co-founder of Value Investor Insight, an investment newsletter, and the Value Investing Congress, a biannual investment conference.

title: Activist Fund to Back C.E.O. Candidate at Cliffs
description: The activist hedge fund pushing for change at Cliffs Natural Resources plans to back a candidate for chief executive as it steps up its fight at the mining company.

title: New York Loves, but It Forgets
description: Dear Diary:

title: Nerve-Rattling Days for Cinematographer of Gravity
description: This movie was the most scary film Ive ever done. We created our own hell.

title: U.S. Businessman Accused of Being Crime Boss Stands Trial in China
description: BEIJING  An American businessman who is accused of loan-sharking, arson, kidnapping rivals and paying thugs to toss acid in the face of a judge, among other crimes, went on trial this week in a case that has raised questions about the use of forced confessions by Chinese courts and that has prompted concern from United States officials.

title: Daily Report: Spy Chief Says Snowden Took Advantage of Security Lapses
description: The director of national intelligence acknowledged Tuesday that nearly a year after the contractor Edward J. Snowden scraped highly classified documents from the National Security Agencys networks, the technology was not yet fully in place to prevent another insider from stealing top-secret data on a similarly large scale, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt report.

title: Truck Thiefs Getaway Try Ends in a Bus Drivers Death
description: A stolen truck sideswiped a taxi and hit a scooter before colliding with a New York City bus in the West Village early Wednesday morning, sending both vehicles careering onto the sidewalk where they smashed into a building on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 14th Street.

title: A View From the Mountains: Ted Ligetys World in Photos
description: American skier Ted Ligety chronicles his travels on the ski circuit and shares them with his fans and followers on Instagram.

title: New York Fashion Week: Fingers Crossed Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: For Wearable Computers, a New User Interface Challenge
description: We often think of user interfaces in terms of the way something looks. Is it flat, bright, clean or cluttered? Is it easy to navigate? Wheres the search box?

title: CreatureCast: Stealing Poison Capsules
description: Cnidarians, including corals and many jellyfish, feed and defend themselves with stinging capsules. Some sea slugs have evolved several lines of defense.

title: Poisonous Prey Turned Into Hunters Defense
description: Delicate beauty can often belie dangerous weapons. Take the cnidarians (pronounced ni-DAR-ee-uns), a group of animals that includes jellyfish, corals, hydroids, and other predators both small and large. Many are colorful and beautiful, and all of them are loaded with stinging capsules that each contain a neurotoxin-filled harpoon.

title: Redrawing a Line That Is Sometimes Crossed
description: The relationship between those who consume sports and those who play them is changing, and probably not for the best.

title: Womens Ski Jumping
description: Women ski jumpers made their Olympic debut on Tuesday night, taking historic flights down the normal hill at the Sochi Olympics.

title: Live Stream | Michael Korss Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
description: The latest womens collection from Michael Kors at New York Fashion Week.

title: Railway Ministers Budget Proposes More Trains But Leaves Fares Alone
