description: NEW DELHI  The railroad minister asked Parliament on Wednesday for an 8 percent increase in his budget for the next fiscal year so that cash-strapped Indian Railways could add 72 new trains while leaving passenger fares and freight charges unchanged.

title: Olympic Demonstration Sports Wed Like to See
description: The illustrator Bob Eckstein has some suggestions for the International Olympic Committee on how it could improve the Games.

title: Atlanta Frozen Again as Winter Woes Chill South
description: ATLANTA  Here, in a nod to the Civil War, people joke that Atlanta is the city that wont get burned twice. Wednesday, as the second major ice storm in two weeks froze the city in place, it proved true.

title: Preparing for Disaster by Betting Against It
description: At 2 a.m. on Oct. 29, 2012, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (M.T.A.) shut down the New York City subway system in preparation for Hurricane Sandy. By 9 p.m. storm surges reached nearly 14 feet at Manhattans Battery, as the waves of the East and Hudson Rivers deluged the citys rail stations and tunnels, flooding tracks, corroding antiquated electric controls and wreaking $5 billion in damage on the largest regional transportation provider in the Western Hemisphere. As it emerged from Sandys wreckage, the M.T.A. found it impossible to buy any existing kind of insurance against future storms.

title: Vehicle Dependability Declines Significantly in J.D. Power Study
description: For the first time since 1998, vehicle dependability has declined, according to the 2014 J.D. Power Vehicle Dependability Study released today. Most of the problems are with engines and transmissions, the report said.

title: The First Daughters Club
description: Audrey Rhodes is a pretty typical 13-year old in every respect but one: The home she returns to at the end of the school day is 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. In Rebecca Behrenss debut novel, When Audrey Met Alice, the perks that come with living in the White House (swimming pool, bowling alley, fresh-baked cookies on demand) fail to outweigh the loneliness and restrictions Audrey suffers in her role as first daughter. Her mother, the president, is distracted by matters of national importance. Her father, a medical researcher known as the first gent, is often away at his lab in Baltimore. Audreys ordinary teenage conundrums  how to make friends at a new school; how to act around a boy she likes  are amplified by the demands of presidential protocol and security: she cant even choose her own clothes. Its no wonder Audrey, who doesnt mince words, says she sometimes feels like punching a hole through one of my historic walls.

title: In Our Pages: February 13
description: 1914: Inventor Tests Parachute

title: Manchester United Trophy Tour Heads to New York
description: In and around the red half of Manchester, England, the Premier League of the present may look bleak  but the past has a resonance heard from Old Trafford to New Delhi, and now to New York.

title: Trimmings NYFW, Day 5
description: From aviator sunglasses to plaid backpacks, these are the standout accessories from Tommy Hilfiger, Phillip Lim, Carolina Herrera and more.

title: Sochi 2014: Interactive Stories
description: Athletes at the 2014 Winter Games barrel down an icy chute at 80 miles per hour and fly more than 15 vertical feet above the edge of the halfpipe, among other physical feats. In these interactive graphics and videos, learn their tricks and techniques  and then see how they used them to take home the gold.

title: Sochi Video Notebook: Ted Ligety
description: The American skier talked about growing up in Park City, Utah, and about how he first learned to ski.

title: Earthquake Strikes Remote Area of China
description: HONG KONG  A mountainous part of the Xinjiang region in far western China was hit by an intense earthquake on Wednesday, but officials said the area was isolated and thinly populated and there were no initial reports of deaths.

title: Supercell Revenue and Profit Soared in 2013
description: LONDON  Supercell, the Finnish gaming company behind the popular Clash of Clans and Hay Day franchises, has pretty good reason to be happy.

title: Grupo Bimbo to Buy Canada Bread for $1.7 Billion
description: Updated, 7:22 p.m. | Grupo Bimbo, a large Mexican baking company, is crossing North America for its latest bread deal.

title: Dutch Speedskater Halts Shani Daviss Reign in 1,000
description: SOCHI, Russia  Wednesday was supposed to provide the latest milestone moment in a career full of them for the American Shani Davis. Instead, it featured another dominant performance by the mighty Dutch speedskating team.

title: Off the Runway | Shine On
description: Metallic, once the sheen of choice for louche after hours, is stepping out into the daylight in casual new ways.

title: Hospitals Dialysis Plan Is Under New Scrutiny
description: For 400,000 people across the country with failed kidneys, dialysis care is a matter of life and death. It is also a lucrative business, in part because Medicare pays for such treatment regardless of age.

title: Foundation to Offer New Commission for Symphonies by Women
description: The womens opera commissioning program that Opera America announced in December will have a symphonic counterpart, supported by the Virginia B. Toulmin Foundation program for commissioning women in the performing arts  the same foundation that is supporting the opera project. The new orchestral project, announced on Wednesday by the League of American Orchestras, is to be administered by the league, and is part of EarShot, a national network of orchestras that offer readings and workshops for composers in the early stages of their careers.

title: Maybe I Do Like Carrots
description: Five weeks ago, 4-year-old Andrew Nostrame was a picky eater. Dinnertime was a succession of jump-ups for his parents, Christine Zanchi and Fran Nostrame, who were aggravated and defeated. Andrews twin brother, Nathaniel, had a much wider repertory and was more willing to try things, but even so, dinnertime was not a happy place. Christine and Fran werent battling so much as they were retreating. They needed to make a change and asked that Dr. David Ludwig and I step in to offer tools, including recipes and encouragement.

title: New York Fashion Week: Diesel Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

title: TV Network Meets Social Network
description: Late-night television is having a Gen X moment, with Jimmy Fallon, 39, and Jimmy Kimmel, 46, going head-to-head, and Seth Meyers, 40, soon to take over Late Night. Each has a strong social media presence and a vision for viral content that appeals to his own, and younger, generations.

title: The Limbo of Asian Markets
description: SURABAYA, Indonesia  The docks at big Indonesian ports like this one are quieter these days, as Chinas demand for raw materials has begun to cool.

title: Image of the Day: February 12
Retail Businesses That Try Crowdfunding Face Some Skepticism
description: After nine years in Brooklyn, the Chocolate Room  a popular purveyor of wine, cake, candy and coffee  experienced one of those cataclysmic events retailers fear: a crippling rise in rent. Informed in late 2012 that they would face an increase of more than 500 percent, the cafes owners, Naomi Josepher and Jon Payson, reluctantly decided to abandon their space and begin figuring out how to finance a $200,000 relocation.

title: The Bulldozer
description: When Ariel Sharon was elected prime minister of Israel in a landslide 13 years ago, many close to David Landau, a left-leaning British-born Israeli journalist, thought seriously of leaving the country. The future under Sharon, it seemed to them, held only war and bloodshed. Yet when Prime Minister Sharon collapsed from a stroke less than five years later, We wept, Landau writes. Not just for him; for ourselves.

title: The Backup Singers Can Be Divas, Too
description: In a career devoted largely to films about music, Morgan Neville has directed or produced documentaries about acclaimed performers as different as Ray Charles and Iggy Pop, and James Brown and Brian Wilson. But it took 20 Feet From Stardom, his examination of a group of predominantly black, female backup singers known only to the kind of obsessive music fan who reads the fine print on the back of CD covers, for him to earn his first Oscar nomination.

title: Was the Chocolate Room a Good Candidate for Crowdfunding?
description: After nine years in Brooklyn, the Chocolate Room, a popular cafe that sells wine, cake, candy and coffee, experienced one of those cataclysmic events retailers fear: a crippling rent increase. As Stacy Cowley reports in an article we have just published, the cafes owners, Naomi Josepher and Jon Payson, were informed in late 2012 that they would face an increase of more than 500 percent. Reluctantly, they decided to abandon their space and begin figuring out how to finance a $200,000 relocation to their new store in Brooklyn.

title: Technology Gives Ski Jumping Hills a Boost
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  At its most basic, ski jumping looks simple: slap on a pair of skis, strap on a helmet and ski down a slope at roughly 60 miles an hour, leap into the sky and land one leg in front of another about a football field away.

title: Classical Playlist: Danish String Quartet, Thomas Meglioranza, Gidon Kremer and More
description: CARL NIELSEN: The Masterworks, Vol. 2  Chamber and Instrumental WorksDanish String Quartet and others(Dacapo Records) The chamber music of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen, composed in the late 19th and early 20th century, has been enjoying a renaissance recently. The superb Danish String Quartet offers passionate, elegantly rendered interpretations of its compatriots lyrical, characterful quartets. The six-disc set also features the genial Piano Trio in G, as well as works for wind; piano and violin sonatas; and pieces for solo violin and solo piano. (Vivien Schweitzer)

title: New York Fall 2014: Elements | Shape
description: A thematic visual diary of New York Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

title: Looks That Are Up to the Job
description: No designer today can ignore the working woman. She is the one who demands the practicality (leaving aside perilously high heels) that was once reserved for the male of the species. So the conundrum becomes how to create appropriate clothes that still keep their feminine essence. That was the subject of three very different collections during New York Fashion Week for fall 2014.

title: Folk Art Building May Be Lost, but Facade Will Live: In Storage Someplace
description: Contrary to what you may have read lately, the Museum of Modern Art is intent on carefully preserving the former American Folk Art Museum next door.

title: Work and Health Insurance: Is There An Alternative?
description: Threeblogpostsanda columnshould probably suffice to cover the debate over Obamacare and work incentives, but I dont want to let the topic drop without firststepping back and talking about the actual health policy disagreement here. My column and posts last week criticized what struck me as a kind of insouciance from liberals about this issue, shading into apost-work utopianism that doesnt wrestle with what, in practice, the decline of work is actually likely to mean for issues of class, mobility, and social equality. But its also important to recognize that for many liberal writers, the controlling assumption here is not anti-work or pro-work. Its just pro-universal health care as a basic standard for a decent society, with the consequences taken as they come.

title: Meghan Collison Transforms Backstage at Rodarte
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Meghan Collison before (left) and after (right) makeup by Dick Page and hair by Guido Palau.

title: Gabriel Axel Dies at 95; Directed Babettes Feast
description: Gabriel Axel, a director whose 1987 labor of love, Babettes Feast, received the first foreign-language Oscar awarded to a Danish motion picture  and heralded a growing popular interest in all things food  died on Sunday in Copenhagen. He was 95.

title: At Long Last, Westminster Gives Rat Terriers a Chance to Show
description: Harriett Browne had the chicken morsels that Q and Dinger coveted. They were hungry Tuesday afternoon, up on their hind legs, seeking their rewards after competing in the first breed judging for rat terriers in the history of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Q belongs to Browne, who lives in Columbus, Ohio, and Dinger is owned by her friend Darice Ragan, a rat terrier breeder from Greenback, Tenn.

title: Times Minute | Helping Cuba's Old Guard
description: Also on the Minute, health food co-ops and and Olympic skier Ted Ligety explains the mechanics of the perfect turn.

title: Times Minute | Helping Cubas Old Guard
description: In the Video

title: A Short Affair, Now With Songs
description: Robert James Wallers 1992 novel The Bridges of Madison County slipped onto best-seller lists despite being ignored at first by many major reviewers. The unapologetically romantic tale of a lonely Iowa farm wifes short, tempestuous affair with a photographer who passes through town, though, captivated booksellers and readers. There was a film version in 1995, too, starring Clint Eastwood and Meryl Streep.

title: On the Death Penalty, Too Many Doubts
description: While multiple states continue to haggle over whether they can hide the way they kill people, the governor of Washington has decided to enter what he calls the growing national conversation about capital punishment on the other side  issuing a moratorium on all executions in the state because he is not convinced equal justice is being served.

title: German Officials Discuss Plans for a New Center for Art Restitution
description: BERLIN  German culture officials will begin discussing plans for a new, independent center as part of efforts to strengthen the countrys handling of the restitution of art looted by the Nazis. The decision comes in the wake of international criticism over the handling of a discovery of hundreds of possibly stolen works.

title: New York Fashion Week: J. Crew Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Dina Litovsky.

title: Browsing for Bargain Spring-Break Airfares
description: If youre a student or teacher  or are in any way connected to the school schedule  youve are likely to have spring break coming up in March or April. Many public school systems have next week off, too.

title: Paddling 2,500 Miles Around Florida
description: With a series of unfulfilling office jobs behind him, Justin Riney, 32, decided to step off the ledge three years ago. He spent the next year back home in Vero Beach, Fla., creating a plan to combine his attachment to the ocean with his desire to protect it. I grew up a surfer, but I also loved fishing, camping, boating  anything that connected me with the water, he said.

title: After Marquee Roles, an Epiphany
description: Alexandra Silber stole the show at the Inner Voices series in November 2012, seated at an upright piano singing Beautiful Dreamer as if it had just been written by Taylor Swift (rather than in the 1860s by Stephen Foster). The song was the highlight of Victor Lodato and Polly Pens Arlington, a mini-musical about war, which began performances Wednesday in an expanded version at the Vineyard Theater.

title: Hotel Review: Topnotch Resort in Stowe, Vt.
description: Rates

title: Homes for $600,000
description: This weeks homes include a midcentury modern in Oregon, a converted school in Vermont and a 1930 colonial in Florida.

title: What You Get for... $600,000
description: SALEM, ORE.

title: Today in Small Business: Competing With Chains
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Standard Chartered Looking to Sell Swiss Private Bank
description: LONDON  Standard Chartered, the British bank that earns most of its profit in Asia, is prepping its Swiss private bank for a sale as it prunes its non-core operations, a spokeswoman confirmed Wednesday.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 12
description: Womens downhill skiing, mens speedskating and womens halfpipe on the seventh day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

title: A New York City State of Mind
description: After 15 years in San Francisco, Meg Crosby was eager to return to the East Coast. New York was on my mind for a long time, said Ms. Crosby, a Maryland native.

title: Mob Princess Wages War on Concept of Inevitable
description: In Philosophy for Gangsters, a fitfully amusing dark comedy, Callie Rizzoli, a college-educated Mafia princess being groomed to lead the family business, is particularly aggrieved by the way her parents and brothers have departed  in a firefight with the police, shrugging that they were always meant to die that way.

title: A. A. Gill Honored for Top Hatchet Job
description: As conversations continue to swirl around whether negative reviews are a worthy use of the dwindling amount of space devoted to covering books, the Hatchet Job of the Year Award has been given to A. A. Gill for his dyspeptic view of the rock star Morrisseys Autobiography.

title: An Act of Surrender May Strengthen Boehners Control
description: WASHINGTON  On Tuesday morning, after extended discussions of political fund-raising at the Capitol Hill Club, Speaker John A. Boehner stood to change the subject. He then told his House Republican troops that he would put to a vote a measure to raise the governments borrowing limit, without preconditions.

title: Disney Plans to Encourage Digital Start-Ups
description: LOS ANGELES  The Magic Kingdom is letting 10 technology start-ups inside its walls as part of an effort to find new digital growth.

title: Judge Sets Nov. 3 as Start of Trial for Boston Bombing Suspect
description: BOSTON  A federal judge here on Wednesday set Nov. 3 as the start of the trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of the deadly bombing of the Boston Marathon last year.

title: New York Fashion Week: Marc by Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: How Not to React When a Childs News Surprises You
description: Maybe this is a good time to take a moment and consider what you would say if your child made an announcement that really surprised you  especially if it both surprised and disappointed you. It could be, Mom, Im not going to college, because Im traveling the country with my punk rock band. Or it could be, Dad, Im leaving the Joffrey Ballet. It doesnt matter  but what you say does. That first reaction stays with your child no matter how you eventually turn it around, whether its disappointment in his choice of spouse or disbelief over her career decision.

title: Doing the Math on Grupo Bimbos Deal for Canada Bread
description: In its latest deal north of the border, Grupo Bimbo, the acquisitive Mexican bread maker, is spending $1.8 billion to buy Canada Bread. Paying 20 times earnings to move into a mature market may seem questionable. But Bimbos earnings fetch an even higher multiple at home  and the deal should lower its weighted average cost of capital.

title: Backpack Key to Snowboarders Survival
description: The professional snowboarder Jeremy Jones trusts his life to the contents of his backpack. Whether in Alaska or Antarctica, the equipment he carries on his back is essential.

title: Below the Line: Makeup for Dallas Buyers Club
description: For Dallas Buyers Club, much has been said about the physical transformations Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto went through to portray characters struggling with the complications of AIDS. But their conversions were helped by makeup artists who sometimes used experimental techniques to create their sickly looks. Robin Mathews, who, along with Adruitha Lee, is nominated for a makeup Oscar, said that because of the films low budget and 23-day shooting schedule, much of her design came together on the set.

title: The Gaming Console Winner
description: Molly Wood tests the Sony PlayStation 4 and the Xbox One and declares one gaming console the winner.

title: Two Game Consoles Battle for a Dubious Prize
description: A philosophical war is being waged in the world of video game consoles.

title: Russian Environmentalist, and Critic of Olympics, Gets 3-Year Prison Sentence
description: SOCHI, Russia  An environmentalist and leading critic of Russias preparations to host the Winter Olympics was sentenced Wednesday to serve three years in a penal colony, in a ruling that rights groups condemned as legally flawed and obvious retribution for his political activities.

title: Chief Executive Turnover High in January, Report Says
description: New year, new chief executive.

title: Nagin Guilty of 20 Counts of Bribery and Fraud
description: NEW ORLEANS  C. Ray Nagin, a former corporate executive who became mayor in 2002 pledging to modernize city government and instead became an emblem of government dysfunction in the months and years after Hurricane Katrina, was found guilty in federal court on Wednesday on 20 counts of bribery and fraud.

title: High-Traffic Walkways in Bronx Become Slippery Obstacles as Snow Lingers
description: Old men wielded their canes like ski poles across the slippery ice. Couples clung tightly to each other for balance. And subway riders climbing out of the 174th-175th Street station in the Bronx wobbled unsteadily as they tried to find a foothold.

title: Mets Sign Reliever Jose Valverde
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  In 2012, pitching for the Detroit Tigers, Jose Valverde was considered a competent closer, perhaps on the verge of being elite. He had compiled 110 saves in his first three seasons in Detroit, but in the 2012 playoffs, as the Tigers marched to the World Series, they did so in spite of him. He imploded. He blew one save, allowed nine runs in four appearances, and was mercifully benched.

title: Syrian Rebels Sketch Peace Plan That Omits Demand for Assads Ouster
description: GENEVA  The Syrian opposition coalition on Wednesday presented its most detailed vision yet of a political transition to end Syrias conflict, in a 24-point plan that, strikingly, made no mention of President Bashar al-Assad or his ouster, while outlining strong requirements for human rights and justice in a future Syria.

title: Michael Kors: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Feeling For | Wearing Your Heart on Your Bag
description: From heart-studded store windows to Cupid-covered dinner menus, its hard to ignore the fact that Valentines Day is just around the corner. But come this time next week, empty chocolate boxes will get tossed into recycling bins, love notes will be tucked away for safe keeping and red-and-pink decorations will give way to the next Hallmark holiday, perhaps Easter. For a sweet statement with more staying power, consider this Stella McCartney bucket bag. The drawstring shape gets a playful boost from a painterly coeur print accented with Stellas signature chain-link trim. This bonbon of a bag is one long-term commitment we wouldnt be afraid to make.

title: Upstart Ends Gold Medal Run by the Big 3 in Womens Halfpipe
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The cattle auctions were on Wednesdays, Kaitlyn Farrington remembered. On the ranch near Bellevue, Idaho, before she left for school, she and her father would load a cow, maybe two, into the back of a trailer attached to the pickup truck. Gary Farrington drove about 40 miles south to Shoshone and made the sale, maybe $1,000 a head.

title: The Gun Report: February 12, 2014
description: One thing we have discovered since we began chronicling gun violence is that a surprising number of Americans use guns to end arguments or register their frustration. This probably would not happen if guns werent so readily available. Sometimes when these stories make their way into the press, you have to wonder whether youre reading The Onion.

title: Teaching the Sochi Olympics | Science, Health and Math
Storm Causes Traffic Chaos in North Carolina
description: Updated, 10:35 p.m. Thousands of motorists in North Carolina found themselves stuck on snow-covered highways Wednesday in a situation that looked similar to what took place in Georgia only two weeks ago, when motorists were stranded for hours.

title: Apple and Samsung Took All Handset Profits in Fourth Quarter
description: Last year, Asian handset makers like Huawei and Lenovo gained major traction in the mobile phone business. Yet Samsung Electronics and Apple, the top two handset makers in the world, made all of the industrys profits last quarter.

title: Alan Alda Challenges Scientists to Explain Color to Kids
description: Alan Alda, the actor and evangelizer for effective science communication, is at it again, asking scientists for accurate, but engaging answers to a new question: What is color?

title: Young Adults Need Flu Shots Too
description: Young adults who have not had a flu shot are at disproportionate risk of serious illness and hospitalization this flu season, a small new study suggests.

title: A Night of Comedy (and Political Jabs) for a Cause
description: Feminism and comedy may seem like uneasy bedfellows: Does an activist, progressive cause thrive in an industry that prides itself on political incorrectness? But at One Billion Laughing, the comedy fund-raiser held on Tuesday night at the Creek and the Cave in Long Island City, Queens, it felt like a natural fit.

title: Survey Suggests Voters Prefer Cuomos Proposal for Pre-K
description: ALBANY  A new poll released on Wednesday seemed to give a lift to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as he quarrels with Mayor Bill de Blasio over the best way to pay for prekindergarten classes.

title: Krawcheck Says Women on Wall Street Have Gone Backwards
description: It has long been a feature of Wall Street that women are underrepresented in the executive ranks. But since the financial crisis, the situation has gotten worse, according to one former big bank executive.

title: The High by Kelela
description: A single produced by Gifted & Blessed.

title: Go All Night by Kelela
description: A single from her 2013 album, Cut 4 Me.

title: In Marrakesh, Art by Churchill
description: La Mamounia, the upscale hotel in Marrakesh, Morocco, is hosting an art exhibition in its Grand Salon from Feb. 20 to March 3 in which eight paintings by Sir Winston Churchill and 17 by the 90-year-old Moroccan artist Hassan el Glaoui will be on display.

title: Derek Jeter Says Hell Retire at End of 2014 Season
description: For the past several weeks, Derek Jeter has been doing what he has long done as the Yankees redoubtable shortstop for two decades: getting a head start on spring training by working out almost daily at the teams complex in Tampa, Fla.

title: Death to America in Perspective
description: For many Americans, the familiar chants of death to America on the 35th anniversary of the Iranian Islamic revolution on Tuesday were no doubt infuriating. How can the United States ever complete a nuclear deal, much less consider normalizing relations in the future, with such a relentlessly hostile country?

title: With U.S. in Sights, Norwegian Airline Wins Irish License
description: PARIS  Norwegian Air Shuttle said Wednesday that its long-distance subsidiary had formally received an operating license from Ireland, paving the way for the budget carrier to seek approval in the United States for a plan to offer cut-rate flights across the Atlantic that has been fiercely opposed by airlines and pilots there and in Europe.

title: App Smart: Your Family Tree
description: The Timess Kit Eaton on Ancestry, MyHeritage and other apps to trace your family tree.

title: Trace Your Family Tree, From Roots to Green Shoots
description: Im British, Welsh to be exact, which means if I consulted the right databases and cross-referenced family documents I could probably trace my ancestry back 400 or 500 years. Nowadays, I can even carry out genealogy research with my smartphone.

title: Listen Up | Melody Maker
description: Mixing soulful R&B with thumping club beats, the singer Kelela is bringing her underground dance mash-ups to the mainstream.

title: Report Details Atrocities in Central African Republic
description: On Jan. 8, a man named Soba Tibati was sitting on a straw mat under a tree outside of his familys hut in a small town called Boyali in the Central African Republic.

title: Nanette Lepore: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Former Top S.E.C. Enforcer Returns to Milbank
description: Updated, 7:03 p.m. | After spending the last few years investigating financial institutions, George Canellos will now be defending them.

title: Video: Snowboarder Trusts His Life to His Backpack
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: Scene City: The Benign King of Hollywood
description: Dozens of famous friends honor Bryan Lourd, the powerhouse agent of CAA.

title: G.O.P. Senate Leaders Avert Debt Ceiling Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  It was a moment of real drama in a chamber known for its somnambulism. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, counted votes on his hand, at one point holding up three fingers as he searched for the remaining votes. Senator John Cornyn of Texas, his No. 2, paced the Senate floor.

title: I.M.F. Study Details Perils of Iranian Economy
description: The International Monetary Fund issued a sobering appraisal of Irans economy on Wednesday, warning that years of government mismanagement aggravated by the impact of the Wests antinuclear sanctions had left the country vulnerable to anemic growth and rampant inflation that require urgent attention.

title: Russia Prevails in Pairs Skating, Renewing a Tradition
description: SOCHI, Russia  Maxim Trankov screamed and slid on his knees in a moment of triumph and renewal.

title: BlackBerrys Market Share Falls Below Others
description: Continuing a well-established pattern, BlackBerry posted a sharp market share loss in the latest global estimates released Wednesday by IDC, the market research company. Even though smartphone shipments rose 39 percent in 2013 compared with the year before, exceeding one billion units for the first time, BlackBerry shipments fell 41 percent.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 6
description: Miu Miu screened fashion film; Rodarte partied at Acme.

title: 49th Now Compilation Is No. 1
description: Now Thats What I Call Music!, a series of pop compilation albums that have been coming out like clockwork in the United States since 1998  and since 1983 in Britain  has topped the Billboard chart once again.

title: Scientists Hope to Sequence Genome of Richard III
description: LONDON  About a year and a half after finding King Richard IIIs corpse under a parking lot in Leicester, British scientists will proceed to grind up some of his bones to try to sequence his genome. They hope to discover his hair and eye color and see what kind of infectious bacteria he might have been hosting.

title: 3.3 Million Enrolled on Health Marketplaces, Including More Young People, Government Says
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly 3.3 million people have signed up for health insurance through the marketplaces established by President Obamas health care law, and about one-fourth of them are young adults, the administration said Wednesday.

title: Stings Musical The Last Ship Finds a Home and a Cast
description: Casting and a Broadway theater were announced on Wednesday for The Last Ship, the new show with music and lyrics by the Grammy Award-winning singer Sting and a book by the Tony Award-winning author John Logan (Red) and the Putlizer Prize winner Brian Yorkey (Next to Normal).

title: Canada Rallies to Beat U.S. in Womens Hockey
description: SOCHI, Russia  Since 2010, the United States womens hockey team got younger and faster while Canadas Hayley Wickenheiser, the games gold standard, merely grew older. That was the running narrative, anyway, as the Canadians, the three-time defending Olympic champions, lost four consecutive games to the speedy, streaking Americans in the lead-up to the Sochi Games.

title: Model-Morphosis | Juliana Schurig at Vera Wang
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Juliana Schurig before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Jimmy Paul.

title: An Antique Palazzo in Malta
description: A renovated four-bedroom mid-19th-century palazzo on a narrow, cobbled lane is on the market for $1.13 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Malta
description: A RENOVATED PALAZZO IN BIRKIRKARA

title: The Short Life of a Hard Choice
description: The real cave on Capitol Hill this week wasnt the agreement to raise the debt ceiling, which was merely the victory of common sense over partisan posturing. It was actually the rush by both parties to reverse a small and perfectly sensible cut in a few military pensions.

title: Left and Right Object to I.R.S. Plan to Restrict Nonprofits Political Activity
description: WASHINGTON  With time running short, both progressive and conservative advocacy groups are raising serious objections to new rules proposed by the Obama administration to rein in political activity by nonprofit organizations that are not required to disclose sources of their funding.

title: The Art of Tuning Skis
description: A ski technician plays a behind-the-scenes role that is part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor. Ales Sopotnik spends countless hours tuning the skis of the American Alpine racer Leanne Smith.

title: Making Instruments, Not Just Music: A Competition for Inventors
description: Are you a musician who has always felt that the current crop of musical instruments cant quite capture that special, otherworldly sound that you can feel permeating your soul? You may want to keep an eye on the Margaret Guthman Musical Instrument Competition at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, where 23 instrument inventors from 14 countries are competing for a $10,000 in prizes (the top prize is $5,000) and recognition for their design, performance and engineering ingenuity.

title: Video: The Art of Tuning Skis
description: The Alpine skiers at the Sochi Games are reaching speeds in excess of 80 miles an hour  and at that velocity, the condition of their equipment can spell the difference between a spot on the podium and a helicopter flight to a hospital. Little wonder that ski technicians are so valued. Part crew chief, part caddie and part counselor, a ski technician is responsible for maintaining and tuning the dozens of pairs of skis a racer might use in a season.

title: Highlights From the Owners Manual
description: Every theater in New York should hire Stefan to make the precurtain announcements. With his baby face, bedroom eyes and alluring if indeterminate European accent, he can order us to turn off our cellphones and unwrap our hard candies any time.

title: With His First Budget, de Blasio Hews to Familiar Campaign Themes
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday proposed his first budget for New York City, a $73.7 billion spending plan that gave more palpable, if not practical, shape to the robust liberal platform that carried him into office last year.

title: Sid Caesar, Comedian of Comedians From TVs Early Days, Dies at 91
description: Sid Caesar, a comedic force of nature who became one of televisions first stars in the early 1950s and influenced generations of comedians and comedy writers, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

title: Southern Gentleman as Hollywood Agent
description: The actress Ellen Barkin strode onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, champagne in hand, to toast her best friend Bryan Lourd, the powerful but low-key managing partner of the Creative Artists Agency.

title: Giant Laser Complex Makes Fusion Advance, Finally
description: After years of disappointing results and missed deadlines, a $5 billion laser complex has now achieved a step that revives optimism that thermonuclear fusion, the process that powers the sun, can one day be harnessed for almost limitless energy.

title: Conservative Group Enters Michigan Fray on Side of Tea Party
description: One of the countrys most influential conservative political organizations announced Wednesday that it was diving into a bitter Republican primary in Michigan, its first such intervention into the broader battle  between the party establishment and Tea Party conservatives.

title: Style Points Prove Scarce in Sochi
description: Bless the crazy-pants Norwegian curlers, the guys wearing trousers no one can quite believe, to compete in a sport few understand. For Sochi, the media-savvy Norwegians packed a wardrobe of multiple wacky changes  Missoni-on-acid zigzags (shout-out to Al Roker and Matt Lauer!); Mondrian squares; granny-print knickers, all designed by a California sportswear company specializing in golf duds  that garnered 500,000 likes on an unofficial Facebook page even before the Winter Games began.

title: In Performance: Jonathan Groff
description: Jonathan Groff, who performed in Lincoln Centers American Songbook series on Feb. 15, sings I Got Lost in His Arms, a number from Irving Berlins 1946 musical Annie Get Your Gun.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Q. and A. With Dick Page
description: Dont ever accuse Dick Page of holding back. The British makeup artist fires off witty remarks and unvarnished opinions as effortlessly as he paints on the perfect lipstick. Here, we caught up with the affable pro backstage at Michael Kors for some straight talk (and friendly ribbing) on how to be pretty but not boring, the virtues of undereye bags and why the show must always go on  yes, even if it snows.

title: Valentines Stays With a Little Spice
description: Rose petals on the bed? Been there. Champagne on ice? Done that. This year in honor of Valentines Day, hoteliers are edging into racier territory.

title: How Nonprofits Have Played in Politics
description: The I.R.S. has proposed new restrictions to rein in the political activity of nonprofit social welfare groups, which has increased with changes to federal campaign finance laws over the past decade.

title: Rand Paul Files Lawsuit Over N.S.A. Call Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, on Wednesday filed a lawsuit against President Obama and the leaders of several intelligence agencies. The suit challenges as unconstitutional the National Security Agencys once-secret program that is collecting bulk records about Americans phone calls.

title: Pictures of the Day: Algeria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Algeria, Syria, New York and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

title: White House Puts Out Critical Infrastructure Security Guide
description: Updated: Industry reaction has been added to this post. |

title: Hugo Boss: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: How to Survive the Next Wave of Technology Extinction
description: Dont mock the beleaguered Nook owner. That could have been you.

title: While Earth May Tremble, This Pianist Is Unlikely To
description: The ability to focus and perform well in myriad, and sometimes subpar, circumstances is a requisite skill for any successful musician. The Taiwanese-American pianist Steven Lin recently proved his unshakable mettle when he continued to play through an earthquake that struck during his performance in a competition in Sendai, Japan.

title: Cate Blanchetts True Jasmine
description: In Blue Jasmine, Cate Blanchett plays a wealthy socialite who has to start over again. The character is both palatable and unpalatable, Ms. Blanchett says, but the result is a richer role.

title: Amid the Debris of Homs, a Guerrilla Is Born
description: Among the dwindling holdouts in the rebel-held Old City neighborhood of Homs, an area of the devastated Syrian city that international relief officials are trying to evacuate, is the former star goalkeeper of the national soccer team, transformed over three years from a pacifist antigovernment protest leader into a homegrown guerrilla fighter.

title: Challengers Take On the Big Three in Gamings Arena
description: Here is a question with a surprisingly complex answer: What is the best option for playing video games these days?

title: Sochi Video Notebook: Women's Halfpipe
description: Kaitlyn Farrington, Torah Bright and Kelly Clark, who won medals in the womens halfpipe finals, spoke to the media after the event.

title: Young Talents Working With Those Comedians Stravinsky and Berlioz
description: James Levine was just 37 when, in 1980, he inaugurated what is now called the Metropolitan Operas Lindemann Young Artist Development Program. His desire to foster young talent has now taken him across the Lincoln Center plaza to the Juilliard School. On Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, he conducted the opening performance of a program of comic scenes from works by Mozart, Berlioz and Donizetti along with Mavra, Stravinskys rarely heard one-act. This ambitious program, lasting three hours, was the fourth co-production between the Mets young artist program and Juilliard Opera since the two institutions began a partnership in 2010.

title: Drew Nieporent to Open Btard in Cortons Former Space
description: The restaurateur Drew Nieporent has settled on the new venture he plans to install in the TriiBeCa space that once housed Montrachet: Btard, a name that references the Montrachet wines of Burgundy.

title: Lebanese Bloggers Defend Olympian Criticized for Racy Photo Shoot
description: Last Updated, Thursday, 11:44 a.m. | Lebanons fractured sense of national identity was on full display this week, as bloggers rallied online to defend the honor of a female Olympian, the skier Jackie Chamoun, accused by the countrys sports minister of tarnishing the nations image by posing for seminude photographs on the slopes outside Beirut.

title: The Incomprehensible Sometimes Has Its Charms
description: The performing arts space of Roulette in Brooklyn appears only sporadically on the dance calendar. This week, however, its DanceRoulette season presents a different anthology of new pieces each evening.

title: I Remember van Druten
description: In 1953, a writer leveled harsh criticism at John van Drutens romantic comedy London Wall, calling its story almost shamelessly inadequate and arguing that the play would never work for American audiences. His name: John van Druten.

title: Sweeney Todd (Progressive Rock Remix)
description: Updated, 6:36 p.m. | When the demon barber of Fleet Street is next seen in the nations capital, he may be wielding an ax  six-string variety  rather than a razor. The Landless Theater Company of Washington has announced that it will stage Sweeney Todd  Prog Metal Version at the Undercroft Theater, in Washington, in August. And the project has Stephen Sondheims blessing, or at least his permission.

title: Second Act | Screen Siren
description: Agns Troubl is best known as the creator of the Agns B. fashion brand, but with her directorial film debut this spring, the 72-year-old designer reveals that her true passion has always been edgy, experimental cinema.

title: Long Island Bar in Brooklyn
description: After sitting empty for nearly seven years, a Brooklyn bar and its beloved neon sign have been brought back to life. In October, Joel Tompkins and the mixologist Toby Cecchini (who ran Passerby in Chelsea during the 1990s and is an occasional contributor to The New York Times) reopened the Long Island Bar, a fixture of Atlantic Avenue for more than 50 years until it closed in 2007 when the owner moved to Spain.

title: Bird Thou Never Wert
description: Half a century or so ago, when literate Americans still read poetry or thought they should, everyone knew about Marianne Moore, the white-haired, great-auntish New York writer who loved polysyllables, exotic animals and the Brooklyn Dodgers, and turned up around town in a signature Paul Revere hat.

title: Levine to Tackle Six Operas for the Met
description: James Levine, who is continuing to recover from the spine injury that sidelined him for two years, plans to conduct six productions at the Metropolitan Opera next season, including a new production of Mozarts Le Nozze di Figaro on opening night and Wagners majestic Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg, which is not exactly known for its brevity.

title: Hes a Real Rebel: Hell Tell You Himself
description: In Nashville, most houses are made of glass, and most people love living in them. Merely pointing that out can qualify you as a rebel.

title: Sacrificing His Fries for a Starring Role
description: Samuel Barnett ordered a salad. It wasnt exactly what he wanted at Cafe Luxembourg, especially with its noted French fries on the menu, but as he noted wryly, I have to get into a corset.

title: Peeling Back Time at Marc by Marc Jacobs
description: SITTING FRONT ROW at a fashion show on Tuesday afternoon was the designer Marc Jacobs, clad in Adidas track pants and surrounded by famous and powerful friends: Sofia Coppola, Alexa Chung, the LVMH executive Delphine Arnault.

title: London Director to Draft Arts Vision for Ground Zero
description: Executives developing a performing arts center at ground zero have hired a temporary artistic director from the Young Vic theater in London, one of a series of steps to be announced Thursday to advance a project that has long faced political and logistical hurdles.

title: A Night for Art on the Floor and Onstage
description: New York City Ballet presented the second of its Arts Nights series last Friday, and in honor of the occasion the principal dancer Adrian Danchig-Waring spoke a few words. His talk had nothing to do with the repertory, even though that surely would have been helpful to the youngish crowd, drawn to the David H. Koch Theater for a peek at the current promenade installation by the artist JR.

title: Conflict in Oil Industry, Awash in Crude
description: HOUSTON  T. Boone Pickens has personified the nations oil industry for more than a generation. So when he made an offhand comment at a conference here a few weeks ago expressing reservations about lifting the nations ban on exports of crude oil, he startled some of his old allies in the business.

title: Taking the Plunge at the Awards
description: Out with the Wonderbra, in with the ... sag? (And we dont mean the Screen Actors Guild.) Dresses with revealing necklines have been stealing the spotlight this awards season, signaling, perhaps, a new era in red-carpet dcolletage.

title: Blowing This Way and That
description: Few violin concertos are as tightly scripted as those making up Vivaldis Four Seasons. Four sonnets chronicling the agricultural calendar  possibly by Vivaldi himself  accompany the music. Their lines are written into the score like stage directions, instructing the player to evoke the sounds of buzzing gnats on a hot summer day, hunting calls in autumn or the motion of someone walking gingerly on ice. Additional labels identify particular kinds of birds  a finch, a cuckoo, a turtledove  and barking dogs.

title: Unskewing Obamacare
description: If youve been tracking the news on signups under the Affordable Care Act  which is easy thanks to Charles Gabas invaluable site  you already knew that the program was making a pretty good recovery from the botched start. Now, however, its official: as of the end of January signups were only about a million behind their projected track as of last spring, which means that as of March 31 the total is likely to be 6-point-something million rather than the projected 7 million. In other words, basically OK.

title: Tranquil Islands in Passionate Seas
description: In both Beethovens Sonata No. 30 (Op. 109) and Schuberts Wanderer Fantasy, quiet moments of resignation and introspection emerge suddenly from tempestuous thickets. In his admirable recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, the pianist Garrick Ohlsson rendered these elements with striking contrast.

title: Record-Breaking Play at Bridge Base Online
description: The Internet has hurt attendance at bridge clubs, but it has been highly beneficial for pairs who live far apart. They can practice regularly online.

title: The Problem With Mammograms
description: The front-page news today that mammograms dont decrease the death rates from breast cancer  but do increase the likelihood of unnecessary treatment  reminded me that its worth going back to Peggy Orensteins cover story from last April. Even before the results of the newly published study, involving 90,000 women, were released, Orensteins reporting led her to the same conclusion: There is such a thing as too much screening. And she made a powerful argument that the Komen Foundations pink-ribbon awareness campaign is a big part of the problem. She also wrote insightfully about how difficult it is not to have a mammogram even if the science tells us that isnt helpful.

title: Desperate Times Call for Her
description: Cate Blanchett has played Blanche DuBois, the Queen of England (twice), Katharine Hepburn and all manner of elegant yet troubled heroines. But to portray Jasmine French, the socialite on a swift and bumpy fall from rank, and grace, in Blue Jasmine, she looked to Richard II for inspiration.

title: Costass Pinkeye Keeps Him Away Another Day at the Olympics
description: The viral infection in Bob Costass eyes did not clear up enough for him return on Wednesday to host the Winter Olympic broadcasts from Sochi, Russia, keeping Matt Lauer in the anchor seat while he co-hosts the Today show.

title: Wheelies: The Half-Baked Jeep Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Times Minute | Derek Jeter to Retire
description: In the Video

title: Times Minute | Derek Jeter to Retire
description: The Yankees shortstop announces that the 2014 season will be his last. Also on the Minute, the U.N. evacuates Homs and a sinkhole swallows eight sports cars at the National Corvette Museum.

title: London Auction Houses See High Prices for Contemporary Art
description: LONDON  Last week Sothebys and Christies proved that Impressionist and modern art hasnt lost its luster, with a still life by Juan Gris fetching $56.7 million and a dreamy cityscape by Pissarro bringing $32 million.

title: The Deficit on the Milk Carton
description: Has anyone noticed what were not talking about? I mean, really not at all? The budget deficit. After all those years when deficit scolds completely dominated the conversation, when Fix the Committee for a Responsible Debt Coalition were, if you listened to the press, the source of all that was good and noble and BowlesSimpsonish, quite suddenly the whole thing has dropped off the agenda.

title: Blackstones Burger and Beer Night for Charity
description: High-flying financiers from the Blackstone Group would normally frequent power lunch spaces like the Four Seasons restaurant in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Beyond the Runway
description: Although New York Fashion Week officially begins on a Thursday (and, unofficially, days earlier than that), Saturday is the day when the full force of the event begins to take its toll.

title: Court Challenge on Bond Buying Poses Test for Central Bank, and for E.U.
description: FRANKFURT  Courts are normally supposed to resolve disputes. But a decision last week by the Federal Constitutional Court in Germany has raised more questions than it has answered about the legality of a financial weapon that many analysts say saved the euro in its darkest hour  without even firing a shot.

title: The Bright Side of the New Bulbs
description: A look at whats replacing the old incandescent and compact fluorescent bulbs.

title: For Skater Jason Brown, a Disciplined Approach Yields Joy on Ice
description: SOCHI, Russia  Many of the fans in TD Garden were on their feet before Jason Brown finished his free program at the United States figure skating championships last month in Boston.

title: Sinkhole Beneath National Corvette Museum Devours 8 Cars
description: A huge sinkhole opened up early Wednesday at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., swallowing eight rare and notable versions of the Chevrolet sports car.

title: Skin Deep: Runway Maximal
description: Follow these steps to recreate Rodarte's runway look at home.

title: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from New York Fashion Week.

title: Reed Krakoff: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: The Winter Olympics Gear Guide
description: The gear behind the sports of the Winter Games.

title: After Changes, Banking Group Drops Suit Against Volcker Rule
description: The American Bankers Association announced on Wednesday that it was dropping its lawsuit to block parts of the Volcker Rule from going into effect after regulators modified what the group found most objectionable.

title: Dental Group Advises Fluoride Toothpaste Before Age 2
description: Parents should use a tiny smear of fluoride toothpaste to brush baby teeth twice daily as soon as they erupt, instead of waiting until children are older, according to new guidelines by the American Dental Association.

title: Should I Have a Mammogram, or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Fashion Week: Michael Kors Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Olivia Locher.

title: Pregnancy Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Warnings of Ethnic Cleansing in Central African Republic
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Tens of thousands of Muslims are being forced by Christian militias to flee the Central African Republic in what human rights groups and a top United Nations official characterized on Wednesday as de facto ethnic cleansing.

title: The Only Witches Brew Here Is the Beer
description: On a frigid evening in early January, 20-something hipster women of a boyish sartorial bent filled the Tandem Bar in outer Bushwick, Brooklyn, tall Narragansett beer cans in tow, sporting lots of arm-sleeve tattoos, knit stocking caps and their fair share of Theda Bara-esque kohl-rimmed eyes and blood-red lips. Several of them wore black football jerseys whose backs read WITCHES 13. (The number required for a coven.)

title: Mayday Calls at the Navy Yard
description: The howls of anguish could be heard all the way to Manhattan. On Saturday night, as the fashion flock headed out in their town cars to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the unlikely and inconvenient space that Alexander Wang, above, had chosen to show his fall 2014 collection, New York Fashion Week entered its gridlock phase. Streets were packed, drivers got lost, anxiety mounted about missing the start time and Uber bills skyrocketed. If misery loves company, then Twitter was the place to be that night.

title: Endangered Post Offices, on Main Street, U.S.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea a Priority as Kerry Begins Asia Tour
description: ELMENDORF AIR FORCE BASE, Alaska  Secretary of State John Kerry headed to Asia on Wednesday to seek Chinas help to try to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program.

title: A Friendly Gesture to Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: The Doodles in a Book
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little of This or a Lot of That
description: Runway beauty looks, usually concocted with some alien She-Ra in mind, are hard to translate into trends relatable to the average Jane. But this Fashion Week, a clear divide appeared between minimalist and maximalist makeup. Herein, experts who applied it explain how to attempt the same thing at home (if you dare).

title: Beauty for Valentines Day
description: Better than bonbons: some pampering Valentines Day gift ideas.

title: Basking in a New Glow
description: If you havent noticed the virtual disappearance of old-school incandescent bulbs from retailers shelves, theres good reason.

title: A Big Step Closer to Nutritional Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Even a Stationery Logo Pits Palestinians Against Israel
description: JERUSALEM  The latest skirmish between Israel and the Palestinian Authority does not concern settlements or refugees, but stationery.

title: At Reed Krakoff, Vivid Blue Sandals With a Plush Touch
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Night Stands: Snooze but Dont Lose
description: At nearly three feet wide, the Ico Parisi cabinets at Bernd Goecklers antiques store in the East Village were much too big to be night stands. That was this reporters opinion, anyway. Barry Goralnick, an architect who has designed lighting for Visual Comfort, carpets for Starck and furnishings for Ferrell & Mittman, disagreed.

title: A Marriage of Convenience
description: In 1999, Antony and Richard Joseph, twin industrial designers, were asked to update a part of their familys 63-year-old British housewares business. Four years later, they created their own company, Joseph Joseph, which produces smartly functional items for the home like colorful stacking mixing bowls with integrated measuring cups. Their Nest containers, shown at the New York Now design show last week, tackle the problem of storage boxes that hog precious space when not in use. Whereas lids and bases often need to be stored separately, turning matchups into a problem, this design efficiently packs together bases and lids for up to six sizes of containers; color-coding makes the pairings foolproof. The containers are airtight and microwave-, freezer- and dishwasher-safe. A 12-piece set (6 containers, 6 lids) is $35, and an 8-piece set (4 containers, 4 lids) is $25. Information: 917-338-0900, or josephjoseph.com.

title: Nature Woven in Silk
description: Rocio Moreno, a Spanish interior and product designer, works with artisans in northern India who hand-weave silk brocades in brilliant colors. Her newest collection includes Orissa, a wall hanging that depicts a stylized tree and takes the former name of a state in India. Orissa ($1,795), seen in magenta on green, is 29.5 inches wide by 79 inches long and available by special order from Barneys. To complement the garden theme, Ms. Moreno pored through a collection of natural history books for images of insects, which inspired two cushions, Mantis and Moth. Mantis ($365) is 24 inches square, and Moth ($350) is 20 by 24 inches. Both will be available in turquoise or orange at Barneys in late March. All three designs can be ordered in advance. Information: 212-450-8454 or rociomorenotextiles.com.

title: Child-Proof Minimalism
description: A couple chooses a one-room suburban life with two young children. And their toys.

title: The Anti-McMansion
description: Living in a one-room house with an ultra-minimalist aesthetic and two small children sounds more like the setup for a joke than something any reasonably sane person would attempt.

title: Marchesa: Fall 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: The New Domestics
description: Dylan Leonard Brown is all of 30, with a masters in psychology and an expansive rsum that includes three years working as an estate manager for a former ambassador and overseeing a household staff of 12, along with three properties, one yacht, numerous automobiles and a multimillion dollar annual budget. Mr. Brown also planned around 100 events every year, including a three-day colloquium on human trafficking and an orchestral concert. (The ambassador was an amateur composer, so Mr. Brown hired an orchestra and choir, auditioned soloists and hired street canvassers to hand out fliers at the Gay Pride Parade in Boston to drum up interest.)

title: Table Manners at Work
description: Clive Wilkinson, a 59-year-old architect, has designed attention-getting offices for TBWA\Chiat\Day and Google, and now he has done one for the Barbarian Group, an Internet advertising company in New York. Its centerpiece is the endless table, a 1,100-foot-long surface that snakes around the 23,000-square-foot office, providing work space for all 125 employees, including the chairman, Benjamin Palmer. The $300,000 table, which was installed last month, forms seven archways leading to conference rooms, a video screening room and restrooms. In our last office, there were separate offices, and people had to hunt people down, Mr. Palmer said, adding that now he is seeing more people than I have in years.

title: 2 U.S.-Led Coalition Soldiers Are Killed by Attackers in Afghan Uniforms
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two people wearing Afghan security forces uniforms opened fire on American-led coalition soldiers in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, killing two of the soldiers, officials said.

title: Hot 97s Owner in Deal for 2 Other Stations
description: In a deal that will align some of New Yorks most popular radio stations specializing in black music, the owner of WQHT-FM  the hip-hop station better known as Hot 97  is buying WBLS-FM and one other station for $131 million in cash.

title: Modernisms Giant Showcase
description: The dealers who attend the Palm Springs Modernism Show and Sale must luxuriate in their home-field advantage: With its copious midcentury architecture, the city is one big ad for their wares. This years show, which is timed to Modernism Week and begins Friday, is the largest in its 14 years. More than 85 exhibitors will be selling furniture, jewelry, pottery, textiles and other items representative of 20th-century design, like a welded steel sculpture by Paul Kasper ($14,000, from Fat ChanceLos Angeles) and a signed lithograph by Alexander Calder ($3,150, from Palette Contemporary Art & Craft).

title: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Ballard Designs and Others
description: A blanket and a pillow are on sale at Brookstone, while supplies last (the Nap throw blanket, regularly about $40, is about $15; the FOM fun pillow, regularly about $20, is about $15); 30 Rockefeller Plaza (Fifth Avenue), concourse level, 212-489-3234, brookstone.com.

title: Furniture with a Magic Touch
description: Man Machine, which opens Thursday at Galerie Kreo in Paris, features nine limited-edition furniture pieces by Konstantin Grcic made of window plate glass. Glass is seen as fragile, and sometimes its scary, said Mr. Grcic. To make it dynamic as well, he has worked gas pistons into the designs: The reclining chair adjusts as a car seat would; the dining table glides up to standing height, and the crate can be opened with a pinkie.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,294 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Facing Questions on Future, Cisco Posts a Revenue Drop
description: Changes in the technology business are hurting Cisco Systems, and so far its chief executive, John Chambers, hasnt shown Wall Street many numbers that say his recovery strategy is working.

title: Prices Skyrocket for Tickets to See Jeters Last Games
description: When Derek Jeter announced on Facebook on Wednesday that the 2014 season would be his last, fans fled to social media to express their reactions. More enterprising enthusiasts, though, rushed immediately to their computers for a different purpose  to scoop up tickets to games in late September at Yankee Stadium.

title: Taking the Bite Out of Winter With a Crisp White Shirt
description: If you are eager to take the leap into spring (and who isnt at this point?), a crisp and tailored cotton shirt is the easiest way to get a jump on the season. When indulging in trends, its always a plus to go with the classics, and the shirts now in the shops are easygoing tweaks on traditional tailoring. Among them, some shown in this sampling, are shirts covered in fringe (Junya Watanabe), cut with capelike backs (Margiela, Balenciaga) and accented with romantic needlework and lace (Carven, Chlo, Christopher Kane). While we are still in throes of winter, wear with wool pinstripe trousers and an oversize mannish coat; or, as Diane Kruger did at Sundance last month (above right), with a knee-length skirt and printed parka. When the days warm up, try with a sexy slit skirt  very Altuzarra.

title: G.L.O.W. by y Cathy Park Hong.
description: A reading of the poem by Cathy Park Hong.

title: Embracing the Struggle
description: Look, sometimes a cape is just a cape. When the first model hit the runway at the Public School show, he wore a wide-brimmed hat and a wool cape, beautifully cut, that suggested papal vestments and Amish rigor. Paired with a washed-out plaid shirt, it was structure and swagger in one.

title: Live Stream | Proenza Schoulers Fall 2014 Collection at New York Fashion Week
description: The latest womens collection from Proenza Schouler at New York Fashion Week.

title: Part of Kentucky Marriage Law Overturned
description: A federal judge in Kentucky on Wednesday struck down a portion of the states constitutional ban on same-sex marriage, ruling that Kentucky must recognize marriages that have been performed legally in other states.

title: Dont Sell Cheap U.S. Coal to Asia
description: EASTSOUND, Wash.  FROM where I live on Orcas Island in Puget Sound, north of Seattle, I can see Cherry Point across the wind-whipped waters of the Salish Sea. This sandy promontory jutting into Georgia Strait has become the focus of heated debate here in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Vows of Love
description: Our nine favorite videos about love.

title: Italian Premiers Latest Challenge Comes From His Own Party
description: ROME  Like a piata that has been battered but remains unbroken, Enrico Letta has demonstrated an unexpected resilience as Italys prime minister. He took office in April amid predictions that his coalition government would quickly collapse. It did not. Then Silvio Berlusconi, the powerful former prime minister, vowed to bring him down. That did not happen, either.

title: An Unexpected End to the Oscar de la Renta Show
description: Urban nightmare, meet fashion emergency.

title: Opposition Outlines Plans for a Future Syria
description: During a second round of peace talks in Geneva, Syrias opposition presented its most detailed plan yet for a transition, but it did not mention removing President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Maggie Estep, Who Brought Slam Poetry to TV, Dies at 50
description: Maggie Estep, a novelist and spoken-word poet who helped popularize slam poetry on MTV, HBO and PBS in the 1990s, died on Wednesday in Albany. She was 50.

title: When Emily Was Sold for Sex
description: BOSTON  Emily, a 15-year-old ninth-grader, ran away from home in early November, and her parents are sitting at their dining table, frightened and inconsolable.

title: Events and Sales Starting the Week of Feb. 13
description: Valentines Day

title: Making College Pay
description: It seems logical: College graduates have lower unemployment and earn more than less educated workers, so, the thinking goes, the fix for todays anemic growth in jobs and wages is to make sure that more people earn college degrees. But thats a common misperception, deflecting attention from the serious work that has to be done to create jobs and improve incomes.

title: Laying the Lox on Thick, a Dating Site Focuses on Jewish Humor
description: AMONG married Jews, the intermarriage rate of those wed since 2000 is 58 percent, well above the rate of those wed before 1970, when just 17 percent tied the knot with non-Jews, according to a 2013 survey by the Pew Research Centers Religion & Public Life Project. Now the Jewish dating website JDate is introducing an advertising campaign that hopes to help buck the trend, with ads that may strike a chord with Jews but leave others scratching their heads.

title: Derek Jeters Two Decades of Excellence
description: Jeter has earned awards, acclaim and championships in his 19 full seasons with the Yankees.

title: Trimmings NYFW, Day 6
description: From fur-lined muffs to iridescent sunglasses, these are the standout accessories from Marc by Marc Jacobs, Tory Burch, Rodarte and more.

title: Also Cheering at the Olympics: Russian Critics
description: SOCHI, Russia  If anyone has a right to resent the Sochi Olympics, it is Andrei Martynov, whose house was seized by the Russian authorities and then demolished without compensation to clear land near the hockey arena where Russia will play Slovenia on Thursday.

title: Trade Dispute Centers on Ukrainian Executive With Ties to Clintons
description: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have built a sprawling network of powerful friends around the globe, one that could aid Mrs. Clintons chances were she to seek the presidency. But those relationships often come with intersecting interests and political complications; few people illustrate that more vividly than the Ukrainian oligarch Victor Pinchuk.

title: The Number Cisco Left Out
description: Changes in the technology business are hurting Cisco Systems, and so far its chief executive, John Chambers, hasnt shown Wall Street many numbers that say his recovery strategy is working.

title: Jared Leto at Jeremy Scott
description: For those who enjoy a good fashion spectacle, the showman Jeremy Scott lived up to expectations. On the runway, male and female models wore football-inspired pieces as if from a Super Bowl gone mad, while the front row was a lurid scene, including the ubiquitous Joe Jonas, in his usual black jacket; Kat Graham, in a red snakeskin harness crop top and matching bondage-style skirt (Ive been wearing Jeremys crop tops since I was 16, she said); and a nearly late Jared Leto, who shouted to the crowd: My apologies! You all look fabulous. It turns out Mr. Leto, who had dressed for the gelid weather in a roomy parka and a flannel around his waist, was only in the city briefly.

title: U.N. Report Says Progress for Women Is Unequal
description: UNITED NATIONS  Twenty years after a landmark United Nations summit meeting in Cairo called on countries around the world to allow women greater control over their health and destiny, women worldwide have fewer children, are less likely to die of childbirth and have made great strides in literacy, according to a major report released Wednesday by the world body.

title: For de Blasio, No Magic Lost in Budget Draft
description: Our new mayor can sound much taken with himself. He talks so insistently of progressive values, policies and appointees that Im convinced someday soon he will unveil his progressive gone-to-lunch stroll. (Long-loping, left-leaning strides?)

title: Weapon in Slaying of Florida Teenager Figures Again in Court
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  As Michael Dunn, the man accused of shooting a teenager to death during a dispute over loud music, sat stone-faced, a prosecutor hammered away on Wednesday at his self-defense claim, arguing that the teenager never pointed a weapon at Mr. Dunn.

title: Thomas Speaks ... Blindly About Race
description: Associate Justice Clarence Thomas doesnt often speak during oral arguments before the Supreme Court.

title: Why Team G.B. Needs Scotland
description: Much of the debate over Scottish independence has focused on whether the Scots would be better off in or out of the United Kingdom. With the Sept. 18 Scottish referendum now only seven months off, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has raised another critical question: Would Britain be better off without Scotland?

title: Jeters Retirement Announcement Hits the Right Note
description: This retirement is so Derek Jeter. So smooth, so efficient, so convenient for all concerned.

title: Mr. de Blasios Welcoming Gesture
description: Creating a citywide identification card for people who cant get drivers licenses  unauthorized immigrants, mostly  sounds like a modest, well-meaning, good-government initiative that is part practical, part symbolic. Cities like New Haven and San Francisco have already done it. Bringing such an innovation to New York City, as Mayor Bill de Blasio proposed on Monday, would be a big deal.

title: We Need Proof on Marijuana
description: MANY people have heard the story of Charlotte Figi, a young girl from Colorado with severe epilepsy. After her parents began giving her a marijuana strain rich in cannabidiol (CBD), the major nonpsychoactive ingredient in marijuana, Charlotte reportedly went from having hundreds of seizures per week to only two or three per month. Previously, her illness, Dravet Syndrome, was a daily torture despite multiple high doses of powerful anti-seizure drugs.

title: Escaped Inmates From Iraq Fuel Syrian Insurgency
description: BAGHDAD  A series of daring but little noticed breakouts from Iraqi prisons has freed hundreds of hardened militants who are now among the leaders and foot soldiers of the radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and, increasingly, in Iraq itself.

title: Ending Gay Conversion for Good
description: NEW HAVEN  THERAPY programs that purport to convert lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender kids have caused immeasurable harm since they became prominent in the 1970s. Rigorous studies have shown again and again that efforts to change young peoples sexual orientation not only fail, but are also linked to suicidal behavior, depression, anxiety, drug use and risky sexual behavior.

title: Derek Jeter Lived a Dream, and Never Disappointed
description: The greatest compliment we can give Derek Jeter, as he prepares to leave the grandest stage in baseball, is that he never let us down. He has made thousands of outs and hundreds of errors and finished most of his seasons without a championship. Yet he never disappointed us.

title: Over 1 Million Added to Rolls of Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON  More than 1.1 million people signed up for health insurance through federal and state marketplaces in January, according to the government, and the number of young people enrolling increased faster than that of any other group.

title: Doug Mohns, N.H.L. All-Star Who Played for 22 Seasons, Dies at 80
description: Doug Mohns, a durable and versatile skater who lasted 22 seasons in the National Hockey League, playing in seven All-Star Games, died on Feb. 7 in Reading, Mass. He was 80.

title: Is Keystone Worth the Fight?
Reports of South Sudan Fighting, Despite Pact, Prompt Worry and Warnings
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The ranks of displaced people have swelled to nearly 900,000, close to a tenth of the entire population. Humanitarian groups warn that millions could go hungry if fields remain unplowed before the coming rainy season. Aid workers themselves are on the run, hiding ever deeper in the bush to escape attack.

title: Call if Youre Feeling Lonely
description: When I lived in New York after college, I suffered from depression and insomnia. So I volunteered for a 24-hour suicide prevention hotline.

title: Fusion Advance Demonstrates Value of Long-Haul Energy Research
description: Some readers may recall a pair of 2012 posts weighing the value of seemingly never-ending research on fusion as a source of usable energy: In Defense of Sustained Research on Fusion and With Tight Research Budgets, Is There Room for the Eternal Promise of Fusion?

title: Obama and Jordans King Take Visit on the Road
description: WASHINGTON  King Abdullah II of Jordan is visiting Washington this week, making the rounds at the State Department, the Pentagon and on Capitol Hill. President Obama is in town, too, playing host to the French president, signing an executive order on wages and getting briefed on a snowstorm bearing down on the East Coast.

title: Debate Over de Blasio Call on Bishops Arrest
description: When a teacher at his daughters school was arrested at a political protest, Bill de Blasio, then a New York City councilman, pleaded with the district attorney not to seek jail time, then wrote to the judge to request leniency. Mr. de Blasio would frequently call the local police precinct to inquire about crime reports.

description: WASHINGTON  After the shutdown, the filibusters and years of stalled bills, it was the actual passage of legislation this week that revealed the true depth of congressional dysfunction.

Boyland Jr., who is on trial on corruption charges.

description: WASHINGTON  The snowy owl that was hit by a bus and a sport utility vehicle here two weeks ago has been moved to a rehabilitation clinic to complete its treatment, the City Wildlife group said this week.

title: In Jeters Impressive Rsum, One Thing Is Lacking
description: From his earliest days in pinstripes, Derek Jeter inspired fierce debate. Among any group of fans you could find those who believed he was the best player in the game and others who considered him a liability  at least in the field.
