description: In the spring 2014 womens fashion issue, T looks at the way women really want to dress. Our cover subject is the cult fashion-designer Phoebe Philo, whose quiet, understated designs for Cline give new meaning to the term power dressing  and are coveted by some of the smartest, savviest women out there. In our Sign of the Times essay, Cathy Horyn examines the divide between what women actually want to wear  beautiful clothes that they feel good in  and the tricked-out, challenging get-ups that come down the runway. We also celebrate three women who insist on doing things their way: the designer Maria Cornejo, whose art-inspired designs stay true to her singular vision; the up-and-coming singer Kelela, who is finding her voice somewhere between electronic music and old-school R&B; and the Fiat heiress Ginevra Elkann, who juggles duties as a film producer, art museum boss and mother while building a legacy  and a home  that goes beyond her famous name. Additional highlights include a behind-the-scenes look at Matthew Barneys epic new art film; a pair of New York icons, Elaine Stritch and Chlo Sevigny, tune in to the latest rap music; and five prominent novelists  Colson Whitehead, Douglas Coupland, Mona Simpson, Joyce Carol Oates and Roddy Doyle  invite us into the spaces where they created their latest works. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Efforts to Mark Turf When Snowstorms Hit Endure Despite Critics
description: BOSTON  It is a time-honored winter tradition here: Shovel out your car, and guard your newly cleared parking spot with whatever you have handy  a traffic cone, a potted plant, a bust of Elvis.

title: As Services Expand, Cable Bills Keep Rising
description: WASHINGTON  Of the many benefits that Comcast executives said would flow to consumers from its proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable  more innovation, advanced technology, improved service  the one it did not mention is probably the one consumers care about most: their cable bills.

title: De Blasios Vow to End Traffic Deaths Meets Reality of New York Streets
description: The announcement was bold, if somewhat quixotic: Mayor Bill de Blasio, whose campaign was focused on reforming the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk tactics, would commit his administration to reducing traffic deaths literally to zero.

title: Disgraced Scientist Granted U.S. Patent for Work Found to be Fraudulent
description: Korean researcher Hwang Woo-suk electrified the science world 10 years ago with his claim that he had created the worlds first cloned human embryos and had extracted stem cells from them. But the work was later found to be fraudulent, and Dr. Hwang was fired from his university and convicted of crimes.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: A bad winter for travelers, a submersible computer and a dispute over exporting oil from the United States.

title: A Steady Path to Supreme Court as Gay Marriage Gains Momentum in States
description: WASHINGTON  A sweeping decision on Thursday night struck down Virginias ban on same-sex marriage and continued a remarkable winning streak for gay rights advocates, putting new pressure on the Supreme Court to decide the momentous question it ducked last summer: whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

title: Medicines Made in India Set Off Safety Worries
description: NEW DELHI  India, the second-largest exporter of over-the-counter and prescription drugs to the United States, is coming under increased scrutiny by American regulators for safety lapses, falsified drug test results and selling fake medicines.

title: Innovation, Optimism and Jobs
description: Is digital technology destroying middle-class jobs? Does it exacerbate income inequality? Does it boost economic growth and productivity  without creating the jobs that ought to come with economic growth?

title: If You Shovel It, Its Yours? Not so Fast
description: The neighborhood of South End wants to ban the practice of space saving: shoveling out a parking spot and then leaving anything from a chair to a laundry basket to reserve it.

title: The Common Core in New York
description: The new Common Core learning standards, which set ambitious goals for what students should learn from one year to the next, are desperately needed in New York, where only about a third of high school students graduate with the math and English skills necessary to succeed at college. But the standards, adopted in 2010, have had a bumpy rollout and are under siege from several constituencies.

title: Making Retirements Less Secure
description: The chief executive of AOL, Tim Armstrong, was roundly criticized for wrongly connecting the expensive health problems of two babies born to his employees and the health care reform law to the companys rising health care costs. He eventually apologized for those remarks. Just as wrongheaded was his plan to deal with higher costs by changing the way the company contributes to retirement accounts.

title: No Evidence of Coffee Break on Mars
description: Scientists did not find a Dunkin Donuts on Mars, but they did figure out where a rock that looks like a small jelly doughnut came from. Last month, the rock, about an inch and a half wide, showed up in one of the photographs taken by the NASAs Opportunity rover. In addition to the unusual appearance, it had not been there when Opportunity photographed the same spot on the Martian landscape less than two weeks earlier. A new photograph shows an overturned rock with a similar dark red center and white surface about a yard away. The jelly doughnut piece, named Pinnacle Island, broke off and rolled downhill when the rover drove over it in early January, scientists working on the mission said Friday.

title: 2 Companies to Destroy Chemicals in Syrias Arsenal
description: Two hazardous-waste disposal companies, based in the United States and Finland, have been selected to help incinerate the chemicals in Syrias weapons arsenal, the organization responsible for overseeing the destruction announced on Friday, as new worries emerged about possible Syrian procrastination in exporting the 1,200-ton stockpile.

title: Next Move on Press Freedom
description: Last July, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. spoke eloquently of the importance of the constitutionally protected news gathering process, the essential role of a free press when it comes to government accountability and an open society, and the need to better protect journalists from federal leak investigations.

title: New York Tries to Rid Its Sewers of FOG (Fat, Oil and Grease)
description: Out of sight of most New Yorkers is a sprawling underground labyrinth of about 7,500 miles of sewers, part of the citys vast and, in many cases, aging subterranean infrastructure. Besides old age, the sewers, which are essential to the health of the city, are under assault from a nemesis above ground: grease.

title: Time for N.F.L. Sponsors to Demand Change
description: You know those funny Campbell Soup ads starring N.F.L. players and their mothers? The ones where moms pop up in locker rooms and on fields to bring their sons bowls of steaming Chunky soup?

title: Where to Read a Plot Summary
description: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! If you havent already signed up for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, running from March 7 through March 9 in Brooklyn, New York  and why not? You can play along at home too, you know  you can still register here. Feeling shy? Dont know anyone who will be there? Pish tosh. Sign up for the annual Cru dinner (click the first link to register) and meet your tribe: friendly folk who love crossword puzzles almost as much as you do.

title: A Friend in Need, or Merely a Swindler
description: She was approached by a male and a female, the police captain explained. Very well dressed. Late 40s, early 50s.

title: Volkswagen Vote Is Defeat for Labor in South
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  In a defeat for organized labor in the South, employees at the Volkswagen plant here voted 712 to 626 against joining the United Automobile Workers.

title: South China Sea Tensions a Backdrop to Kerrys China Visit
description: North Korea and bilateral relations between the United States and China are dominating Secretary of State John Kerrys visit to East Asia this week, but tensions continue to simmer in the South China Sea as well.

title: Genevieve Bell on Furby vs. Siri
description: During a lecture at Stanford University, Ms. Bell, an anthropologist at Intel Labs, compared the Furby toy with Siri, Apples personal assistant.

title: A Newscast Unveiled by Cuomo, for Cuomo
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is often unhappy about the news coverage of his administration. So now his administration is starting to cover itself.

title: Dining Outside in Little Italy: Im Starting to Miss My Mouth
description: Even in the dead of winter, Mulberry Street in Little Italy does its best to look festive. The lights glow. Open-armed hosts in restaurant doorways greet prospective diners.

title: Flips and Spins in Sochi and on Mammograms
description: It was a week of grand spectacles that would have made Julius Bread and Circuses Caesar proud. There were the Sochi Games, of course, a festival of sports both familiar and arcane, many set against the stunning white peaks of the Caucasus. And there was the state dinner on the South Lawn of the White House for President Franois Hollande of France, so rich in pomp and gossip that it was easy to forget that the host was a liberal and the guest a socialist, and that both their countries were forged in revolution.

title: After Storm, 100% Attendance Is Not 100% Accurate
description: On a day when more than half of the citys students were marked absent, three public schools reported 100 percent attendance on Thursday, a seemingly miraculous feat in the face of all the ice and snow.

title: Jeters Decision Makes Things Easier for Girardi and Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Derek Jeter announced Wednesday that 2014 would be his final year in baseball, it probably removed a burden from the Yankees, particularly from Manager Joe Girardi.

title: Legislator Up for Re-election Wants to Delay Bribery Trial
description: State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, who has been charged in a plot to bribe his way onto the ballot to run for mayor of New York City, asked a judge recently to delay his corruption trial for a very practical reason: It would interfere with his re-election campaign.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 14, 2014
Jim Fregosi, All-Star, Dies at 71; Angel Was Traded for Nolan Ryan
description: Jim Fregosi, a baseball lifer who made six All-Star teams as a player and managed the 1993 Philadelphia Phillies to the National League pennant, but who is probably best known  by New Yorkers, at least  as the player the Mets received from the California Angels in exchange for the future Hall of Fame pitcher Nolan Ryan in one of baseballs more infamous trades, died Friday in Miami. He was 71.

title: Alice Babs, Who Sang for Ellington, Dies at 90
description: Alice Babs, a Swedish singer acclaimed for her work with Duke Ellington, died on Tuesday in Stockholm. She was 90.

title: Curtain Call | New York Fashion Week
description: To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of some fashion visionaries.

title: It May Be a Nonprofit Theater, but the Tickets Look For-Profit
description: New Yorks nonprofit theaters are acting more like for-profits, and theres no greater sign than the return of Cabaret at Roundabout Theater Company.

title: Obama Promises New Aid to Jordan in Refugee Crisis
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  President Obama announced during a meeting here Friday night with King Abdullah II of Jordan that he would seek to renew a five-year aid package to help Jordan bear the burden of the more than 600,000 Syrian refugees who have fled the civil war there.

title: Filipino Figure Skater Is Happy Just Being in Sochi
description: SOCHI, Russia  Michael Christian Martinez did not win a medal at the mens singles competition at the Iceberg Skating Palace. His 19th-place finish was marked by trips and tossups.

title: Sweet, Slushy Valentine
Corrections: February 15, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: What to Watch at the Olympics: Saturday
description: HOCKEY It may not be the Miracle on Ice  this game is merely about positioning for the medal round  but United States versus Russia seems worthy of setting an early-morning alarm. The Czech Republic then faces Switzerland in a noon game. They split their first two games and trail Sweden (2-0) in Group C. NBCSN, 7:30 a.m.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (CBS) 48 HOURS PRESENTS: THE WHOLE GRITTY CITY Wynton Marsalis hosts this documentary, in which the filmmakers Richard Barber and Andre Lambertson follow five students in New Orleans marching bands whose directors, while preparing them to perform in Mardi Gras parades, have also instilled survival lessons in a city with one of the highest murder rates in the country. The students have all lost someone close to them. This is the street I dont like, because it has guns, says Jaron Williams, 11, not far from where his 19-year-old brother was shot to death. I cried the whole day. I couldnt get him out of my head. Then Jaron, above, joined the Roots of Music, a free music education program for middle schoolers, and learned to play the trumpet, earning his way into the Marching Crusaders  and a parade. I feel like Im the best thing in the world and I cant be stopped, he says. Its the power of the music, Wilbert Rawlins Jr., one of the featured band directors ,maintains. I dont care if you just had something very tragic that happened to you in your life, he says. Once that band gives you that downbeat, and that music is right, and its powerful  just for that brief two or three minutes, you forget everything, every problem you had. You have no cares in the world.

title: As Austrians Prevail, American Skiers Falter
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The ski racing rivalry between Austria and the United States has been less than subtle at times in the last eight years.

title: Oshie Lifts U.S. Over Russia in Hockey Shootout
description: The United States defeated Russia, 3-2, in a shootout in mens hockey at the Sochi Olympics.

title: A List of Favorites From a Man Who Knows His Apps
description: Some people have a friend that can recommend the hottest new music album or latest and greatest upcoming television show. My friend Michael Galpert is my go-to person for the most obscure and often most useful apps that would otherwise be lost to me amid the million-plus options in the App Store.

title: Curtain Call | The Designers of New York Fashion Week Take Their Bows
description: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of New York Fashion Week, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 19 fashion visionaries.

title: Suit Change Does Not Matter as U.S. Misses Podium Again
description: SOCHI, Russia  Zbigniew Brodka of Poland won the mens 1,500-meter speedskating event here Saturday, but the continuing story at Adler Arena was the Americans baffling performances. The United States team includes world-record holders and Olympic and world champions. Yet Americans won none of the first 21 speedskating medals at the Sochi Games.

title: Monopsony Begets Monopoly, And Vice Versa
description: Nothing to see here, folks, says Comcast. The cable giants defenders insist that its already awesome market power wont be increased if it acquires Time Warner, because they serve (i.e., are local monopolists in) different geographical areas:

title: Whats Happening Off the Runway During London Fashion Week
description: London Fashion Week has begun, and out-of-towners and locals alike are making their final preparations for another season of back-to-back shows and star-studded events. Here, a guide to surviving (and enjoying) the festivities.

title: Mentally Ill Inmates
description: Responses to Nicholas Kristofs column about how jails have become mental hospitals.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Feb. 16
description: A clean debt ceiling is a complete capitulation on the speakers part.

title: The Case for Swapping Roles With China
description: Stephen Roach proposes to remake the two largest economies on the globe, ours and Chinas. For decades, he writes, the United States and China relied too much on a marriage of convenience that guaranteed China a huge market for its exports. In exchange, China gave American consumers a cornucopia of inexpensive products, while creating a willing buyer of the United States governments swollen debt. But that marriage has played out, Mr. Roach says; it has warped the two economies, leaving them ill-equipped for further growth.

title: Patrolling a Bruised City
Drama, if Not Miracle, as U.S. Beats Russia
description: SOCHI, Russia  Every member of the United States mens hockey team playing in the Sochi Games was born after the Americans shocking victory at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y., against a Soviet team stocked with stars. Four times since that Miracle on Ice, the teams had met in Olympic competition, with the Americans compiling a 1-2-1 record, but none of the games were on Russian soil.

title: Small Business, Joining a Parade of Outsourcing
description: Going abroad for cheap labor isnt just for big businesses anymore. Thanks to the rise of online job marketplaces, small businesses are increasingly using foreign contract workers to lower their costs.

title: Expedited Service, Except When Its Not
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: Where the Fish Swims, Ideas Fly
description: When I was in Reykjavik, Iceland, last summer on vacation, a peculiar object in a local design store caught my eye. It was a cod that had been turned into a light.

title: At the Ready, at the Sochi Games
description: In January 2008, an American skier named Brett Buckles flew 10 feet into the air during a training run in the village of Tignes, France. Instead of landing gingerly on her skis, she came down with a thud 40 feet down the course and was knocked unconscious. Later, at a small local hospital, she learned that she had broken her pelvis in two places, fractured her sacrum, sustained a severe concussion and torn the labrum in her right shoulder.

title: An About-Face for the Stock Markets 5-Year Return
description: Take the long view. Thats standard advice in investing, and it makes sense. After all, if youve salted money away for a serious purpose like retiring or buying a house or paying for a childs education, you really dont want to focus on how the stock market has done today or on what it might do tomorrow. You need a longer perspective.

title: Microfoundations and Mephistopheles (Wonkish)
description: Simon Wren-Lewis asks whether New Keynesians made a Faustian bargain by accepting the New Classical dictat that models must be grounded in intertemporal optimization  whether they purchased academic respectability at the expense of losing their ability to grapple usefully with the real world.

title: Yes, the Wealthy Can Be Deserving
description: In 2012, the actor Robert Downey Jr., played the role of Tony Stark, a.k.a. Iron Man, in The Avengers. For his work in that single film, Mr. Downey was paid an astounding $50 million.

title: A Great Teammate Is a Great Listener
description: This interview with  John W. Rogers Jr., chairman, chief executive and chief investment officer of Ariel Investments, based in Chicago, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Untouchable Profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: Would you buy stock in a company that barred you from sharing in its future earnings? Of course not. Participating in the upside is what stock ownership is all about.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: What to Watch: Sunday
description: ALPINE SKIING It has been a rough Olympics so far for the stars of mens skiing. Aksel Lund Svindal, Bode Miller and Ted Ligety are without medals entering Sundays super-G. Svindal won the event at Vancouver. NBC, 7 p.m.

title: Comcast vs. the Cord Cutters
description: The typical American household pays about $90 a month for cable television service, according to the NPD Group, the market research firm. But according to the research firm of You and Pretty Much Everyone You Know, when you click on your TV and browse the guide, what you often find hardly seems worth $90 a month.

title: Variety: A Philosophical Diagramless
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  From 2005 to 2008, Nickelodeon broadcast an Asian-influenced animated series called Avatar: The Last Airbender, which my children watched fanatically, and which they insist was mangled as a live-action film in 2010. (The sequel, The Legend of Korra, is still in production.) In this series, some people are able to manipulate the classic ELEMENTs of FIRE, AIR, WATER and EARTH by bending them.

title: Coveted Player to Train With U.S. Team
description: Julian Green, a young, promising player for Bayern Munich, will train with the United States national team for two days before the Americans travel to Ukraine for an international friendly match on March 5.

title: Creighton Is Succeeding on Strength of a Father-Son Bond
description: Doug McDermott, a star forward for No. 18 Creighton, has almost wordless communication when he looks to his coach for guidance during a game. Sometimes, they are so alike in their thinking that nothing more than a nod is needed for a critical adjustment to be made.

title: Defeat of Auto Union in Tennessee Casts Its Strategy Into Doubt
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  Bob King has pursued one goal above all as president of the United Automobile Workers  to unionize several foreign-owned auto plants in the South. He said he viewed that as pivotal if his once-mighty union was to gain numbers and strength after decades of decline.

title: A Debate Becomes a Brawl as Turkeys Parliament Votes to Rein In Courts
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys Parliament met through the night, Friday into Saturday, and passed a controversial new bill that gives the government greater control over the judiciary  but not before a brawl on the floor of the assembly left one lawmaker with a broken finger and another with a bloodied nose.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 15
description: Hockey, skiing, and speedskating highlight the 10th day of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

title: Ugandan President Says He Will Sign Tough Antigay Measure
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Gay rights in Africa suffered another setback when President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda told members of his party on Friday that he would sign a bill imposing harsh sentences for homosexual acts, including life imprisonment in some cases.

title: A Generational Wealth of N.B.A. Talent
description: NEW ORLEANS  Tim Hardaway Jr., a rookie swingman who has been a bright spot for the Knicks in an otherwise drab season, is a full-grown adult capable of his own decisions, but he still calls his father for advice.

title: Behind Bars
description: The secret vocabulary of New Yorks finest drinking establishments.

title: In Report on Bullying, the Vile and the Gripping
description: My first reaction to reading Ted Wellss 144-page report on the Miami Dolphins harassment case was that Commissioner Roger Goodell should ensure that Richie Incognito never be allowed to play another down in the N.F.L. Incognito, the Dolphins suspended offensive lineman, was the ringleader and catalyst of a reign of terror directed primarily at his teammate Jonathan Martin for two seasons.

title: Ancestral Enemies Meet at Olympics for a Toast to Amity
description: SOCHI, Russia  I nearly missed my tea with a Cossack.

title: Lebanon Forms a Cabinet After 11 Months of Deadlock
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanons new prime minister, Tammam Salam, announced the formation of a cabinet on Saturday that represents many of the countrys deeply divided political factions, ending a nearly 11-month standoff that had left the government ill equipped to deal with increasing violence and a growing Syrian refugee population.

title: At 18, Mikaela Shiffrin Has Envisioned the Best and the Worst
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old defending world champion in slalom, arrived here Friday night, and less than 24 hours later reporters asked her if she could rescue the struggling American ski team.

title: Document Describes Eavesdropping on American Law Firm
description: Following is an excerpt from a document provided by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden. It is from the February 2013 edition of a monthly bulletin of SUSLOC, the acronym for the N.S.A. office that handles liaisons with Australian intelligence. It describes how Australian intelligence conducted surveillance of trade talks between Indonesia and the United States and, in the process, monitored communications between Indonesian officials and an American law firm retained by Indonesia for help with the trade dispute. The Australians then sought legal guidance from the N.S.A. (The document refers to the D.S.D  the Defense Signals Directorate  the former name of Australias counterpart to the N.S.A. In May 2013, the agency was renamed the Australian Signals Directorate, or A.S.D.)

title: Spying by N.S.A. Ally Entangled U.S. Law Firm
description: The list of those caught up in the global surveillance net cast by the National Security Agency and its overseas partners, from social media users to foreign heads of state, now includes another entry: American lawyers.

title: After Second Round of Syria Talks, No Agreement Even on How to Negotiate
description: GENEVA  The United Nations mediator for Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, wrapped up the second round of peace talks here on Saturday without breaking a longstanding deadlock or setting a date for a third round, and urged the parties to think seriously about their commitment to the negotiations.

title: Chinese Ask Kerry to Help Tear Down a Firewall
description: BEIJING  A group of Chinese bloggers asked the United States to take up the cause of Internet freedom in an unusual meeting on Saturday with Secretary of State John Kerry.

title: Mob Attacks More Than a Dozen Gay Men in Nigerias Capital
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A mob attacked gay people in a neighborhood in Abuja, the capital of Nigeria, dragging young men from their homes, beating them with nail-studded clubs and whips, and shouting that they were cleansing the community of gays, several Nigerian activists and a witness said Saturday.

title: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Olympians May Go From Sochi to N.H.L. Trading Block
description: The best hockey players in the world are competing in the Olympics, but some of them face the prospect of being traded by their N.H.L. teams when the season resumes.

title: A Severe Winter Breaks Budgets as Well as Pipes
description: SYRACUSE  Century-old water mains here have ruptured behind City Hall, popped in residential areas and split under the citys bar and restaurant district. The mayor says she has personally reported three breaks, while exhausted crews work 18-hour shifts in subfreezing temperatures to repair the damage.

title: The Remarkable One-Man Show Called T. J. Oshie
description: SOCHI, Russia  Hockey is a team game, and this one was so big that it pitted country against country. But by the end, it turned into a simple contest of one-on-one.

title: The Tame Truth About the Wolves of Wall Street
description: MAYBE its those five Oscar nominations for The Wolf of Wall Street, including for best picture, best director and best actor, but we seem to be in another of those moments in popular culture when Hollywood plies us with skewed answers about how Wall Street miscreants caused so much mayhem.

title: Driving to the Music of Chance
description: I BOUGHT my car, a Jetta wagon, back in 2006. It was four years old and came with a five-CD cartridge lodged, impractically, over a rear wheel well. Not surprisingly, the CD player refuses to function on any less-than-perfect road  and in Brooklyn, where I live, there are few perfect roads. Even stop-and-start traffic makes the discs, well, stop and start. So when we want to hear music in the car, which is always, my family relies on the ad-riddled idiosyncrasies of commercial radio.

title: The Never-Ending Candy Crush Saga
description: BY the end of 2013, more than half a billion people had installed Candy Crush Saga, and the addictive game app was generating just a little less than $1 million per day, according to its developer, King. Candy Crush Saga was the most downloaded app of the year in 2013, according to Apple.

title: Start-Up America: Our Best Hope
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  THE most striking thing about visiting Silicon Valley these days is how many creative ideas you can hear in just 48 hours.

title: Marry First, Then Cheat
description: PARIS  ONLY the French could have an etiquette scandal.

title: The Line at the Super PAC Trough
description: If you need something out of Washington and want to give a satchel of cash to a political candidate, no need to give it directly to the candidate. Federal law limits those contributions to $2,600 anyway. The thing to do is to give the money to the candidates super PAC, where no limits apply, to pay for attack ads against the candidates opponent.

title: An Encouraging Chinese Courtship
description: Just a few years ago, the rivalry between mainland China and Taiwan was seen as one of the more likely triggers for international conflict. But while fundamental differences remain, the two sides have worked to ease tensions.

title: James Bridle
description: James Bridle is a British writer and artist whose work focuses on technology and how it shapes culture and societies. He is the creator of Dronestagram, on the photo-sharing site Instagram, which supplies images of the locations of drone strikes as they occur.

title: Transgender, Schlumpy and Human
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  THERES a scene in the new Amazon show Transparent when the family patriarch, Mort, walks in on his oldest daughter in flagrante with her lesbian lover. The character, whos been struggling throughout the pilot with how to come out as trans, stands there in drag with a bemused expression. Hello, ladies, Mort  now Maura  says.

title: The Lore of Labor
description: WHEN my water broke during the 35th week of my first pregnancy, I waddled down the block to our neighborhoods brand-new hospital. This was in London, where I then lived, around 2 a.m., Dec. 13, 1993.

title: Parental Pity Party
description: WHEN I became a father, I expected to change in all the predictable ways  to become more responsible and more exhausted, to lose contact with friends and lean more heavily on relatives, to grow steadily balder of head and softer of belly.

title: To Save Fish and Birds
description: One of the few bright spots in the struggle to protect the worlds fragile oceans has been the rapidly increasing number of marine-protected areas, places where fishing is limited or banned and where, presumably, depleted species can recover by simply being left to themselves. The benefits of hands-off environmental protection may seem self-evident. But creating a preserve and rebuilding a healthy ecosystem are not necessarily the same thing. A recent study published in Nature found that, more often than not, marine-protected areas dont work as well as they could.

title: Professors, We Need You!
description: SOME of the smartest thinkers on problems at home and around the world are university professors, but most of them just dont matter in todays great debates.

title: Is Harlem Good Now?
description: WHEN I was walking to work one day last summer, I noticed that Crab Man Mike was gone from his usual post at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue. Mike has been cooking shellfish in his special pot on the streets of Harlem for 23 years. Concerned, I began asking the other street vendors where he went. Johnny Portland, one of the Jamaican guys who also sets up some days at 125th and Fifth, told me Crab Mike had moved.

title: Social Media, a Trove of Clues and Confessions
description: IT seems as if every week theres a news story about someone committing a crime and confessing to it on Facebook, bragging about it on Twitter or sharing photos of it via Instagram. In many ways, social media has been a boon for law enforcement, handing the police ready admissions of guilt, equipping criminal investigators with new types of evidence and empowering prosecutors to better dispel reasonable doubt of guilt.

title: Home, Dismantled
description: This is the first part of an eight-part series.

title: Let Our Lawmakers Hide!
description: AN idea for the Senate: brown paper bags. You know, the kind in which you cut little holes for your eyes and your nose and a bigger, wider hole for your mouth. Senators could wear these in the chamber, so that the C-Span cameras and the outside world wouldnt know precisely whos supporting what. Or maybe ski masks, though those wreak havoc on hairdos. Alternately, the lawmakers could communicate in code: anything to obscure their actions and make it easier for them to actually cast votes in line with their best judgment and consciences. Oh, you thought they always did that? Well then I wont spill the beans on Santa or the Easter bunny, either.

title: Sochi Video Notebook: T. J. Oshie
description: T. J. Oshie, who took six of the Americans eight shots, scoring on four of them to lift the team to a victory over Russia, spoke to the media after the game.

title: London Fashion Week: Central Saint Martins Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Photos Become Ads With New Technology
description: Online publishers have been doing a lot of soul-searching lately about how to give their advertising revenue a shot of adrenaline without upsetting their readers. Native advertising, in which stories commissioned by sponsors are dressed up to resemble editorial material, is one of the most widely discussed efforts by publishers (including efforts at The New York Times).

title: A Long, Strange Trip to the Basketball Hall of Fame
description: In the 1992 Summer Olympics, most eyes were on the Dream Team. Perhaps the greatest group of players ever assembled, the Americans took the world by storm, reclaiming supremacy in basketball and inspiring the world to take up the sport in earnest.

title: Out in the Cold
description: Cities deal with water main breaks, potholes and roof damage as a result of the severe winter weather.

title: In Short-Track Speedskating, Skill Struggles to Overcome Dumb Luck
description: The collision that sent Eddy Alvarez sprawling on the ice and out of the mens 1,000-meter short-track competition happened so fast that even his description of it, a few minutes later, was barely longer than a haiku.

title: Bridging the Moat Around Universities
description: My Sunday column is about the unfortunate way America has marginalized university professorsand, perhaps sadder still, the way they have marginalized themselves from public debate. When I was a kid, the Kennedy administration had its brain trust of Harvard faculty members, and university professors were often vital public intellectuals who served off and on in government. Thats still true to some degree of economists, but not of most other Ph.D programs. And were all the losers for that.

title: U.N. Panel Finds Crimes Against Humanity in North Korea
description: GENEVA  United Nations investigators say North Korea has committed wide-ranging crimes against humanity to sustain its political system, and recommend that it be referred to the International Criminal Court.

title: Addendum: Geithner and Treasury Department on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: Efforts to obtain comment from both the Treasury Department and Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, were unsuccessful before publication of The Untouchable Profits of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (Feb. 16, 2014). A Treasury Department spokesman declined to comment, and Mr. Geithner did not respond to a request for comment. In both instances, they were asked why the department had not disclosed to Fannie and Freddie stockholders the administrations commitment to deprive them of any future positive earnings generated by the companies.

title: One Nation Under Guard
description: Another dubious first for America: We now employ as many private security guards as high school teachers  over one million of them, or nearly double their number in 1980.

title: Ahn Wins Second Medal in 1,000 Meters
description: Picture sequence showing who held the lead in each lap of the race.

title: Obama Meets With the King of Jordan
description: President Barack Obama meets with King Abdullah II to pledge $1 billion in loan guarantees for Jordan and to consider new ways to pressure the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

title: Intels Sharp-Eyed Social Scientist
description: Behind the gray, noise-absorbing cubicle walls at the Intel Corporation in Hillsboro, Ore., researchers who forecast the future of computing can sense her arrival.

title: As Bubka Watches, His Record, Set in 1993, Falls
description: The timing could have been better for the French pole-vaulter Renaud Lavillenie.

title: On the Mountain, a Wild Ride
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  I was not enjoying my cable car ride high above the mountains the other day, so I turned for reassurance to my gondola-mates, some Russian luge fans passing the time by cracking what seemed to be jokes about Kazakhstan. They did not understand me  I think they thought I was making the international signal for choking rather than for vertigo  so I tried to focus on the matter at hand: getting from the snowboarding park to the luge track sometime within the next 24 hours.

title: Jury Reaches Partial Verdict in Florida Killing Over Loud Music
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  After four days of deliberation, the jury in the racially tinged trial of Michael Dunn, a Florida man who set off another firestorm over the states self-defense laws when he shot a teenager to death in a parking lot during a dispute over loud music, said it could not agree on whether Mr. Dunn had acted to protect himself or was guilty of murder.

title: A Hockey Rivalry Moves Beyond the Ice
description: SOCHI, Russia  The Sochi Games organizer Dmitry Chernyshenko has turned to the same line again and again when asked to describe how he and certain other Russians feel about the United States Olympic hockey team.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 16
description: A powerful storm dumped record amounts of snow and ice on the East Coast, leaving stranded travelers and downed power lines in its wake. North Carolinas highways were littered with abandoned cars after snowfall during the day paralyzed the evening rush, a similar scene to Atlantas gridlock in late January.

title: Americans Skeleton Run Goes Awry
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  John Daly of the United States was in fourth place going into the fourth heat of the mens skeleton final on Saturday when he botched his run just as it was beginning. It is unclear how exactly it happened  possibly he was too eager or too aggressive  but as he ran alongside and flung himself onto his sled at the top of the track, the sled popped out of the groove meant to guide it through its initial descent.

title: Now No. 96 for Yankees, Possible Future Alternative to No. 13
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There is no better time for wishful thinking, if not pure fantasy, than on the day of the first spring training workout for pitchers and catchers. So mull over the delicious possibility, however distant or remote, of Alex Rodriguezs eventual long-term replacement at third base being a converted catcher who hails from Miami and happened to play a season of college baseball at the ballpark that bears A-Rods tainted name.

title: Polish Ski Jumper Sweeps Individual Events
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Kamil Stoch of Poland and Noriaki Kasai of Japan seemed to wait forever as they watched the scoreboard to see who would get the gold medal and who would settle for the silver in the large-hill ski jump on Saturday.

title: The Oddities of Olympic Park
description: SOCHI, Russia  Snicker all you like at the well-publicized oddities and spectacular expense of these Winter Games, but give it up for the train that delivers visitors to Olympic Park. A digital sign on the platform at the next-to-last stop says that it will arrive at 1:14 and leave at 1:15, and it delivers on that promise, right down to the second.

title: Mets Hope an Aging Ace Can Still Provide a Lift
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Early in the summer of 2002, Omar Minaya, the general manager of the Montreal Expos, made what he thought was an easy trade. After five consecutive losing seasons, the Expos, behind Vladimir Guerrero and Jose Vidro, were surprise contenders, in need of a boost. This was perhaps their last hurrah.

title: Tanaka Gains a Mentor but Loses His Breath
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Soon after Masahiro Tanaka signed with the Yankees last month, one of the first things he did was to call Hiroki Kuroda, his new teammate and Japanese compatriot. It was part of Tanakas duty in accordance with the senpai-kohai relationship.

title: Passing Grades
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Its always a relief when you find out the teacher is grading on a curve, and thats precisely what Yaakov BenDavid has for us today. You wouldnt want to get all the way to the end of your solving week just to find out that you had failed.

title: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

title: A Ukraine City Spins Beyond the Governments Reach
description: LVIV, UKRAINE  Oleh Salo, the Ukrainian states senior representative in this western region, was hard at work keeping up appearances. He had just completed a new budget, he explained, and had an urgent meeting with the newly appointed local chief of Ukraines security service.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: February 14, 2014
description: Volkswagen autoworkers in Tennessee may form the nations first works council, a type of union popular in Germany in which employees and management work together to make decisions. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine how significant the move would be for the nations labor movement, and why some officials and policy groups are opposed to it. Plus, a discussion of Comcasts purchase of Time Warner Cable.

title: Crossing Borders and Changing Lives, Lured by Higher State Minimum Wages
description: ONTARIO, Ore.  Carly Lynch dreams of a life one day on the professional rodeo circuit, but for now she commutes 20 miles from Idaho to this small city in eastern Oregon to work as a waitress. There are restaurant jobs closer to home, but she is willing to drive the extra miles for a simple reason: Oregons minimum wage is $1.85 higher per hour than Idahos.

title: Pete Camarata, Who Fought Fellow Teamsters for Reforms, Dies at 67
description: In 1976, Frank Fitzsimmons, president of the Teamsters, struck a defiant note in a speech at the unions convention in Las Vegas. To those who say it is time to reform this organization, and its time officers stopped selling out the members, he said, I say to them, Go to hell.

title: Examples of Health Care 'Props'
description: Both Democrats and Republicans like to use real-life examples to back up their positions on the Affordable Care Act. But sometimes reality is more complicated.

title: In the Debate Over Health Care, Real People Become Human Volleyballs
description: WASHINGTON  In the Republican response to the State of the Union address, Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington lamented the travails of Bette in Spokane, whose insurance policy had been canceled because of the health care law and who faced huge premium increases to replace it.

title: Reconsidering the Legacy of Lyndon B. Johnson
description: Relatives and friends of Lyndon Baines Johnson say that his legacy has been tainted by the Vietnam War, and they are working to put forth a broader view of his presidency.

title: Legacy of L.B.J.
description: The agony of Vietnam looms over all of us, said Luci Baines Johnson, who argues that the war overshadowed the domestic achievements of her father, President Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: A New Resource for Buddhist Scholars
description: The Tibetan Buddhist Resource Center opened its library, with 12,000 works, at the Southwest University for Nationalities in Chengdu, China, in October. Archivists plan to scan the texts digitally.

title: In the Party, but Trying Hard to Stand Out
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: After Winding Odyssey, Tibetan Texts Find Home in China
description: CHENGDU, China  Decades ago, the thousands of Tibetan-language books now ensconced in a lavishly decorated library in southwest China might have ended up in a raging bonfire. During the tumultuous decade of the Cultural Revolution, which ended in 1976, Red Guard zealots destroyed anything deemed feudal. But an American scholar, galvanized in part by those rampages, embarked on a mission to collect and preserve the remnants of Tibetan culture.

title: Rescuing a Vietnam Casualty: Johnsons Legacy
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Luci Baines Johnson leaned forward in her fathers private suite at the L.B.J. Presidential Library, her voice breaking as she recounted the agony of Vietnam that engulfed Lyndon Baines Johnson and the pain she feels to this day of witnessing his presidency judged through the prism of a failed war.

title: Union Hears From Potential Leaders
description: NEW ORLEANS  The N.B.A. players union, which has been without an executive director since Billy Hunter was fired a year ago, gathered Saturday afternoon for a two-hour meeting during which candidates for the position gave presentations and answered questions from about 30 players, including the Knicks Carmelo Anthony.

title: Las Marthas: Debutantes in Laredo, Surprisingly Colonial
description: Most contemporary entertainment set along the Mexican border tends to focus on the brutal drug wars that have killed scores of thousands. Consider the film No Country for Old Men, or the FX series The Bridge. And with the exception of the occasional hard-driving female detective, women in these stories tend to be passive figures or the victims of grisly violence.

title: Elite Couples Valentine: Be Mine but Be Rested
description: On the sixth anniversary of their first date, Ashton Eaton and Brianne Thiesen-Eaton skipped the fancy dinner and were in bed by 9 p.m., forgoing romance for much-needed rest. A big afternoon awaited.

title: The Confederate Washingtons
description: Abraham Lincoln must have been pained by the number of Washingtons on the other side during the Civil War. He idolized George Washington. One of the first books he read as a boy was Parson Weemss apocryphal biography of the first president, and it made a lasting impression. Later, as a congressman, Lincoln made a pilgrimage to Washingtons Mount Vernon and regaled his friends afterward about the experience.

title: The Next Colorado or Washington: Probably Not Here
description: EL PASO  It was not long after Gov. Rick Perrys remarks that states shouldenact their ownmarijuana laws that social mediasitesbegan wondering if the theory of relativity was a sham or whether Pink Floyds estranged founder would finally rejoin the band.

title: Pregnant Inmates Find Help to Ease Shift to World Outside
description: HOUSTON  At the pregnancy tank at the Harris County Jail, asking a female inmate How much longer do you have? can get a puzzled look in response. She could answer with a due date or an anticipated date of discharge from jail.

title: Afghan Armys Test Begins With Fight for Vital Highway
description: CHAK, Afghanistan  In a deserted village off Highway 1, southwest of Kabul, an Afghan Army bomb disposal team was unearthing its 15th bomb of the day when sniper shots began to rain down.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 15, 2014
After Unexpected Climb Into Playoff, Bulgarian Is King of the Rock
description: Ivan Cheparinov won a three-way playoff to take the title at the 12th Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival this month.

title: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund Trust and Estate Donors
description: TRUSTS

title: Fund Provided Relief, and Then Readers Gave Even More
description: Once again, a host of empathetic readers and donors helped those seeking a change in their lives, with their contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during its 102nd campaign.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 16, 2014
description: Nobody wanted that war less than Lyndon Johnson. No matter how hard he tried, he didnt seem to be able to get out of that quagmire. Not only did he not get out of it in his lifetime, but his legacy indeed has that weight of the world on it.

title: Slave No More
description: As the runway revolves, one front-row fashion fixture ponders how practical dressing has come to feel like the most modern of ideas, and why designers havent quite caught on.

title: Corrections: February 16, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Adam Rose and Peter McQuillan
description: Adam R. Rose, a son of Sandra Priest Rose of Rye, N.Y., and the late Frederick P. Rose, was married Tuesday evening to Peter R. McQuillan, the son of Celia M. McQuillan of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Richard J. McQuillan. Betsy Gotbaum, a friend of the couple who until 2009 was the public advocate of the City of New York, became a Universal Life minister for the occasion and officiated at the couples Manhattan apartment.

title: Danielle McFall, Schuyler Weiss
description: Danielle Rene McFall and Schuyler Sussman Weiss are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Nikki L. DeBlosi at the Park restaurant in New York.

title: Eve Weston, Zachary Pincus-Roth
description: Eve Meryl Weston and Zachary Pincus-Roth are to be married Sunday at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego, where Rabbi Wayne D. Dosick will officiate in the Robert Paine Scripps Forum for Science, Society and the Environment.

title: Delia Pais and Joseph Kristol
description: Delia Ann Pais, a daughter of Mara D. Pais and Richard A. Pais of Bel Air, Md., is to be married Sunday evening to Joseph Max Kristol, the son of Susan S. Kristol and William Kristol of McLean, Va. Rabbi David Kalender is to officiate at the Columbus Club, an event space at Union Station in Washington.

title: Diana Dosik and Matthew Schwab
description: Diana Alix Dosik and Matthew Aaron Schwab were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the city clerks office, officiated. On Sunday, Dr. Mark H. Kaplan, the brides uncle who became a Universal Life minister for the event, led a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions at the St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort in Rio Grande, P.R.

title: Julia Foster, Mark Mezrich
description: Julia Kurz Foster and Mark Nathaniel Mezrich are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Steven A. Exler at the Harvard Club of New York.

title: Carrie Kingsley, Marc Miller
description: Carrie Beth Kingsley and Marc Matthew Miller were married Saturday evening at the City Winery in Manhattan. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann officiated.

title: Kathryn McLoughlin, Christopher LaVine
description: Kathryn Towler McLoughlin and Christopher Dalton LaVine were married Saturday at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in George Town, Grand Cayman. The Rev. Suresh Rajaian, a Roman Catholic priest and pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: David Rodriguez Lind and George Thomas II
description: David Anthony Rodriguez Lind and George Arthur Thomas II were married Saturday at the Loft at Prince, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Gregory Anton McCants, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Varinda Missett, Eric Straus
description: Varinda Singh Missett and Eric Peter Straus are to be married Sunday evening at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in New York. Jacob Straus, the grooms son who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate. The couples other four children, Mitchell Kuhnert, Samantha Missett, Madison Missett and Emily Straus, also became Universal Life ministers, and will contribute to the ceremony.

title: Courtney Booth and Gus Christensen
description: Courtney Elizabeth Booth and Gus Christensen were married Saturday at St. Christophers Church in Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: From Love to Friendship and Back Again
description: Erin Elizabeth OBrien Breen and Steven Daniel Zecca were married Saturday in Port Jefferson, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick M. Riegger performed the ceremony at Infant Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

title: Clarissa Cruz, Theodore Maniatis
description: Clarissa Lynn Cruz and Theodore Jason Maniatis were married Saturday at SS. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Pacific in Honolulu. The Rev. Alexander Leong, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Natalia Bedoya and Timothy McGinn Jr.
description: Natalia Beatriz Bedoya and Timothy John McGinn Jr. were married Saturday at Ges Catholic Church in Miami. The Rev. Eduardo J. Alvarez, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Beth Rosen, Maryann King
description: Beth Susan Rosen and Maryann King are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Sharon A. Kleinbaum at Congregation Habonim in New York.

title: Always Room at the Inn for Another Medal
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Displayed next to the reception desk at the Mirror Lake Inn in Lake Placid, N.Y., is a bronze medal from the 2010 Winter Olympics, a prize taken home by the son of the inns owners.

title: Whats On Today?
description: 8 P.M. (Telemundo) TOP CHEF ESTRELLAS Eight Hispanic celebrities  above from left, Nancy lvarez, David Chocarro, Erika De La Rosa and Christian Chvez, along with Fernando Arau, Christian de la Campa, Lorena Herrera and Cynthia Olavarra  demonstrate their culinary skills in an effort to win $100,000 for charity in this new Spanish-language series, based on Bravos Top Chef franchise. The actress Ayln Mjica hosts; the chefs Lorena Garca, Jaime Martin Del Campo and Ramiro Arvizu are the judges. In a twist, eliminated contestants will become sous chefs instead of going home. Suelta La Sopa Extra, at 10, features recaps with cast members and behind-the-scenes footage.

title: At Asia Air Show, Plenty of Competition for Sales of Drones
description: SINGAPORE  While the supersonic jets, attack helicopters and surface-to-air missiles longer than a stretch limousine wowed an estimated 80,000 people who attended the final days of the Singapore Airshow over the weekend, it was a small, silent and unarmed weapon that took center stage as major players in the Southeast Asia weapons market hawked their wares.

title: Preen: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: In Carolina Herrera They Trust
description: When Michelle Obama wore a Carolina Herrera dress, with a scoop front lacy embroidered top and French blue ball skirt, to greet President Franois Hollande of France at the White House, she could not have given a better fillip to New York Fashion Week.

title: Jason Wu Debuts at Hugo Boss
description: Mens wear companies expanding their female lines seem to be a strong fashion trend. Even before Ralph Lauren made his bold New York Fashion Week statement by showing a new female Polo range, Hugo Boss, the German mens fashion powerhouse, had tapped Jason Wu to expand and clarify its womens collection.

title: Anna Sui: Asia Through Western Eyes
description: The idea of designers with Asian roots being inspired by a Western parody of their countries clothes would have been unthinkable a decade ago, but fusion fashion is fast following the food version.

title: Reed Krakoff: Fusing Luxury and Minimalism
description: Reed Krakoff has finally found his comfort zone for modern style. His collection for winter 2014 was all about a rare but important species: the WWWs, or the wealthy who work.

title: Lindsey Jacobellis Again Comes Up Short in Snowboard Cross
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Again, there was nothing in front of Lindsey Jacobellis but open snow, a finish line and a mountain of possibility. She was in the lead, a pack of women chasing with little hope of catching the most accomplished female snowboard-cross rider in history.

title: Coachs New Designer Puts the Emphasis on American Luxury
description: When Bonnie Cashin, the inventor of American sportswear, worked at Coach from 1962 to 1975, she revolutionized the handbag, giving it color, practical inside pockets for a dynamic new woman and the silver toggle  an early brand hallmark  that was inspired by the hood fastening on her convertible.

title: Marchesa Goes to the Scottish Highlands
description: Could Marchesa, a fashion child of the red carpet, really be pulling back from celebrity and migrating to the Scottish Highlands? The most immediate statement from Keren Craig and Georgina Chapman might have been the colors, inspired by copper pans, a fiery hearth, smoky fog and cinnamon in the soup. It all seemed a long way from the duos favored Los Angeles.

title: Richard Nicoll: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: In Our Pages: February 17
description: 1889: A Church Scandal

title: The Dogs One Big Headache, but My Kids Adore Her
description: Our dog, who is nervous, incontinent and prone to other accidents, has been a liability since Day 1. The sensible thing for me to do would be to find her a good new home, which Im sure I could do. But not only do I feel like that would be a failure on my part, I also suspect it might send the message to my kids that problematic family members can be cast off when they become burdensome. As an older parent, I need to consider these things carefully.

title: Marios Schwab: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Pringle of Scotland: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: 18 Feared Dead in Nepalese Air Crash
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  A Nepal Airlines plane bound for the city of Jumla from Katmandu, the capital, crashed in the forests of western Nepal on Sunday, almost certainly killing all 18 people aboard, officials said.

title: Difficult Day for South Koreans as Native Son Wins Gold, for Russia
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When the short-track speed skater Viktor Ahn waved the Russian flag on his victory lap and sang the Russian national anthem on Saturday after winning the gold medal in the mens 1,000 meters at Winter Olympics on Saturday, it was a poignant scene for South Koreans.

title: Bombing of Tourist Bus Kills at Least Three in Sinai
description: CAIRO  At least two South Korean tourists and their Egyptian driver were killed on Sunday when an explosion ripped through a tour bus in a resort town in the Sinai Peninsula, in what officials said was the first deadly attack on tourists by militants in Egypt in at least three years.

title: Iron Men of Wall Street
description: Greg Mankiw has written another defense of the 0.1 percent  and this one is kind of amazing.

title: Disruptions: Using Addictive Games to Build Better Brains
description: First it was Doodle Jump. Then Dots. And now  will it never end?  Flappy Bird.

title: Iraqi Cleric Says Again Hell Quit Politics
description: BAGHDAD  Moktada al-Sadr, the anti-American Shiite cleric who became one of Iraqs most powerful political leaders, said he was withdrawing from politics and would no longer be represented in the Iraqi government or Parliament.

title: Phil Kessels Hat Trick Gives Americans a Win
description: SOCHI, Russia  Both goaltenders making their Sochi Games debuts in Sundays round-robin game between the United States and Slovenia had a certain measure of international success in 2010.

title: Christopher Raeburn
description: Christopher Raeburn is known for repurposing materials in exciting ways. At London Fashion Week, Suzy Menkes talked with the designer about his vision and the future of his work.

title: Black Coal, Thin Ice Wins Top Prize at Berlin Festival
description: A Chinese film noir, Black Coal, Thin Ice, directed by Diao Yinan, took the Golden Bear prize for best feature film at the Berlin Film Festival, while The Grand Budapest Hotel, a period caper set in interwar Europe took the Silver Bear Grand Jury Prize.

title: A Harrowing Trip, Far From the Runways
description: Never let it be said that the Brits dont have a sense of irony. Whether by design or odd coincidence, the models in the Marios Schwab show here on Sunday morning strutted out to the strains of the Doors Riders on the Storm, which drew a wry smile from more than a few people sitting in the front row.

title: The Dutch Speedskaters Are Thrilled, the Americans Baffled
description: SOCHI, Russia  It was another tale of two speedskating teams here on Sunday night, with the Dutch team sweeping the podium yet again in the womens 1,500 meters and the United States coming up empty-handed.

title: South Africans in Mine Rescued and Then Arrested
description: Emergency crews in South Africa rescued 11 miners who were trapped while working illegally in an abandoned gold mine near Johannesburg on Sunday, but other miners decided to stay underground to avoid being arrested, emergency workers said.

title: Protesters Vacate Kievs City Hall in Deal for Amnesty
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ending an occupation of City Hall here that began in December, Ukrainian protesters cemented an amnesty deal with the authorities on Sunday amid signs that both sides in a volatile political crisis were seeking to reduce tensions.

title: Topshop Unique: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Russian Skier Who Broke Her Spine Is Moved to a German Hospital
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  A day after a six-and-a-half-hour operation to repair her spine, which was fractured when she fell during a training run, the Russian ski cross racer Maria Komissarova was transferred to a hospital in Munich, where she will receive additional treatment, the Russian Olympic Committee said Sunday.

title: Paul Smith: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Kerry Implores Indonesia on Climate Change Peril
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Secretary of State John Kerry urged Indonesia on Sunday to take steps to combat climate change, warning that failure to act would jeopardize the nations resources and damage its economy.

title: Lego Movie Tops Box Office, With About Last Night Strong Second
description: Bookended by Valentines Day and Presidents Day, the weekend was a strong one for Hollywood, despite a flatlining Winters Tale and worries that winter storms in parts of the United States would keep moviegoers on their sofas. Certifying itself as a full-blown phenomenon, The Lego Movie (Warner Brothers) will take in a projected $60 million between Friday and Monday, for a two-week domestic total of roughly $140 million. About Last Night (Sony), one of three 1980s-era remakes to arrive over the weekend, was expected to be the No. 1 newcomer by selling a strong $30.2 million in tickets. Co-starring the popular comedian Kevin Hart, About Last Night cost $13 million to make. Third-place RoboCop from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Sony was a disappointment considering that it had a production budget of at least $100 million; if analyst projections hold, the science-fiction remake will take in $25.1 million over the long weekend, for a total since opening on Wednesday of about $30 million. (A Sony spokeswoman noted that RoboCop is performing very strongly overseas, where it has taken in more than $70 million since opening earlier this month.) The Monuments Men, also from Sony, was expected to be a solid fourth, generating a projected $17.3 million, for a two-week total of about $46 million. Analysts estimated that Universals poorly reviewed remake of Endless Love would take in about $15.2 million, which is fine for a lightly marketed movie that cost about $20 million to make. But Akiva Goldsmans Winters Tale (Warner) bombed badly, taking in a projected $8.5 million. Adapted from the 1983 magical realism novel, Winters Tale cost Warner and financing partner Village Roadshow at least $45 million to make.

title: Kerry on Climate Change
description: On Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry delivered remarks on climate change to an audience of students in Jakarta, Indonesia. He accused climate change deniers of burying their heads in the sand.

title: Obama Condemns Ugandas Tough Antigay Measure
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  President Obama on Sunday condemned a measure to criminalize homosexuality in Uganda, publicly warning the countrys president that such discrimination could harm its relationship with the United States.

title: Mulberry Bags Raise Eyebrows
description: LONDON  They call me bag lady,' said Cara Delevingne, better known in the fashion world as Ms. Eyebrows. And on Sunday, the model of the moment staged a handbag happening, surrounded by greyhounds and a fairy tale forest created by the British set designer Michael Howells.

title: Deadly Blast on a Bus in Egypt
description: A television news feed captured the explosion of a tourist bus in Saba, Egypt, that killed at least four people.

title: Obama on Ugandas Antigay Bill
description: President Obama said the bill, likely to be signed by Ugandas president, would be more than an affront and a danger to the gay community in Uganda.

title: Author Resigned to Ill Fate of Book in India
description: After Penguin Books India recently decided to recall and pulp all copies of The Hindus: An Alternative History in the face of legal action, the books author, Wendy Doniger, was not surprised.

title: A Mad Dash for Salt Rescues Olympic Slopes
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  A senior adviser to the Sochi Olympics convened an emergency meeting late last week with top winter sports officials at the Park Inn hotel in the Alpine village here.

title: Jazzman, Newly Lauded, Stays Contained but Loose
description: About an hour into his Town Hall concert on Friday night, Gregory Porter, a good man singing good-man music on Valentines Day, started to ease out of Nat Adderleys Work Song. He gripped the microphone stand at chest level, humming slowly in a blues scale, with the same level, deliberate, ethical steadiness hed put into everything else up to that point. His band played a vamp, waiting for signals. The humming seemed as if it could go on for a while.

title: Kerry Blames Syrian Government for Deadlocked Talks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Secretary of State John Kerry issued a statement on Sunday night that blamed the Syrian government for the deadlock in peace talks but asserted that the United States remained committed to the Geneva process.

title: Mary Katrantzou: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: A Year After Acid Attack, Bolshoi Director to Visit New York
description: Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet artistic director who was wounded in an acid attack last year, will come to New York in April as one of the judges in the Youth America Grand Prix ballet competition, officials from the contest announced.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Class 5
description: Here (pdf).

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 16
description: Among the highlights were Bode Millers bronze medal, a victorious Czech womans painted-on mustache and a postponement of a biathlon because of fog.

title: Dont Mess With Malvolio
description: How do you exact revenge on people who have cruelly tricked you and humiliated you in front of the woman you work for and hope to marry? You steal the show, thats how.

title: London Fashion Week: House of Holland Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: Fighters for Freedom Abroad Found Another Battle at Home
description: The short version of the relationship between the military and racial equality goes like this: In 1948, President Harry S. Truman issued an executive order desegregating the armed forces, and that spurred the civil rights movement. The documentary Breath of Freedom, Monday night on the Smithsonian Channel, is clumsily structured and unnecessarily sentimental, but at least it puts across how oversimplified that narrative is.

title: A Program That Honors Two Vital Mentors
description: If youve managed to run your own dance company for 20 years, chances are you havent made it alone. Pascal Rioult, the director of Rioult Dance New York, had some serious mentors as a young artist: May ODonnell and Martha Graham, with whom he danced in the 1980s and 90s.

title: Honing Their Chances With Photos and Wit
description: SOCHI, Russia  Each ice dance and pairs figure skating team at the Olympics will have no more than seven minutes of ice time, if they are lucky, to prove to a panel of judges and the world that they are a single unit, a duo that can twizzle, trot and leap harmoniously as one.

title: Disparate Backgrounds but a Common Thread
description: When two dancers as eloquently meticulous as Elena Demyanenko and Dai Jian decide to choreograph a work, you know that youre in for silky fluidity: movement that emanates from deep under the skin, where joints are loose, and the spine is airy.

title: A Bit of Sondheim, a Bit of Judy Garland, and a Whole Lot of Glee
description: A garrulous apple-cheeked farm boy with a grin on his face, stars in his eyes, and Judy Garland in his heart: that describes the Broadway and TV star Jonathan Groff in his New York concert debut at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series on Saturday evening. The only thing wrong with that description is the word boy. Mr. Groff may look and act 15, but he is 28 and has amassed an impressive list of theatrical and TV credits, including Spring Awakening, Glee, and the new HBO series Looking.

title: Bandit Buddies Separated by a Woman
description: Bikram and Bala, the outlaw heroes of Gunday, are all hair spray, body oil and swagger. Their chests  no shirts can contain them  glisten; and their muscles bulge as they grimace and run in slow motion. As for their personalities, it takes an hour or so before you discern, or even care, which one is which: Bikram (Ranveer Singh) is shorter, and his hair does more tricks; Bala (Arjun Kapoor) has a temper.

title: 40 Kilometers to Glory
description: Sweden, Russia and France won medals in the mens 4x10-kilometer cross-country race in Krasnaya Polanya, Russia.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Feb. 17
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Fighting the Last Macro War? (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Oh, good  Noah Smith has given me some more economic methodology stuff to waste time on, instead of turning to my various deadlines. OK, Ill make this shortish.

title: Family Life Was Complicated, Then the Body Turned Up
description: The characters in Laura Lippmans After Im Gone are so well drawn that its easy to forget why they happen to be connected. Almost all of them are strong, willful women, starting with this novels matriarch: Bambi Brewer, ne Gottschalk, a raving beauty whose role in the story spans more than 50 years. Even as a teenager at a high school dance, Bambi is aware of how valuable her allure can be. She plays it to her best advantage, even after life hands her an exceedingly raw deal.

title: A Breezy Chameleon, Blurring Social Borders
description: When the literary scholar George Hutchinson was in the archives at Howard University one afternoon a decade ago, he thought he knew which story of a neglected African-American woman writer he was chasing.

title: Tubby Stayman Feted for Her Charity Work and Her Play
description: Tubby Stayman turned 90 two weeks ago. The milestone was celebrated with 34 family members in Palm Beach, Fla., her winter retreat.

title: Matthew Williamson: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Minnesota Orchestra Drama Plays On
description: Just over a month ago, on Jan. 14, the warring parties of the Minnesota Orchestra  management and musicians  agreed to a treaty, of sorts, though in some ways it seems more like a truce. The peace still feels all too tentative.

title: A Romance From Beyond Mars and Venus
description: CW series are like nesting dolls. At the center of each is a weepy young-adult melodrama, hidden inside a vampire show, a superhero show or a costume drama. The latest, Star Crossed, on Monday night, uses science fiction as its shell.

title: Behind Meryl Davis and Charlie White, U.S. Is Close to Its First Ice Dance Gold
description: SOCHI, Russia  The ice dance teams train together in suburban Detroit, tossing world titles back and forth like jugglers. One seems certain to win a gold medal after Mondays free skate.

title: Bachs Art of Fugue Inspires Art of Ballet
description: LONDON  You could assemble a rewardingly hybrid festival of all the choreography of note thats been made to the music of Bach. His scores welcome dance anachronisms: point work or bare feet, jeans or leotards.

title: Jonathan Saunders: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: There, There
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This is only David Grays second time out in The New York Times, and here he is, telling us what to SAY. Should we repeat after him?

title: Israeli Water, Mideast Peace?
description: Nuclear proliferation, religious militancy and income inequality are all major threats to Middle East stability. Sadly, a new one is brewing: water scarcity.

title: A Strategic Tale
description: Two Afghanistan exit strategies.

title: Euro Finance Ministers to Meet; Fed to Publish Meeting Minutes
description: EURO FINANCE MINISTERS TO MEET ON BANKING UNION

title: Breitbart News Network Plans Global Expansion
description: It has been nearly two years since the conservative provocateur Andrew Breitbart died, but the online news organization that carries his name is not only continuing to wage his political battles, it is taking the war global.

title: Resigned to the Sideline, Harvey Focuses on Rehabilitating His Elbow
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There was a time last year when Matt Harvey thought that despite having a partly torn ulnar collateral ligament in his pitching elbow, he could avoid Tommy John surgery, rehabilitate his elbow and pitch this season.

title: Doctor, Help Me Understand This ...
Minimum Wage Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Trade Talks Threaten Obamas Longtime Balancing Act
description: WASHINGTON  Aficionados liken trade expansion to riding a bicycle: If it does not move forward, it tips over. Under President Obama, the bicycle has wobbled.

title: Cost of Preterm Births
description: To the Editor:

title: Faith in the Future
description: To the Editor:
