description: To the Editor:

title: For Parents Juggling Work, a Snow Day Is No Holiday
description: I am interrupting my previously scheduled column on issues of great weight and importance for a commuting parents lament.

title: Banking Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Transgender Former Member of Italian Parliament Detained in Sochi
description: SOCHI, Russia  Vladimir Luxuria, a transgender former member of the Italian Parliament, was detained by the Russian authorities Sunday after holding up a sign that read, Gay Is OK, at Olympic Park, the leader of an Italian gay-rights group said.

title: Real Discipline in School
description: LAST month, Maryland became one of the first states to tackle the widespread injustice of overly harsh discipline policies in our schools, adopting regulations that require an end to practices that have doubled the number of out-of-school suspensions for African-American students in the past decade.

title: A Berlusconi Reminder as Italy Faces Another Unelected Premier
description: ROME  It speaks to the strange state of Italian democracy that Silvio Berlusconi, the disgraced former prime minister, is now claiming the high moral ground in politics  and that his claim is not completely without merit as Italy prepares for its third consecutive unelected prime minister.

title: For Yankees, Big Money Cant Buy Certainty
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Soon after Mark Teixeira became the first high-priced veteran to arrive in training camp and concede that Id be lying if I said there wasnt some anxiety about his surgically repaired right wrist, C. C. Sabathia seconded the motion that uncertainty might be one of the few certainties about the 2014 Yankees.

title: Reframing Obamacare
description: As Democrats head into the 2014 midterm elections, they are taking a new approach to talking about the Affordable Care Act: acknowledging that the law has problems, and offering their own solutions.

title: On Health Act, Democrats Run in Fix-It Mode
description: WASHINGTON  The ad supporting Representative Ann Kirkpatrick, Democrat of Arizona, opens with a montage of Americana Main Streets, followed by the green fields and dirt roads of the West  the small towns and wide-open spaces, the narrator explains, where Ms. Kirkpatrick listens and learns.

title: Common Core Curriculum Now Has Critics on the Left
description: The Common Core has been applauded by education leaders and promoted by the Obama administration as a way to replace a hodgepodge of state standards with one set of rigorous learning goals. Though 45 states and the District of Columbia have signed on to them since 2010, resistance came quickly, mostly from right-leaning states, where some leaders and political action groups have protested what they see as a federal takeover of local classrooms.

title: Mary Katrantzous High-Heeled Loafers
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: In Egypt, a Chasm Grows Between Young and Old
description: CAIRO  Shady el-Ghazaly Harb says he has given up trying to help the military-backed government address its worries about losing the support of young Egyptians.

title: A Watchful Eye in Hospitals
description: HANOVER, N.H.  DESPITE the intensely personal moments that happen in hospitals, patient privacy can be elusive. Hospitals are multimillion-dollar corporations that look like shopping malls and function like factories. Doctors knock on exam room doors to signal they are about to enter  not to ask permission. The curtain that encircles the hospital bed always lets in a crack of light.

title: Barons of Broadband
description: Last weeks big business news was the announcement that Comcast, a gigantic provider of cable TV and high-speed Internet service, has reached a deal to acquire Time Warner Cable, which is merely huge. If regulators approve the deal, Comcast will be an overwhelmingly dominant player in the business, with around 30 million subscribers.

title: Florida Self-Defense Law Complicated Jurys Job in Michael Dunn Trial
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  In failing to acquit or convict Michael Dunn on the most significant charge  the premeditated murder of a teenager in a dispute over loud music  a jury on Saturday may have run headlong into the breadth and reach of Floridas contentious self-defense law.

title: In Praise of Disregard
description: Perhaps this experience sounds familiar to you: Sometimes, particularly during elections or other politically feverish moments, I spend many hours reading about the issues; but I have a tendency to dwell on stories I find truly distressing, such as tales of leaked videos showing the blunt discrepancy between a politicians on- and off-screen selves. I am drawn to the most hopeless headlines, the reports that make humans seem like wolves, the kind that make it impossible to stifle my expletives. I feel it physiologically: My adrenaline surges, my breaths get quick and short, and I pace and fume around the apartment trying to get rid of this nervous energy.

title: Scenes of Confusion
description: This is the second part of an eight-part series.

title: Labor Regroups in South After VW Vote
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  Volkswagen labor officials in Germany renewed calls on Sunday for the companys three-year-old plant here to establish a German-style works council even though its workers voted days earlier against unionizing.

title: At Church Service, Pastor Makes No Mention of de Blasio or Arrest
description: The pastor whose arrest last week has turned into a political headache for Mayor Bill de Blasio appeared publicly on Sunday for the first time since the incident, leading a rousing service in Brooklyn but saying nothing about his arrest  or the controversy that has entangled the mayor.

title: Regulatory Favoritism in North Carolina
description: North Carolina citizens have good reason to wonder just whom their environmental regulators are trying to protect. The states Department of Environment and Natural Resources has engaged in a series of maneuvers that seem designed to protect the states largest utility, Duke Energy, from paying big fines for water pollution from coal ash ponds and meeting reasonable requirements that it move toxic coal ash to lined landfills away from rivers and lakes used for drinking water and recreation.

title: Stealthily, Comcast Fortifies Its Arsenal
description: Big media companies are generally warships, bristling with firepower and declaring their might long before they attack. But Comcast, which is headed toward being one of the biggest of them all, is much more like a submarine, silently running beneath the waves and making its presence known only when it is too late for its targets.

title: The New College Campus
description: Imagine meeting someone who says she works at a university. Some years ago, it would have been fairly safe to assume that she was a professor, and a member of the middle class with enviable job security. Not anymore. Two reports make clear that the nature of the college work force has changed substantially, possibly to the detriment of educational quality.

title: Japans Growth Slows, Raising Concerns About Obstacles That Lie Ahead
description: TOKYO  The Japanese economy grew at a tepid rate of 1.0 percent in the final quarter of 2013, falling short of analyst expectations and heightening concerns that Japans recovery may not be strong enough to weather further challenges expected this year.

title: New Yorks Broken Parole System
description: The fact of a crime never changes, but the person who commits it can, and often does. This is the basic principle of parole  that while people must be punished for their wrongdoing, most are capable of growing, changing and rejoining society before the end of their sentence.

title: One Group Sees Silver Lining in Winters Storm Clouds: Meteorologists
description: Brian A. Colle woke up at 1 a.m. on Thursday and headed out into the snow. Using plates of glass he had been storing in a freezer in his garage, he collected snowflakes for analysis with a powerful microscope.

title: The Games Unfamiliar Honor (Even Among Its Recipients)
description: SOCHI, Russia  Gold. Silver. Bronze. Paper?

title: Magnet Schools Find a Renewed Embrace in Cities
description: MIAMI  Nearly five decades ago, as racial tension raged in cities, magnet schools were introduced here and elsewhere as an alternative to court-ordered busing in the hope that specialized theme schools would slow white flight and offer options to racial minorities zoned for low-performing schools.

title: Turnabout in Bolivia as Economy Rises From Instability
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  Argentinas currency has plunged, setting off global worries about developing economies. Brazil is struggling to shake concerns over years of sluggish growth. Venezuela, which sits atop the worlds largest oil reserves, has one of the worlds highest inflation rates. Farther afield, countries like Turkey and South Africa have watched their currencies suffer as investors search for safer returns elsewhere.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 17, 2014
description: Its kind of like the one you get for participation. Its really nice. I mean, its not the same as medaling, of course.

title: In Kansas, Right Joins Left to Halt Bill on Gays
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A bill that would have allowed individuals to refuse to provide business services to same-sex couples in Kansas because of religious beliefs met a surprising and quick end last week when conservative senators sided with liberal advocates in saying that the measure promoted discrimination.

title: De Blasio Strikes Conciliatory Note on Pre-K
description: ALBANY  A strong winter sun streamed through the green and yellow stained-glass windows at Wilborn Temple as worshipers swayed and clapped to rousing hymns and chants of Praise the Lord.

title: Body of Michele Savoia, Fashion Designer, Found in Hudson River
description: The body of a fashion designer known for his flamboyant vintage clothing was pulled from the Hudson River on Sunday, days after he apparently slipped and fell into the water while trying to board his boat at the Chelsea Piers, the police and a friend said.

title: Sleepless in New York
description: Dear Diary:

title: Downton Recap, Episode 7: Advice From the Dowager
description: [Programming note: this weeks regularly scheduled recap of Downton Abbey will not be seen, so that we can bring you this edition of Dear Dowager Countess, the popular advice column that is syndicated in hundreds of fictional British newspapers of the early 20th century. Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess of Grantham, is a member of the aristocracy, president of the Downton Cottage Hospital and a multiple winner of the Best Bloom in the Village award. She is not a licensed therapist and her views do not necessarily represent those of this newspaper or anyone born after World War I.]

title: Tonight Show Returns to New York After Nearly 42 Years
description: On Monday night, for the first time in almost 42 years, NBCs Tonight show will be hosted from New York. The show, which invented the form of entertainment known as late-night television, is returning to the place of its birth: Manhattan.

title: Polk Awards Honor Articles on N.S.A. Surveillance
description: Four journalists who revealed the National Security Agencys vast electronic data mining operation were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2013, announced on Sunday by Long Island University, which administers the prizes.

title: Merkel Backs Plan to Keep European Data in Europe
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has embraced proposals to create European data networks that would keep emails and other communications on the European side of the Atlantic, farther from prying American eyes, and said she would raise the matter this week with President Franois Hollande of France.

title: Science Linking Drought to Global Warming Remains Matter of Dispute
description: In delivering aid to drought-stricken California last week, President Obama and his aides cited the state as an example of what could be in store for much of the rest of the country as human-caused climate change intensifies.

title: Crossing His Fingers, Yankees Teixeira Counts on Full Comeback From Wrist Injury
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Robinson Cano is gone, Derek Jeter is trying to come back from a twice-broken ankle at 39, and Alex Rodriguez is suspended. In other words, the Yankees infield, once a dominant feature of a World Series champion, has been sacked by free agency, age, infirmity and penalty.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 16, 2014
A Poet Mines Memories of Drug Addiction
description: Gil Fagiani pulled out a copy of White Lightning, a tabloid from 1972, whose yellowed, brittle pages declared revolution. Inside, he pointed to a polemic he wrote headlined Racism and Dope. It described how he  a heroin addict with white, middle-class roots  was let off by the police with a warning inside an East Harlem tenement while his would-be connection, a Puerto Rican ex-con, was stripped, arrested and clubbed.

title: Tunisian B-Boys Biggest Battle: Keeping Youths From Extremism
description: BEN AOUN, Tunisia  The youth center in this small provincial town is brimming with energy on a Saturday morning. Teenage girls in pink tracksuits compete in a fencing tournament in one room, and soccer teams play on a bright emerald green patch on the far side of the compound. But the most intense activity is inside a classroom where youths of all ages are crammed around a dance floor watching break dancers test their skills and wits against one another to a thumping music track.

title: Fallout From the Auto Unions Defeat
description: In recent months, a majority of workers at the Volkswagen car assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., reportedly signed cards in favor of joining the United Auto Workers.

title: Abbas, Talking to Israeli Students About Peace, Finds a Receptive Audience
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A decade ago, after the suicide bombings of the second Palestinian uprising, Israelis mostly came to Ramallah and the Mukata, the West Bank headquarters of the Palestinian leadership here, in tanks or armored military vehicles. On Sunday, about 300 Israeli students and youth leaders arrived in busloads to meet President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority for a conversation about the peace process.

title: Girls Recap: A Beach House and a Fight
description: How perfect is it that the Shoshi Games tumblr was born mere days ago?

title: Love Fine With Timberwolves but Hungry to Win
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The amateur mind-reading bothers Kevin Love the most, even though he caused most of it.

title: Reporting From the Webs Underbelly
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the last year, Eastern European cybercriminals have stolen Brian Krebss identity a half dozen times, brought down his website, included his name and some unpleasant epithets in their malware code, sent fecal matter and heroin to his doorstep, and called a SWAT team to his home just as his mother was arriving for dinner.

title: One Step Goes Awry, and Mulders Pitching Comeback Ends
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Mark Mulder was always proud that the competition never drove him from the game. When Mulder was healthy, he was a force. His shoulder betrayed him after 103 major league victories in his 20s, and he accepted the occupational hazard. He did not miss baseball, he said, because he knew his body would not let him play it.

title: South Africas Growing Pains
description: South Africa  the democratic version fathered by Nelson Mandela  turns 20 this year. Like most adolescents emerging into adulthood, it has issues. It could use more impulse control, better self-esteem, less conformity to peer pressure and some plain old parental wisdom. For those of us who watch and root for this struggling young democracy, the year began with a disappointing setback.

title: The Highs and Lows of City Life
description: Early this month, Michael M. Grynbaum of The New York Times took a look at New Yorks Bunyanesque mayor, Bill de Blasio, and how he takes in his new job from his elevated viewpoint. At 6-foot-5, Mr. de Blasio is the tallest mayor in the citys modern history, requiring City Hall to make a series of ergonomic adjustments. So we wondered about other New Yorkers, how they navigate the city daily, and whether for them bigness is a burden too. Here are some of the stories  edited for space  that we heard from New Yorkers, tall or not:

title: What to Watch: Monday, Feb. 17
description: FIGURE SKATING The Americans Meryl Davis and Charlie White, who won the Olympic short dance Sunday, are a solid free dance performance away from a gold medal. Davis and White, the reigning world champions, earned 78.89 points and lead the 2010 gold medalists, Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir of Canada, by 2.56. The two teams train together in the Detroit area and share a coach. NBCSN, 10 a.m.

title: Corrections: February 17, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Punching Above Its Weight, Upstart Netflix Pokes at HBO
description: On the night of the Golden Globes ceremony last month, Netflix and HBO held dueling parties at the Beverly Hilton hotel. Bono and Julia Roberts mingled underneath a bejeweled tent as Netflix, the upstart streaming service, joined forces for the party with the Weinstein Company and celebrated a small piece of history  its first Globe, for House of Cards, its splashy entrant into original programming. At HBOs party, Matt Damon and Lady Gaga sipped drinks by the pool as the cable network toasted its two awards, pushing its total to 101.

title: U.S. in Nordic Combined: Its About Now
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  It is one of the rarest of rarities: Americans attempting to win medals in Nordic combined in consecutive Winter Games.

title: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Critic of Police Policies Basks in a de Blasio Moment
description: If Mayor Bill de Blasios announcement on Jan. 30 that his administration would agree to reform the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk tactic was a stunning about-face for a city that has promoted aggressive policing for nearly two decades, there was a smaller surprise, for those with long memories, in his choice of one guest. Sitting near the mayor was Eric L. Adams, a former police officer, longtime irritant to several mayors and police commissioners, former state senator, and now, Brooklyn borough president.

title: Saving an Endangered British Species: The Pub
description: LONDON  One by one, the pubs are disappearing in Hampstead, a jewel-box village of cobbled lanes and Georgian homes that has become one of this citys most fashionable neighborhoods. The Nags Head has become a realty office. The King of Bohemia is now a clothing shop. The Hare & Hounds has been replaced with an apartment building.

title: Biathlon Penalty Loop Is Like the Dunce Cap of the Olympics
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  For many Olympians, there is no place more wretched these days than a 150-meter patch of snow, ringed with bright red cones, that sits in the corner of the biathlon stadium.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Washingtons Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Writers Guild Plans Forum on Affordable Care Act
description: LOS ANGELES  On Tuesday night, an expected crowd of 100 or so screenwriters and others will gather in Lower Manhattan at the headquarters of the Writers Guild of America East to hear thoughts about the Affordable Care Act and its place in comedy and drama.

title: Hudson, Gallerist and Nurturer of Artists, Dies at 63
description: Hudson, a former dancer and performance artist known only by his last name, who went on to become one of the most prescient, independent-minded and admired gallerists of his generation, died on Feb. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: Venezuelan Leader Announces Expulsion of 3 U.S. Officials
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  After several days of student-led protests against his government, President Nicols Maduro said Sunday that he was expelling three American consular officials who he said had been visiting universities here.

title: Bollywood Superstars Movie Gets Tangled in Electoral Politics
description: NEW DELHI  For most Bollywood movies, earning 1 billion rupees at the box office would be seen as a resounding success.

title: Jacques le Sourd, Theater Critic, Dies at 64
description: Jacques le Sourd, a theater critic whose Broadway and Off Broadway reviews for The Journal News of Westchester were syndicated nationally in the Gannett Companys newspaper chain for three decades, died on Feb. 5 in Preston, Lancashire, England. He was 64.

title: Water-Cleaning Technology Could Help Farmers
description: FIREBAUGH, Calif.  The giant solar receiver installed on a wheat field here in Californias agricultural heartland slowly rotates to track the sun and capture its energy. The 377-foot array, however, does not generate electricity but instead creates heat used to desalinate water.

title: Lashing Out
description: So much happens in the blink of an eye. A single flutter, a slow sweep downwards: What will a womans eyelashes reveal? Interest? Curiosity? Sexual chemistry? Ennui? Tenderness? Excitement? Or distress, as in that most famous Man Ray image of 1930-32, Tears? Those perfect globules of glass are clearly fake, but the eyelashes give pause for thought. How did their owner get such precise separation? Such fabulous length? Those wonderful eighth-note-shaped ends?

title: Before Blaming the Robots, Lets Get the Policy Right
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Caring for the Alzheimers Caregiver
description: Paul Divinigracia does not consider himself a saint. But to observe how he cares for his wife, Virgie, now 11 years into Alzheimers disease, you might think otherwise.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) LAS MARTHAS (2014) In the border town of Laredo, Tex., debutante season is centered on bicultural celebrations, many of them involving its city sister, Nuevo Laredo, Mexico. The pre-eminent event is the invitation-only Colonial Ball, hosted by the Society of Martha Washington, in which young women, most of them Mexican-American, make their debuts in elaborate colonial gowns  weighing as much as 100 pounds and costing up to $30,000 representing figures from Americas revolutionary history. Their goal: to recreate a party hosted by Martha herself. In this Independent Lens documentary, the director Cristina Ibarra follows two of the debutantes  one from a prominent Laredo family, the other a newcomer from Mexico  as they prepare for this rite of passage. (Above, the debutante Laura Garza Hovel.)

title: Electrifying Rivalry and Overheated Scoreboard in N.B.A. All-Star Game
description: NEW ORLEANS  After 45 minutes worth of pregame festivities that included a music concert, an appearance by Snoop Dogg, streamers that fell from the ceiling and player introductions, LeBron James finally christened the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday night in familiar fashion: with a steal near midcourt, a handful of loping strides and a dunk with just the right amount of ferocity.

title: Well-Conditioned St. Johns Runs Georgetown Out of the Garden
description: Throughout the course of its march back to respectability in the Big East, St. Johns came to rely on two numbers.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: The Stars Come Back Out
description: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Popular Demand
description: Smartphone sales totaled 968 million units in 2013, capturing 53.6 percent of the worldwide market and outselling feature mobile phones for the first time.

title: The Weeks Mens College Basketball Games to Watch
description: 13 LOUISVILLE at 10 CINCINNATI

title: NBC Pushes Too Far in Bringing Bode Miller to Tears
description: Bode Miller had just tied for a bronze medal in the mens super-G at the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, on Sunday and it was time to be interviewed. NBC had already established Millers quest as an emotional story line, putting a microphone on his wife, Morgan, to hear her reactions to his races, and having the couple sit for an interview with Tom Brokaw. He was being humanized  as the changed man, the family man, the mature 36-year-old whose brother had died last year.

title: Indonesia Takes Aim at Australia Over Spying on Talks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias foreign minister said Monday that it was a bit mind-boggling that the Australian intelligence agency had spied on his nations trade deliberations with American officials.

title: Economic Growth in Thailand Cools to 0.6%
description: HONG KONG  It was, until recently, one of the fastest-growing economies in Asia. It shrugged off coups, street protests and natural disasters. And it earned the nickname Teflon Thailand.

title: Ethiopian Co-Pilot Hijacks Jet, Then Asks for Asylum in Geneva
description: GENEVA  The co-pilot of an Ethiopian Airlines passenger jet en route to Rome from Ethiopia seized control of the Boeing 767-300 early on Monday and flew it to Geneva, where he asked for asylum, a spokesman for the Geneva police said.

title: As Edgy Chinese Films Sweep Berlin Festival, Pride and Caution at Home
description: After a very long wait, Chinese films have finally burst forth magnificently again in the worlds film festivals, with fireworks, the state news agency Xinhua wrote. The proud statement was a play on the Chinese title for Black Coal, Thin Ice, the gritty detective movie by Diao Yinan that took the top award at the just-concluded 64th Berlin International Film Festival: Fireworks in Daylight.

title: Differing Accounts of Recent Violence in Xinjiang
description: The ethnic polarization troubling the northwestern Chinese region of Xinjiang has brought a grim succession of bloody incidents pitting Uighurs against security forces  and has also been echoed in the vastly different interpretations from the government and from advocates of Uighur self-determination that invariably follow those incidents. The latest bloodshed has followed that pattern.

title: A Note on Presidents Day
description: We are taking the day off on this national holiday  and, since many schools will be out this week, we are also suspending daily lesson plans until Monday, Feb. 24.

title: The Hunter Collection
description: Alasdhair Willis is the creative director for Hunter, the English boot maker, and its new Hunter Original clothing. The advice from his wife, the designer Stella McCartney? Trust your instincts.

title: For the Love of Art, and Money
description: LONDON  A record 413 million pounds of Impressionist and modern art sold at Sothebys and Christies in one week. Nearly 200,000 went for a canvas painted by a 24 year-old with a fire extinguisher a week later. Auctions of high-end artworks were booming in London in February, to be sure. But in the 21st centurys increasingly financialized market  where art is treated as an investment and where paintings are tracked and traded instantaneously  one has to ask, what does the word collector mean nowadays?

title: Bouygues to Take 1.4 Billion Euro Write-Down on Its Alstom Stake
description: LONDON  The French conglomerate Bouygues said on Monday that it would take a 1.4 billion euro write-down on its stake in the transport and energy company Alstom.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Wendy Davis and the Challenge of Biography
description: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of this weeks cover story about the Texas gubernatorial candidate Wendy Davis. Draper is the author of When the Tea Party Came to Town. He last wrote for the magazine about the National Rifle Association.

title: South Korean Lawmaker Jailed on Treason Charges
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean court sentenced an opposition lawmaker to 12 years in prison on Monday for forming a revolutionary organization and conspiring to start an armed revolt to overthrow the Seoul government in the event of war with North Korea.

title: Waffle House Shows Atlanta How to Handle a Snowstorm
description: Atlantas second snow jam of 2014 shut down practically every business of every size in the city. But I dont think we can entirely blame Mother Nature or even the governor this time for the lost revenue and customers we will all be adding up at the end of the month.

title: Readers Comments on Freedom of Speech in India
description: NEW DELHI  Last week, Penguin, one of Indias biggest publishing houses, declared that it would withdraw and destroy remaining copies of a book on Hinduism written by Wendy Doniger after Dinanath Batra, a right-wing campaigner filed a lawsuit terming the book dirty and perverse.

title: Christopher Kane: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Gravity Takes 6 Prizes at Baftas
description: Considered the last major set of trophies before the Academy Awards, the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars, were handed out on Sunday, and the winners may presage ours  or they may further muddle the race.

title: Cornelius Gurlitt, German at Center of Art-Cache Case, Sets Up Website
description: BERLIN  Cornelius Gurlitt, the 81-year-old German who inherited a collection of drawings, prints and paintings from his father, an art dealer who worked for the Nazis, has set up a website to provide his side of the story.

title: Roksanda Ilincic: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: C.V. Starr and Partner Buy Health Care Concern in a $4.4 Billion Deal
description: Updated, 6:24 p.m. | A group of investors led by an affiliate of C. V. Starr & Company and the Swiss investment firm Partners Group announced on Monday that it had acquired MultiPlan, a health care cost management company.

title: The Trouble With Being Abstruse (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Political scientists who write clearly for a broader audience are upset with Nick Kristof for saying that political scientists no longer write for a broader audience. Im not going to get into that fight. I do want to register one point, however: In my field there is indeed a problem with abstruseness, with the many academics who never even try to put their thoughts in plain language.

title: Live Stream | Burberrys Fall 2014 Collection at London Fashion Week
description: The latest womens collection from Burberry Prorsum at London fashion week.

title: The Ski Jumpers View
description: A look from the dizzying heights at the top of ski jump, where the women made their first jumps in Olympic history.

title: London Fashion Week: Mary Katrantzou Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

title: Medals, and Time, Slip Away
description: SOCHI, Russia  After finishing her 1,500-meter race Sunday, Heather Richardson stepped off the speedskating oval and buried her face in her hands. She did not have to say a thing. The leader board said it all.

title: Erdem: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Fog Postpones Snowboard Cross and Biathlon Events
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  As fans gathered for the mens snowboard cross race on Monday at the Winter Olympics, they could barely see beyond the finish line. Competitors headed to the starting area on a chairlift, but it was an ascent into a white unknown, the thick fog obscuring even the chair in front of them.

title: Weekends Made for Maple
description: Adirondack maple syrup producers will open their maple farms and sugar bushes across the six-million-acre park for one of New York States tastiest traditions  Maple Weekends, this year on March 22 and 23 and March 29 and 30.

title: Partys New Leader Agrees to Form Government in Italy
description: ROME  Pledging to commit all his enthusiasm, courage and energy to the task, Matteo Renzi, the leader of the Democratic Party, said on Monday that he would try to form a new government that could stabilize Italys politics and economy.

title: In Our Pages: February 18
description: 1889: Demonstration in Buda Pesth

title: Threes, a New Addictive Puzzle Game
description: If I can just connect the red 2 card with the blue 1 card, and then slide together those 3s, Ill be able to get another 12 andSorry, youll have to excuse me, Im in the middle of another game ofThrees, the latest game for iOS that Im slightly obsessed with.

title: Tepid Economic Growth in Japan
description: TOKYO  The Japanese economy grew at the tepid rate of 1 percent in the final quarter of 2013, data showed Monday, falling short of analysts expectations and heightening concerns that the countrys recovery might not be strong enough to weather an impending sales tax increase, a worsening trade balance and other problems expected this year.

title: Philomenas Composer: Turning a Secret Into a Score
description: Having been nominated now six times in eight years, the composer Alexandre Desplat is a veteran of Academy campaigning. He called his latest Oscar-nominated work, the score for Philomena, among his most difficult assignments, and not only because it had more music than his first Oscar-nominated film, The Queen.

title: 3 Who Worked at Barclays Face Charges in Libor Case
description: Updated, 7:16 p.m. | LONDON  Regulators in Britain said on Monday that they had begun criminal proceedings against three former Barclays employees suspected in the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate.

title: Standing Out Amid Monotony in Residential Design
description: David Boyle did not build his house out of shipping containers to be hip, though he does live in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He left the water pipes exposed not in pursuit of an industrial chic aesthetic, but to make them easier to fix.

title: No Beauty Goes Unexplored in La Clemenza di Tito
description: Munich  Kirill Petrenko, the new general music director of the Bavarian State Opera, is enjoying a honeymoon with his audience. He assumed the post in September, fresh from conducting Wagners Ring cycle at the Bayreuth Festival, where he won a slew of accolades, even as Frank Castorfs new production was roasted to a crisp by critics.

title: Apple Compote
description: Apple compote is what the French call applesauce. It is utterly simple to make, but freshly made it is several cuts above storebought. Serve it warm, for a comforting dessert, topped with a dollop of crme fraiche if you like. Or use it as a filling for crpes.

title: Apple and Bitter Lettuces Salad
description: You can use a mix of lettuces for this salad, and you can also add some milder lettuce. My favorite combination is endive, radicchio and arugula. It is a simple salad with wonderful contrasts. Dice the apples small.

title: Apple, Lime and Chia Smoothie
description: I love the pale green color of this smoothie. Granny Smith and lime make a great marriage and the yogurt and chia seeds make the sweet and tart smoothie substantial enough to get me through the morning.

title: Buckwheat Crpes With Caramelized Apples
description: Buckwheat crpes have wonderful earthy/nutty flavor. They are equally at home with a sweet or savory topping. If you have any caramelized apples left over, stir them into your yogurt for breakfast.

title: Country Bread With Apples
description: This is a whole wheat version of a classic Norman country bread. Normandy is apple country and apples find their way into many dishes in this region. I came across the bread in Bread Alone by Daniel Leader, and have adapted the recipe. The dough ferments overnight in the refrigerator, and after it has come back to room temperature the chopped apples are kneaded in. It goes beautifully with cheese.

title: On Short-Track Speedskating
description: Short-track speedskaters whip around a relatively small oval, pushing forward in short bursts of acceleration on extremely sharp blades.

title: A Conversation About Young Wall Streeters
description: Kevin Roose, a former reporter for DealBook, has been at New York magazine since 2012, writing about the more offbeat aspects of Wall Streets culture.

title: Burberry Prorsum: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Former Prime Minister of Georgia Convicted of Corruption
description: TBILISI, Georgia  A former prime minister of Georgia, Ivane Merabishvili, was convicted on Monday of public corruption charges and sentenced to five years in prison, making him the most senior official yet to be convicted in a series of seemingly politically motivated prosecutions that followed a change in control of the government in 2012.

title: In Moscow, Russians Protest Disallowed Hockey Goal
description: MOSCOW  It was the biggest demonstration so far concerning the Sochi Olympics, and it had nothing to do with gay rights, environmental damage or corruption.

title: London Fashion Week: Jonathan Saunders Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: Humble-Nishiyama Randomness Game
description: This weeks challenge was suggested by Steve Humble (aka Dr Maths), a mathematics educator from Newcastle University. The game starts with a standard 52-card deck of playing cards, which includes, obviously, 26 red cards and 26 black cards. At the start of a game, each player announces, one player after the other, a three-color sequence she will be watching for as the deck of cards is dealt out card by card. Cards are then dealt, and when a players sequence appears in a series of three consecutive cards, all cards in play are removed from the game as a winning trick. This continues until the full pack of 52 cards is exhausted. At the end, the player with the most tricks is declared the winner.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 17
description: Biathlon, figure skating and a thick fog that postponed some events on Day 12 of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

title: The Beatles Started the British Invasion, but Not One in Cars
description: On Feb. 9, 1964, the Beatles took to the stage on The Ed Sullivan Show. It wasnt long before other bands  the Rolling Stones, the Kinks, the Who and the Yardbirds, among others  joined what is now known as the British Invasion.

title: Wireless Charging: Still Plenty of Kinks in the Cord
description: As personal devices proliferate  smartphones, wearable fitness bands, Kindles, tablets, smart glasses  our charger collections are starting to look like the electrical outlet in the movie A Christmas Story.

title: U.N. Panel Says North Korean Leader Could Face Trial
description: GENEVA  A United Nations panel has served notice to Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, that he may be personally held liable in court for crimes against humanity committed by state institutions and officials under his direct control.

title: Driving Under the Influence, of Marijuana
description: If you are pulled over on suspicion of drunken driving, the police officer is likely to ask you to complete three tasks: Follow a pen with your eyes while the officer moves it back and forth; get out of the car and walk nine steps, heel to toe, turn on one foot and go back; and stand on one leg for 30 seconds.

title: Indian Journalist Charged With Rape of a Reporter
description: NEW DELHI  The police in the coastal state of Goa charged Tarun J. Tejpal, an investigative journalist and magazine editor, with raping and sexually assaulting a staff reporter during a November encounter in a hotel elevator.

title: Attendance Up, Disney to Add Hotel Rooms at Hong Kong Park
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company on Monday said that it planned to increase the number of hotel rooms at Hong Kong Disneyland by 75 percent following gains in attendance and profit at the eight-year-old resort.

title: Penn State Looks South in Naming New President
description: Eric J. Barron, the president of Florida State University and a nationally known climatologist, was named on Monday as the president of Penn State University, which has spent the past year trying to find a new leader as it continues to wrestle with the aftermath of the Jerry Sandusky child sex-abuse scandal.

title: Peter Pilotto: Fall 2014 RTW
description: London

title: Meryl Davis and Charlie White Give U.S. First Olympic Gold in Ice Dancing
description: SOCHI, Russia  When Meryl Davis and Charlie White began skating together in suburban Detroit, she was 9 and he was 8. It was an awkward age, when a girl is not yet comfortable looking into a boys eyes, even for the theatricality of sport.

title: Jailed Russian Critic of Sochi Olympics Now on Hunger Strike
description: SOCHI, Russia  An environmental activist critical of the Olympic Games who was sentenced to three years in prison last week has gone on a hunger strike, members of a public oversight committee who met with him in jail said Monday.

title: The Peruvian Green Velvet Tarantulas Gift
description: Venoms from spiders and other animals, fine-tuned by evolution to stun and paralyze prey, are an abundant source of painkillers and other drugs. But screening for useful toxins can be an arduous process.

title: Neil Gaiman Brings a Storytelling Performance to the States
description: The novelist Neil Gaiman (American Gods; The Graveyard Book) who turned his novelette The Truth Is a Cave in the Black Mountains into a performance that is a synchronized mix of music, art and storytelling for audiences abroad, is bringing the show to these shores.

title: The Daily Shoe | Erdems Ruby Sparklers
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Retreat on Debt Fight Seen as G.O.P. Campaign Salvo
description: WASHINGTON  Senators Mitch McConnell and John Cornyn, two Republican leaders facing primary challenges, knew they would take an immediate political hit from the Republicans Tea Party wing by voting to clear the way for a debt-limit increase. They also knew that their willingness to cast that vote would enhance their partys chances of gaining a majority in the Senate next year.

title: At New-York Historical Society, Civil War History Told Through Textiles
description: In time for the upcoming sesquicentennial marking the end of the Civil War, the New-York Historical Society is featuring the exhibition Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts & Context in the Civil War. Running April 4 through Aug. 24, the exhibition uses approximately 130 objects, including quilts, clothing and other artifacts, to explore the ways that textiles expressed the eras politics and culture. The show, from the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., where it was shown in 2012, includes additional artifacts from the New-York Historical Societys collection.

title: Treating Tuberculosis and AIDS Together Saves Lives
description: Patients who have multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and AIDS are more likely to live if they get simultaneous treatment for both diseases rather than waiting weeks to start the AIDS treatment, a new study has found.

title: Cigarette Ads Come Back to British TV
description: LONDON  About 50 years after Britain banned television advertisements for cigarettes, they are back. Except this time they are for the electronic kind.

title: Bill Cunningham | Ugh!
description: Fashion and reality had a head-on smashup during Fashion Week, with more than 250 shows throughout the city in often freezing, snowy or slushy weather.

title: Russia to Release Loan Money for Ukraine, Lifting Leader
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The protracted struggle for Ukraine between Russia and the West was on vivid display on Monday with Russia throwing an unexpected financial lifeline to the embattled Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, just as Germany rolled out an unusually high-level reception for two of the presidents most ardent opponents.

title: A Writer Recalls His Amnesia
description: David Stuart MacLeans first book, The Answer to the Riddle Is Me, opens with a scene out of Robert Ludlum: The protagonist wakes from a blackout to find himself on a crowded train platform in India, with no idea who he is or what hes doing in a foreign country.

title: The Tall and the Small
description: Q. Among dogs, small breeds often live longer than larger ones. Is there any evidence that life expectancy for taller humans is also briefer?

title: Monday Motorsports: A Demolition Derby at Daytona
description: A new Nascar season got off to an exciting start over the weekend at Daytona International Speedway in Florida with a demolition derby-caliber Sprint Unlimited shootout. Denny Hamlin won the bruising Unlimited after a late race rally, and a Sprint Cup rookie, Austin Dillon, set the fastest qualifying time for the Feb. 23 Daytona 500.

title: U.S. Bombards One Swedish Goaltender, Then Another
description: SOCHI, Russia  Add another competitor to the list of extreme athletes at the Winter Olympics, those skicross racers, snowboarders and skiers who risk life and limb for their one shining moment. Valentina Wallner is her name, and it can be argued that there was no rougher patch of ice in all Rosa Khutor Extreme Park than the goal crease Wallner tried mightily to defend Monday when her country, Sweden, played the United States in a womens hockey semifinal at Shayba Arena.

title: Little Optimism as Iran Nuclear Talks Resume
description: VIENNA  Talks with Iran over a permanent agreement on its nuclear program begin on Tuesday in Vienna, but there is little immediate optimism over a negotiation that is expected to last up to a year.

title: Skating With a Smile, No Matter What
description: SOCHI, Russia  Hockey players gnash their teeth. Ski jumpers can hide their fear behind goggles. Speedskaters huff and puff as they round the bend.

title: Russians Return to Cyprus, a Favorite Tax Haven
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  When the Cypriot government forced bank depositors  many of them Russian  to pay their share of an international bailout last spring, Vasilis Zertaliss phone started ringing.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Dewy Skin and Modern Mermaid Hair at Mary Katrantzou
description: I dont know why Im telling you this, but we have changed the makeup three times in the past hour, the makeup artist Val Garland said backstage at Mary Katrantzou. Garlands early tests had included stronger, darker eyes and lips in an attempt to go someplace different from Katrantzous typical fresh-faced runway look. But why do away with a great thing? The designer and Garland decided to stick with what Garland called very Mary makeup. The Katrantzou woman is pure and statuesque, Garland said. What stands out ultimately is her skin. To complement the architecture and craftsmanship of the new collection, which strayed from the designers famed and oft-imitated digital prints, Garland opted for a down-to-earth and dewy look created using MAC products. Models lips were matte and natural, cheekbones were dusted with pink blush and eyelids sported a faint wash of silver. I havent picked up a tube of mascara yet in London, Garland said.

title: Quadruple Bombing in Baghdad Kills at Least 25
description: BAGHDAD  Three bombs that targeted public markets and a fourth bomb placed outside a Shiite mosque exploded Monday night in Baghdad, killing 25 people and wounding dozens, the police reported.

title: Holcomb Skilled at Ending 62-Year Slumps
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Four years ago at the Vancouver Games, Steven Holcomb helped end a 62-year medal drought in bobsled by piloting the United States to a gold medal in the four-man event. On Monday at Sanki Sliding Center here, Holcomb did it again, this time teaming with Steve Langton to drive an American sled to its first medal in 62 years in the two-man.

title: Chinese Officials Widen Campaign Against Vices
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government has widened a crackdown on prostitution, gambling and drug use to major provinces across the country, according to reports on Monday in state-run news organizations.

title: Itching: More Than Skin-Deep
description: The experiment was not for the squirmish. Volunteers were made to itch like crazy on one arm, but not allowed to scratch. Then they were whisked into an M.R.I. scanner to see what parts of their brains lit up when they itched, when researchers scratched them and when they were finally allowed to scratch themselves.

description: London

title: Earwaxs Smell Influenced by Ethnicity
description: The smell of a persons earwax depends partly on his ethnic origin, a new study reports, suggesting that the substance could be an overlooked source of personal information.
