The program also chronicles the creation of the Broadway musical The Last Ship, with music and lyrics by Sting, above, and a book by John Logan and Brian Yorkey, which is to begin previews on Sept. 30 at the Neil Simon Theater. The Last Ship contains Stings first new songs in nearly a decade, and he has said that they came in a surge, Nate Chinen wrote in The New York Times. The breakthrough was in writing for voices other than his own, though Sting admits that one song features the self-taught, pompous intellectual of the shipyard, played by me, of course. Mr. Chinen added, The dream-filled boy that Sting once was, and the privileged artist he became, have that much in common.

title: The Red Chains of Bureaucracy That Torment Chinese
description: The Germans coined a word for its excesses: Behrdengang. Franz Kafka, the great novelist of pain, described its dehumanizing effect: The chains of tormented mankind are made out of red tape. And Confucian China may have perfected it: bureaucracy.

title: North Carolina Rallies Late to Upset No. 5 Duke
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Inside the Dean Smith Dome, fans clad in Carolina blue lusted for an upset. They roared for it, demanded it and urged the underdog Tar Heels to complete their mission against No. 5 Duke.

title: Ukraine Has Deal, but Both Russia and Protesters Appear Wary
description: KIEV, Ukraine  A deal aimed at ending a lethal spiral of violence in Ukraine began to show serious strains late Friday just hours after it had been signed, with angry protesters shouting down opposition members of Parliament who negotiated the accord and a militant leader threatening armed attacks if President Viktor F. Yanukovych did not step down by morning.

title: Corrections: February 21, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Negotiating in Ukraine
description: Antigovernment protesters and police clashed violently on Independence Square in Kiev this week.

title: Profit Falls at French Luxury and Sportswear Group Kering
description: PARIS  Profit at Kering, the French luxury-to-lifestyle conglomerate, slumped last year, reflecting sharply weaker sales at Puma, its struggling sportswear brand, as well as a slowdown in growth at Gucci, its flagship high-end brand.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Feb. 21, 2014
description: Use the following question for practice in rewording phrases.

title: 6 Qs About the News | An Oscar-Nominated Song in a Hit Movie
description: In The Nominees Are Blockbusters Melena Ryzik writes about the making of Frozen. Watch the video and read the article to answer the questions.

title: Born by a River, Watching the Change
description: The interplay of images in LaToya Ruby Fraziers Landscape of the Body (Epilepsy Test) is haunting: a portrait of the artists mother in a disheveled hospital bed hooked up to monitors, juxtaposed with a shot of the Braddock, Pa., hospitals demolition taken shortly after her stay, its tangled wiring exposed (Slide 14).

title: How Much of a Daredevil Are You?
description: How much physical stimulation do you need? How comfortable are you in taking physical risks when you do sports? Are you always trying to go faster or higher, or are you happier with a slower, more controlled experience?

title: Shell to Sell Refinery and Gas Stations in Australia
description: LONDON  Royal Dutch Shell said Friday that it would sell most of its Australian refining and marketing business to Vitol, a large commodity trading house, for about $2.6 billion.

title: Snapdeal, the EBay of India, Sees Plenty of Room to Grow
description: BANGALORE  Snapdeal and Flipkart, Indias two largest online marketplaces, are frequently recipients of honorific, hopeful nicknames. They are, respectively, called the eBay and Amazon of India.

title: The Courage of Transgender Soldiers
description: SYDNEY, Australia  IT was 2 a.m., just a few days before Christmas, in a remote part of Afghanistan. Eight hours into a 16-hour shift, Ryan, a 23-year-old American naval sailor, was standing tense and alert, watching the footage of soldiers undertaking a nearby mission on a screen in front of him.

title: South Korea Aids North as Families Are Reunited
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Friday approved a shipment of $988,000 worth of medicine and powdered milk for North Korea and promised more humanitarian aid as the two Koreas continued the emotional reunions of families separated by the Korean War six decades ago.

title: New York Today: Winter Interruptus
description: Updated 11:32 a.m.

title: Stray Dogs and Stateless Babies
description: ON National Geographic Traveler Magazines Best of the World list this year, Sarajevo joined such select destinations as Liechtenstein, Puglia and Rocky Mountain National Park. But had the innocent tourist recently visited the Balkan urban phoenix, as the list labeled the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, he would most certainly have run into packs of stray dogs roaming the city.

title: Times Minute | Profiting From Marijuana
description: Also on the Minute, the roots of the violence in Ukraine's opposition groups and watch for record online viewership for today's hockey match between the U.S. and Canada.

title: Times Minute | Profiting From Marijuana
description: In the Video

title: Sleep Apnea May Worsen Diabetes
description: Sleep apnea can worsen blood sugar control in people with Type 2 diabetes by disrupting the deepest stage of sleep, a new study suggests. The findings provide another good reason for people with sleep apnea to wear a CPAP mask that helps assure uninterrupted breathing, the standard treatment for the condition, throughout the night.

title: Billionaires Arrest Intensifies Focus on Former Security Chief
description: A Chinese billionaire, Liu Han, stands accused of running a mafia-style gang that ran roughshod over one of the countrys most populous provinces for more than a decade, reportedly killing nine people and bullying villagers into surrendering their land to fuel his growing empire that included real estate, mining and natural gas.

title: Beijing Official Detained in Investigation of Former Security Chief
description: HONG KONG  A Communist Party corruption investigation focusing on the former head of Chinas domestic security apparatus has reached into the secretive realm of the intelligence services with the detention of a senior official, people close to party and military leaders said this week.

title: Sweden Beats Finland, 2-1, to Advance to Hockey Final
description: For the second time in three Olympics, Sweden will be playing for the gold medal in mens hockey. Sweden, the 2006 gold medalist, defeated its longtime rival Finland, 2-1, Thursday.

title: Your Ancestors, Your Fate
description: Inequality of income and wealth has risen in America since the 1970s, yet a large-scale research study recently found that social mobility hadnt changed much during that time. How can that be?

title: 2 Prominent Women Under Detention Are Hospitalized
description: Two prominent women  Liu Xia and Cao Shunli  were hospitalized in poor health this week, after months or years of detention, according to their lawyers and friends.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Bets on Users First and Profits Later
description: Technology companies have always been paranoid about missing the next big thing, be it email, e-commerce or social media, David Gelles reports.

title: A Business Owner Talks About Having to Cut Costs to Stay Competitive
description: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, Susan Parker shared some of the challenges facing her company, Bari Jay.

title: Militants Attack Presidential Palace in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  In a deadly attack on the heart of the Somali government, multiple explosions and a firefight erupted on Friday near the presidential palace in Mogadishu, killing 12 people, nine of them militants, officials said. The Shabab, the militant Somali Islamist group, claimed responsibility.

title: Detroit Outlines Map to Solvency, Stressing Repair
description: DETROIT  Seven months after this city entered bankruptcy, its leaders on Friday presented a federal judge with the first official road map to Detroits future  documents designed to show how it aims to settle its $18 billion debt to creditors and make itself livable again.

title: Techs New Feeding Frenzy
description: TECHS NEW FEEDING FRENZY | As soon as Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging start-up, for up to $19 billion, almost everyone asked the same question: Why? What it boils down to is Facebooks fear of missing out (F.O.M.O., for you cool kids). Today, with Google, Facebook and others all fighting for the same customers and wallets, the competition has never been more intense, and big companies have never had to act so quickly  and with such conviction  to avoid being left behind, David Gelles writes in DealBook. But the deal has raised fears that, by valuing the number of users above revenue, Facebook is inflating another dot-com bubble.

title: Applying for College? Writing About Money?
description: The New York Times is seeking college application essays about money, working or social class from current high school seniors. We will publish the best ones in a Your Money column in May (and pay the writers our normal freelance rate), as we did last year. Please send essays to MoneyEssays@nytimes.com.

title: Structural Reform is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels
description: OK, lets be clear: Im in favor of structural reform (as long as its the right kind of reform). Im also in favor of peace, kindness, and good coffee for everyone.

title: Behind These Olympic Doors Is Anyones Guess
description: SOCHI, Russia  Deep in the back alleyways of the Ice Cube Curling Center in the Olympic Park stands a door marked TER Secondary. It is not clear exactly what goes on in there or why it is so close to doors labeled Language Services and Venue Technology Operations, but it is further evidence, if any was needed, that the Olympics occupy an exotic alternative world that makes sense only on its own terms.

title: Court Convicts 8 in 2012 Protest Against Putin
description: MOSCOW  Eight people were convicted on Friday of taking part in a violent protest before the inauguration of President Vladimir V. Putin in 2012, after a prolonged trial that became a symbol of the Kremlins renewed stifling of political dissent.

title: HearSay Economics
description: David Glasner has another interesting post on the history of economic thought, this time on Says Law  which, at least since Keynes, has come to be identified as the doctrine that shortfalls in overall demand arent possible, because money has to be spent on something. If people save more, well, their money goes into banks, which lend it out, so it finances business investment, and overall spending doesnt change.

title: Shredlocks and Lucky Socks
description: Olympic athletes in Sochi talk about the rituals and superstitions that help them focus.

title: Commissioner Bratton on a Threat to Pedestrians
description: Dear Diary:

title: Act of Killing and Oscar Voters Aversion to Violence
description: No feature documentary film in recent years has provoked more debate than Joshua Oppenheimers Act of Killing, one of five nominees for the Oscar in that category. Its not only that Mr. Oppenheimer tackles an extremely difficult subject  the mass murders that followed a military coup in Indonesia in 1965 and resulted in the deaths of as many as a million people  but also the way he tells the story, through extensive use of re-enactments featuring members of death squads that carried out the killings.

title: Aint It Not Grand?
description: Hurray: President Obama has dropped his notion of using a change in the price index to cut Social Security benefits.

title: In Slalom, Mikaela Shiffrin Zips to Bottom and Reaches the Pinnacle
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Mikaela Shiffrin, the 18-year-old wunderkind of ski racing, is a product of a countercultural movement in American youth sports, an initiative of parents who encourage their children to focus on the process of athletic achievement instead of the results. In theory, both the journey and the destination are enhanced.

title: Inadvertently Baring Necessities
description: Although the name Disney is synonymous for some with timeless entertainment, The Jungle Book occupies a special place in Disney company history. Newly released on Blu-ray (as well as on DVD and digital HD), it was the last of the studios animated features to have been made under Walt Disney himself. That pop-culture titan died in December 1966, three years after work on the movie began and 10 months before its release.

title: In the Back of the Bobsled, the Not-So-Scenic Route
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Judith Vis is a member of the Dutch womens bobsled team and, by all accounts, a dutiful and conscientious athlete. Yet earlier this month  only minutes after she completed a practice run at the Sanki Sliding Center  she struggled with a relatively basic question.

title: Stasha Yatchuk Transforms Backstage at Prada
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Stasha Yatchuk (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

title: No Surprise, Fed Was Biggest Buyer of Treasuries in 2013
description: THE Federal Reserve financed most of the governments deficit in 2013, in sharp contrast to the year before, when the Fed did not add to its holdings of Treasury securities. The American private sector appears to have been a net seller of Treasuries in 2013, but the foreign private sector was a substantial buyer, according to government estimates released this week.

title: The Final Battle for a REIT May Be Drawing Near
description: Is this the endgame for the battle to control CommonWealth REIT, or will shareholders once again be left to wait for the Portnoys, the father and son who control the real estate investment concern, to admit defeat?

title: Fed Misread Crisis in 2008, Records Show
description: WASHINGTON  On the morning after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in 2008, most Federal Reserve officials still believed that the American economy would keep growing despite the metastasizing financial crisis.

title: California: 4 Killed at Indian Tribal Meeting
description: A former tribal leader in California opened fire during eviction proceedings on Thursday, killing four people and injuring two others, the police said. The former leader, Sherie Rhoades, 44, shot five people inside the headquarters of the Cedarville Rancheria in Alturas, the police said, before stabbing a sixth person with a knife. Leaders were holding a meeting about evicting several residents, including Ms. Rhoades, the Modoc County Record, a local newspaper, quoted the police as saying. Ms. Rhoades is facing murder and attempted murder charges. The police had not identified the dead, two men and two women, as of midnight Thursday. According to its website, the Cedarville Rancheria is a small, federally recognized tribe of 35 members on 26 acres in Cedarville, about 20 minutes from Alturas.

title: In Our Pages: February 22
description: 1914: Leap Proves Parachutes Value

title: Hundreds of Anne Frank Books Vandalized in Japan
description: TOKYO  Japan on Friday promised to begin an investigation into the mysterious mutilation of hundreds of copies of Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl and other books related to her at public libraries across Tokyo.

title: In Store | Pamela Loves Finer Things
description: I love to layer on a lot of big sterling silver statement jewelry, says Pamela Love, but Im getting a bit more delicate. The young jewelry designer has drawn a celebrity and fashion-world following to her signature bohemian aesthetic since she began making pieces in her Brooklyn apartment in 2006. She has since gotten married and moved into a design studio in Manhattan and is starting to notice that her clientele has been growing up, too. And so, this week, Love has reached another milestone: her first fine-jewelry line called, appropriately, Pamela Love Fine.

title: The Home Crowd at the Sochi Games
description: Russian fans have welcomed the Sochi Games as an opportunity to be creative and patriotic in the way they dress for the events.

title: A Wine Trail, by Ski and Snowshoe
description: In many wine regions of the world, aficionados can bike or hike between tasting rooms. But Michigan offers a novel vineyard-to-vineyard option: by ski and snowshoe.

title: Send a Payment With Square Cash, the Service Thats Free, for Now
description: Its rare that any new product or service quickly and simply makes our financial lives a whole lot easier. Its rarer still that the offering is free.

title: Marginal Marginalia
description: The prime ministers cat; get a haircut.

title: Who Made That Ski Lift?
description: It is essential, wrote the railway magnate William Averell Harriman in a telegram dated April 15, 1936, . . . to develop a method of lifting skiers 2,000 feet above the valley floor. For Americas first ski resort  Idahos Sun Valley  Harriman wanted a new approach to moving skiers up the slopes that would be more comfortable than the pulls and hoists that had come before. So he posed the problem to his staff at the Union Pacific office in Omaha.

title: Reply All: The 2.9.14 Issue
description: SEXLESS BUT EQUAL

title: Red(dit) Alert at the Workplace!
description: I recently realized a colleague posts several times a day to the website Reddit. If the opinions he shares on this site are about his boss or his work environment (or even reveal his political leanings), he could potentially lose his current contract and have a hard time getting a new position in our insular field. I find this colleague to be immature and ill suited for our profession  he seems to spend most of the day posting on Reddit  and some of his posts have made his identity obvious to me. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell him that this behavior could hurt his career? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

title: David J. Hands Lottery Tips
description: Your latest book, The Improbability Principle, aims to prove that extremely improbable events are in fact commonplace. Can you explain that a bit?  Things like roulette wheels coming up in strange configurations or the same lottery numbers hitting two weeks in a row are clearly very rare events, but if you look at the number of lotteries and the number of roulette wheels, then you realize that you should actually expect these sorts of things to happen. I think within the statistical community people accept this. Theyre aware of the impact of the law of truly large numbers.

title: Milan Fashion Week Street Style: Day 2
description: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Milan Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

title: Working to Block Those Advertising Annoyances
description: WITH so much attention to digital overload  too much email, too many photos on Facebook, too many mindless tweets  some of lifes biggest annoyances are still analog, especially when people want to sell you things.

title: Inside the Feds 2008 Proceedings
description: On Friday, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of its policy meetings of 2008, a year that began with little hint that a recession and a world financial crisis were unfolding. The transcripts provide new insights into the debates, miscalculations and actions of the Feds policy making council, the Federal Open Market Committee, in assessing and countering the crisis. In a running analysis of the documents, reporters for The New York Times shared their findings.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Canada Defeats United States in Mens Hockey Semifinal
description: Canada defeated the United States, 1-0, in the semifinals of the mens hockey tournament to advance to the gold medal game.

title: That Sweet Lamb in Wolfs Clothing
description: It seems likely that Leonardo DiCaprio will not win an Oscar next Sunday for his portrayal of the financial scam artist Jordan Belfort in The Wolf of Wall Street. As a rule, Academy voters prefer displays of suffering and stoicism in the face of adversity from leading men. Jordans brief sojourn in a country-club prison hardly qualifies; nor do the ill effects of too many quaaludes in the films most celebrated scene not involving cocaine and a prostitutes rear end. And though Jordan gives up stock swindles for sales seminars, he can hardly be said to undergo the kind of redemption that the Academy likes to consecrate.

title: Being Human Seems Enough
description: It was at the 2008 Venice Film Festival that Jennifer Lawrence  future Oscar winner, squirrel skinner, American warrior  signaled that she was no ordinary starlet. She wasnt yet famous then, just a paparazzi afterthought to Charlize Theron, her co-star in The Burning Plain, one of those agonizingly dopey movies that play at major festivals because of their red-carpet power. During a pseudo-event for the movie, Ms. Theron spoke about the limited number of older actresses working in the industry and showered praise on another co-star, Kim Basinger, who wasnt there. Ms. Lawrence apparently silenced the room by joking that Ms. Basinger had died. The girl cant help it!

title: Start-Up Disguises Wearable Tech as Jewelry
description: There are two broad strains of wearable technology emerging: the doo-dads that proclaim their techiness from the wrists, faces and other body parts that they are fastened to, and those that try to conceal that quality.

title: Video and Tweets From Kievs Independence Square
description: This post will be updated as new information becomes available.

title: New Yorker to Be Music Director of Phoenix Symphony
description: The Phoenix Symphonys new music director is a native New Yorker who goes west by way of France: Tito Muoz, who has led French orchestras in Lorraine and Nancy.

title: Crossing a Divide, Seeking Good
description: As he does every year, David Wilson recently faced a decision about which documentary film to honor with a major prize in the True/False Film Fest, which he co-directs. And as he does each year, he reached out to the Dave Cover, a founding pastor of the Crossing, a 4,000-member Evangelical Presbyterian church in Columbia, Mo., to set up a screening of a candidate.

title: Miscarriage, Superstition and the Jewish Baby Shower
description: No baby shower. No baby names. No nursery set up in the appropriate bedroom or apartment corner. Thats the common Jewish approach to pregnancy. The baby shower mishegas is an outright invitation to the evil eye to descend upon the unborn baby in vengeance for rubbing your happiness in others faces and counting your chickens before they hatch.

title: Special Squalor
description: Within a five-day period in 1962, two reviews in The Times captured the variety of reaction to William S. Burroughss Naked Lunch. The book had appeared three years earlier in more lenient Paris; Charles Poore wrote that it arrived in the United States already somewhat barnacled with notoriety and no doubt considered demi-passe in demi-avant-garde quadrangles. Poore sniffed at the news that participants at an Edinburgh festival pronounced it a work of considerable influence. This we can easily believe, in view of the more esoteric tendencies of current writing. The sad realm of squalor may look to it for, shall we say, inspiration.

title: Rural Life
description: OUT OF THE WOODS

title: An Indian Appetizer, Subtly Spiced
description: NEW DELHI  Mumbai is one of cinemas great divas. She storms onto the screen with blasts of color, noise and music. She can be beautiful, with ocean views and stunning tableaus. And she can be ugly, her slums among the worlds worst.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Blumarine Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

title: A World of Ties
description: Seigo Neckwear on Madison Avenue is a small boutique specializing in regular ties, bow ties and pocket squares.

title: Image of the Day: February 21
Movie Review: 'Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me."

title: Etro: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Pledging a Fraternity of Silk
description: There is a certain kind of man who, even amid the sea of New York men in ties, can spot a fellow Seigo traveler. Yo-Yo Ma, Eliot Spitzer and select others  newscasters, doctors, lawyers  are members of this tacit clique, which extends well beyond the city limits. These ties that unite them come from Seigo Neckwear, and each one is the handiwork of Seigo Katsuragawa, the designer and proprietor, who cares for his creations deeply. Each tie is our baby, he said.

title: Pharrell Williams Auctioning Grammy Hat for Charity
description: The Vivienne Westwood hat that earned Pharrell Williams a great deal of attention at the Grammy Awards last month is now for sale on eBay. With nine days to go, the high bid stood at $10,500 on Friday, with 64 bids so far. Proceeds are to benefit From One Hand to Another, a nonprofit that Mr. Williams founded in 2008 to support community centers and education.

title: Movie Review: 'In Secret'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "In Secret."

title: Paperback Row
description: THE HOUR OF PERIL: The Secret Plot to Murder Lincoln Before the Civil War,  by Daniel Stashower. (Minotaur, $16.99.) This is a swift and detailed rendering of the little-known Baltimore-based plot to assassinate Abraham Lincoln in February 1861, days before he assumed the presidency. Stashowers narrative hurtles along Lincolns train route from Springfield, Ill., to Washington; standing tall among the conspirators and politicos is the fierce and incorruptible lawman Allan Pinkerton, who led efforts to thwart the scheme.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SIXTH EXTINCTION: An Unnatural History,  by Elizabeth Kolbert. (Holt, $28.) A powerful examination of the role of man-made climate change in causing the current spasm of plant and animal loss that threatens the planet.

title: Out of Character
description: Before you dismiss B. J. Novaks debut fiction collection, One More Thing, as the latest example of a Hollywood actors trespassing into the far more glamorous and affluent gated community of short stories, read his humor piece If I Had a Nickel.

title: A Guest of My Time
description: All conservatism begins with loss, Andrew Sullivan writes. If we never knew loss, we would never feel the need to conserve. Thats why the first and still canonical conservative text is Edmund Burkes Reflections on the Revolution in France, a lamentation on the uprooting of that countrys monarchical order. And thats why America, as an experiment in modernity, hasnt had many genuine conservatives in its history.

title: Monument Man
description: No president has written as well as Abraham Lincoln. He could thrill, reason, prophesy, mourn and crack jokes. Who wouldnt want to read a book in his own words  all the more enticing if it scanted the political and administrative minutiae that fill his collected works and gave us a window into his inner life?

title: Poet of the Caribbean
description: Writing poetry is an unnatural act, Elizabeth Bishop once wrote. It takes skill to make it seem natural. The thought is kin to the one John Keats expressed in an 1818 letter to his friend John Taylor: If Poetry comes not as naturally as the Leaves to a tree it had better not come at all. Bishop and Keats both evoked a double sense of natural: that which is concerned with nature, with landscape, flora and fauna, and that which is unforced and fluent. In both senses, Derek Walcott is a natural poet.

title: The Rage in Harlem
description: One of the milestones of modernism occurred in Paris on May 29, 1913, when The Rite of Spring debuted at the Thtre des Champs-lyses and almost caused a riot. Startled by Stravinskys pounding rhythms and Nijinskys salacious choreography, the well-heeled philistines in the audience roared with disapproval while the connoisseurs, the happy few, tried shouting them down. One of the most memorable accounts of that first night was written by the American critic Carl Van Vechten, who allied himself decidedly with the latter camp, reporting that a kindred soul in the seat behind him was so carried away that he began beating a tattoo on the critics head with his fists. My emotion was so great, Van Vechten wrote, that I did not feel the blows for some time. Sharing his box was another pillar of the avant-garde, Gertrude Stein, who remembered certain details differently  as well she should, Van Vechten assured her. They had actually attended the less eventful second night of the ballet, but, as he suavely added, one must only be accurate about such details in a work of fiction.

title: King of Cool
description: William S. Burroughs didnt say anything for shock value, his student Sam Kashner once observed. His life had shock value.

title: The Last Trial
description: In Jay Cantors 1988 novel, Krazy Kat, the feline heroine praises Rube Goldberg contraptions: Krazy liked having her mind pulled through one of Goldbergs gadgets. He was a real artist; he had a vision. Cantors vision often focuses on public figures: George Herrimans cartoon cat and J. Robert Oppenheimer; Che Guevara in Cantors first novel, The Death of Che Guevara; and now Kafka in Forgiving the Angel. These works and his graphic novel, Aaron and Ahmed, are contraptions of mixed materials: animal and human characters in Krazy Kat, fact and invention in Che Guevara, lucid writing and hallucinatory illustrations (by James Romberger) in Aaron and Ahmed, and now a story putatively by Kafka and stories about contemporaries who loved him. All of Cantors fiction (including Great Neck, his un-gadgety novel of the American 1960s and 70s) pulls the readers mind through sensitive history: atom bomb tests at Alamogordo; the Cuban revolution; the events of 9/11; and, in Forgiving the Angel, Stalins gulag and Hitlers death camps.

title: Video Reviews of Omar, Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me and In Secret
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Omar, Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me and In Secret. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: A Singular Ballerinas Multiple Paths
description: The dancer Misty Copeland has performed with the singer Prince and the pop group TLC. She has appeared in commercials for Diet Dr Pepper and Coach handbags, is national youth of the year ambassador for Boys & Girls Clubs of America and has a contract with the Under Armour sports clothing brand. She has her own dance wear line, and next month Simon & Schuster will publish her memoir, Life in Motion: An Unlikely Ballerina.

title: Lundqvist and Sweden Return to Gold Medal Game
description: SOCHI, Russia  In 2006, Henrik Lundqvist was a 23-year-old rookie for the Rangers who went to the Turin Games motivated to win a gold medal for the older players on the Swedish team that he grew up idolizing.

title: Garrick Utley, a Mainstay at NBC News, Dies at 74
description: Garrick Utley, a former anchor for NBC News who for many years was one of a rare breed in television news reporting, a full-time foreign correspondent, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Out of the Black featuring Robyn
description: A single from Neneh Cherrys new album, The Blank Project.

title: All Is Losts 2 Crucial Characters: Redford and That Boat
description: Sound design is one of the technical aspects of filmmaking that may be the most mystifying to non-filmmakers; at the very least, sound editing and mixing are the categories that will probably cause you to lose your office Oscar pool.

title: Ole Miss Students May Face Charges in Racist Episode
description: OXFORD, Miss.  The University of Mississippi said Friday that students could face criminal charges for placing a noose on a statue honoring the colleges first black student, and a fraternity announced that it had expelled three men because of the incident.

title: The Sounds of Things Ending, Continuing and Reshaping
description: Neneh Cherry

title: Inside the List
description: The Contender: Martin Sixsmiths book Philomena was originally published in 2009, under the title The Lost Child of Philomena Lee. But once the movie version appeared last year, with its sleeker name and attention-grabbing story of a single mother forced by nuns to give up her child for adoption, Sixsmiths publishers retitled the book in a successful effort to cash in: Last week, Philomena was No. 17 in its fifth week on the paperback nonfiction list.

title: Movie Review: 'Omar'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Omar."

title: The Marxist Dalai Lama Visits a Washington Shrine to Free Markets
description: The Dalai Lama, who has said, Deep inside, as far as social economic theory is concerned, I am a Marxist, spent Thursday morning speaking on two panels at a Washington shrine to free markets and limited government  the American Enterprise Institute.

title: From Johnny Weirs Team, a Fresh Voice for NBC
description: NBCs deployment of two figure skating announcing teams for the Sochi Games creates an opportunity to compare how each performed at an important moment.

title: Getting Together to Say Goodbye
description: Vivian Girls died so that Williamsburg could ... live? Die? Get really into dance music? For a time, it was the most exciting band in the city, and then, in the way the city squashes all good things, it was a band in pieces. Its legacy: three albums of dirty lite-garage-rock with strong instinctual melodies, some EPs and singles, a warp-speed tour through the Internets hype cycle  and a mention in a Jeopardy clue.

title: Kentucky Challenger Sets Sights on Senate G.O.P. Heavyweight
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Alison Lundergan Grimes leaned across a table at an upscale bar near her home in this citys historic district, sipped Makers Mark bourbon  a Kentucky staple  mixed with Diet Coke, and let out a belly laugh. Were in this campaign to kick butt! she said.

title: Son of Robert Johnson to Retain Photograph Rights
description: The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the son of the Delta blues musician Robert Johnson retains the rights to the only two known photographs of his father and the profits from those pictures, The Associated Press reported.

title: When Muscle Meets Tension
description: In all of us theres that little monster inside that comes out to play when the time is right, says Cobra Rhodes, a trained chef and Zen master. When it happens, its pretty intense. Youre trying to impose on someone, and they have other ideas. Someones going to eat, and someones not. Arm wrestling is when my monster comes out. Mr. Rhodes, a world champion arm wrestler on the Rolling Thunder team of Kansas City, Mo., is one of the incredible hulks on view in Game of Arms, to have its premiere Tuesday at 10 p.m. on AMC.

title: Tales of Vienna (With Coquette)
description: Hot on the heels of theMets recent production of Johann Strauss Jr.s comic opera Die Fledermaus comes Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburgers Oh ... Rosalinda!! (1955), an adaptation of the same material, playing March 1 at the Museum of Modern Art as part of Vienna Unveiled: A City in Cinema.The program, which marks the 50th anniversary of the Austrian Film Museum, runs fromFridaythroughApril 20and spotlights some 70 movies pertaining to that city by the likes of Max Ophuls, Erich von Stroheim, Billy Wilder, Ernst Lubitsch, Michael Haneke, Carol Reed and Richard Linklater.

title: A Little Sizzle for a Cold City
description: When will it stop snowing? No, seriously: When? Brazil sounds good right about now, and a holiday in the theater is better than none. Starting Wednesday, the Joyce hosts a showcase of Brazilian dance starting with Mimulus Companhia de Danas take on the darkly humorous films of the Spanish director Pedro Almodvar in Dolores, created by the artistic director, Jomar Mesquita, and company members.

title: Protests Swell in Venezuela
description: In February, Venezuela was convulsed by the biggest protests since the countrys longtime president, the charismatic Hugo Chvez, died 11 months earlier.

title: Still Rebels, Even as Maturity Looms
description: Interviewing Calle 13, the firebrand Puerto Rican hip-hop duo, involved a little 21st-century technology. Ren Prez Joglar, the rapper who calls himself Residente, was at Electric Lady Studios in Greenwich Village, where Calle 13s new album, Multi_Viral, was being mixed. Residentes stepbrother and partner in Calle 13, Eduardo Cabra Martnez, the producer and musician who calls himself Visitante, was on a tablet screen in a Skype window, speaking from his studio, Msica Satnica, in San Juan.

title: Filling a Museum With Baroque Art
description: The charismatic French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky has recently released a disc of arias written by the Baroque composer Porpora for Farinelli, his student and a famous castrato. Sparks should fly on Tuesday, when Mr. Jaroussky joins the Venice Baroque Orchestra and the conductor Andrea Marcon to perform selections from the disc; the ensemble will also offer works by Vivaldi and Geminiani. (7 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 212-570-3949, metmuseum.org/tickets.)

title: Many Losses, and Fans, Surround Yeshiva Coachs Departure
description: Jonathan Halpert has coached at Yeshiva University for 42 years, the longest tenure of any mens basketball coach in New York City history. But even Division III Yeshiva, which has not had a winning season since 2007, is not immune to the pressures that much larger N.C.A.A. institutions face.

title: Piecing Together Dream Fragments
description: Laure Prouvost, bornin France in 1978 and now living in London, was the dark-horse winner of the 2013 Turner Prize, but she is still something of a mystery in New York. And for all the right reasons, her solo show at the New Museum lets the mystery be. Multimedia is her form: The New Museum installation combines video, painting, drawing, sculpture and found objects. Narrative is her mode.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: George F. Kennans Diaries
description: This week, Fareed Zakaria talks about The Kennan Diaries; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jodi Kantor discusses HRC; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: George F. Kennans Diaries
description: This week, Fareed Zakaria and Jodi Kantor.

title: Times Minute | Origins of the Ski Lift
description: Also in the Minute, the challenges ahead for the truce in Ukraine and 'Bridges of Madison County' comes to Broadway.

title: Times Minute | Origins of the Ski Lift
description: In the Video

title: Making Antifreeze Less Deadly for Pets, and People
description: Toxicologists have long considered ethylene glycol, the active ingredient in many antifreeze and engine coolant formulas, to be a seductive and uniquely dangerous poison.

title: How Do You Like These Apples?
description: When I was in France late last fall, every time I went to the market I was reminded of what an integral part apples play in everyday cooking in that country. This is especially true in fall and winter, when shoppers buy them by the kilo to use for compotes, pies, cakes, savory dishes and salads. Bakers in Normandy, the region of apples, even work them into rustic country breads.

title: Mayor Do as I Say
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio gave an impassioned presentation about traffic safety on Tuesday. On Thursday, under the immutable law of political comeuppance, he got busted by a TV news crew that caught his two-S.U.V. detail rolling through stop signs, changing lanes without signaling and barreling down the highway over the speed limit.

title: Protest All You Want, but Itll Cost You
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  When the coach of the Canadian womens snowboarding team gathers his belongings each morning, he makes sure he has his hat, his sunglasses, his cellphone and 100 Swiss francs.

title: Book Review Podcast: George F. Kennans Diaries
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Fareed Zakaria reviews The Kennan Diaries by George F. Kennan, who died at 101 in 2005. Mr. Zakaria writes:

title: Wheelies: The Big Brother Is Not Watching Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Instagram Photos from South America
description: A collection of David Guttenfelders Instagram photographs from South America.

title: Canada Wins Third Straight Gold in Mens Curling
description: SOCHI, Russia  There was a certain paradox to the Canadian mens curling teams victory Friday night in the Olympic final against Britain.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Emporio Armani Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: German Biathlete and Italian Bobsledder Fail Doping Tests
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  A German biathlete and an Italian bobsledder were kicked out of the Olympics Friday for doping, the first known violations of the Sochi Games.

title: Four Decades of Preservation
description: Although the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was once considered among the nations most devastated neighborhoods, efforts to preserve its resplendent Victorian architecture have been pursued energetically for more than four decades.

title: Argument Over a Brownstone Neighborhood
description: Most people would agree that the brownstones and small apartment buildings nestled in the southwest corner of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, are for the most part drop-dead gorgeous. The 800 largely intact residential buildings, representing Italianate, Queen Anne, Romanesque Revival and Renaissance Revival styles, are executed in rich rusts, browns and terra cottas, and adorned with gracious bowed windows, generously proportioned stoops and adorable little turrets. The result, in the opinion of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, is an extraordinary well-preserved late-19th-century streetscape.

title: Toledo Museum Announces Review of Items Received From Suspect Dealer
description: The Toledo Museum of Art has announced that it is reviewing the legality of 64 Indian artifacts it obtained from Subhash Kapoor, a former Madison Avenue art dealer who is accused by United States officials of operating one of the largest antiquities smuggling rings uncovered on American soil.

title: On Being Both the Wolf and the Lamb
description: One of the first questions you confront in any five-borough conversation is, Where do you live?

title: An East-West Divide, Played Out on TV News
description: Its the same story, sort of.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Competing Dates

title: The Feds Actions in 2008: What the Transcripts Reveal
description: On Feb. 22, the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy. The transcripts provide a detailed account of some of the Feds key decisions during that crisis year.

title: Today in Small Business: From Minimum Wage to Owning the Franchise
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

title: Attack on Presidential Palace in Somalia
description: A militant Somali group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility for a deadly attack in Mogadishu, the capital, in which militants blasted through a gate and fought a gun battle with guards.

title: Accord Signed in Ukraine
description: Opposition leaders and President Viktor F. Yanukovych signed an agreement on Friday to try to defuse a deadly political crisis that has left scores of protesters and security officers dead or wounded.

title: Listen Up | Neneh Cherry Makes a Cathartic Comeback
description: Its been 18 years since Neneh Cherry released her last solo album. During that time, shes been highly productive: shes worked as a D.J. around Europe; formed a band, cirKus, with her husband and daughter; had guest spots on countless other records; co-hosted a cooking series on BBC Two and focused on raising her three children. It was the pain of loss, however, that brought her back to the spotlight. When her mother, the Swedish painter and textile artist Monica Karlsson (known as Moki), passed away in 2009, Cherry began to write in a journal, documenting dark emotional recesses she hadnt previously explored. Her entries became the basis for The Blank Project, a soulful new album thats danceable, but comes from the deep.

title: Federal Reserve 2008 Transcripts
description: The Federal Reserve released the transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy.

title: China Criticizes Obama Over Visit by Dalai Lama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama welcomed the Dalai Lama to the White House on Friday morning, provoking a sharp rebuke from the Chinese government, which warned that the meeting would severely damage relations between Washington and Beijing.

title: Basque Group Is Said to Disable Some of Its Arms
description: MADRID  ETA, the Basque separatist group, has disabled some of the weapons that allowed it to wage a lengthy terrorist campaign for independence that has killed more than 800 people, an international verification commission said Friday.

title: Disclosure Statement for the City of Detroit
description: This is a detailed description of how Detroit intends to repay its creditors and how it aims to restore the city to health, including by lowering police-response time, restoring streetlights and renewing blighted neighborhoods.

title: A Translator of Blueprints
description: When 60 Minutes, the CBS News show, secured an exclusive interview with a member of the Navy SEAL team that killed Osama bin Laden, one of the first things it did was search for a model maker who could replicate the compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan.

title: Stained Gold Can Help Clean Up System
description: SOCHI, Russia  Adelina Sotnikova of Russia is a 17-year-old with a teenagers insatiable appetite. She sees her Olympic gold medal as a mere appetizer on figure skatings endless buffet.

title: Semper Opera Severs Ties With Appointed General Manager
description: BERLIN  Just months before he was supposed to take over as the general manager of the Semper Opera in Dresden, Germany, cultural authorities have severed their contract with Serge Dorny, citing a climate of mistrust.

title: Barnes & Noble Receives Conditional Offer
description: G Asset Management, a little-known investment firm, offered on Thursday to acquire 51 percent of Barnes & Noble in a deal that would value the booksellers shares at $22 apiece.

title: On a Caribbean Rum Trail
description: Care to kiss the ground?

title: Back to Borneo, and an Eden at Risk
description: There are no roads to the village of Pa Lungan, just a mucky water buffalo trail beneath a tight-knit canopy  among the last standing highland jungles on the island of Borneo. In spots, the trail is more swamp than path. But that does not mean all is quiet: The rain forest is a cacophonous place. Cicadas squeal and monkeys hoot as they romp through the trees. Bamboo creaks in the breeze as its stalks grind and rub in a primitive dance.

title: N.F.L. Combine Camp
description: At Prolific Athletes in Carlsbad, Calif., Ryan Flaherty uses the latest exercise science to prepare N.F.L. draft prospects like Johnny Manziel, Mike Evans and Logan Thomas for the combine test.

title: 7 Years Before Recall, Crash Investigator Raised Concern Over Switched-Off G.M. Air Bags
description: In 2007, about seven years before General Motors recent recall of 778,000 small cars because a jolt or a heavy key ring could turn off the engine and disable the air bags, an investigator for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration raised the possibility of such danger after researching a crash that had killed two teenagers.

title: Volkswagen Offers to Buy Rest of Swedish Truck Maker for $9.2 Billion
description: LONDON  Volkswagen said late Friday that it had made an offer to acquire the outstanding shares of the Swedish truck maker Scania it doesnt already own for 6.7 billion euros, or about $9.2 billion.

title: Speed Coach Prepares N.F.L. Prospects for Combine
description: CARLSBAD, Calif.  Mike Evans, a former star receiver at Texas A&M, crouched in a three-point stance in shorts and a T-shirt and then bolted down a soccer field as a high-speed camera recorded every step. Evans was here not to catch footballs or to practice dodging defenders, but to hone his technique for the 40-yard dash.

title: Calle 13 Goes Multi_Viral
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss Calle 13, the political hip-hop and reggaeton band from San Juan, Puerto Rico, and its new album, Multi_Viral.

title: France Honors Two Women With Burial in the Panthon
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande, who had been strongly urged for more than a year to add more women to those awarded the honor of burial in the Panthon, named two women on Friday  but also two men.

title: Is There Any Escape From Recommended for You?
description: Based on what The New York Times thinks Im interested in reading, I am not a fun person.

title: Aching Canada Hands United States a Stinging Loss
description: SOCHI, Russia  From the twin beds in the athletes village to the cramped competition schedule, the Olympics are not a comfortable fit for N.H.L. players. Crossing the globe to play five games in nine days, as the semifinalists United States and Canada did, is a prescription for insomnia at best and injury at worst.

title: Popcast: Calle 13 Goes Multi_Viral
description: Calle 13, from San Juan, Puerto Rico, led by the stepbrothers Ren Prez Joglar and Eduardo Cabra Martnez, is a hip-hop and reggaeton band, but not only that; its a political band, but not only that; its a band thats heading toward fatherhood and middle age, but not only that.

title: The Gun Report: February 21, 2014
description: What does the current uprising and subsequent bloodshed in Ukraine have to do with gun rights in America? Plenty, say Second Amendment advocates.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Etro Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

title: Light in Her Heart and on Her Feet
description: Even as a little girl, Kristen Schulte was serious, shy and driven to succeed. She was an honors student and the star sweeper on her high school soccer team in Ewing Township, N.J. She made lists of tasks and arrived on time for appointments.

title: Better Than a Credit Card
description: Every time we read or hear about older adults victimized by scams on the phone, scams on the street, thefts in senior residences or attacks via the Internet, we wince.

title: Want a Flight Upgrade? Schmooze the Crew
description: As part of the magazines Voyages issue, Paul Mallatt, a flight attendant and 30-year veteran of the airline industry, explains how to earn an upgrade without paying extra.

title: Ex-Evercore Managing Director Charged With Insider Trading
description: It might have been little more than a tabloid curiosity: A married New York investment banker has a child with a woman in Austin, Tex., and the couple goes through a breakup.

title: Lesson for de Blasio as His S.U.V. Breaks Rules of the Road
description: Political scandals can be complicated. Kickbacks are hard to explain, pay to play is rarely black and white, even elaborate frauds seldom boil down to a sentence or two.

title: Corbat Receives a 23% Pay Raise at Citigroup
description: Michael Corbat, the chief executive of Citigroup, received a 23 percent increase in compensation for 2013, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

title: The Making of 'Omar'
description: A closer look at the Palestinian thriller Omar, an Oscar nominee for best foreign language film.

title: Making an Android Tablet Easier to Read
description: Q. The seven-inch Nexus tablet itself is just big enough, but I find the type too small. Is it possible to increase the size of the text on the screen?

title: Bermuda Court Rules in Dispute Over Lucerne Opera House
description: It is one of the most closely watched disputes in the world of classical music: a lawsuit filed by a group including officials of the Lucerne Festival to compel a Bermuda-based trust to honor the pledge of a philanthropist who had offered to donate more than $130 million to build a new opera house in Lucerne, but who died before the money was paid.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Sportmax Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Weekend Reading: Which Technology Pundit Are You?
description: Facebooks $16 billion bid for the text messaging application WhatsApp has captured everyones attention. Is it a sign that the tech bubble is about to burst or is it a savvy move to cement the future of the social media giant?

title: Versace: A Bias Toward Beauty
description: MILAN  I wanted to clean up what is not necessary, said Donatella Versace  usually a designer who likes at least a flourish and prefers lavish excess.

title: The Jury Pool Wrangler
description: At 9 a.m. sharp on Wednesday, a door opened in the front of the central jury room in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and an impeccably dressed man walked in and sat alone at a broad lectern.

title: House Republicans in Texas Donate to Protect One of Their Own
description: One of the surest signs that an incumbent is concerned about re-election is the amount of money that other lawmakers send his way.

title: Meat and Potato Skillet Gratin
description: Melissa Clark transforms two cold-weather favorites into a single luscious, flavor-layered meal.

title: Should Obesity Be a Disease?
description: IN June 2013, millions of Americans contracted a disease. They developed it not because of some pathogen or illness, but thanks to the American Medical Associations decision to label obesity a multi-metabolic and hormonal disease state.

title: An Artful Bike Path to the Armory Show
description: Enjoy looking at art? How about riding it? The opportunity will be available next month when the Armory Show art fair teams up with Citi Bike to offer 10 art-adorned bicycles for the duration of the Armorys annual art fair, March 6-9 at Piers 92 and 94.

title: Rich Comfort Food to the Extreme
description: The colder the weather, the more rich and hearty the meals you can justify eating. And this is why, ever since the polar vortex forced me to layer on two down coats before leaving the house, Ive craved the likes of potato gratin and shepherds pie.

title: A Surprise Guest at the S.E.C.s Annual Gathering
description: WASHINGTON  In a room overflowing with suited lawyers scribbling handwritten notes, the man live tweeting in a hooded sweatshirt stood out.

title: A Bonus Is Declined; a Problem Remains
description: When IBM reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings a few weeks ago, they could have been an excuse for popping champagne corks in the executive suite.

title: How the Fed Saw a Recession, Then Didnt, Then Did
description: Federal Reserve officials went back and forth on whether the economy was in a recession in 2008.

title: The Dream of Moving Abroad in Later Life, With Good Health Care
description: FOR the well-traveled, the idea of retirement abroad can seem an idyll. You pick a place youve loved visiting, whether its the thrumming avenues of Paris or the sunny strands of Panama, and jet off for the perfect permanent vacation.

title: Exploring a World of Animals
description: Dinaw Mengestu, 35, has racked up a list of enviable accomplishments. He is a highly acclaimed novelist. He was a recipient of a MacArthur genius grant in 2012. The New Yorker named him one of its 20 Under 40 writers in 2010. And on Sundays, he says, he makes a mean roast chicken. All Our Names, the third novel by Mr. Mengestu, who was born in Ethiopia and raised in Illinois, is being published next month by Knopf. Mr. Mengestu lives in West Harlem with his wife, Anne-Emanuelle Mengestu, 41, and their sons, Gabriel, 4, and Luis-Selassie, 3.

title: Haters Going to Hate, Research Suggests
description: Not only is it lonely at the top, but a paper by two business professors suggests that, at least for literary prize winners, the view can get a little ugly, too. The study, by Balazs Kovacs of the University of Lugano and Amanda Sharkey of the University of Chicago, compared online reader reviews for 32 pairs of books that either won or were nominated for a major literary prize. They found that winning a prestigious award not only garners more attention for a book, but also more negative reviews.

title: To Warm Two Hearts That Beat as One
description: When shopping for wedding gifts, think about the couples comfort during the next big chill.

title: A Tenor Finds Energy for Intense, Lyrical Pain
description: Most tenors, after singing the challenging title role of Massenets Werther, especially for the high-pressured opening night of a new production at the Metropolitan Opera, would welcome a few days of rest.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 21
description: Canada defeated the U.S. in a mens hockey semifinal and Mikaela Shiffrin of the United States won the womens slalom.

title: Versace: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Cacophony Amid the Cool Marble
description: For a dancer turned choreographer, there are pros and cons to having danced for someone as famous as Mark Morris for 14 years. The label former Mark Morris dancer will trail you for a long time as you try to chart your own creative path. On the upside, though, your former boss is very well connected.

title: Sills Award Goes to a Rising Tenor
description: Michael Fabiano, a 29-year-old tenor from Montclair, N.J., has been given the Beverly Sills Artist Award for young singers, the Metropolitan Opera announced on Friday. The $50,000 award honors singers between the ages of 25 and 40 who have had featured roles at the Met.

title: A Celebration of Sandhill Cranes in Nebraska
description: From February to April, more than half a million sandhill cranes and millions of waterfowl will make their way to central Nebraska as a part of their yearly migration north.

title: Emulating a Model Communist Through Cosmetic Surgery
description: For the poor, the homeless, people down on their luck in the central province of Anhui, Zhang Yidong has often been there to help. He has made a career of raising money and public interest to help the downtrodden.

title: Big Ticket | Sweeping Views for $17.8 Million
description: A corner unit in the 35-story limestone tower portion of 15 Central Park West, the address where units perform like blue chip stock on the resale market, sold for $17.8 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Clothes and Character: Her
description: Working in a screen trade was a no-brainer for Casey Storm, who grew up on the sets of television shows of Laverne and Shirley and Mork and Mindy, watching his father, the prolific director Howard Storm, at work. My parents, their friends were all involved, he said, so it was obvious that he would be too.

title: The Online Challenge for Banking
description: Francisco Gonzlez, chairman of BBVA, recently said that banks needed to take on Amazon and Google or die. He aims to be one of the survivors.

title: First Times the Charm With Fresh Pita
description: Im giving you a great recipe for a kind of rustic homemade hummus. And Im going to tell you how to make your own pita bread at home.

title: Prince Williams Ivory Intolerance, The Newest Kardashian Kids and Cara Delevingnes Designs for Mulberry
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Review: 2014 BMW 428i
description: The new BMW 428i coupe is one better than the 3 Series sedan. Thank a sleek design and a lower center of gravity.

title: A Daughters Loyalty Shines Through Song
description: Deep into Jonatha Brookes solo theater piece the other night, a gentle wave of sniffles swelled through the audience at the Duke on 42nd Street, where a daughters love and loyalty were on tender display.

title: Women as Bosses Still Face Bias
description: Marissa Mayer. Indra Nooyi. Virginia Rometty. Mary T. Barra.

title: Oprah Winfrey, the Comfort Queen
description: WHO Oprah Winfrey

title: Oprah Winfreys Style
description: Ms. Winfreys red carpet style is all about comfort.

title: Greenwich Village Condo: A Nod to the Past
description: Greenwich Village is known for its corner cafes and doglegs of streets. But in recent years, its been associated with something that doesnt wind up in too many guidebooks: divisive development projects.

title: At Private Schools, Another Way to Say Financial Aid
description: SHANNON LUBIANO never dreamed she could send her children to the Duke School, an independent elementary school in Durham, N.C., where the tuition is $15,000 for prekindergarten, rising to nearly $18,000 for eighth grade.

title: Just Adding a 1 Alters the Equation
description: If two heads are better than one, and four of a kind beats three, BMWs naming strategy makes perfect sense.

title: One Step Up
description: While some rivals have closed the performance gap, the 4 Series is another reminder that BMW still knows how to make a fast, hugely entertaining car.

title: Get Your $50,000 Hatchback Here
description: TESTED 2014 BMW 335i Gran Turismo

title: In a Dark Year, a Lighter Side at the Fed
description: The Federal Reserves 2008 transcripts are shot through with dark and corny  very dark, and very corny  humor.

title: Olympians Stand Tall in Their Onesies
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The German bobsledders had a day off before their competition began, so they decided to go shopping in the charming Alpine village that has sprouted in the mountains above Sochi.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Chad, Afghanistan and Sochi, Russia. More images from the Winter Olympics here.

title: Credit Suisse Admits Guilt in Settling With S.E.C.
description: Updated, 8:49 p.m. | Credit Suisse on Friday became the latest big bank to admit wrongdoing to the Securities and Exchange Commission, striking a deal over its failure to comply with a cardinal rule of the financial industry.

title: With Some Selfies, the Uglier the Better
description: Thirteen-year-old Ruby Karp was sitting in a dark corner of a coffee shop on the Upper West Side, angling a glowing iPhone underneath her chin. She scrunched up her face and tilted her head downward.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Moschinos Tomboy Tresses
description: Despite the loud pop-culture references in Jeremy Scotts first Moschino collection strewn with McDonalds, SpongeBob SquarePants and candy bar insignia hair and makeup felt fairly down-to-earth. Backstage at yesterdays show, the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni explained the inspiration for the gorgeous, tomboyish look. Its a Linda Evangelista kind, with very boyish eyebrows, brushed up to make them strong, she said, adding that the flawless finish on the skin was inspired by Peter Lindberghs photography. To achieve the milky complexions, Pieroni stuck to the basics: a light foundation base, cream color on the eyes for a bit of shine and nude M.A.C. lipsticks that ranged from peachy and pink to soft shades of mocha. And on top of all those neutral faces, Paul Hanlons shaggy, pixie-cut wigs lent just enough attitude to the models as they walked past the front row, from which a very happy Katy Perry cheered them along.

title: Fitbit Recalls Force Device After Complaints of Rashes
description: Fitbit said on Friday that it was issuing a voluntary recall for the Fitbit Force wrist-worn fitness tracker and would stop selling the device immediately after determining that the device caused serious skin irritation for some users.

title: Casting Shadows on Ice Cream Castles in the Air and Feather Canyons Everywhere
description: An actor first, and a singer second: that was how Jessica Molaskey described herself during her enthralling Thursday evening concert of Joni Mitchell songs, Portraits of Joni: Jessica Molaskey Sings Joni Mitchell, at the Allen Room, presented as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series.

title: How Mikaela Shiffrin Won the Slalom
description: Looking powerful and poised, the 18-year-old American dominated the first run and hung on in the second to pick up the gold medal.

title: Descents Into Sounds Of Dementia and War
description: Discerning the correlation between a composers description of a new piece and its actual sound is not always easy. But there was no such ambiguity in Veras Ghosts by Lisa Rene Coons, which received its premiere on Thursday evening at Zankel Hall by the American Composers Orchestra, conducted by George Manahan.

title: Plan to Limit Some Drugs in Medicare Is Criticized
description: An alliance of drug companies and patient advocates, joined by Democrats and Republicans in Congress, is fiercely opposing an Obama administration proposal that would allow insurers to limit Medicare coverage for certain classes of drugs, including those used to treat depression and schizophrenia.

title: Philharmonic Clarinetist to Return to Chicago Symphony
description: It seemed as if the New York Philharmonic had successfully poached some talent from the competition last year when it announced it had lured Stephen Williamson away from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra to be its new principal clarinet player. But Mr. Williamson remained technically on a leave of absence, and on Friday he announced that he would be taking his woodwind back to Chicago next season.

title: Semifinals of the District 24 Grand National
description: One team in the semifinals of the District 24 (New York City and Long Island) Grand National Teams qualifying event is Kelley Hwang, Michael Kopera, Michael Lipkin and Michael Radin, all of New York City.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Tods Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: In Drag, It Turns Out, There Are Second Acts
description: LOS ANGELES  RuPaul Charles zoomed down Sunset Boulevard in a 1979 red Volvo he inherited from his mother. He wore a pinstripe suit and an open-collar shirt revealing a wedge of shaved chest.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks On the Market properties in New York City include a two-bedroom loft in Greenwich Village; a hotel-like studio in Lincoln Square; and a Downtown Brooklyn condo corner unit.

title: Brooklyn on the Spree
description: BERLIN  The music reminds me of Brooklyn! said Winston Chmielinski, a 25-year-old painter who moved here from New York last year. Like one of the cranes hanging over the city but never managing to create a skyline, he was dancing with outstretched arms, lowering and raising himself at the Panorama Bar, the upstairs dance floor at Berghain, a popular club.

title: Leaders in Supporting Roles
description: LOS ANGELES  Forget the celebrity stylists. That persnickety bunch tends to a handful of the highest-wattage Oscar contenders. There are 203 nominees this year.

title: Cost $1,000, Sold for $21 Million
description: The bull market in vintage racing cars recently gained an eye-opening data point: A 1958 Ferrari 335S that had been bailed out of a United States Customs warehouse in New York for $1,000 in 1963 was sold for $21.5 million in a private transaction to an Austrian collector, Andreas Mohringer.

title: A Stable Full of Thoroughbreds
description: Found among the holdings of collectors  any of the millions of enthusiasts who accumulate stamps, coins, autographed baseballs, ticket stubs, anything from bottle caps to Rembrandts  are both the detritus of civilization and the objects that recall its finest hours.

title: Bill Cunningham | Unbuttoned
description: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s).

title: A Singular Obsession, Ranging Far and Wide
description: Sam Mann, a New Jersey industrial designer, has a collection that reflects everything from his background as an engineer to his fascination with the dirt-track competitors of his youth.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Lighting systems that watch and gather data, conversations inside the Federal Reserve during the financial crisis and a new wave of mortgage problems for homeowners.

title: The Music of Fire, Stars, Tears and Light
description: I feel so lonesome I could cry, Angel Olsen sings at the beginning of Hi-Five. And sure, she sounds the part  ravaged, tense, dark, history-minded.

title: Bill Cunningham | Unbuttoned
description: The nonchalant style of coats worn wide open on the coldest days was popular during New York Fashion Week (when daytime temperatures were in the 20s). This vanity dates from 1940s Hollywood stars, who wore their coats on their shoulders. A few women left their coats in chauffeured cars, expecting to rush into a runway show  only to wait in the freezing cold. Tourists (above) were buttoned up to the chin. Near right: another laugh-at-the-cold look, shredded jeans, resembled icicles.

title: Evening Hours | On the Catwalks
description: Fashion Week took us from heaven to earth, and then to church.

title: Adventure With an Italian Accent
description: LAS VEGAS  No international motorcycle manufacturer, it seems, can afford to be without an adventure-touring offering  and an attendant line of high-couture color-coordinated rider apparel  in its lineup.

title: The Magnetic Pull of Touching, and Not Touching
description: Tao Ye doesnt think in terms of Eastern or Western where his art is concerned. This Chinese choreographer, who formed his company in Beijing in 2008, avoids such categorical boxes; his dances, he believes, should stand on their own, and they do, with a quiet, dazzling resolve.

title: Sculptural Slip-Ons at Tods
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Fannie Mae Posts Profit That Sets a Record
description: The mortgage giant Fannie Mae passed a symbolic milestone at the end of the fourth quarter, generating profits that will push its total payments to the federal government higher than the amount it received in the 2008 bailout, the company reported Friday.

title: Times Minute | Preps and Superstitions
description: In the Video

title: Times Minute | Preps and Superstitions
description: Whether it's the N.F.L. scouting combine or luck at the Olympics, a look at how athletes prep. Also on the Minute, 2008 Fed transcripts reveal Janet Yellen's actions before she was chairwoman.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: This weeks On the Market homes in the New York region include a six-bedroom home on 1.27 acres in Colts Neck, N.J., and a five-bedroom home with a separate 1,000-square-foot artists studio in Sea Cliff, Long Island.

title: A House of Cards Binge Takes Its Toll
description: As last weekend approached, I was astonished to hear how many people were planning on binge watching Netflixs House of Cards. I had dismissed the show the very first episode when the hot female journalist tried to seduce the bad Congressman Frank Underwood, played by Kevin Spacey, as a shortcut to what we in the business call reporting. I understand the impulse. Reporting can be deadly dull and take days, whereas the hotties method can be dispensed with in 20 industrious minutes.

title: Imitation of Life, Outsiders Version
description: I thought of James Benning exclusively as an experimental filmmaker until I saw four of his drawings in Macho Man, Tell It to My Heart, the marvelous exhibition at Artists Space, which closes on Sunday. Displaying works by nearly 50 artists, it is based on the collection and many friendships of Julie Ault, the artist, writer and founding member of the Group Material collective.

title: High School Wrestlers in New Jersey Apologize for Photo Seen as Racist
description: Eight members of one of New Jerseys top high school wrestling teams were suspended and barred from participating in a state tournament this weekend after they arranged a photo that looked like a lynching scene, with a black dummy hanging by a rope around its neck.

title: Exonerated. Now What?
description: It had been a while since Jeffrey Deskovic hosted one of his weekday evening singalongs, so last month he made a few calls and brought some friends together at the Karaoke Cave, a noisy little bar on East 13th Street in Manhattan. At 6 p.m. the place was filled with young professionals sipping beers and shouting into microphones in an undemanding, if embarrassing, environment. But to Mr. Deskovic and the men who joined him, standing up in public and singing cheesy pop songs was more than an innocent release.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,298 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Singular Art, Made by Plurals
description: In Sienna Shieldss spacious studio in Dumbo, Brooklyn, with homemade rag dolls decorating one wall and hair-bead sculptures dangling from the ceiling, the mood was festive one recent frigid night. The Yams, as members of her high-energy artist collective call themselves, danced, sipped wine and traded tales about projects. If youre doing it, Im in it was a frequent refrain.

title: Photographers Band Together to Protect Work in Fair Use Cases
description: To many photographers, a federal appeals court ruling last spring that permitted Richard Prince to use someone elses photographs in his art was akin to slapping a Steal This label on their work.

title: Was Anyone Killed at the Knickerbocker Club?
description: Q. Has there ever been a murder at the Knickerbocker Club?

title: Week in Pictures for Feb. 21
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes Valentines Day deliveries, sledding in Central Park and pothole repairs in Queens.

title: Venezuela Battles Media, Social and Otherwise, to Restrict Protest Coverage
description: Tensions escalated further in Venezuela on Friday as street protests that began nine days ago continued and the government persisted in clamping down on coverage of the unrest in the broadcast media and online.

title: The Fun of Having a Single Parent
description: NBC is on a love campaign.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | At Blumarine, Low-Maintenance Loveliness
description: This collection reminds me of the times of Mr. Yves Saint Laurent, the makeup artist Tom Pecheux said backstage at Blumarine, where models were dressed in lavish brocades and furs. There is a richness, there is a glamour. So we had to make the girls look so beautiful. To achieve that aim, Pecheux kept things simple. He left skin almost nude, with only a light application of M.A.C foundation  no blush or highlighter necessary. He didnt touch the eyebrows or eyelashes either; the sole element of visible makeup was a simple sweep of M.A.C black eyeliner around the inner rims of the eyes and in the tiny spaces between eyelashes.

title: Where Death Was a Friend, and Gods Were Ordinary Folk
description: I can imagine worse fates for my bones than being housed for eternity  or at least 6,000 years or so  in one of the astonishing ossuaries now on display at New York Universitys Institute for the Study of the Ancient World in a modest but weighty new exhibition, Masters of Fire: Copper Age Art From Israel. If facial expressions have any enduring meanings across cultures and time (and it often seems that they do), the figures who adorn these ancient clay burial vaults would provide congenial company.

title: Collectors of Keith Haring Works File Lawsuit
description: A group of nine collectors of artwork by Keith Haring sued the foundation that bears his name and its directors on Friday, accusing the defendants of wrongfully destroying the value of their paintings by publicly labeling them as fakes and refusing to consider information that would establish their provenance.

title: Hollywood and the City, Take 2
description: By the early 1970s, New Yorks reign as a television and filmmaking capital seemed to be over. The transplanting of Johnny Carson and the Tonight show to California, coupled with the demise of The Ed Sullivan Show the year before, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, marked the end of Manhattans parity with Hollywood as a glitz capital for a national audience.

title: More Ex-Players Join Concussion Suit Against N.H.L.
description: Four more former N.H.L. players have joined the concussion lawsuit against the league, their lawyers said Friday.

title: Children in School, and Out of Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing Seasons to Take Woolmark Prize
description: The International Woolmark Prize scours the world for talent, then travels the world to reward it. This year, it has arrived in Milan.

title: A Sharp-Eyed Squirrel, Leaping Into the Darkness
description: Few of us ever get a good view of a flying squirrel, but then again, not many of us know they truly exist. Not unlike its cartoon depiction, as the brainy, be-goggled sidekick of Bullwinkle the Moose, the Southern flying squirrel is an impressively well-adapted resident of New York City. With a preference for older beech and oak woods, these squirrels are primarily nocturnal. An uncommon habitat and our very urban instinct to avoid late-night walks through obscure woodlands make finding one a deliberate effort.

title: The Joy of Swimming, and Meditating
description: To the Editor:

title: Uninsured? Get Covered
description: To the Editor:

title: Reforming the Port Authority
The Once and Future Gowanus
description: By a recent and not remotely exacting tally, the Gowanus neighborhood in Brooklyn has at least eight community groups dedicated to its planning and self-analysis: the Gowanus Alliance, the Gowanus Canal Conservancy, Bridging Gowanus, the Gowanus Canal Community Advisory Group, the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation, Friends and Residents of Greater Gowanus, Save Gowanus and the Gowanus Ecology Initiative. This does not include the block associations and housing groups that have an interest in the area, nor does it take full measure of the conferencing that Gowanus has inspired. Four years ago, after the Gowanus Canal was designated a Superfund site, a summit called Reconsidering Gowanus was held. Last month, Gowanus was the subject of its own TEDx talks.

title: Under Cover: The Voyages Issue
description: This weeks cover image features a photograph of the beach in Santos, Brazil, taken by David Guttenfelder, a photographer for The Associated Press. Guttenfelder traveled across South America on the recently opened Interoceanic Highway for the magazines Voyages issue.

title: Women in Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Basque Separatists Display Surrendered Weapons, in Front of Picassos Guernica
