description: As my colleague Raphael Minder reports, an international verification commission said on Friday that the Basque separatist group ETA had disabled some of the weapons that allowed it to wage a lengthy terror campaign for independence that has claimed more than 800 victims.

title: Marriage, a Matter of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: A Discussion About Bright Lights, Big City
description: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, Little Failure, about his upbringing as a Russian migr in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected Bright Lights, Big City, Jay McInerneys touchstone novel of the hedonistic 80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m.

title: Unequal From the Start
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, Behind the Facades
description: The photographs of Sean Vegezzi go beyond closed doors and down subway tunnels.

title: David M. Herszenhorn Answers Questions on Ukraine
description: The center of Ukraines capital, Kiev, came to resemble a war zone this week when protesters and riot police officers used firearms against each other as they battled for control. On Friday, President Viktor F. Yanukovych and opposition leaders signed a political deal aimed at ending the days of violence and three months of protests, and Parliament voted to allow the release of the presidents imprisoned rival. David M. Herszenhorn, a Moscow-based correspondent for The New York Times who has been covering the crisis in Ukraine since it began in November, answered readers questions on the situation submitted via comments, Facebook and Twitter.

title: Closed Doors? Not a Problem
description: Its safe to say that most New Yorkers have a limited, even literal view of their city: The door to that building over there leads to a lobby, right? The stairs to that subway station head down toward the J train.

title: U.A.W. Asks Labor Board to Examine Vote at Tennessee Plant
description: The United Automobile Workers asked the National Labor Relations Board on Friday to order a new unionization election at the Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., asserting that the unions loss last week was because of improper interference by the states lawmakers.

title: Attorney General Signs New Rules to Limit Access to Journalists Records
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who drew fire last spring over the Justice Departments aggressive tactics for secretly obtaining reporters phone logs and emails as part of leak investigations, on Friday signed new guidelines narrowing the circumstances in which law enforcement officials may obtain journalists records.

title: Friday Night Music: Fleetwood Mac, The Chain
description: In honor of President Obamas decision not to propose cutting Social Security by switching to a chain-linked price index, a blast from the past:

title: Flaws Persist in L.I.R.R.s Disability Claims, a Report Finds
description: A federal watchdog has concluded that the method of granting occupational disability payments to former employees of the Long Island Rail Road is still so flawed that roughly 96 percent of those who apply receive it, roughly the same approval rate as before a vast cheating scandal was first exposed more than five years ago.

title: F.D.A. Orders 4 Bidi Cigarette Brands Removed From Shelves
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday ordered four tobacco products removed from the market, the first time the agency has done so since being given the legal authority in 2009.

title: Yankees Top Starting Pitchers Impress Girardi
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Before Friday, the last time Masahiro Tanaka had thrown a pitch to a batter was in the ninth inning of Game 7 of the Japan Series against the Yomiuri Giants  Nov. 3, Tanaka said in English, a date he will find difficult to forget. He threw a split-fingered fastball to get the final out and secure the Rakuten Golden Eagles first championship.

title: Ted Nugent Apologizes for Obama Insult
description: HOUSTON  The rock guitarist Ted Nugent, responding to cascading criticism that had become an embarrassment for his conservative Republican allies, apologizedFridayfor calling President Obama a subhuman mongrel. But Democrats expressed frustration that their calls for an apology from the Texas Republican who took Mr. Nugent on the campaign trail had been ignored.

title: Another Step on the Path to Settling Frisk Cases
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan cleared the way on Friday for the lawsuits challenging the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk practices to be sent back to a lower-court judge, a step toward negotiating a final settlement in the longstanding legal dispute.

title: Streaming of Olympic Hockey Continues to Expand
description: With each succeeding United States Olympic hockey game from Sochi, Russia, this week, NBC Sports watched as the number of people streaming the game live grew.

title: In Sake, Japan Sees a Potential Stimulus
description: NIHONMATSU, Japan  As Japan confronts troubling economic data and memories of its stagnant lost generation, the countrys government is offering a little something to take the edge off: a bottle or two of sake.

title: Will the Net Stay Neutral?
description: It is no doubt a coincidence that six days after the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger was unveiled, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, announced that his agency was planning  yet again  to come up with rules to ensure that no Internet service provider could discriminate against any company or website. And it is also a coincidence  for sure!  that on the same day as the Wheeler announcement, Google let it be known that it was going to begin discussions with 34 cities to expand its Google Fiber business. Google Fiber provides high speed Internet service, though so far only in Kansas City and Provo, Utah. (It is about to begin service in Austin, Tex.)

title: To Make Shipping Oil Safer, Railroads Agree to 8 Measures
description: Responding to concerns about the safety of trains carrying oil around the country, federal regulators on Friday outlined steps to reduce the risk of rail shipments and bolster confidence in the fast-growing industry.

title: Coping With Infectious Disease
description: The list of infectious diseases that could leap from remote areas of the world to strike countries thousands of miles away is growing. A warning of what can happen occurred a decade ago when an outbreak in China of a mysterious new viral disease, known as SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, was covered up by the Chinese authorities, allowing infected airline passengers to carry the virus to more than two dozen other countries. The disease killed nearly 800 people and caused large economic losses in Asia and Canada.

title: Army Generals Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Sexual Misconduct Charges
description: One week after the lead prosecutor in the court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey Sinclair abruptly quit the case, defense lawyers have asked a military judge to dismiss sexual misconduct charges against General Sinclair in a motion that asserts that officials all the way up to Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the Army chief of staff, have acknowledged weaknesses in the case.

title: Uncovering Legacies in Staten Islands Neglected Graveyards
description: Lynn Rogers is proud of her work and is not concerned that she receives no recognition from those whose stories she unveils. Not that they could sing her praises  they are all dead.

title: Alcoholics Anonymous, Without the Religion
description: Three floors above a Manhattan street of loading docks and coffee shops, in a functional room of folding chairs and linoleum tile, a man who introduced himself as Vic began to speak. Today is my 35th anniversary, he said. The dozen people seated around him applauded, and several even whooped in support.

title: Fed Fretted Over Reaction to Demise of Lehman
description: Six weeks after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, Ben S. Bernanke, then chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his central bank colleagues an imitation of the people who were already criticizing the governments decision to let the Wall Street bank collapse.

title: Rewriting the Gettysburg Address
description: Abraham Lincoln did not give the Gettysburg Address on Nov. 19, 1863  at least, not the one engraved on the Lincoln Memorial, the one memorized by millions the world over. Lincoln actually wrote the words recognized today as the Gettysburg Address months after the cemetery dedication, during a full and complete revision of his speech that he finished in February 1864.

title: To Read or Not to Read?
description: This is the seventh part of an eight-part series.

title: Dont Let Up on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  LIKE all Americans, we strongly hope that the Obama administrations diplomatic efforts lead to the peaceful dismantling of Irans nuclear weapons program. To achieve this key national security goal, we support a policy that complements the current negotiations with a range of congressional actions that threaten greater economic and diplomatic pressure on the Iranian government.

title: Montessori Schools Surge in Popularity Among New Generation of Jewish Parents
description: In the boys classroom at Lamplighters Yeshivah in the Hasidic Jewish stronghold of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Montessori number-counting boards and decimal beads share space with Hebrew-learning materials. A colorful timeline on the wall shows two strands of world history in parallel: secular on the left, Jewish on the right. A photo of the grand rabbi of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic movement hangs above a list of tasks that children perform individually: make a fractions poster, practice cursive, learn about the moons phases.

title: In Sochi, Connecticut Is a Winner
description: MADISON, Conn.  The board of selectmen for this tranquil shoreline town addressed an unusual request on Feb. 10. Andrea Perullo, the proprietor of a local jewelry store, asked if this years Presidents Day could be formally recognized as Mac Bohonnon Day.

title: Medals of Honor, Denied Because of Prejudice, to Be Belatedly Awarded
description: President Obama will award the Medal of Honor next month to 24 Army veterans, most of them Hispanic or Jewish, who were passed over for the nations highest military award because of their race or ethnicity, the White House announced on Friday.

title: Collins Would Be an Asset on the Court, the Nets Say, Not a Distraction Off It
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Nets continued internal conversations on Friday about potential frontcourt players to add to their roster. After the team practiced at the Olympic Club, a private athletic and social club, Coach Jason Kidd said he had briefly joined discussions with the front office.

title: Texas Strikes Again
description: Election season in Texas! Theyre voting right now in the primaries. And I know you are interested because whatever happens in Texas has a way of coming back and biting the rest of the nation.

title: Terror Case Has Lawyer With Several Distinctions
description: When the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, begins next month in Manhattan, his defense team will include one lawyer with a particularly interesting background.

title: Accommodating Divisiveness
description: Ted Nugent, a.k.a. the Motor City Madman, an ex-rocker whos off his rocker, is at it again.

title: Turkeys Internet Crackdown
description: President Abdullah Gul, Turkeys head of state, has now joined Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in the governments assault on free speech. On Tuesday, Mr. Gul approved a new law, passed earlier by Parliament, that is intended to help protect Mr. Erdogan and his allies from a widening corruption scandal by tightening government control of the Internet. It would allow the authorities, without a court order, to block web pages under the guise of protecting personal privacy, and to collect users browsing histories.

title: An End to the Grand-Bargain Charades
description: The phony budget games finally came to an end this week. After years of trying to entice Republicans into serious negotiations over a fiscal deal  years of instant rejection and painful austerity  the White House announced it was giving up.

title: Syrians Seek New Delay in Export of Chemical Arms
description: The Syrian government has sought a new delay, until mid-May, for the export of its chemical weapons arsenal and is balking at a deadline looming in three weeks to destroy the 12 facilities that once produced the munitions, Western diplomats said Friday. The announcement is a new indication that Syrias pledge to eradicate the banned arsenal  under a timetable already weeks behind schedule  is fraying.

title: G.O.P. Congressman in South Carolina Takes a Risk With a Foray Into Immigration
description: GAFFNEY, S.C.  After the sterling conservative voting record he has established during three years in Washington, Representative Mick Mulvaney, a Republican, can take a few political risks in his South Carolina district, one of the most conservative in this reliably Republican state. This week he did just that.

title: New Comptroller Stands by Handling of a Wrongful Conviction Case
description: The city comptrollers decision to pay $6.4 million to a man wrongfully convicted of murder before he even filed a lawsuit marked a sharp break with past practice and could have ramifications for similar cases, lawyers who specialize in wrongful convictions said.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 21, 2014
Religious Right in Arizona Cheers Bill Allowing Businesses to Refuse to Serve Gays
description: In New Mexico, a photographer declined to take pictures of a lesbian couples commitment ceremony. In Washington State, a florist would not provide flowers for a same-sex wedding. And in Colorado, a baker refused to make a cake for a party celebrating the wedding of two men.

title: What to Watch at the Olympics: Saturday
description: MIX AND MATCH Youve feasted on hockey, skiing, figure skating and biathlon during the past two weeks, so why not use the final full day of competition in Sochi to experience something new? Skip the hockey bronze medal game (NBCSN, 10 a.m.) and the figure skating gala (NBCSN, 12:30 p.m.) and opt instead for snowboardings parallel giant slalom (NBC, 2:30 p.m.). Or wait for the pursuit events in speedskating (NBC, 8 p.m.), in which teams of three skaters start on opposite sides of the ice and race as groups to the finish, mano-a-mano-a-mano-a-mano. Its just like the cycling version held at the Summer Games. Only colder.

title: A Week of Fire and Ice
description: That barricades remain a brutal but effective final resort for desperate citizens was amply on display this past week, not only in Ukraine, where President Viktor F. Yanukovych appeared finally to surrender, but also in Venezuela, where the batons and tear gas of riot police officers failed to quell anti-government demonstrations, and in Thailand, where the police engaged in bloody efforts to clear sites occupied by protesters since late November.

title: Bad Egg
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Something wicked this way comes.

title: As Crisis Loomed, Yellen Made Wry and Forceful Calls for Action
description: As the worlds financial system stood on the verge of collapse in October 2008, Janet L. Yellen was not even a full voting member of the Federal Reserves policy-making committee, but she was not shy about admonishing her colleagues for not acting faster.

title: With Tumult Around Him, Russian Diplomat Keeps Calm
description: UNITED NATIONS  Sweptback silver hair, polar blue tie, signature pinstripe suit: The only thing out of place was a bandage around Vitaly I. Churkins right thumb as he departed for a meeting of his fellow United Nations Security Council ambassadors the other day to have what he called a thorny discussion about Syria.

title: U.S. Proposes Cuts to Rates in Medicare Payments
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday proposed cuts in Medicare payment rates for managed-care plans serving more than one-fourth of all beneficiaries, and Republicans immediately pounced on the proposal, which appears likely to become a significant issue in this years midterm elections.

title: In Struggles of Artist With His Work, Hints of Mexicos Own
description: MEXICO CITY  DAMIN ORTEGAS completed installation outside the new Museo Jumex here looks, at first, like a workaday kitchen filmed in space. A teapot, plates, bowls and utensils slowly spin above an unassuming wooden table. A chair, then another, seem to be balancing on one leg.

title: Video Notebook: Mexican Art
description: The Timess Damien Cave tracks the delayed debut of Damin Ortegas modern art installation outside the new Museo Jumex in Mexico City.

title: Walter Ehlers, Last of Medal of Honor Recipients in D-Day Attack, Dies at 92
description: Walter D. Ehlers, who received the Medal of Honor for his exploits as an Army sergeant in the D-Day invasion of France and came to personify the heroism of the G.I.s who stormed the beaches of Normandy on June 6, 1944, died on Thursday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 92.

title: Richard Cabela, Who Sold the Great Outdoors, Is Dead at 77
description: Richard N. Cabela, founder of the hunting and outdoors retail chain Cabelas, one of the largest sellers of guns and ammunition in the country, died on Monday at his home in Sidney, Neb., where the company is based. He was 77.

title: Amid Fence-Mending, Another U.S.-Russia Rift
description: WASHINGTON  After putting the tense Russian-American relationship on pause last year, President Obama and his team have lately been working to get it back on track by quietly planning a possible meeting this summer with President Vladimir V. Putin. The two sides have even begun discussing a trade agreement for the two to sign.

title: Two Ticks of Clock Against Magic Prove Microcosm of the Knicks Fading Season
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The entire sequence lasted less than two seconds, yet it provided the perfect summation of everything that had gone wrong for the Knicks this season.

title: Two Sexual Assaults Are Reported at Yale
description: The Yale University Police Department has received anonymous reports that two undergraduate students were sexually assaulted at an off-campus party this month, the university said on Friday night.

title: Growing Support, and Tea From Young Women, Embolden Kiev Street Fighters
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The street fighters in Independence Square, kitted out with motorcycle helmets, plywood shields and baseball bats, are an intimidating lot by any measure, and this week they turned whole battalions of riot police officers on their heels in epic, bloody clashes that stunned the world.

title: WhatsApp Deal Bets on a Few Fewer Friends
description: The address book is making a billion-dollar comeback.

title: U.N. Office Criticizes Australia Detention Policies
description: Australias treatment of asylum seekers sent to offshore processing centers is cruel, inhuman and degrading and it violates international law, the United Nations human rights office said Friday.

title: Response From Latin American Leaders on Venezuelan Unrest Is Muted
description: MEXICO CITY  When President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela arrived in Havana for a regional summit meeting last month, Latin American and Caribbean solidarity seemed triumphant. The United States was not invited, and in speech after speech, the regions leaders expressed confidence in a shared, unified future.

title: Hope Springs, Again, for Yankees and Mets
description: With new faces and renewed optimism, the Yankees began training in Tampa, Fla., while the Mets opened their camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Brushing Up On the Most Curious New Beauty Tools
description: Backstage at Diane von Furstenbergs fall show, there was an unusual makeup tool being swept across the preternaturally smooth complexion of the singer Annie Clark, a.k.a. St. Vincent. From a distance, it looked a bit like a toothbrush or perhaps one of those hand-held, skin-firming wands. Nope! Turns out, it was one of three new Masterclass Makeup Brushes from M.A.C. Launched this winter, these newfangled tools perform all the usual beauty tasks  blending eye shadow, smudging eyeliner, buffing foundation into the skin, saturating the lips with color  albeit with a supercool design unlike that of a traditional brush. The most noticeable difference: The head and handle point toward the face, rather than away from it, which allows you to actually see what youre doing in the mirror without hands getting in the way (imagine that!). Another plus: The densely packed synthetic bristles  or, rather, cosmefibres  evenly disperse makeup particles over the face, sans streaks. Oh, and the rubberized handles are just comfy to hold, which is key for a busy makeup artist like Regan Rabanal, who spent hours painting faces at numerous New York Fashion Week shows, including Zac Posen, Cushnie Et Ochs and Badgley Mischka.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) NOW YOU SEE ME (2013) A group of magicians  a sleight-of-hand virtuoso (Jesse Eisenberg, above), a mentalist (Woody Harrelson), a pickpocket (Dave Franco) and an escape artist (Isla Fisher)  turned Robin Hoods try to outrun an F.B.I. agent (Mark Ruffalo) and an Interpol detective (Mlanie Laurent), sending cash showering down on their audiences. Up to this point, Now You See Me is an enjoyable goof that in its giddy way evokes a world propelled by technological wizardry enabling those who are clever enough to steal from everybody else, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this caper directed by Louis Leterrier, which also stars Morgan Freeman and Michael Caine. But long before the story culminates with a preposterous final revelation, whatever hopes you had that Now You See Me might have had anything to say about the profession of magic, rampant greed or anything else have been dashed.

title: U.S. Army Seeks Better Ties With Chinas Military
description: BEIJING  A top American military commander said Saturday that the United States Army was working to start a formal dialogue and exchange program with the Chinese Peoples Liberation Army before the end of the year.

title: Corrections: February 22, 2014
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Archrival Is Freed as Ukraine Leader Flees
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Abandoned by his own guards and reviled across the Ukrainian capital but still determined to recover his shredded authority, President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev on Friday night to denounce what he called a violent coup, as his official residence, his vast, colonnaded office complex and other once impregnable centers of power fell without a fight to throngs of joyous citizens stunned by their triumph.

title: Extreme Park Rosa Khutor
description: A view from Sochis Extreme Park, which hosts newer events like snowboard slopestyle and ski cross.

title: The Narrow Margin Between Agony and Ecstasy
description: Canada advanced to the final of the mens ice hockey tournament with a 1-0 victory over the United States at Bolshoi Ice Dome.

title: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Once Filled With Stars, Yankees Infield Now Hopes to Overachieve
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Whenever the Yankees made a pitching change from 2009 through 2012, the superstars lined up behind the mound in a grand array of infield royalty, a foursome of the best, the best known or the best paid at each position.

title: Three Stand as Test Cases for the Hidebound N.F.L.
description: Richard Sherman, Jonathan Martin and Michael Sam are young African-American football players who represent three explosive elements in American culture: race, class and sexual orientation.

title: Protecting the Square
description: In Kiev, Ukraine, the opposition fighters in Independence Square are considered heroes by many supporters of the movement.

title: White Sox Lean on Sale, the Skinny Guy Throwing Strikes
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Chris Sale stands 6 feet 6 inches and weighs only 180 pounds. In the history of baseballs major leagues, only one pitcher at least that tall, weighing no more than Sale, has ever made more starts. His name was William Jennings Bryan Harriss, but he was known, naturally, as Slim. He pitched in the 1920s.

title: A Fabled Track Tries to Come Back
description: John Brunetti Sr., owner of Hialeah Park, revived the famed track with quarter horse racing and a casino, and he hopes thoroughbreds will follow.

title: Hialeahs Fabled Track Seeks a Rebirth
description: HIALEAH, Fla.  John Brunetti is 83, which makes him slightly younger than Hialeah Park, the famous racetrack he owns. Both are looking pretty good for their age.

title: Sasha Luss Transforms Backstage at Etro
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Sasha Luss (left) and after (right) makeup by Mark Carrasquillo and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

title: The Urge To Tighten
description: People are going through the Feds 2008 transcripts, and finding that most officials had no idea what was going down. (Incidentally, guys, whatever you want to call 2008, the one thing it definitely wasnt was a FISCAL crisis. A case of BowlesSimpson on the brain?) Im a bit surprised, but thats not the most surprising thing.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Feb. 23
description: Facebook is constantly working to not lose anybody.

title: Roberto Cavalli: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Rewarding the Rich
Writing Her Own Story
description: Thuy Vu left Vietnam in 1975 with her family, eventually settling in California. She is the host of KQED Newsroom on the PBS television station in San Francisco, and does occasional reporting for the program.

title: Caution: Stuffed Shirts Ahead
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: 1964: U.S. TV Corps Grapples with Cops, Alps and Lingo
description: INNSBRUCK  The project of televising the ninth Winter Olympics from Austria to the United States requires, among other things, some rapport with the local cops.

title: Chicken Soup for Flu-Weary Guests
description: With flu season at its peak in the United States, some hotels, especially in New York City, are trying to help guests ward off the illness or at least make it easier to manage. The Kitano in Midtown Manhattan has a new immune-system-boosting menu with ingredients like ginger and plum paste in dishes like steamed egg custard with crab meat. The Hotel Chandler in the Murray Hill neighborhood has a Flu Away package through the end of March  a room with a pamphlet that has tips on staying healthy and a Vicks GermFree humidifier. Prices start at $250 a night.

title: Going the Distance Grows Shorter for Many Runners
description: When 30,000 competitors considered what distance to run in this weekends Gasparilla Distance Classic, they had five choices: traditional or stroller-friendly 5-kilometer, an 8k, a 15k or a half marathon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mars, Venus and the Handling of Money
description: I was out at dinner with a friend and her husband when they started squabbling about her financial adviser.

title: Winners Take All, but Cant We Still Dream?
description: Its clear that the lives of many creative artists are being transformed by digital technology. But competing schools of thought cite the very same technology in support of strikingly different conclusions.

title: David Rosenblatt of 1stdibs, on Teamwork at the Top
description: This interview with  David Rosenblatt, chief executive of 1stdibs, an online marketplace for high-end goods including art, antiques, jewelry and furniture, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: A New Light on Regulators in the Dark
description: In the five years that have elapsed since the direst days of the financial crisis, weve learned much about how the nations high-level banking regulators worked to keep the debacle from turning into a full-blown economic Depression. Tales of these herculean efforts have emerged in books by some of the major players, and in the exhaustive testimony theyve presented before congressional inquisitors and others trying to determine what went wrong and why.

title: A Young Inventor, Finding the Crunch Factor
description: The way Mark King tells the story, the idea came to him in an instant just three years ago, when he was a 21-year-old community-college dropout. Like the proverbial Edisonian light bulb, there it was: an organoleptic analyzer.

title: In His Office, Theres Always Cause for Celebration
description: Reluctant officeholder

title: Jimmie Johnson Does Triathlons, but Is He an Athlete?
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A typical week in the life of Jimmie Johnson on the way to winning his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship last season included five miles of swimming, 40 miles of running, 100 miles of cycling and one race.

title: Oysters Make a Comeback
description: Connoisseurs across the country are binging on oysters. The trend is, at least in part, the result of a rapid growth of oyster farms on the East and West Coasts.

title: Loss Leaders on the Half Shell
description: The joint is jumpin: Three mixologists in striped dress shirts, dark slacks and suspenders pour drinks almost as fast as three shuckers send platter after platter of raw oysters to their fate. A bluesy soundtrack wafts over the standing-room-only din as patrons sip and slurp, oblivious to the crowd that has gathered outside for what can be a 90-minute wait.

title: Jil Sander: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Wisconsins Legacy for Unions
description: Three years ago, a labor leader named Marty Beil was one of the loudest opponents of Gov. Scott Walkers budget repair bill, a proposal that brought tens of thousands of protesters out to the Wisconsin State Capitol in Madison in frigid February weather. A gruff-voiced grizzly of a man, Mr. Beil warned that the bill was rigged with booby traps that would cripple the states public-sector unions.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Versaces Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Test in Northwestern Case: Is College Football a Job?
description: CHICAGO  For four days last week in a courtroom on the 13th floor of the Dirksen Federal Building, a National Labor Relations Board panel heard testimony concerning whether Northwestern football players should have the right to collectively bargain as university employees.

title: Jordan Keeps Haunting Knicks Playoff Hopes
description: There was a time when it felt as if the only thing standing in the way of a Knicks championship was Michael Jordan. Throughout the 1990s, the Knicks would charge into the playoffs looking for the teams first title since 1973 only to be sent home unceremoniously by Jordans Chicago Bulls.

title: N.H.L. and Players Differ Over 2018 Games
description: No moment symbolized the uncertain future of N.H.L. Olympic participation more than the friendly disagreement between Commissioner Gary Bettman and Ren Fasel, the president of the International Ice Hockey Federation, at their news conference last week in Sochi, Russia.

title: U.N. Orders Both Sides in Syria to Allow Humanitarian Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS  In a rare show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution on Saturday ordering the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment for those who disobey.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Bottega Veneta Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Shiffrin Wants 5 Alpine Wins in 18
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Less than 24 hours after winning her first Olympic gold medal, Mikaela Shiffrin announced that her goal in the 2018 Winter Olympics was to win all five Alpine events. It would be an unprecedented sweep for a ski racer.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: February 21, 2014
description: The F.C.C. is making a renewed push to pass net neutrality rules to keep the Internet free and open. This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine whether broadband Internet service should be regulated like a utility, similar to power, water or telephone service. They also weigh in on Facebooks $19 billion acquisition of the messaging app WhatsApp, and the imminent I.P.O. from King, the creator of the ubiquitous cellphone game Candy Crush Saga.

title: Variety: Miracle on Ice
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The Sochi Olympics are underway, and this weeks acrostic takes inspiration from some of the events held during the Winter Games. The quote has to do with ice skating, and several answers and clues are related to sports done in an ice rink, like hockey and figure skating.

title: With Presidents Departure, Ukraine Looks Toward a Murky Future
description: KIEV, Ukraine  As ranks of riot police officers, Interior Ministry troops and even the president vanished from the capital, Ukraine slipped, with often-eerie calm after months of tumultuous protests and a week of bloody mayhem, into the hands of revolution.

title: El Chapo, Most-Wanted Drug Lord, Is Captured in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Just before 7 a.m. on Saturday, dozens of soldiers and police officers descended on a condominium tower in Mazatln, Mexico, a beach resort known as much as a hangout for drug traffickers as for its seafood and surf.

title: Translating Thrills on the Skiing Trails
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  For the past two weeks, cross-country skiing fans have been among the most boisterous, screaming, waving flags and ringing cowbells as the athletes circled on the trails around them.

title: Updates on a Day of Upheaval in Ukraine
description: As my colleagues Andrew Higgins and Andrew Kramer report from Kiev, on a day of upheaval, Ukraines president, Viktor Yanukovych, fled the capital, the Parliament called for early elections to replace him, protesters strolled the grounds of the abandoned presidential palace and the jailed opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko was released from a prison hospital in eastern Ukraine where she was being held.

title: What to Watch at the Olympics: Sunday
description: MENS HOCKEY Gold medals will be awarded in four-man bobsled, the mens 50-kilometer cross-country race and, finally, mens hockey. The final game will not feature the beloved home team, but it is a meeting of hockey heavyweights nonetheless. Canada and Sweden have won three of the four gold medals since N.H.L. players became part of the mens tournament in 1998, Canada in 2002 and 2010 and Sweden in 2006. Neither team has lost in the tournament. Henrik Lundqvist and Sweden have given up just six goals in the tournament; Carey Price and Canada have allowed only three NBC, 7 a.m.

title: How It All Began: A Cold War Battle Heats Up
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Three months of civic unrest in Ukraine spiraled out of control last week with dozens of people dead, the center of this elegant city turned into a burning war zone and the eventual flight from the capital on Friday by the president. Puzzled about the conflict and how it got so bad? Heres a primer.

title: Holdouts Faith Rewarded Amid Olympic Makeover
description: SOCHI, Russia  It was a year ago, almost to the day, that Prokofey Drovichev stood in his mud yard and wondered what would happen to him and his family. The Olympics were coming, and he needed to get out of the way.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Roberto Cavalli Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

title: Antonio Marras: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: U.S. Fans Snap Up World Cup Tickets
description: More tickets to the 2014 World Cup have been allocated by FIFA to fans from the United States than to those in any other nation, other than Brazil, the host.

title: Live Stream | Emilio Puccis Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
description: The latest womens collection from Emilio Pucci at Milan Fashion Week.

title: In a First for Spain, a Woman Is Convicted of Inciting Terror Over Twitter
description: MADRID  The line between youthful rebelliousness and something more dangerous is not always clear. But in her angry musings on Twitter, Alba Gonzlez Camacho, 21, who describes herself as a very normal girl, sailed across it. After she posted messages calling for a far-left terrorist organization to return to arms and kill politicians, Spains national court convicted her of inciting terrorism using a social media network.

title: Resolution From the United Nations Security Council on Syria
description: In a hard-fought show of unity among world powers, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday to order the warring parties in Syria to stop blocking the delivery of humanitarian aid, though without the immediate prospect of punishment against those who disobey.

title: Celtics-Lakers Rivalry, Once Lustrous, Is Now Lackluster
description: LOS ANGELES  It was just four years ago that the Celtics were beaten by the Lakers, and Coach Doc Rivers went around the visitors locker room and collected $100 from every player and coach. He removed a ceiling tile and hid the money, then told his players they would be coming back in June to collect it.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Feb. 22
description: Saturday was the next-to-last day of competition at the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 23
description: The Ukrainian Parliament voted Saturday to oust President Viktor F. Yanukovych after weeks of antigovernment protests and violent clashes with the military. Protesters claimed to have established control of the capital city, while Mr. Yanukovych called the events a coup in a television interview on Saturday.

title: Flying High While Still on the Ground
description: Emily Cook, of the United States freestyle ski team, visualizes each aerial jump as part of her training for the Olympics.

title: Olympians Use Imagery as Mental Training
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The Canadian bobsledder Lyndon Rush had not yet arrived in Sochi. But he was already on the Olympic sliding track as he sat in a chair in the Munich airport several days before the Winter Olympics, his eyes wide open but his minds eye far away as he traced a sinuous path through the air with his left hand.

title: When Doctors Need to Lie
description: I ONCE had the unenviable task of informing a 22-year-old Jamaican man that he was suffering from severe heart failure and would probably need a heart transplant. The mans father warned me that his son would be devastated to hear the diagnosis. It would mean a lot to me if you could go back in and tell him hes going to be all right, the father pleaded. Please tell him that if he does the things you say, hes going to be O.K.

title: Audiobooks and the Return of Storytelling
description: STANFORD, Calif.  THE ferns under my oak trees evoke moments from The Great Gatsby for me. I read the book many years ago, but I listened to it last summer while planting 50 polypodium californicas and 50 festuca idahoensis in the dappled light beneath my oaks. Now, when I look at them, I think about that last awful accident, the yellow Rolls-Royce screaming past the repair shop, and what F. Scott Fitzgeralds narrator called Gatsbys extraordinary gift for hope.

title: A Picasso in Trouble
description: The largest and most endangered Picasso many of us have never seen lives on Park Avenue, in the Seagram Building. To get to it, walk to East 52nd Street, past the idling Town Cars, through the door of the Four Seasons restaurant. Give a nod to the friendly coat-check guy, then head up the stairs, into the soaring space of the Grill Room, where the citys uppermost crust is having lunch or drinks. Keep going into the corridor that leads to the Pool Room. Look right, and up.

title: Can God Make It in Hollywood?
description: LOS ANGELES  SOME years ago, when I was producing films at Columbia Pictures, I learned up close how hard it was to make Hollywood get religion. It was in the mid-1990s, and a good writer, earlier nominated for an Oscar, had an earnest modern-day Christ story about a damaged man in Los Angeles who might or might not be the Messiah. The Greatest Story Ever Told meets Falling Down, more or less.

title: How to Get a Job at Google
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  LAST June, in an interview with Adam Bryant of The Times, Laszlo Bock, the senior vice president of people operations for Google  i.e., the guy in charge of hiring for one of the worlds most successful companies  noted that Google had determined that G.P.A.s are worthless as a criteria for hiring, and test scores are worthless. ... We found that they dont predict anything. He also noted that the proportion of people without any college education at Google has increased over time  now as high as 14 percent on some teams. At a time when many people are asking, Hows my kid gonna get a job? I thought it would be useful to visit Google and hear how Bock would answer.

title: The F.C.C. Tries Again
description: After losing two court cases on the issue, the Federal Communications Commission last week came up with a promising way to prevent broadband companies from giving preferential treatment to big players like Netflix and Google, which could hurt smaller businesses and start-ups, as well as consumers.

title: Happiness Is a Warm iPhone
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  IN Spike Jonzes new film Her, Theodore Twombly, a lonely writer living in the nearish future, develops feelings for Samantha, an operating system. It is a love story wrapped around a thought experiment wrapped around a metaphor: We fall in love with our technology. Thats how we talk about our gadgets  with the language of emotional attachment, with irrational expectations about happily ever after. Now that Im holding you, my sexy 5G smartphone, my life will never be the same.

title: Elias Ghanem
description: Elias Ghanem is the director of the Middle East and North Africa division of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

title: On Campaign Trail, Missteps on Gender
description: KATHA POLLITTs judgment, on Twitter, was harsh. The feminist writer observed: NYT mag: First Hillary as giant bald fleshball, now Can Wendy Davis Have It All? Sexist much?

title: The Games Putin Plays
description: THE last time geopolitics intruded into an Olympics, during the 2008 Beijing Games, Vladimir Putin was the crisiss winner: his military delivered a decisive spanking to Russias neighbor Georgia, whose government had fatally overestimated the Wests willingness to intervene on its behalf. The mini-war sent a clear message: after a long period of retrenchment, the Russian bear still had an appetite for power politics, and the claws to satisfy it.

title: Mumbais Empty Parlor Games
description: GOA, India  THERE was a time, only a few years ago now, when I prided myself as a host of parties  soirees, as some plummy guests called them. Before one such gathering, I was asked: Are you having another sorry this week? Rather than correct my guests French, I simply furnished the time, and the usual address: my sparse studio in the north Mumbai enclave of Juhu, overlooking a pond and a parking lot dotted with identically hooded black and yellow rickshaws.

title: In the Treetops, a Winter Gift
description: THEY looked, at first glance, like trees in a paint-by-number picture, snow outlining branches in idiot-proof chiaroscuro  a childs Winter Scene. Yet as I stood in a recent wet snowstorm on 110th Street, looking down Fifth Avenue along Central Park, I saw that the elms flanking the sidewalk had an aspect in winter less observable in other seasons, when their branches are cloaked in leaves.

title: When Even the Starting Line Is Out of Reach
description: POINT PLEASANT, W.Va.  JOHNNY WEETHEE, a beautiful and beaming child who at the age of 3 still struggles to speak, encapsulates the shortcomings of our approach to poverty.

title: A Viable Common Core?
description: Educators and others take part in a national debate over the new learning standards.

title: Christie Puts the Gloves On
description: PORT MONMOUTH, N.J.  THERES nothing more amusing than a bully forced to be on his best behavior.

title: What the Stimulus Accomplished
description: Of all the myths and falsehoods that Republicans have spread about President Obama, the most pernicious and long-lasting is that the $832 billion stimulus package did not work. Since 2009, Republican lawmakers have inextricably linked the words failed and stimulus, and last week, five years after passage of the Recovery Act, they dusted off their old playbook again.

title: Slalom Champion Sets an Age Record
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  A day after Mikaela Shiffrin became the youngest womens Olympic slalom champion, the 34-year-old Mario Matt of Austria became the oldest mens Olympic slalom champion on Saturday, winning the gold medal over his teammate Marcel Hirscher by 28-hundredths of a second.

title: Parliament Votes to Dismiss Yanukovych
description: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to declare Viktor F. Yanukovych constitutionally unable to be the president of the country. It scheduled an early vote for May 25.

title: Classics Aflame at Bottega Veneta
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: New York City Chancellor Meets With Charter School Leaders
description: The meeting was something like an early gathering of merging families. Both sides already knew each other, but no one was ready to broach potential conflict, lingering instead in the space of common interest: the well-being of the children.

title: At N.F.L. Combine, Michael Sam Says He Wants Focus on Field
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Like the other top N.F.L. draft prospects this year, Michael Sam met with reporters Saturday at Lucas Oil Stadium. Unlike any other soon-to-be professional football players, Sam wore a special button on the lanyard that hung around his neck.

title: Chain of Betrayal
description: It was big news this past week when President Obama dropped the notion of effectively cutting Social Security benefits by switching to chain-linked consumer prices, because it marked a turn away from BowlesSimpsonized discourse, from Grand Bargain-seeking. But theres a bit more to it: an acknowledgement, finally, that todays Republicans are utterly cynical and untrustworthy, that theres no point in seeking compromise.

title: Investing in Kids
description: My Sunday column, about the importance of anti-poverty efforts that focus on children, was motivated by a sense of frustration about the debate in this country. On the one hand, its terrific that were beginning to have a serious discussion about inequality, poverty and opportunity. On the other, the debate is mostly about the minimum wage and unemployment benefits, which to my thinking are useful but not the most cost-effective measures. The single most important measures we could take to build opportunity is to invest in children at the dawn of life to try harder to snap the cycle of poverty.

title: Age of Austerity
description: Zachary Goldfarb defends the argument that weve been living in an age of austerity against conservative denialists. Hes right, of course  but I think there are more graphic ways to make the point.

title: Mets Matt Harvey Tosses a Ball for the First Time Since Surgery
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Exactly four months after having Tommy John surgery on his right elbow, Matt Harvey stood in the outfield grass at the Mets complex Saturday and tossed a baseball 20 times to the bullpen catcher Dave Racaniello about 60 feet away.

title: Ready to Shed 2 Players, Knicks Let Game Get Away
description: ATLANTA  As the ball went up for the opening tip at Philips Arena on Saturday night, Cole Aldrich draped his left arm over the back of the folding chair next to him. It was empty.

title: Reel-Life Anniversary
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Its a strange feeling when someone has the same name as you.

title: The Memory Stone
description: This is the last part of an eight-part series.

title: Obama to Propose Shift in Wildfire Funding
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas annual budget request to Congress will propose a significant change in how the government pays to fight wildfires, administration officials said, a move that they say reflects the ways in which climate change is increasing the risk for and cost of those fires.

title: Behind Gates, Bizarre Vision of Opulence
description: KIEV, Ukraine  An eerie calm and a light mist shrouded President Viktor F. Yanukovychs sprawling residential compound just outside the capital on Saturday morning as street fighters from the center of Kiev made their way inside, gingerly passing a wrought-iron gate and cautioning one another about booby traps and snipers.

title: South Korea Puts Anger Aside After Olympic Skating Disappointment
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Yu-na was a perfect heroine for her country. Like postwar South Korea, she rose from a humble start, skating on a tatty rink as a 6-year-old, to win gold for a nation that had felt sidelined in a sport dominated by Western athletes.

title: 30 Seconds with Kyle Larson
description: Kyle Larson will begin his first full season in the Nascar Sprint Cup Series at the Daytona 500 on Sunday, driving the No. 42 car for Target Chip Ganassi Racing.

title: A Hot Debate Over E-Cigarettes as a Path to Tobacco, or From It
description: Dr. Michael Siegel, a hard-charging public health researcher at Boston University, argues that e-cigarettes could be the beginning of the end of smoking in America. He sees them as a disruptive innovation that could make cigarettes obsolete, like the computer did to the typewriter.

title: After Farmers Commit Suicide, Debts Fall on Families in India
description: BOLLIKUNTA, India  Latha Reddy Musukula was making tea on a recent morning when she spotted the money lenders walking down the dirt path toward her house. They came in a phalanx of 15 men, by her estimate. She knew their faces, because they had walked down the path before.

title: Opening the Corporation
description: Software may be eating the world, as Marc Andreessen likes to say, but the habits around modern software seem to have just as profound an impact.

title: An Underground Eye for the Border Patrol
description: Federal agents rely on military-grade robots to search drug-smuggling tunnels in Nogales, Ariz.

title: Borders New Sentinels Are Robots, Penetrating Deepest Drug Routes
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  Tom Pittman has made a career as a Border Patrol agent here guarding this citys underground drainage system, where the tunnels that carry sewage and storm runoff between the United States and Mexico are also busy drug-smuggling routes. Over the years, he has crawled and slithered past putrid puddles, makeshift latrines and discarded needles left behind by drug users, relying on instincts, mostly, to gauge the risks ahead.

title: Opponents of Same-Sex Marriage Take Bad-for-Children Argument to Court
description: As they reel from a succession of defeats in courtrooms and legislatures, opponents of same-sex marriage have a new chance this week to play one of their most emotional and, they hope, potent cards: the claim that having parents of the same sex is bad for children.

title: Officer Shoots Knife-Wielding Woman in Brooklyn, Police Say
description: A police officer shot a woman inside a Brooklyn apartment on Saturday after she lunged at officers with a knife, an official said.

title: Mexican Drug Kingpin Is Captured
description: Joaqun Guzmn Loera, El Chapo, one of Mexicos top drug bosses and a Forbes list billionaire since 2009, was captured today in a Mexican resort after a 13-year manhunt.

title: Asylum Fraud in Chinatown: An Industry of Lies
description: A Chinese woman walked into a law office in New Yorks Chinatown and asked to see her lawyer. She had applied for asylum, claiming that she had been forced to get an abortion in China to comply with the countrys family-planning laws, and she was anxious about her coming interview with immigration officials.

title: Wildcat Red Emerges as Derby Contender
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  The trainer Jose Garoffalo spent all of his $30,000 budget last June to buy Wildcat Red as a 2-year-old, never imagining the bargain he was bringing home.

title: A Lesson for Detroit in Efforts to Aid a New Orleans Devastated by Katrina
description: NEW ORLEANS  As Detroit confronts some of the most intractable challenges of any city in America, with an array of civic leaders and urban planners offering solutions and ideas, it may be helpful to consider Harvey Bender.

title: In Japans Drill With the U.S., a Message for Beijing
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  In the early morning along a barren stretch of beach here last week, Japanese soldiers and American Marines practiced how to invade and retake an island captured by hostile forces.

title: Horst Rechelbacher, Father of Safe Cosmetics, Dies at 72
description: Horst Rechelbacher, an Austrian-born hairstylist who went on to found Aveda, a company whose pledge to eliminate toxic chemicals from its products helped give rise to a vast market for so-called natural cosmetics in the United States, died on Feb. 15 in Osceola, Wis. He was 72.

title: The Wisconsin Labor Fight
description: An epic fight with unions continues to dominate the tenure of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.

title: Princeton a Repeat Champ at Amateur Tournament
description: Princeton Universitys A team won the United States Amateur Team East championship last week for the second year in a row.

title: Terry Adkins, Composer of Art, Sculptor of Music, Dies at 60
description: Terry Adkins, a conceptual artist whose work married the quicksilver evanescence of music to the solid permanence of sculpture, died on Feb. 8 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 60.

title: Lviv, in Western Ukraine, Mourns One of Its Own Killed in Kiev
description: LVIV, Ukraine  Under a leaden sky that wept intermittent rain, this fiercely proud city bade farewell on Saturday to one of its sons, a 28-year-old university lecturer killed by a bullet on Thursday in Kiev in the carnage on and around Independence Square.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 22, 2014
Environmental Groups Resort to Suing Industries Directly
description: Starting Monday, a federal judge in Waco will hear arguments from the Sierra Club that Luminant Generation Company, the states largest electric generator, has been spewing far more pollution into the air from an East Texas coal plant than is allowed by federal and state law.

title: For the Sake of the Primaries, a Simple Vision
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Kerry Says Venezuela Crackdown Is Unacceptable
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Secretary of State John Kerry has markedly stepped up his criticism of Venezuela over its response to more than two weeks of antigovernment demonstrations, as the protests continued to grow this weekend.

title: Trying to Help Thousands in Colonias Obtain Health Coverage
description: EDINBURG  Sitting at an old picnic table in front of a dilapidated house, Mara Daz, a hotel housekeeper, tells stories of the rejection that comes with living in impoverished Texas colonias.

title: Lets Talk a Bit More About Bates and Anna
description: Ernie Manouse traveled to Amsterdam at the end of August 2012 but spent the three-day trip holed up in his hotel room, unexpectedly binging on the first two seasons of Downton Abbey.

title: After Boeheim Leaves in a Rage, Syracuse Exits With a Loss
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Forward C. J. Fair had never played at Cameron Indoor Stadium before Saturday night. Point guard Tyler Ennis had never dribbled on Coach K Court. Guard Trevor Cooney had never risen for a 3-pointer with the Cameron Crazies screaming at him.

title: Declaring Victory in Kiev
description: After months of protests and a week of bloody mayhem, demonstrators in Independence Square celebrated the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych.

title: A Forensic Approach to a Sidewalk Nuisance
description: NAPLES, Italy  Problems? Yes, conceded Tommaso Sodano, the vice mayor here, Naples has problems. Unpaid debts have reportedly topped $2 billion. Many streets are pocked with potholes. The police department is underfunded, organized crime operates like a shadow state, and illegal dumps are scattered around what is still a grittily beautiful port city.

title: Monica Hickey and Joseph Coquelin
description: Monica Clare Hickey and Joseph Anthony Coquelin were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the city clerks office, officiated.

title: Grace Lin, Michael Paley
description: Grace Liting Lin, a daughter of Jane S. Tsai and William T. Lin of Indianapolis, was married Saturday evening to Michael Alexander Paley, the son of Marianne Steiner and Dr. Robert H. Paley of Washington. Cantor Sharon Grainer officiated in the Hamilton Garden at the Kimmel Center in Philadelphia.

title: Ruth Halvey and Francisco Morales Barrn
description: Ruth Kathryn Halvey, a daughter of Louise Platt Halvey and Dr. Cornelius H. Halvey of Sarasota, Fla., was married there Saturday evening to Francisco Jos Morales Barrn, a son of Odette Barrn and Jos A. Morales of Zapopan, Mexico. Cantor Marci Vitkus officiated at the Field Club.

title: Bronwen Baumgardner and David Sanders
description: Bronwen Baumgardner, a daughter of Colleen Reidy Baumgardner and Andrew Baumgardner of Fairfield, Conn., was married Saturday to David Robert Sanders, a son of Isabelle Peck Sanders and the Rev. Robert E. Sanders of Waterbury, Vt. The grooms father, a Presbyterian minister who retired as the pastor to Princeton Theological Seminary, officiated at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John E. Barclay, also a Presbyterian minister, participated.

title: Marissa Teicher, Andrew Miller
description: Marissa Ellen Teicher and Andrew Douglas Miller were married Saturday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein officiated.

title: Gillian Tullman, Ryan Whalen
description: Gillian Blythe Tullman and Ryan James Whalen were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. Judge William J. Corbett, who retired as a village justice of Floral Park, N.Y., officiated.

title: Priscilla Painton and Andrew Heyward
description: Priscilla Painton and Andrew John Heyward were married Tuesday evening at the Manhattan home of their friends Lili Lynton and Michael Ryan. Judge Carol Stokinger, the supervising judge of Queens County Family Court, officiated.

title: Emily Hart Cobb, Bradley Breece
description: Emily Hart Cobb, a daughter of Margaret M. Cobb and Ike W. Cobb of Atlanta, was married Saturday to Bradley Joseph Breece, a son of Rose D. Breece and Brooks J. Breece of Dale City, Va. The Rev. Joanna Adams performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Atlanta.

title: Lea Paganelli, Ryan Cassidy
description: Lea OBrien Paganelli and Ryan John Cassidy were married Saturday at the First Parish Church of Groton in Groton, Mass. The Rev. Dr. John A. Nelson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Jamie Shupak, Brian Stelter
description: Jamie Gayle Shupak and Brian Patrick Stelter were married Saturday evening at the Sheraton Society Hill in Philadelphia. Cantor Amy E. Levy performed the ceremony.

title: Nathan Lump and Charles Runnette
description: Nathan Lump and Charles Runnette were married Saturday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. The officiant was Mary Shields, a friend of the couple who is a minister affiliated with the Church of Gaiabriel in Alexandria, Va.

title: Ninamarie Bojekian, Daniel Mendoza
description: Ninamarie Bojekian, the daughter of Maria Bojekian and Stephen Bojekian of Franklin Lakes. N.J., was married Saturday to Daniel Manuel Mendoza, a son of Olga Delgado-Mendoza and Carlos A. Mendoza, both of North Bergen, N.J. The Rev. Panagiotis Lekkas, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony at St. John the Theologian Cathedral in Tenafly, N.J., with the Rev. Basil Gikas, also Greek Orthodox, taking part.

title: Hinda Schuman, Susan Toler
description: Hinda Schuman and Susan Gayle Toler were married Saturday in Brooklyn at the apartment of Thomas Halper and his wife, Marilyn Halper. Mr. Halper, who is a Universal Life minister and a cousin of Ms. Schuman, officiated.

title: Zoe Settle, James Schriebl
description: Zoe Grace Settle and James Hubert Schriebl were married Saturday evening in New York. Peter Kendall, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Sarah Norton, Michael Burns
description: Sarah Christine Norton and Michael George Burns were married Saturday at the Old Mission Church in Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Larry Gosselin, a Franciscan friar and the associate pastor of St. Barbara Parish at the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Amanda Wolin, Jonathan Moskowitz
description: Amanda Nicole Wolin and Jonathan David Moskowitz were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Los Angeles. Cantor Marcus Feldman performed the ceremony.

title: Angeli Saijwani and Rahul Sharma
description: Angeli Saijwani and Dr. Rahul Sharma were married Saturday at Cipriani 42nd Street, an event space in Manhattan. Pandit Himanshu D. Jani, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Sara Gillesby, Peter Sabatino
description: Sara Michelle Gillesby and Peter Anthony Sabatino were married Saturday at Devils Thumb Ranch in Tabernash, Colo. The Rev. Martin N. Hunckler, a retired Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: He Won Her Vote
description: Amy Cecilia Salomone and Nicholas Justin Thornton were married Saturday by the Rev. Emmanuel Taylor at St. Dominics Catholic Church in San Francisco.

title: Big Shot by Curry and Frustrating Night for Nets
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Stephen Curry has delivered countless late-game daggers. His latest one left his hand askew, but it did its job nevertheless.

title: Corrections: February 23, 2014
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Gas Leak Kills Man at Long Island Mall
description: A carbon monoxide leak at a mall on Long Island killed one person Saturday night and sickened more than two dozen, according to the local authorities.

title: Taliban Raid Afghan Army Base, Killing Soldiers in Their Sleep
description: ASADABAD, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents overran an Afghan National Army base near here on Sunday morning, killing 21 soldiers in their bunks in what appeared to be the worst single blow to government forces since 2010, according to both government and insurgent officials.

title: Ukraine Rushes to Shift Power and Mend Rifts
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukrainian lawmakers moved swiftly on Sunday to assert control over the government, racing to restore calm after a week of upheaval and bloodshed that ended in President Viktor F. Yanukovychs flight and ouster on Saturday, and in sudden fears that the country might fall into civil war.

title: In Milan
description: Designers send out their autumn 2014 collections, with highlights ranging from furry fantasies to intricate embellishment.

title: Sochi Olympics Closing Ceremony Latest Updates
description: Russia had so much to prove at the Winter Games. That spending however-many-billion dollars to build an Olympics-industrial complex from scratch on the edge of the Black Sea was worth it. That despite a thicket of security worries, logistical obstacles, weather annoyances and the darkening specter of revolution in nearby Ukraine, the country could put on a Games that ran seamlessly, at times even exuberantly.

title: Marni: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Strong Finish Gives Russia Most Medals
description: SOCHI, Russia  The host country shone on Sunday, the final day of the 2014 Winter Olympics, as Alexander Zubkov drove Russia to victory in the four-man bobsled, Alexander Legkov led a Russian sweep of the 50-kilometer cross-country skiing race, and Russia ended the Games at the top of the medals table.

title: In Our Pages: February 24
description: 1914: French Armored Cruiser Driven Ashore

title: The Price of a Child I Wouldnt Let Go
description: When I was a child, my family never discussed money. It was sufficient to know we didnt have any. I was the quintessential American dream: girl from a trailer park who ate government cheese but became a first-generation high school graduate. I went on to earn a masters degree and sit solidly in the top 25 percent of taxpayers, hovering around six figures as a family, a demographic reached with great effort.

title: Stingy Defense Adds to Canadas Gold Pile
description: SOCHI, Russia  The Canadian mens hockey team was one of the favorites to win the gold medal here when the Winter Games began, and on the road to the final, it steamrollered Norway and Austria before winning battles over Finland, Latvia and the United States.

title: Samsung Introduces Two New Smartwatches
description: Samsung Electronics introduced two new smartwatches on Sunday, the Gear 2 and Gear 2 Neo, and dropped the popular Galaxy branding from its first smartwatch, the Galaxy Gear. Also, unlike Samsungs first smartwatch, the new products use Tizen, an operating system that Samsung developed with several partners, instead of Googles Android.

title: Live Stream | Missonis Fall 2014 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
description: The latest womens collection from Missoni at Milan Fashion Week.

title: An Odd Couple in the News Business Partner in a Series on Fatherhood
description: In recent days, The Deseret News, a newspaper in Salt Lake City, prominently displayed on its website a feature about Mormons on reality TV shows. The Atlantic magazines home page, meanwhile, drew readers to an article on why women struggle to write about sex.

title: Fatal Violence Strikes Antigovernment Rallies in Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Four people were killed, including three children, and more than 50 injured at antigovernment protests in Thailand over the weekend as the countrys protracted power struggle gave rise to more violence.

title: What Did I Know and When Did I Know It?
description: The big takeaway from the 2008 Fed transcripts is that for the most part Fed officials other than Janet Yellen and Eric Rosengren failed to appreciate the danger the economy was in  that many were preoccupied with the supposed threat of inflation even as a once-in-three-generations crisis in demand was building.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Jil Sander Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: After WhatsApp Deal, Visions of Magic Numbers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Whats your number?

title: The Myth of German Austerity
description: Every once in a while I hear people trying to dismiss the overwhelming evidence for large economic damage from fiscal austerity by pointing to Germany: You say that austerity hurts growth, but the Germans have done a lot of austerity and theyre booming.

title: Can California Avoid a Shock to Trance Approach to Water Policy?
description: Forecasters predict heavy rains will sweep in from the Pacific Ocean over much of California late next week. The states extreme drought will be far from over, but the shift from parched days to downpours illustrates on a short time scale one factor explaining why its hard to change deeply ingrained and wasteful approaches to water policy.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Emilio Pucci Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

title: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 7 P.M. (NBC) NANCY & TONYA (2014) In this documentary, Mary Carillo looks back at events leading up to the 1994 Winter Olympics, which pitted the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan against her rival Tonya Harding (above left, with Ms. Kerrigan), just weeks after Ms. Hardings ex-husband and bodyguard were charged with plotting an attack on Ms. Kerrigan that injured her knee. Both women are interviewed, as are their coaches, the skater Scott Hamilton and members of the media. The closing ceremony of the Sochi Games follows at 8.

title: Nicklas Backstrom Misses Final After Failed Drug Test
description: SOCHI, Russia  Nicklas Backstrom, a player for the Washington Capitals in the N.H.L. who represented Sweden in its five victories on the way to the Olympic gold medal game, failed a drug test at the Sochi Games. He was removed from Swedens lineup Sunday before the final, which Canada won, 3-0.

title: Missoni: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Model-Morphosis | Lindsey Wixson at Emilio Pucci
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Lindsey Wixson (left) and after (right) makeup by Yadim and hair by Luigi Murenu.

title: Those Lego Bricks Keep Piling Up at the Box Office
description: And the Lego pieces keep marching on. For the third weekend in a row, The Lego Movie was the top draw at North American theaters, while an expensive new volcano adventure, Pompeii, blew its chance at profitability. The Lego Movie (Warner Brothers) took in an estimated $31.5 million, for a new domestic total of $183.2 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data.

title: Bottega Veneta: Tomas Maier Turns Soft Into Sharp
description: MILAN  Taking a scalpel to all that is fancy, yet controlling pattern in a defined space. It sounds so easy. Yet only a designer of the caliber of Tomas Maier atBottega Veneta can pull off such a combination.

title: Dolce & Gabbana Create a Fashion Fairytale
description: MILAN  There was not a church, a cross or a Sicilian landscape in sight as Dolce & Gabbana sent out its winter 2014 show on Sunday. Instead, falling snow, the bare branches of winter trees and Tchaikovskys soaring music started a fashion fairy tale.

title: Ominous Stirrings In a Fitful Realm
description: BERLIN  The nightmares evoked by the title of Georg Friedrich Haass new dark dreams, which the Berlin Philharmonic played with its chief conductor, Simon Rattle, on Saturday evening at the Philharmonie here, involve repetition and circling back: the ominous sense that even as things change, they remain the same.

title: A Fall Collection, and a Giant New Boutique, From Cavalli
description: Roberto Cavallis ambitions have never run small. Not content to simply put on a show at Milan Fashion Week, he staged what his team called a Roberto Cavalli Day.

title: Jason Collins, First Openly Gay N.B.A. Player, Signs With Nets and Appears in Game
description: LOS ANGELES  Jason Collins, a 35-year-old center, signed a 10-day contract with the Nets on Sunday afternoon and played against the Lakers hours later, appearing in an N.B.A. uniform for the first time since last spring, when he announced that he was gay.

title: Q.&A. With Joe Belfiore on the Future of Windows Phone
description: Joe Belfiore is the corporate vice president of Microsoft Windows Phone, and he oversees the software that powers handsets using the companys operating system. Microsoft is expected to close its $7.2 billion deal to buy the handset and services division of Nokia by the end of March. The acquisition will give Microsoft control of both mobile software and hardware, as it looks to expand its 4 percent market share in global smartphone sales. Mr. Belfiore will play a crucial role in Microsofts efforts to take on Apple and the cellphone makers that use Googles Android operating system.

title: Strutting With Style in Sochi
description: They come in Red Army hats, silly hats, even cowboy hats. They have painted faces and wigs in the national colors. A few wear bear costumes, tongue-in-cheek displays as much for the television cameras as for the tourists.

title: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: Michigan Beats Michigan State to Grab Big Ten Lead
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Nik Stauskas had been quiet and cold for the better part of February. Stauskas, a sophomore guard, had scored more than 11 points once in Michigans past five games, and with him taking just three shots in the first half against Michigan State on Sunday, the dormancy seemed likely to continue.

title: MSGM: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Milan

title: At Mobile World Congress, a Sign of Tech Industrys Shifting Focus
description: In a sign that the tech industry may have moved past computers, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, will be the most prominent speaker this week at the Mobile World Congress, a trade show in Barcelona that revolves around smartphones and other devices.

title: Taking Stock in Ukraine
description: Ukrainians turned out in Kiev to mourn those who died in last weeks conflict while pro-Yanukovych protests took place in several cities in the south and east.

title: Salvatore Ferragamos Quietly Luxurious Knee-High Boots
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Old Railroad Stirs Memories of a Pre-Industrial China
description: My father rode the Xinning Railway once. He was 4 years old and traveling from Hong Kong with his parents and older brother to their ancestral village in Guangdong Province. It was 1936, in a China without six-lane highways and gleaming airports. They were returning to the countryside to build a new family home.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Bailout
description: Notes here (pdf).

title: Sochi Wrap-Up
description: Athletes discuss their experiences getting into the 2014 Olympics and once in Sochi.

title: Comcast and Netflix Reach Deal on Service
description: Comcast, the countrys largest cable and broadband provider, and Netflix, the giant television and movie streaming service, announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcasts subscribers.

title: Happy Days and Happy Feet, Despite the Depression
description: What, if anything, does it mean that the giddiest, most euphoric popular music ever produced in the United States bubbled and kicked up its heels while the country was sliding into the Great Depression? That question hovered over the joyous opening-night performance on Saturday of Sweepin the Clouds Away: Boom, Bust and High Spirits, presented by the 92nd Street Ys Lyrics & Lyricists series, almost all of whose songs were written between 1929 and 1932.

title: A Hint of Jazz From a Classical Quartet
description: The superb Quatuor bne has made a name for itself not only as an elegant purveyor of classical fare but also for jazz performances. That influence could be heard on Friday evening at Zankel Hall in the groups encore, an arrangement of Erroll Garners Misty, and in its interpretation of Schumanns String Quartet in A (Op. 41, No. 3).

title: Floating Together, Staring and Circling
description: No man is an island, John Donne said, and it would seem that the choreographer Vanessa Anspaugh agrees. In her we were an island, which debuted at Danspace Project on Thursday, the five performers are distinctive, but the connections among them are more various and ineluctable than they appear on the surface. Once the dancers have all made their entrances, no one escapes the others gaze.

title: Balanchine and Robbins, With Echoes of a Long-Ago Star
description: What seemed like just another New York City Ballet program on Friday night at the David H. Koch Theater turned out to be nothing of the sort. It was impossible to be in the presence of Jerome Robbinss Afternoon of a Faun and George Balanchines La Valse without thinking of Tanaquil le Clercq.

title: Stories and Explanations Rooted in the Personal
description: One part of Asaf Avidan, the Israeli songwriter who gave a solo concert on Friday night at Irving Plaza, is a lot like Leonard Cohen: the Leonard Cohen who sings delicately fingerpicked songs full of finely calibrated metaphors, aphoristic phrases, paradoxes and mournful romance. I said, Baby you are magic/ She said, No, hon, just a trick, he sang in Anchor.

title: A Four-and-a-Half-Ring Circus Ends, and a Relieved Russia Roars
description: SOCHI, Russia  Russia had so much to prove at the Winter Games. Was spending however-many billions of dollars to build an Olympics-industrial complex from scratch on the edge of the Black Sea worth it? How could the country overcome a thicket of potential problems: security worries, logistical obstacles, weather annoyances and the darkening specter of revolution in nearby Ukraine?

title: A Show of Love: Farewell, City Opera
description: Often, when a performing arts institution is forced to shut down, it at least is able to present a special closing performance, an occasion for artists and audiences to look back at all the accomplishments and find comfort together.

title: Audiences That Devise Game Plans
description: On Friday at New York Live Arts, in the wake of a government collapse, 63 citizens  humanoids, we were called  gathered to develop strategies for rebuilding society. There to help us were two experts in catastrophe survival from the former Yugoslavia.

title: Thailand at an Impasse
description: Thailand rolls to a democratic standstill.

title: Seth Meyers: Smart Guy in the Wiseguy Seat
description: Seth Meyers is the oldest, most experienced and most hostlike comedian to take the reins of NBCs three-decade-old Late Night.

title: Writers Biographer Creates a Portrait of His Own Family
description: Blake Bailey has now written four books about families blessed with literary talent and plagued by the ravages of alcohol. His fierce affinity for these subjects is now a little easier to understand. The writers Richard Yates, John Cheever (my father-in-law) and Charles Jackson, who wrote what he knew in his novel The Lost Weekend, all spoke to Mr. Baileys own turbulent background. Both he and, to a much greater extent, his older brother, Scott, walked a thin line between self-discipline and drunken disaster.

title: Applying Olympic Sinew to Strauss
description: The Winter Olympics may have been seven time zones away, in Sochi, Russia, but energy, athleticism and showmanship also filled the air at another Olympus, Carnegie Hall, on Friday evening, in a concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: Looking for Characters
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Time to hit the reset button and get started on a brand new week. After two challenging Sunday puzzles, a Monday crossword is a most welcome sight.
