title: Listening to Ancients in Zimbabwe and Finding a Prehistoric Fable
description: Coming up with the right story for a new musical is notoriously difficult. Yet the measures that Chris Berry took to get the narrative for The Legend of Yauna still count as extreme. Mr. Berry, a musician of European descent, has said that the tale came to him in Zimbabwe, through a spiritual medium, from people who lived 12,000 years ago.

title: What the West Must Do for Ukraine
description: BRUSSELS  Thanks in part to the coordinated efforts of Germany, Poland, France and the United States, irrevocable change has finally come to Ukraine, with President Viktor F. Yanukovychs flight from Kiev and Parliaments vote to call for new elections in May.

title: 12 Years a Slave Is Headed to Schools
description: High school students could soon be studying 12 Years a Slave. Starting in September, the film, the book and a study guide will be distributed to public high schools by the National School Boards Association in partnership with New Regency, Penguin Books and the filmmakers. Montel Williams coordinated the program, which is modeled after similar distribution by The Montel Williams Show of copies of the Civil War film Glory. When Hollywood is at its best, the power of the movies can be harnessed into a powerful educational tool, Mr. Williams said in a statement. This film uniquely highlights a shameful period in American history, and in doing so will evoke in students a desire to not repeat the evils of the past while inspiring them to dream big of a better and brighter future. Steve McQueen, above, the films director, said: Since first reading 12 Years a Slave, it has been my dream that this book be taught in schools.

title: NBC to Bring Back Heroes in New Form
description: Theyre coming back: once-dead television series, that is  revived as so-called event series by networks discovering a form that has distinguished cable drama for much of the past decade. The latest example is the onetime hit science-fiction series Heroes, which NBC announced it would resurrect as Heroes Reborn, a 13-episode series in 2015. The network used its platform of the Winter Olympics to tease out the announcement on Saturday, running a brief promotion. The news release that followed on Saturday night confirmed a few details: Tim Kring, who created the original Heroes in the 2006 television season, will be back as the executive producer. Before that, NBC is to create a digital series that will introduce the new story and characters. (Some original cast members may return.) Jennifer Salke, NBCs president for entertainment, said in a statement that most details about the new version would be appropriately shrouded in mystery. Exactly when the show might appear is not known. Perhaps NBC will wait to see how the most immediate progenitor of the idea, Foxs revival of 24, fares this summer. CBS fashioned a hit last summer out of Under the Dome and has another such event-style short-run sci-fi series, Extant, with Halle Berry, planned for this summer.

title: At New England Knockout Team Regional, Rules Are Rules
description: At the New England Knockout Team Regional in Cromwell, Conn., this month Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City entered the two-session Wednesday A/B Pairs. In the diagramed deal, they got a tied top, but it cost them first place. How?

title: Milan Fashion Week: Marni Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: American Held in Israeli Prison Dies in Shootout
description: JERUSALEM  An American-Israeli man who was serving time in a prison in central Israel for the grisly murder of a teenager in a Washington suburb in 1997 was killed in a shootout with Israeli security forces on Sunday after he shot and wounded several prison guards, according to the police.

title: Locke and Load: The Fatal Error of the Stand Your Ground Philosophy
description: I.

title: Piers Morgan and CNN Plan End to His Prime-Time Show
description: There have been times when the CNN host Piers Morgan didnt seem to like America very much  and American audiences have been more than willing to return the favor. Three years after taking over for Larry King, Mr. Morgan has seen the ratings for Piers Morgan Live hit some new lows, drawing a fraction of viewers compared with competitors at Fox News and MSNBC.

title: Vows: A Temporary Separation
description: When Hinda Schuman and Susan Toler separated, Ms. Schuman made a photography series about their breakup. They could only stand eight months apart, however, and are set to wed after 32 years together.

description: The Sochi Games wrapped up with gold medal events in hockey, cross-country skiing and bobsled before the closing ceremony.

title: In New Yorks Strictest No-Parking Zones, Not Even the F.B.I. Is Exempt
description: At the Federal Bureau of Investigations counterterrorism compound in the Chelsea neighborhood, the urgent announcement sends special agents rushing to the streets.

title: New Generation of Stars Emerges in Alpine Events
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  One of the earliest images of the Alpine competition at the 2014 Winter Olympics was Bode Miller as he streaked down the treacherous downhill course far ahead of the field in training. Miller, an Olympian since 1998, was somehow turning back the clock and had made himself the favorite in the opening, and premier, ski racing event of the Sochi Games.

title: Teachers on Campus: A Hierarchy
Turks Protest New Internet Restrictions, in the Streets and Online
description: ISTANBUL  The police used force to disperse hundreds of Turks who gathered late Saturday to protest new legislation that increased government control of the Internet.

title: N.F.L. Weighs Punishment for Slurs
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Tolerance has been as much a topic of discussion as any players 40-yard dash time at the N.F.L.s scouting combine, as the league readies for the expected workout Monday of Michael Sam.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Supporters of same-sex marriage have had many victories in recent years, in courts, in state legislatures and at the ballot box.

title: As a Painter Grows Older, His Creativity Endures
description: Ed Clark stood silently before the canvas on the floor of his studio. He considered the muted morning light, the paint and its promise. Then he pushed a broom across the surface, capturing the hues of daybreak and twilight with each stroke.

title: Stalins Presence Is Still Felt in Host City
description: SOCHI, Russia  The absurdity of the juxtaposition of the festival of commercialism known as the Olympics, and the dacha of Stalin, a leader of the proletariat, was jarringly apparent at a security gate in the hills overlooking the Black Sea.

title: Top Military Body Against Syrias Assad Is in Chaos, Undermining Fight
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  It appeared to be a huge step forward for the scattered rebel groups fighting to topple President Bashar al-Assad of Syria: the creation of a central body of top insurgent commanders who would coordinate military campaigns, direct foreign support and serve as a unifying force for their diverse movement.

title: Trial for Kerry Kennedy Will Focus on Sleeping Aid
description: When the police caught up with Kerry Kennedy on the morning of July 13, 2012, after her collision with a tractor-trailer, she was wearing gym clothes.

title: Turnaround Has Matsuzaka in Hunt for No. 5 Spot in the Mets Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Late last season, after another poor start threatened to cut short his career, Daisuke Matsuzaka went golfing with a group that included his interpreter, Jeff Cutler, and the Mets pitching coach, Dan Warthen.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Young Immigrants Turn Focus to President in Struggle Over Deportations
description: PHOENIX  More than 500 leaders of a national network of young immigrants, frustrated that House Republicans said they would not move on immigration this year, have decided to turn their protests on President Obama in an effort to pressure him to act unilaterally to stop deportations.

title: Amid the Triumphs, an Argument for Tolerance
description: SOCHI, Russia  The closing ceremony of the Sochi Games on Sunday night was a celebration of everything Russian, and everything that Russia does so well.

title: Expand Pre-K, Not A.D.H.D.
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  THE writing is on the chalkboard. Over the next few years, America can count on a major expansion of early childhood education. We embrace this trend, but as health policy researchers, we want to raise a major caveat: Unless were careful, todays preschool bandwagon could lead straight to an epidemic of 4- and 5-year-olds wrongfully being told that they have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

title: Genetically Modified Babies
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  AN advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration is set to begin two days of meetings tomorrow to consider radical biological procedures that, if successful, would produce genetically modified human beings. This is a dangerous step. These techniques would change every cell in the bodies of children born as a result of their use, and these alterations would be passed down to future generations.

title: Health Care Horror Hooey
description: Remember the death tax? The estate tax is quite literally a millionaires tax  a tax that affects only a tiny minority of the population, and is mostly paid by a handful of very wealthy heirs. Nonetheless, right-wingers have successfully convinced many voters that the tax is a cruel burden on ordinary Americans  that all across the nation small businesses and family farms are being broken up to pay crushing estate tax liabilities.

title: How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot
description: MAZATLN, Mexico  They reacted here with utter disbelief. Joaqun Guzmn Loera, El Chapo, drug kingpin to the world, the Robin Hood of Sinaloa, had been arrested in his home state, in the resort town that is a loyal fief of his empire?

title: For Detroit, New Stage in Its Race to Recover
description: DETROIT  Labor union leaders said they hated it. Financial creditors said it was lopsided against them. Some community leaders said it favored the banks over ordinary people. And at least one pension fund official called it premature and draconian.

title: Crime and Punishment and Obama
description: I DOUBT any president has been as well equipped as Barack Obama to appreciate the vicious cycle of American crime and punishment. As a community organizer in Chicago in the 1980s, he would have witnessed the way a system intended to protect the public siphoned off young black men, gave them an advanced education in brutality, and then returned them to the streets unqualified for  and too often, given the barriers to employment faced by those who have done time, disqualified from  anything but a life of more crime. He would have understood that the suffering of victims and the debasing of offenders were often two sides of the same coin.

title: Let the E.P.A. Do Its Job
description: On Monday, for the third time in seven years, the Supreme Court will consider the scope of the federal governments power to regulate the emission of greenhouse gases, which are a major contributor to global climate change.

title: Locked Away in Immigration Jails
description: You can find examples of federal detainees held inexplicably for years without criminal charges or bond hearings much closer to home than Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: New Version of Two-Faced YotaPhone to Have Larger Screens and More Power
description: The Russian start-up Yota Devices will reveal on Monday the next generation of its unusual two-faced YotaPhone at the Mobile World Congress event in Barcelona. The phone stands apart from many of its smartphone peers  which often appear similar to each other  by having a conventional color touchscreen on one side and a low-power electronic paper display filling its other side.

title: Blast Kills 12 Riding in Van in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 12 people were killed and 16 injured when a bomb went off in northwestern Pakistan on Sunday, according to police officials, as security forces continued to attack militant hide-outs in the countrys tribal regions with airstrikes.

title: A Second Front in the Privacy Wars
description: More than a year before Edward Snowden exposed the vast reach of government surveillance, President Obama proposed a Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights to protect Americans from the prying eyes of Internet companies, advertisers and other businesses. In a February 2012 report, his administration offered a well-reasoned argument for giving consumers more control over how much and what kind of data companies can collect about them and what businesses can do with that information.

title: Seeking a Lead on News, Network Turns to Data-Mining Media Group
description: When Ronan Farrow, the young human rights lawyer with a Hollywood lineage, debuts as an MSNBC host on Monday, he will have some prodigious computing power backing him up.

title: Collins Finds Spot Again, Moving the N.B.A. Forward
description: After a Boston Celtics game last season, inside the locker room, Coach Doc Rivers singled out Jason Collins for missing a defensive assignment, for being out of position.

title: First Companies Give to Fund for Victims of Bangladeshi Factory Collapse
description: ROME  Five global clothing brands and retailers on Sunday became the first contributors to a new fund raising $40 million for victims of the Rana Plaza factory disaster in Bangladesh, and activists are campaigning to pressure other brands to also make donations.

title: Yankees Add Four Years to Gardners Deal
description: TAMPA, Fla.  From the moment the Yankees signed Jacoby Ellsbury on Dec. 7, the speculation began that they would trade Brett Gardner. Who, after all, would need two speedy, leadoff center fielders?

title: Feds Aid in 2008 Crisis Stretched Worldwide
description: WASHINGTON  Tuesday morning, Sept. 16, 2008, was perhaps the darkest time for the United States economy in modern memory  even if nobody knew it quite yet. It was barely 24 hours removed from the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers, and a few hours before the government would rescue the insurer American International Group.

title: N.B.A.s 10-Day Contract Is Essentially a Job Tryout
description: The N.B.A. is known for its guaranteed contracts, which stand in stark contrast to the free-for-all in the N.F.L., where a player can generally be terminated anytime. An exception in basketball is the 10-day contract, which serves as a risk-free, on-the-job tryout for a player attempting to make a teams roster.

title: As His Fortunes Fell in Ukraine, a President Clung to Illusions
description: KIEV, Ukraine  As his allies deserted him and throngs of people bayed for his blood almost within earshot of his office, President Viktor F. Yanukovych took time out on Friday to celebrate Ukraines first gold medal at the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia. In a message of congratulations to the womens biathlon relay team, he praised its power and will to win.

title: Pentagon Plans to Shrink Army to Pre-World War II Level
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel plans to shrink the United States Army to its smallest force since before the World War II buildup and eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets in a new spending proposal that officials describe as the first Pentagon budget to aggressively push the military off the war footing adopted after the terror attacks of 2001.

title: N.Y.U. Hospitals Political Fund-Raising Questioned
description: On Nov. 9, 2012, less than two weeks after Hurricane Sandy made landfall, Kenneth G. Langone pulled on a pair of construction workers bright yellow galoshes and accompanied Senator Charles E. Schumer and other officials through a foul-smelling mix of diesel oil and water in the basement of his namesake, NYU Langone Medical Center.

title: Visiting Prisoners, Without Visiting Prison
In Manhattan, Children of Ukrainians Connect to Revolution
description: A group of young boys huddled on Second Avenue in the East Village on Sunday, talking about Ukraine.

title: Yahoo Aims to More Deftly Blend Ads With Content
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  To Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, fashion magazines like Vogue and InStyle have achieved the holy grail of advertising.

description: SOCHI, Russia  Now comes the hard part.

title: Ad Campaign Seeks to Increase Chances of Cuomos Campaign Finance Plan
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo delivered a pleasant surprise to skeptical liberal activists last month by tucking a long-discussed plan to provide public financing for state political campaigns into his state budget proposal.

title: Fresh From Prison, a Former Prime Minister Returns to the Political Stage
description: KIEV, Ukraine  For nearly two years, foreign officials pleaded with President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine to let his archrival, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, leave prison for medical care abroad, but he refused, convinced that she had just one destination in mind: a return to the political stage.

title: Indians Catcher Hopes to Spread His Sport in Brazil
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  The Cleveland Indians gathered around the television in their clubhouse here Friday, most pleading for the United States mens hockey team to come back against Canada at the Olympics. Only John Axford, the reliever from Ontario whose maple-leaf sweater hung proudly in his locker, grinned as the clock ran out.

title: In the DeMint Era at Heritage, a Shift From Policy to Politics
description: WASHINGTON  Not long after Jim DeMint took over the Heritage Foundation last spring, his team summoned the staff for a meeting unlike any the decorous conservative policy organization had ever convened. Music blared in the auditorium. Policy analysts began with a few awkward jokes and then scampered about in a series of skits that laid out the foundations goals.

title: Power Shift Inspires Joy in Kiev, Fury in East
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Red Communist flags flew on Sunday in front of a massive bust of Lenin in this hardscrabble coal-mining city, a stronghold of pro-Russia sentiment in Ukraine. About 500 yards away, a few hundred pro-democracy activists, harangued by hundreds of counterdemonstrators, laid wreaths for the victims of last weeks bedlam in Kiev at a memorial to one of Ukraines most revered figures, the 19th-century poet Taras Shevchenko.

title: Kerik, Out of Prison and More Subdued, Seeks to Rebuild His Reputation
description: The burly Bernard B. Kerik of old may not have recognized the newer, slimmed-down version who showed up to speak to an impressionable group of aspiring police officers in Queens on Saturday morning.

title: Moviefone Is Hanging Up, but Its App Will Go On
description: LOS ANGELES  Mr. Moviefones lines are going dead.

title: To Some Drivers Dismay, Parking Rules Return
description: It is back to the parking line for Sharon Walker.

title: Another Helping of Downton, MLord?
description: The fourth season of Downton Abbey concluded on Sunday with the servants Mrs. Hughes and Mr. Carson joining hands on a beach as they walked into the water together. It was a serene image that belied a year on this PBS Masterpiece period drama that was filled with tumultuous events  a characters rape and the fallout from it, the introduction of race as a plot point  and, at times, tumultuous audience reaction.

title: Moving Leonardos Horse: A Question of Logistics or Pedigree?
description: MILAN  Thousands of years after the citizens of Troy learned about the complications posed by outsize equine sculptures, the modern residents of Milan find themselves embroiled, again, in a debate about how to make the most of a gift horse: a colossal bronze steed presented by a group of American donors.

title: Julian Fellowes on Viewer Criticism and Downton Abbeys Future
description: After a royal audience with King George V and Queen Mary of England, and guest appearances by Shirley MacLaine and Paul Giamatti, the fourth season of Downton Abbey came to a conclusion on PBSs Masterpiece on Sunday night. No major characters met their demises, but this year, which dealt with the rape of the servant Anna and the introduction of a jazz singer who pursues a perilous romance with Lady Rose, among other story lines, was hardly free of conflict or controversy.

title: Girls Recap: A Night at the Gramercy Park Hotel
description: Golly. Did anyone see that coming? Girls found a heart.

title: Garbage Truck Fatally Strikes Rabbinical Student in Brooklyn
description: A garbage truck struck and killed a rabbinical student in Brooklyn on Sunday morning, officials said.

title: Faulty Pipe Led to Deadly Gas in Restaurant
description: A faulty flue pipe attached to a water heater caused the carbon monoxide leak that killed a restaurant manager and sickened 27 others on Saturday on Long Island, a fire official said.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 23, 2014
Venezuela Is Divided Even on Its Death Toll
description: SAN CRISTBAL, Venezuela  At least 11 people have died in more than two weeks of antigovernment protests, according to government and news media reports, and there are no signs of anything calming down. But even the death toll was a cause for argument on Sunday in this bitterly divided country, as officials disagreed over whether the latest death was related to the protests.

title: Stability and Chaos, Hallmarks of Presidential Races, Swap Parties
description: WASHINGTON  For generations, the two major political parties have taken strikingly different approaches to picking their presidential candidates: Republican primaries usually amount to coronations, in which they nominate a candidate who has run before or is otherwise deemed next in line, while the Democratic contests are often messier affairs, prone to insurgencies and featuring uncertain favorites.

title: Miracle-Gro Wants More People to Try Their Hand at Gardening
description: A STAPLE of hardware stores and garden centers for more than six decades, Miracle-Gro  with its descriptive, almost cartoonish name  is so recognizable to consumers that other brands, including AT&T and Hyundai, have featured it in their advertisements. To promote its Mini Countryman, which is much larger than its Cooper model, for example, in 2013 Mini USA produced billboards and print ads in which a giant box of Miracle-Gro blue plant food appeared to have spilled onto a green Cooper and caused a growth spurt.

title: Despite Stroke, Algerian Leader Says Hell Run for Re-Election
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Algerias ailing president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who has been largely incapacitated since a stroke last year, intends to run for a fourth term in an election scheduled for April 17, Algerian officials announced Sunday.

title: From a Backpack, Mountain Refreshment
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  There was a ski-rental shop at the base of the gondola. In exchange for 1,400 rubles (about $40) and temporary custody of my American drivers license, I got skis, poles, boots and a helmet for the day.

title: For Hints at Apples Plans, Read Its Shopping List
description: One company used sensors to read body movements. Another recommended TV programs. Several others offered location and mapping services.

title: Jihadist Mediator Killed in Suicide Attack by Rival Extremists
description: BEIRUT  A high-ranking jihadist operative who was sent to Syria by Ayman al-Zawahri, the head of Al Qaeda, to mediate conflicts between fighters was killed there on Sunday in a suicide attack by another extremist group, activists said.

title: Nets Win Is Ordinary, Though the Night Is Anything But

title: Play About Detroit Riots Wins Kennedy Drama Prize
description: Dominique Morisseaus Detroit 67 has won the Edward M. Kennedy Prize for Drama Inspired by American History, Columbia University and Jean Kennedy Smith are expected to announce on Monday. The prize, which was created in 2012 and first awarded last year, was endowed by Ms. Smith to honor her late brothers legacy and is announced around his birthday, Feb. 22. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize as well as assistance from the Columbia Center for New Media Teaching and Learning at Columbia University Libraries in creating a teaching website that will put the work in historical context, and offer study guides and scholarly discussion.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8 P.M. (Investigation Discovery) THE INJUSTICE FILES: SUNDOWN TOWNS By 1936, the practice of forcing African-Americans from all-white communities after the sun set was so prevalent that Victor Green, the Harlem civic leader, wrote the Negro Motorist Green Book, a guide to help black travelers avoid places where they might be threatened or even killed. In 1968, the Fair Housing Act, which made it a federal crime to deny equal housing opportunities based on race, creed or national origin, in effect outlawed the existence of these sundown towns. But did it eliminate them all? The filmmaker Keith Beauchamp, above, travels the country to find out.

title: Bill Thomas, 89, Dies; Editor Guided Los Angeles Times to 9 Pulitzers

title: Gluten-Free Spaghetti With Baby Broccoli, Mushrooms and Walnuts
description: This week I was really into adding nuts to many of my pasta dishes. They contribute substantial meaty texture and wonderful flavor. Baby broccoli is more elegant than regular broccoli, with long wispy florets and thin stems.

title: Gluten-Free Fettucine With Brussels Sprouts, Lemon and Ricotta
description: Brussels sprouts love a whisper of lemon, which is what the zest provides in this combo. The ricotta becomes creamy when you add a small amount of cooking water from the pasta to it, but you have to serve this right away or the ricotta will stiffen up again. I used gluten free Le Veneziane fettucine made with cornmeal, and thought the color and texture were very good. It only took 5 to 6 minutes to cook.

title: Gluten-Free Penne With Peas, Ricotta and Tarragon
description: The reason I choose penne for this dish is because I always like the way the peas find their way inside the little tubes. The dish is simple, sweet with tarragon, and very quickly made. You must serve it right away or the ricotta will stiffen.

title: Facebook Stock Not So Different Than Bitcoin
description: With its extraordinary swoop on WhatsApp last week, Facebook proved its stock is not so different from the crypto-currency of the moment, Bitcoin. They can both be used for certain, specific purposes. Neither is backed by a government. Both depend on vast networks of individuals. And their worth reflects demand, which is based on murky fundamentals. The trick: monetize them while they still have value.

title: Gluten-Free Spaghetti With Shrimp, Kale and Tomatoes
description: I like to use black kale for this. I blanch it in the pasta cooking water, then I add the chopped blanched leaves to the tomato sauce at the end of cooking, just so they will heat through and soften a little more. I sear the shrimp and make the tomato sauce in the same pan. You can toss shrimp in the tomato sauce or just top each serving with them, which is the way to go if there are vegetarians at the table.

title: Huntingtons Conflicts, Fukuyamas World
description: My Sunday column, on Russian grand strategy and Ukrainian turmoil, doubles as the latest installment in my semi-recurring series dedicated to the idea that ours is still essentially a Francis Fukuyaman world that is, a world in which the Wests combination of liberal cosmopolitanism and democratic capitalism has no ideological rivals worthy of the name. To elaborate a little on that theme and its significance, let me quote from a Walter Russell Mead essay that ran in the Journal late last week, under the Fukuyama-invoking headline Putin Knows History Hasnt Ended:

title: Kiss Wont Play the Rock Hall of Fame Induction
description: The rock band Kiss is about to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and fans of the group have been hoping for a full-scale in-costume reunion of the four players who started the band 40 years ago  Gene Simmons, bass; Paul Stanley, rhythm guitar; Ace Frehley, lead guitar; and Peter Criss, drums. Mr. Frehley and Mr. Criss left and returned several times, and last performed with Kiss a decade ago. But Kiss has continued with other players, including its current guitarist, Tommy Thayer, and drummer, Eric Singer.

title: Thailands Army Chief Cautions Antigovernment Protesters

title: How Much Do You Want?
description: Fast growth entrepreneurs are usually fast talkers, but one of the most valuable lessons that any entrepreneur can learn is when to keep your mouth closed during a negotiation. title: Barcelona Pays $19 Million Tax Related to Neymar Acquisition
description: MADRID  F.C. Barcelona said Monday that it had made a payment of $18.6 million to Spanish tax authorities related to last years acquisition of the Brazilian star Neymar in an attempt to settle a legal dispute that has highlighted the opaque and convoluted system of payments used by soccer clubs to sign players.

title: Why a Fed Governor Bought a Home When He Knew the Market Was Teetering
description: Frederic Mishkin was in a bind. In January 2008, his wife wanted to buy a house, but as we all know now, the housing market was in the midst of a crash. More than one person probably shared similar doubts with friends around the same time, but Mr. Mishkin is a little different. He told his story during a Federal Reserve meeting, as we learned when the minutes were released late last week.

title: Wall of Riot Police Greets Demonstrators at Sentencing of Moscow Protesters
description: MOSCOW  The riot police officers massed in force on Monday morning outside a courthouse here, well before the judges and the defendants had even arrived, to confront the demonstrators who came to criticize what the authorities have done to political dissent in todays Russia. The officers erected barriers half a block away and, with blue-and-white police buses parked nearby, formed phalanxes of shields and body armor.

title: New Italian Premier, in First Speech, Outlines Early Priorities for His Tenure
description: ROME  Making his first appearance before Parliament since becoming prime minister, Matteo Renzi on Monday called for lawmakers to have the courage to make radical change, pledged to push through political and electoral overhauls, and promised bold, innovative measures to revive the moribund economy.

description: A deal announced Sunday between Comcast, the nations largest cable and broadband company, and Netflix, the popular video streaming service, raises several troubling questions about the future of the Internet. Under the agreement, Netflix will hook its servers directly to Comcasts network for an undisclosed fee, cutting out the middlemen that previously connected the companies together.

title: How Many Best-Picture Nominees Have You Seen?
description: With blockbusters like Gravity and films with more than respectable box office receipts, like The Wolf of Wall Street, American Hustle and Captain Phillips, in the running for best picture, Academy organizers and producers of the Oscars broadcast may be thinking theyre in for a sizable home audience. (Viewership correlates most closely to the box office tally for the nominated films; a year of little-watched indies portends badly for the ratings.) But despite what critics and pundits consider an unusually strong cinematic field, most people have still not seen any of the best picture contenders, according to one recent poll.

title: A Token of Anne Franks Childhood, on View
description: The set of marbles that Anne Frank played with before she was forced into hiding are on display for the first time.

title: Obama Delivers Remarks to Governors
description: President Obama speaks to members of the National Governors Association in the White House State Dining Room.

title: Zuckerberg Says WhatsApp Deal Was a Bargain
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Many analysts and technology insiders have suggested that Facebook is overpaying for WhatsApp, the mobile messaging service that it is buying for up to $19 billion.

title: Indonesia Urged to Spend to Make Birth Less Risky
description: If Indonesia wants to better its embarrassingly suboptimal performance in deaths of newborns and their mothers, it will have to make far-reaching and expensive changes in its health care system, American and Indonesian experts say in a new report.

title: How a College Roommate Can Affect Your Child
description: When you have a child off at college, you worry about his general health, state of mind, alcohol use  and, as you sign those tuition checks, academic achievement.

title: Coming Soon: Heroes of the Higgs
description: Physicists get to discover a new particle once in a generation, if they are lucky.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Draw Re-election Challenges From the Right
description: DALLAS  There is the Tea Party Patriots Fire the Speaker petition, which is not to be confused with the FreedomWorks Fire the Speaker petition, or the websites variously urging people to Fire John Boehner and Pledge to Fire Boehner.

title: As Kennedy Trial Opens, Questions on Awareness of a Drugs Effects
description: WHITE PLAINS  There was the matriarch, Ethel Kennedy, 85 and somewhat frail, entering the Westchester County Courthouse in a wheelchair, and two of the brothers, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Douglas Kennedy, with their familiar family looks and style, all recorded by a dozen television cameras stationed outside in a biting cold.

title: Weekend Gun Report: February 21-23, 2014
description: Last month, John Wayne Rogers, 40, escaped first-degree murder charges for shooting his friend to death with an assault rifle after a long drinking session in a Floridahotel room in 2012. After spending two years awaiting trial, a judge granted hisStand Your Groundmotion for immunity and ruled that Rogers acted in self-defense. Rogers had testified that the victim, James DeWitt, 34, punched him and threatened his life.

title: After Meeting With Obama, Governor Goes on the Attack
description: WASHINGTON  It is definitely an election year in Washington.

title: Tenants Living Amid Rubble in Rent-Regulated Apartment War
description: The letter from the landlord said he needed access to the apartments for a couple of weeks to make repairs.

title: From Buffett, Lessons From His Farm
description: Investors around the world hang on Warren Buffetts every word, hoping for a scrap of advice from a legendary businessman. Mr. Buffett often dishes out a few morsels of that advice in a letter that coincides with the annual report from his firm, Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Pope Moves to Reshape Management of Vatican
description: ROME  Pope Francis on Monday announced a major restructuring of the Vaticans outdated administrative and economic bureaucracy as he established an agency to oversee budgets and financial planning and also created a powerful post of auditor general to guard against fiscal mismanagement.

title: Blood Pressure Drugs Tied to Risk of Falls
description: Older adults who take blood pressure drugs have a greater risk of serious falls, a new study reports.

title: Parenting When Even Minimum Wage Is Out of Reach
description: I live in Milwaukee. They just raised the minimum wage here, but I dont have a job. There are not many options out there. Im 24 years old, and I have two kids  my son is 4 years old and my daughter is 6.

title: The Fight for 98 Linden
description: After 23 years of living in their rent-stabilized apartment, Noelia Calero and her family are fighting to stay. The landlord, they say, is using intimidating tactics to push them out.

title: After Hours | A Digital Deconstruction of Chekhovs Uncle Vanya
description: This Was the End, an experimental meditation on Chekhovs Uncle Vanya at the supercool Long Island City arts space The Chocolate Factory Theater through March 8, begins both mesmerizingly and gratingly. Actors walk and run in and out of the set  a wall of doors of various shapes and sizes, sliding open and closed  while, ingeniously, the same actors do a version of the very same thing in a film projected imperfectly onto it. Its an eye-popping sight. Meanwhile, a soundscape, chopped up from the Beatles White Album, assaults you, from speakers fitted close to the audience, half of whom covered their ears. The overall effect is hypnotic and somewhat unbearable. To what end? Is this collage meant to unpack the existential tedium of Vanya itself  a play in which characters frustrate us and break our hearts with their doddering romantic and career obsessions and resentments, all the while knowing that nothing will change?

title: Step 1 Before Red Bulls Opener: Remove Foot of Snow
description: Soccer players can be among the most fickle of professional athletes. Things have to be just so, from the cut of their uniforms to the look and feel of their cleats. But what really gets their attention, their extreme, undivided attention, is the condition of the playing surface.

title: Secrets of the Ages
description: Think too much about your life span and you will never get out of bed in the morning. Once you do, though, all the scientific mysteries of the subject may lie panting on the rug at your feet. Why should your good old faithful dog (avid exerciser, nonsmoker, nondrinker) be condemned to age and die after barely a decade, while you remain firmly in your prime  and the neighbors African gray parrot lives loudly on and on?

title: Monday Motorsports: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Outruns Rain, Crashes and Competition at Daytona
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr. took the victory Sunday in the bruising 2014 running of the prestigious Daytona 500, staying out front much of the second half of a race interrupted for more than six hours by a rain delay.

title: A Weeknight Fish Chowder Reminiscent of the Shore
description: Whats for Dinner answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: A Mouse Brain to Guide Us, Ear Tubes and Infections, Alan Alda Improvs Science
description: In new efforts to map every nook and neuron of the brain, a mouse is more important than you might think; this one is for the parents out there  a quick primer on how to deal with infections if your child has ear tubes; the actor best known for his role in M*A*S*H brings acting techniques into science class.

title: In a Flood, Ants Really Come Together
description: When the need arises, ants that live in flooded areas can link their bodies together to form buoyant rafts that protect the queen and much of her brood. Now scientists have figured out how they do it.

title: Help for Endangered Lemurs
description: Lemurs are the most endangered mammal group on the planet. Native to Madagascar, off Africas Indian Ocean coast, lemurs have suffered from decades of habitat loss and poaching. If protected in conservation sites managed by local communities, they could see a revival, a group of researchers report in the journal Science.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Stella Jean Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

title: Slow Start for Newly Opened Bridges of Madison County
description: The new Broadway musical Bridges of Madison County, based on a best-selling novel and starring an acclaimed musical theater performer, Kelli OHara, opened on Thursday to generally favorable reviews, including some raves. Yet the show is struggling to sell tickets, with a middling gross of $364,888 for eight performances last week, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

title: Like Columbus, It Floated Here
description: By the time Columbus arrived in the New World in 1492, bottle gourds had already conquered much of the globe. After evolving in Africa, one species, Lagenaria siceraria, made a break for East Asia around 11,000 years ago and eventually took up residence in Polynesia, China, Peru and beyond, earning the title of most widely distributed pre-Columbian domesticated plant.

title: Harold Ramis, Director, Actor and Alchemist of Comedy, Dies at 69
description: Harold Ramis, a writer, director and actor whose boisterous but sly silliness helped catapult comedies like Groundhog Day, Ghostbusters, Animal House and Caddyshack to commercial and critical success, died on Monday in his Chicago-area home. He was 69.

title: For the Supreme Court, a Case Poses a Puzzle on the E.P.A.s Authority
description: WASHINGTON  In trying to decide whether the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority under two programs to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from stationary sources like power plants, the Supreme Court on Monday faced what Justice Elena Kagan called the conundrum here.

title: New Sleeping Beauty to Mark American Ballet Theaters 75th Anniversary
description: American Ballet Theater will mark the 75th anniversary of its founding next year with a new production of The Sleeping Beauty choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and based on the production Lon Bakst created for Diaghilevs Ballets Russes in 1921, the company announced.

title: Clues to a Very Old Extinction and Pizza for War Zones
description: A homicide trail that had been cold for 252 million years is suddenly warm. A new vaccine can withstand high temperatures, and here comes pizza that doesnt need a fridge. Even January, it turns out, was warmer than you thought.

title: Syria War Stirs New U.S. Debate on Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  Not long after the uprising in Syria turned bloody, late in the spring of 2011, the Pentagon and the National Security Agency developed a battle plan that featured a sophisticated cyberattack on the Syrian military and President Bashar al-Assads command structure.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, Thailand and South Sudan.

title: The Secrets of Film Sound
description: Melena Ryzik visits Skywalker Sound and learns how sound designers make movies come to life.

title: Thomas Is Getting a New Chance to Break Precedent (if Not Silence)
description: WASHINGTON  Here is a good way to get a belly laugh from Justice Clarence Thomas: Suggest to him that the Supreme Courts decisions should seldom be overruled.

title: Flappy Bird Copycats Keep on Flapping
description: On Feb. 9, the Western world fell into chaos as Flappy Bird, a highly addictive game, was removed from mobile app stores by Dong Nguyen, an independent developer in Vietnam.

title: Threes a Trend | Color-Blocked Fur Coats
description: Last season, Miuccia Prada presented furs printed with hibiscus flowers and the artistic renderings of ladies faces in a rainbow of bright colors. This season, the ripples of those statement pieces have hit designers collections like a tidal wave, making the multicolored fur coat a must-have item for fall 2014. Although it is a trend we have seen before especially at Cline, where color-blocked fur has become a signature of sorts  the frequency with which were now seeing fur with a graphic quality is making what once seemed like a luxury item feel like a new wardrobe staple. We first saw a version in New York at Altuzarra, where the young designer dressed up a simple, dark fur coat with vibrant colors like Yves Klein blue and tangerine. Then at J. Mendel, the house run by a long line of furriers, bold colors and abstract, latticelike color-blocking offered a fresh and modern take on the brands signature material. Finally at Marni in Milan, vertical panels of cobalt, white and crimson made an oversize silhouette seem long and lean and a fluffy, neutral-colored collar provided the ultimate luxurious top-off.

title: When Men Get Breast Cancer
description: Breast cancer is not always pink.

title: Trailer for Ukraines Uprising Stars Will Smith and Sylvester Stallone
description: Looking for a way to pay tribute to the courage of protesters in Kiev, who refused to be dislodged from Independence Square over the past three months despite violent attacks from the security forces, a Ukrainian video blogger found the words he needed in dubbed versions of two Hollywood action movies.

title: Closing Olympics Ceremonies Give NBC a Narrow Win on a Crowded Sunday
description: The final night of the Winter Olympics coverage on NBC was the most-watched event on television Sunday night but the competition was formidable, as Downton Abbey posted its best audience total ever for a finale on PBS and The Walking Dead on AMC scored its usual enormous rating with younger audiences, doubling the total for the Olympics.

title: A Chilling Vision of a Television Future and Its Prescient Seer
description: In the closing chapter of Mad as Hell  informatively subtitled The Making of Network and the Fateful Vision of the Angriest Man in Movies  Dave Itzkoff lays out how the American media has become even more Chayefskyian in the decades since Paddy Chayefsky, the angry man in question, wrote his crazed, perceptive, unwieldy, galvanizing satiric fantasia set in the world of network television news.

title: Nodding to Brahms, but Honoring Stern
description: In 1997, while the great violinist Isaac Stern was still alive, Carnegie Hall named its main listening space the Isaac Stern Auditorium, to commemorate his role in helping to save the building from the wrecking ball in 1960. Stern died in 2001, and what more could Carnegie possibly do to honor his memory?

title: In a Petipa Program, the Exotic Shares Space With the Classical
description: Nineteenth-century ballet, like much of 19th-century European art, loved the Orient. Ballets set in Turkish harems or Indian temples, with costumes and plots that seemed exotic, were highly popular. Yet, as the dance historian Doug Fullington pointed out in an entertaining and enlightening program at the Guggenheim Museum on Sunday, the actual dancing in these productions was almost all classical ballet.

title: Musicians Sing for a Cause Thats Their Own
description: In the music industrys big fights over issues like copyright and royalties, its usually the titans  record conglomerates, Silicon Valley giants  that clash. But as individual musicians feel squeezed by the digital revolution, they are beginning to speak out in increasing numbers.

title: Sounds for the Start of the Day
description: On first listening to Becks placid, self-possessed 12th studio album, Morning Phase, I did not look him up on Wikipedia to see if hed broken up with his wife. I was not fully functional: The records beauty approaches slowly, floats, surrounds and shuts off external awareness in the brain stem.

title: Chinese Arts Company Goes Public in Bid to Grow
description: SHANGHAI  The China Poly Group Corporation, a state-run conglomerate that got its start selling weapons to the Peoples Liberation Army, has over the past few decades successfully branched into developing real estate, selling sports cars and producing television sitcoms. Now the companys huge arts and culture division  Poly Culture Group Corporation  is planning an initial public stock offering that could raise up to $330 million and bolster the prospects of the company in the worlds biggest and fastest-growing art and auction market.

title: Staying on Script, for Now
description: MSNBC turned Ronan Farrow, 26, a handsome celebrity activist, into Chuck Todd.

title: Developer Is Shot in the Head Outside His Long Island Castle
description: Gary Melius, a well-known Long Island developer and prominent political patron, was shot in the head by a masked gunman on Monday in the parking lot of his opulent Gold Coast estate in Suffolk County, the police said.

title: Holder Sees Way to Curb Bans on Gay Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday injected the Obama administration into the emotional and politicized debate over the future of state same-sex marriage bans, declaring in an interview that state attorneys general are not obligated to defend laws that they believe are discriminatory.

title: New Land, New Tongue, New Fame
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Growing up in Beijing as the daughter of a physicist, the writer Yiyun Li seemed destined for a career in science. But she would surreptitiously read from this big book of Tang dynasty poetry, she said, while pretending to do math. Years later, studying for a Ph.D. in immunology at the University of Iowa, she adopted a similar strategy, reading short stories clipped from The New Yorker as she did lab work.

title: Two Sisters With Secrets, Desperate for Escape
description: Part Sam Shepard gothic drama, part Moth Radio Hour yarn, My Daughter Keeps Our Hammer, by Brian Watkins, tells the story of Sarah and Hannah, sisters in their 20s, living with their ailing mother in the farm country of Eaton, Colo., and desperate for a way out.

title: When in India | Spiritual Healing
description: While North India has no shortage of ashrams, the recently opened Vana, Malsi Estate, located in Dehradun near the foothills of the Himalayas, is taking wellness to new heights. The 31-year-old physics major-turned-organic farmer Veer Singh has spent nearly five years and $155 million building this tranquil spa retreat, which offers everything from a few days of yoga to three weeks of Ayurvedic healing.

title: The One-Eyed Witness
description: Anyone who has hired a lawyer knows $1,000 doesnt buy you much. But when Anthony Ray Hinton was on trial for his life in Alabama, thats the total amount his court-appointed attorney thought he could spend on a key expert witness in firearms evidence. All he could find for that price was an elderly one-eyed man with a degree in civil engineering who was laughed out of court for his inability to answer basic questions.

title: Customizing a Mash-Up
description: When opera was a much younger art form, star singers could choose which arias they wanted to sing, often swapping in favorite numbers that showed off their voices to best advantage for whatever the lowly composers and librettists had originally written.

title: Times Minute | Tea Party Challengers
description: Tea Party challengers enter congressional primary races. Also on the Minute, tenants battle for rent-controlled units in New York and the actor Alan Alda talks science.

title: Times Minute | Tea Party Challengers
description: In the Video

title: Zebra Mussels: Young and Invasive
description: In contrast to adults whose shells are always firmly attached to substrates like rocks, the larval veliger stages of zebras mussels swim freely in water currents for several weeks.

title: Science Takes On a Silent Invader
description: Since they arrived in the Great Lakes in the 1980s, two species of mussels the size of pistachios have spread to hundreds of lakes and rivers in 34 states and have done vast economic and ecological damage.

title: Target Push Into Canada Stumbles
description: OTTAWA  When Canadians crossed the border into the United States on shopping excursions, Target was a prime destination. But when Target crossed the border last year and brought its stores to Canada, the magic somehow vanished.

title: Harold Ramis's Many Roles
description: The film critic A. O. Scott discusses the career of the actor and director Harold Ramis, who died Monday. He is best known for his impact on comedy.

title: LinkedIn Goes to China
description: Hoping to greatly increase its presence in one of the worlds great labor markets, LinkedIn has announced the formation of a site dedicated to China.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Season to Include Tributes to Billie Holiday and Wayne Shorter
description: Jazz at Lincoln Centers 2014-15 season, running from September through next June, connects musical traditions that start with jazz and open out to the Americas in general  North and South, Cuba and the Antilles. The details of the concerts, lectures, workshops and other events on the organizations premises within the Time Warner Center and elsewhere are to be released Tuesday, with a piece of added news. What was formerly the Allen Room  the amphitheater within Frederick P. Rose Hall, with 50-foot-high glass windows overlooking Columbus Circle  will be renamed the Appel Room, in honor of Robert J. Appel, chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Centers board, who donated $20 million to the organization earlier this year. (Allen & Co., the financial company for which the room was named in 2004, agreed to give back naming rights to a new donor.)

title: A Bonus: Some Play on a Trip for Work
description: On a business trip to London last fall, Caroline Michaud took the last flight out of Heathrow Airport to Chicago on a Saturday night so she would have time to visit the National Portrait Gallery, take a run by Buckingham Palace and spin through St. James Park.

title: Probing the Parliament of Neurons
description: Clay Reid and colleagues are going deep into the mouse brain to decipher the conversations and decisions of neurons.

title: The Brains Inner Language
description: SEATTLE  When Clay Reid decided to leave his job as a professor at Harvard Medical School to become a senior investigator at the Allen Institute for Brain Science in Seattle in 2012, some of his colleagues congratulated him warmly and understood right away why he was making the move.

title: Regulating the Dark Money of Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukraine as a Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Tarmac Purgatory Ends, but New Trials Appear
description: WALK down memory lane with me to wintertimes in years gone by, when bad weather routinely caused passengers on hundreds of flights to be stranded on airplanes that had pulled away from the gate but then sat idled on tarmacs, neither taking off nor returning to the terminal, for three, five, even 12 hours and more.

title: Inequality in Our Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spirituality of A.A.
Needed: A Parole Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: That Buzz You Hear Is Nascar After Earnhardts Big Victory
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A sport desperate to connect to a new, younger audience took a significant step toward that goal with help from Dale Earnhardt Jr.

title: Dialogue With the Wealthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Suggests Top N.H.L. Teams May Suffer After Sochi
description: Several playoff contenders  the Chicago Blackhawks, the St. Louis Blues, the Montreal Canadiens, the Anaheim Ducks, the Vancouver Canucks, the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Rangers  sent seven or more players to the Sochi Olympics.

title: Judge Likely to Dismiss Script Case
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal judge here said she expected to grant summary judgment against a producer who accused Warner Bros. and others of basing the Clint Eastwood baseball film, Trouble With the Curve, on a script that belonged to him.

title: On a Plane, and Learning the Finer Points of Farming
description: I GREW up in the Midwest and didnt fly much when I was younger. Now, as a consultant and author of Your Network Is Your Net Worth, Im traveling all the time. I find business travel tiring, so I cant say I love it. But I do love being able to support myself in a nontraditional way.

title: With Bounce at Buzzer, Nowitzki Deflates Knicks
description: Another Carmelo Anthony gem was wasted Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Equality of Taxes
description: Same-sex married couples will be required to file their federal income tax returns reflecting their married status for the first time.

title: Steel Industry Feeling Stress as Automakers Turn to Aluminum
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  For nearly a century, Fords River Rouge factory and its neighboring steel mill have worked in close harmony to produce some of Americas most popular vehicles, from the Model A to the F-150 pickup truck.

title: A Mayor in the Middle of Two San Franciscos
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Edwin M. Lee, the mayor of San Francisco, began his career as a lawyer fighting for public housing tenants in the citys Chinatown and likes to think of himself as a champion for those who are struggling.

title: For Same-Sex Marrieds, a Tax Season to Look Back
description: Tax season doesnt usually stir up emotions about the meaning of family and equal rights.

title: At the Oscars, Bringing Brands to Life
description: WHEN viewers watch ABC on Sunday for coverage of the 86th annual Academy Awards, they will see commercials for more than a dozen organizations or companies like AARP, Coldwell Banker, General Motors, Mars, J. C. Penney and Unilever. Those spots will, however, be only part of the marketing efforts that seek to walk the red carpet with Oscar.

title: Live Nation Cut Its Losses Last Year
description: The giant concert company Live Nation Entertainments revenue rose by 11 percent last year and its net loss narrowed significantly, as attendance grew for country and electronic dance events, the company reported Monday.

title: Inside the Museum of Corruption
description: In February 2014, the palatial compound of Viktor Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, was opened to the public after he fled Kiev.

title: Fake Putin Diary!
description: Dear Diary,

title: TV Networks Ask Supreme Court to Shut Down Aereo
description: Aereo, the start-up that uses tiny antennas to stream the free signals of TV stations to its customers Internet-connected devices for a fee, is stealing from the broadcast networks on a giant scale, the broadcasters asserted in a filing with the Supreme Court on Monday.

title: Ford to Drop Microsoft From Car Systems
description: Ford has found a new software partner to power its in-car entertainment and communications systems, making plans to drop technology from Microsoft in favor of software from BlackBerry.

title: Governor of Arizona Is Pressed to Veto Bill
description: PHOENIX  As the Arizona Legislature sent a bill to her desk Monday that would grant business owners the right to invoke religion to refuse service to gays and others, Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, faced pressure from many corners to veto the measure, which has cast unwanted national attention on Arizona.

title: Confessions of a Lifelong Eavesdropper
description: Confession: I eavesdrop. Not only that, I make my students do it.

title: Supreme Court Declines Tennis Channel Appeal
description: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal from the Tennis Channel in its dispute with Comcast over placement on the companys cable channel lineup.

title: Coverage of Olympic Games Delivers a Win for NBC
description: A network buys the rights to the Olympics to beat its prime-time competition for 17 nights in a row.

title: Man Charged in Series of Fires at 2 Queens Shopping Centers
description: A 23-year-old man was charged on Monday night in connection with a series of small fires over several days at two shopping centers in Queens, the police said.

title: Indictments for 28 More in Fraud Case
description: Twenty-eight more people, including retired police officers and firefighters, have been indicted as part of the Manhattan district attorneys investigation into an extensive scheme to defraud Social Security disability insurance, law enforcement officials said.

title: Pentagon Officials Say Theyre Willing to Assume Risks of a Reduced Army
description: WASHINGTON  In shrinking the United States Army to its smallest size since 1940, Pentagon officials said Monday that they were willing to assume more risk the next time troops are called to war.

title: The Wild West of Privacy
description: We are fast approaching a privacy crisis in the United States. Google, Facebook and other big Internet companies collect information about us, which they deploy in the service of advertisers. Big data brokers, like Acxiom, have developed sophisticated tools that allow them to know almost as much about us as we know about ourselves; they then sell that data to all kinds of companies that want to learn everything from our habits to our health, from our sexual orientation to our finances. The digital age has made it easy to collect medical data, which is supposed to be protected under federal law. Huge data breaches at big retailers like Target have made it seem unsafe to use credit cards. And I havent even mentioned the Edward Snowden revelations about the massive data collection by the National Security Agency.

title: Rash Repression in Venezuela
description: PROTESTS have rocked Venezuela in recent weeks, but no one seems to agree on why huge numbers of people have suddenly taken to the streets. Some observers see the demonstrations as a verdict on food and medicine shortages, inflation and economic stagnation. Others see them as the tantrum of a retrograde former elite bent on nullifying the results of the last election. The government, for its part, is sticking to the old script: Venezuela is falling victim to a fascist conspiracy cooked up by American officials who are terrified of its revolutionary aspirations.

title: Connecticut Plans to Market Health Exchange Expertise
description: WASHINGTON  Connecticut has been so successful in getting people to sign up for health insurance through its online marketplace that it is setting up a consulting business to help other states build and operate websites where people can compare and buy private insurance policies.

title: The Capture of Chapo Guzmn
description: Many Mexicans may have found it hard to believe that it was really him. That the pudgy little man with the Super Mario mustache being marched into a helicopter by a masked marine with gloved hand firmly on his neck was El Chapo, Joaqun Guzmn Loera, the worlds most wanted, most elusive drug lord.

title: Apples Serious Security Issue: Update Your iPhone or iPad Immediately
description: This week, Apple rushed out a patch for its iOS 7 and iOS 6 operating systems to fix a serious security issue. Before I explain further, let me just say this: If youve gotten the prompt to update and you havent, do it now. If youre still running older versions of iOS on your iPhone, iPod, or iPad, update now.

title: A License to Discriminate
description: There are 17 states where it is legal for same-sex couples to marry, and there is no evidence that the accelerating progress toward equality has compromised anyones freedom to worship or hold religious beliefs.

title: Scottish Oil and Gas an Issue in Vote on Independence
description: LONDON  They have disagreed over whether an independent Scotland could retain the British pound as its currency. They have sparred over whether Scotland would remain in the European Union if it votes in September to leave the United Kingdom. And on Monday, two of the most prominent advocates of the arguments for and against Scottish independence  Alex Salmond, Scotlands first minister, and David Cameron, the British prime minister  turned to another crucial economic issue at stake in the battle: the future of the still-substantial oil and gas reserves in the North Sea.

title: Prosecutors Talk to Mayor of Fort Lee
description: The mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., met last week with federal prosecutors investigating the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September, his lawyer said on Monday.

title: Ukraines Uncertain Future
description: The venal president of Ukraine is on the run and the bloodshed has stopped, but it is far too early to celebrate or to claim that the West has won or that Russia has lost. One incontrovertible lesson from the events in Kiev, Ukraines capital, is that the deeply divided country will have to contend with dangerous problems that could reverberate beyond its borders.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 25, 2014
description: The truly distressing thing about these folks leaving is that theyre the ones who know how to negotiate, know how to legislate, know how to get things done.

title: Happy Workers, Healthy Bottom Line
Colorblind Notion Aside, Colleges Grapple With Racial Tension
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  A brochure for the University of Michigan features a vision of multicultural harmony, with a group of students from different racial backgrounds sitting on a verdant lawn, smiling and conversing.

title: Pension Funds Sue on a Deal Gone Cold
description: Sitting around a table in Baton Rouge, La., in February 2008, a handful of board members of the Firefighters Retirement System of Louisiana heard an investment pitch that would later come back to haunt them.

title: A Dragon Returns, This Time Onstage
description: Fists fly with all the fury an action fan could want. Legs flash from the hip like lightning strikes. Twirling kicks and jabbing arms all but set your own head spinning. The fight sequences in Kung Fu, the new play about Bruce Lee by David Henry Hwang, bristle with kinetic drive and an innovative combination of dance and martial arts.

title: U.S. and Britain Join Forces in Bank Misbehavior Cases
description: It seemed to be a thumb in the eye of the Justice Department. Britain last week criminally charged a former Barclays employee suspected of trying to manipulate global interest rates, even though the authorities in London were aware that the employee had been assisting American prosecutors in a related investigation for more than a year.

title: Role Reversal
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  There are certain words that pop up time and time again in crosswords. It might be because theyre really common, or it might be because their letters are really helpful in puzzle construction. I tend to think its more the latter. Thats why we see fairly specialized words like epee appear in the grid so often.

title: Two Dolphins Paths to a Bullying Scandal
description: Three days after Jonathan Martin checked himself into a South Florida hospital for psychiatric help, he received a string of conciliatory messages from Richie Incognito, his Miami Dolphins teammate and tormentor, who asked about his health and said that he missed him.

title: @GSElevator Tattletale Exposed (He Was Not in the Goldman Elevator)
description: A three-year parlor game has been taking place on Wall Street to identify the Goldman Sachs employee behind a Twitter account that purports to reveal the uncensored comments overheard in the firms elevators.

title: Bobby Jindal After Meeting With Obama
description: The Louisiana governor accused the president of waving the white flag on the American economy.

title: Israeli Warplanes Strike Near the Border of Syria and Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Israeli warplanes launched two raids near the Syrian-Lebanese border late Monday, according to Lebanons National News Agency, raising speculation that Israel might have targeted a weapons convoy to prevent the Syrian government from delivering missiles to its Lebanese ally, Hezbollah.

title: Rangers Darvish a Model of Success for Tanaka
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.  Would you believe that the first batter Yu Darvish faced in live competition this spring was named Tanaka? He was a nonroster infielder, Kensuke Tanaka, and he did not inspire an intense winter bidding war. But as Darvish pitched the first inning of the Texas Rangers first intrasquad game on Monday, it was hard to miss the link.

title: Rodriguez Still Belongs to Union Despite Lawsuit Rancor, Director Says
description: TAMPA, Fla.  During his one season with the Yankees, in 2004, Tony Clark, now the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, was teammates with Alex Rodriguez. It was 10 years ago, a season that ended in excruciating defeat for the Yankees, who were beaten by the Red Sox in the American League Championship Series.

title: Trimmings, Best of Milan Fashion Week
description: From the Lagerfeld-like bag bug to fast food-reminiscent sunglasses, these are the standout fall 2014 accessories from Fendi, Gucci, Bottega Veneta and more.

title: Injuries at the Olympics Deplete Several Rosters
description: The most palpable effect of the Olympics on N.H.L. teams performance is through injuries. The toll in Sochi was high.

title: Wary Stance From Obama on Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  Televisions around the White House were aglow with pictures of Ukrainians in the streets, demanding to be heard and toppling a government aligned with Russia. It was an invigorating moment, and it spurred a president already rethinking his approach to the world.

title: Young Mets Pitcher Is Quietly on the Rise
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  In the middle of the Mets clubhouse here, two of the organizations brightest pitching prospects have their lockers next to each other. To the left is Noah Syndergaard, a 6-foot-6-inch, 230-pound 21-year-old from Texas, who is hard to miss and has already received much attention and praise this spring.

title: Simn Daz, Venezuelan Folk Musician Heard Worldwide, Dies at 85
description: Simn Daz, one of Venezuelas most popular singers and comedians who also earned recognition worldwide for his prowess as a player of the cuatro, a guitar-like instrument, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Caracas. He was 85.

title: De Blasio Answers Critics on Road Safety
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio was questioned by reporters after a television news crew filmed his chauffeur-driven car breaking traffic rules, only days after he announced a street safety campaign.

title: This Time, de Blasio Confronts S.U.V. Issue Head-On
description: Three days after walking out of a news conference as reporters shouted questions at his back, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday finally fielded inquiries about his motorcades caught-on-camera violations of traffic laws  but he could not resist offering reporters some pointed criticism of his own.

title: Seeking Details on Plan to End Traffic Fatalities
description: Speed humps. Crossing guards. Police officers on patrol just being more alert to lawbreaking drivers around them.

title: Just Like His Power, Ukrainian Ex-Leader Vanishes Into Thin Air
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Ukraines acting government on Monday declared the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, a fugitive sought for mass murder, but it seemed at a loss to find the man whose authority had crumbled over the weekend.

title: In New Home, Policy Group Gets Big Gift
description: WASHINGTON  The American Enterprise Institute  one of the nations oldest conservative think tanks, but one that has never had its own home  is getting financial help for its new headquarters in a stately Dupont Circle building from a $20 million donation by Daniel A. DAniello, a co-founder and chairman of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group.

title: A Sudden Demand for No. 98 Jerseys
description: Jason Collins fell asleep Saturday night without a team. On Sunday, he became the Nets most publicized player, the first openly gay athlete to play in an N.B.A. game, although one on a 10-day contract.

title: Corrections: February 25, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: In Venezuela, Protest Ranks Grow Broader
description: SAN CRISTBAL, Venezuela  As dawn broke, the residents of a quiet neighborhood here readied for battle. Some piled rocks to be used as projectiles. Others built barricades. A pair of teenagers made firebombs as the adults looked on.

title: A Border City on the Edge of the Law
description: MONG LA, Myanmar  The smuggling route into this rebel-run jungle outpost just over the Chinese border begins on the back of a motorcycle that takes passengers through steeply terraced rubber plantations, and skirts the official crossing before ending at an outdoor market where bedraggled prostitutes mingle with Chinese tourists haggling over tiger claws, bear paws and desiccated squares of elephant skin.

title: This Is Your Conductor Writing: Im Sorry
description: As the doors opened to the 6:52 a.m. train from New Haven, the single sheets of paper, one on every seat, came quickly into view.

title: A Lucrative Market in Myanmar
description: Mongla market in Myanmar is best known among Chinese tourists for its large selection of rare and endangered animals.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 24, 2014
Vigilantes, Once Welcome, Frighten Many in Mexico
description: LOMBARDA, Mexico  They have been hailed as saviors, vigilantes marching into town with military-style rifles and submachine guns, wearing no uniforms and threatening to whip miscreants as they bring order to this lawless Mexican region known as Tierra Caliente, or hot lands.

title: What Is a Majority Vote in the State Senate? The Answer Goes Beyond Simple Math
description: ALBANY  There has been a curious question bouncing around certain quarters of the New York State Senate: How many votes, exactly, does it take to pass a bill?

title: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Seeks International Inquiry
description: The United Nations human rights chief on Monday called for an independent international inquiry into possible war crimes committed during Sri Lankas civil war, saying the Sri Lankan government lacks the political will to mount a credible investigation. The United Nations official, Navi Pillay, said national mechanisms have consistently failed to establish the truth and achieve justice with respect to the large number of killings and other abuses in the final chapter of the two-decade-long war in 2009 and continuing abuses that include attacks on religious minorities, journalists and human rights activists. She added that an investigation is fundamentally a question of political will. Sri Lanka rejected the report. President Mahinda Rajapaksas administration called the recommendations arbitrary, intrusive and of a political nature.

title: Mexico: Legal Wrangling Begins Over Drug Kingpin
description: Two days after Mexican marines arrested the drug kingpin Joaqun Guzmn Loera, questions are being asked about whether he will be tried in Mexico or in the United States. Lawyers for Mr. Guzmn, who was charged Sunday with offenses related to organized crime and cocaine trafficking stemming from a 2009 investigation, are seeking an injunction against extradition. Federal officials in Chicago and New York have said they want to try him in those cities, and he faces additional indictments in Texas and Florida. But Mexicos interior minister, Miguel ngel Osorio Chong, said Monday that the governments security cabinet would make the most appropriate decision. Mexicos ambassador to Washington, Eduardo Medina Mora, said Saturday that Mr. Guzmn should face charges in Mexico first. Mr. Guzmn, who is being held in a high-security prison outside Mexico City, escaped from a Guadalajara prison in 2001 and spent almost 13 years as a fugitive.

title: In Plan to Dump Contaminated Soil, Classic New Jersey Politics Emerge
description: CARTERET, N.J.  We slip slided, a zoologist, two environmentalists and I, across ice, snow and mud toward a wire fence with a sign: Environmental Investigation Cleanup.

title: Dark Side of the Moon
description: Keep time while tracking the many lunar phases with springs most out-of-this-world watches.

title: Five Sweet Stops for Paris Fashion Week
description: In 2010, Vogue Paris named the inimitable Irish expat and award-winning cookbook author Trish Deseine one of its 40 women of the decade. That they included her alongside icons like Marion Cotillard and Zaha Hadid is a testament to her talent, to be sure, but also a nod to her invaluable contribution to the annals of French cuisine. Deseines work, which spans 17 books and a long-running recipe column for French Elle, has succeeded in both lifting the complexity from French home cooking and exhorting fat-free hardliners to consider (and taste) the merits of butter and sugar, which she insists are two of the greatest boons to food.

title: Remaking Film Comedy With a Straight Face
description: Harold Ramis, who died Monday at 69, made everyone around him look better. A startlingly creative distributor of laughs, he was a master orchestrator who knew how to create conditions for funny people to excel.

title: Putting Economic Data Into Context
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Newark Stop-and-Frisk Data Is Analyzed
description: A new study about police stop-and-frisk encounters in Newark found that one quarter of police stops ended in an arrest or a summons, about twice as often as they do in New York City.

title: Apparent Theft at Mt. Gox Shakes Bitcoin World
description: The most prominent Bitcoin exchange appeared to be on the verge of collapse late Monday, raising questions about the future of a volatile marketplace.

title: Word of the Day | irremediable
description: irremediable \ir-i-me-de--bl\ adjective

title: Camels Linked to Spread of MERS Virus in People
description: A new study suggests that camels are the major source of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, a viral disease that has sickened 182 people and killed 79 of them since it was first detected in Saudi Arabia in 2012.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS OF THE VATICAN In February 2013, Pope Benedict XVI resigned, the first pope to do so in nearly 600 years. He left behind a divided Vatican, mired in scandal: a sexual abuse crisis; suspected money laundering and corruption at the Vatican bank; and the leak of internal documents revealing cronyism, power struggles and accusations of blackmail. But has Benedicts successor, Pope Francis, managed to lift the Roman Catholic church out of crisis? Frontline uses undercover footage and interviews with Vatican insiders, abuse victims and whistle-blowers to address that question and others in this 90-minute special, nearly a year in the making. It is necessary to open the windows of the church, because we need fresh air, says one of Franciss closest confidants, Cardinal scar Andrs Rodrguez Maradiaga.

title: Pakistan Bombs Militant Area as Officials Weigh a Wider Offensive
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The Pakistani military pressed its campaign of airstrikes against militants in the remote tribal regions on Tuesday, reportedly killing at least 30 people, as the national cabinet met to consider a broader military offensive, officials said.

title: On Twitter, Being Black at the University of Michigan
description: As my colleague Tanzina Vega reported, theres a notion in the media and popular culture that millennials are growing up in a colorblind world and race is a relic of the past.

title: Xi Visits Beijing Neighborhood, Lighting Up Social Media
description: Updated, 3:22 a.m. EDT | President Xi Jinping of China continued his campaign to be seen as a warm, down-to-earth leader by taking a stroll Tuesday morning through a Beijing neighborhood that is popular with tourists and locals alike.

title: A Magazine Cover for a Famously Humble Ambassador
description: Even before he arrived in Beijing, Gary Locke, the United States ambassador, achieved a rare sort of national prominence in China.
