description: MOSCOW  Aleksei A. Navalny, Russias leading opposition figure, was placed under house arrest on Friday and ordered not to use the Internet or telephone for two months, thus removing President Vladimir V. Putins fiercest critic from public life.

title: Times Minute | Heroin in New England
description: A town in Vermont fights back. Also on the Minute, Vladimir Putin's calculation in Ukraine and the power of prayer in the N.B.A.

title: Times Minute | Heroin in New England
description: In the Video

title: Roland Mouret: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Bankia Privatization Starts With Sale of Government Sliver
description: MADRID  The Spanish government announced on Friday that it sold a 7.5 percent stake in Bankia, its first step toward returning the bank to private ownership and recovering part of the bailout money that Bankia received after triggering Spains banking crisis two years ago.

title: Erosion of Faith Was Death Knell for Mt. Gox
description: As the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox was careening toward collapse in early February, its owner, Mark Karpeles, found that even some of his fellow virtual currency advocates were losing faith.

title: Daily Report: British Spy Agency Is Said to Have Collected Yahoo Webcam Photos
description: A British intelligence agency collected video webcam images  many of them sexually explicit  from millions of Yahoo users, regardless of whether they were suspected of illegal activity, according to accounts of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden, Nicole Perlroth and Vindu Goel report.

title: North Dakota Leads on the Road to Recovery
description: SIX years after the recession began, the United States has yet to return to where it was by any of three measures of economic activity: jobs, highway miles driven or house prices. That makes this business cycle unique among recent cycles  within four years of the recessions that began in 1981, 1990 and 2001, each of those indicators was up substantially.

title: Feb. 28 Updates on the Crisis in Ukraine
description: Ukraines ousted president, Viktor Yanukovych, made his first public appearance in a week on Friday, telling journalists in the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don that he remains in office, as our colleague Steven Lee Myers reports.

title: Kolkata Rape Victims Find a Police Officer Whos on Their Side
description: KOLKATA, India  After his 16-year-old daughter was gang-raped twice in their Madhyamgram neighborhood in north Kolkata in October, then set on fire, allegedly by associates of her rapists, Rama Shankar Jha was distraught.

title: Chalayan: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: The Demise of Mt. Gox
description: MT. GOX FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY | As feared, Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers coins in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in DealBook. The Tokyo-based exchange halted trading earlier this week.

title: Daily Report: Mt. Gox, Having Lost Essentially All Bitcoins, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers coins, essentially all of them, in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Balmain Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Currency of China Continues to Decline
description: SHANGHAI  The value of Chinas currency, the renminbi, continued to slide against the United States dollar on Friday, rattling investors by falling to its lowest level in nearly a year before closing higher.

title: Changes (Personal/Professional)
description: Some news: I have informed Princeton that I will be retiring at the end of next academic year, that is, in June 2015. In August 2015 I will join the faculty of the Graduate Center, City University of New York, as a professor in the Ph.D. program in economics. I will also become a distinguished scholar at the Graduate Centers Luxembourg Income Study Center. You can read all about it in the Graduate Centers announcement.

title: Hungary: An Election in Question, Part 1
description: This is the first of a five-part series from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of the Law and Public Affairs Program.

title: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 2
description: Hungary: An Election in QuestionPart II: Writing the Rules to Win  The Basic Structure

title: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 3
description: This is the third of a series of posts by my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of the Law and Public Affairs Program.

title: U.S. Growth at End of 2013 Is Revised Downward
description: The economy finished 2013 on a weaker footing than first thought, the government said on Friday, heightening concern that the United States is in the midst of another of the periodic slow patches that have dogged the recovery over the last five years.

title: Blackfish in the Cross Hairs Again, and Other Developments
description: Awards campaigns have wound down but there have been developments in some stories from the season:

title: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 4
description: Hungary: An Election in QuestionPart IV: The New Electorate (in which Some are more Equal than Others)

title: Paris Looks
description: From floral motifs to texture mixes, designers stage their collections for autumn/winter 2014.

title: Lanvin at 125: Sporty to Sensual
description: PARIS  Lanvin turns 125 this year and Alber Elbaz gave it a happy, tough-and-tender birthday. The fact that one front-row guest was Rihanna, with a boyish new haircut, would surely have pleased Jeanne Lanvin, the founder of a house that has never let women down.

title: Japan to Revisit Apology to Wartime Sex Slaves
description: TOKYO  Japan will re-examine a landmark apology it made two decades ago to women forced to work in Japanese wartime military brothels, a government spokesman said on Friday, in a move that could further outrage South Korea, where many of the women came from.

title: Hungary, An Election in Question, Part 5
description: This is the final post of a new series from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of Princetons Law and Public Affairs Program.

title: Listen Up | Will Owen Pallett Win an Academy Award This Sunday?
description: Its been a really crazy, busy week, Owen Pallett exclaimed as he returned Tuesday from Haiti, where he was performing with his frequent collaborators, Arcade Fire. A maverick virtuoso of the violin, as well as an in-demand composer and arranger, Pallett is now back in Los Angeles to attend a private, Oscar-y dinner with the likes of Burt Bacharach, Randy Newman and John Williams. The event is tied to his recent Academy Award nomination for best original score, which Pallett shares with Arcade Fire for their work on the soundtrack to Spike Jonzes acclaimed film Her. Im going to get a haircut, he said. I dont know how else to prep to meet my big hero, Burt Bacharach. Its kind of strange and disorienting, all thats happening. Its not something Ive been thirsting for my entire life.

title: This Week's Movies: Feb. 28, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on The Lunchbox, Non-Stop and Fatal Assistance.

title: Mattel Agrees to Buy Maker of Mega Bloks, a Lego Rival
description: With The Lego Movie a box office smash, the toy maker Mattel is getting in on the craze for plastic bricks.

title: Changes (Repost)
description: Reposting to put this at the top of the blog for the next few hours.

title: A Yellow Beverage
description: Dear Diary:

title: Citigroup Says Mexican Subsidiary Was Defrauded of as Much as $400 Million
description: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | At the helm of Citigroup for just a year and a half, Michael L. Corbat has been trying to transform into a boring bank a global giant that has been plagued in the past by blowups and bailouts.

title: Rebellions Simmering and Boiling
description: An early champion of Italian Neorealism, Andr Bazin praised movies like Rome Open City and Paisan for the immediacy of their re-enacted reportage. Lionel Rogosins 1959 Come Back, Africa, a clandestinely made expos of South African apartheid, is more like reportage re-enacted under fire.

title: Hotel Review: Lord Balfour in Miami Beach
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Little Nonnas in Philadelphia
description: A craving for a classic Italian Sunday supper  hearty platters of meatballs and macaroni and a long-simmering red sauce  can inconveniently arise on any given evening. Those in Philadelphia are in luck: At Little Nonnas, a cozy restaurant that opened in September in Center City, the family-style Sunday gravy is served every night of the week.

title: On the Beach, on the Cheap, in Mozambique
description: An hour up the sand from the little beach town of Tofo, perched on a peninsula jutting off the southern coast of Mozambique on a bay of gently surfable Indian Ocean waves, I met five children who had never heard of pizza.

title: Fortress Discloses a Paper Loss on Bitcoin
description: The Fortress Investment Group reported a paper loss of $3.7 million from investments in Bitcoin, the first large public company to disclose a stake in the volatile virtual currency.

title: Today in Small Business: Image-Based Ads
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

title: Fast Acquittal for Kennedy, Whose Name Put Prosecutors in Bind
description: WHITE PLAINS  After nearly 20 months of celebrity theater and an incalculable amount of effort and courtroom expense, the misdemeanor trial of Kerry Kennedy ended on Friday in breakneck fashion, as jurors took one hour to find her not guilty of driving under the influence of a drug: a sleeping pill that she said she took by accident.

title: A New Album After 44 Years
description: The psychedelic folk singer Linda Perhacs discusses her hiatus; a little stubble goes a long way; the Meh List takes on the Oscars.

title: Lets Go Ride a Bike
description: Last fall, I moved from Beirut to Los Angeles with my wife, Kelly, a journalist, and our 4-year-old daughter, Loretta, who one evening was ready to get back on her bike.

title: Reply All: The 2.16.14 Issue
description: CAN WENDY DAVIS HAVE IT ALL?

title: Nursing-Home Pitfalls
description: I am an advocate for nursing-home residents. A new technique to control the wandering of dementia patients involves placing black floor mats in front of unsafe areas, such as outside exits. Due to a fear of falling, persons with dementia will not walk on dark spaces on the floor (they tend to see them as holes). This is an alternative to antipsychotic drugs and lockdown units. Since this technique uses fear and a disability to guide behavior, but with the intent of safety, is it ethical? LISA MARIE HAYES, HOUSTON

title: The Brilliant, Unnerving Meta-Marketing of The Lego Movie
description: Princess Leia and Harry Potter are dining in the eat-in kitchen of their midcentury modern home, sunshine bouncing off the white floors and refracting through the enormous aquarium that separates the kitchen from the den. I need more pink tiles for my dining room! their neighbor Hermione calls from her rainbow-colored split-level ranch home next door, which boasts three patios and two hot tubs.

title: The Last, Disposable Action Hero
description: When the screenwriter David Hayter conceived the idea for Wolves, his directorial debut, he wanted to make a coming-of-age drama that he describes as  Twilight with a bit more bite to it  and without abstinence. His script focused on a high-school football-star-slash-werewolf who skips town after his parents are gruesomely murdered and eventually comes to blows with a man-eating alpha dog. Hayter just needed to find the perfect young werewolf, and he settled on a relatively unknown actor named Lucas Till as the lead. I thought of Lucas because I felt this movie was about a kid on the verge of adulthood, said Hayter, who also wrote the screenplays for Watchmen and X-Men. And this is the story that takes him over the brink.

title: Battle of the Kites
description: There is perhaps no event more anticipated in Gujarat, a state in Indias northwest, than the International Kite Festival every January. Residents prepare for months, making kites in bright colors, using elaborate designs that have been passed down for generations. On the main day of the festival, people get up before dawn to fly their kites from rooftops and, with any luck, cut down competing kites. (Some kite strings have been dipped in an emulsion that includes finely ground glass.) When a participant successfully downs another kite, a small trumpet sounds a victory blast. The festival, which is celebrated at the end of the mild Indian winter, when daytime temperatures hover in the 80s, is tied to a traditional day on the Hindu calendar that marks the change of seasons. Flying a kite brings good luck and good fortune in the new year, says Tobias Hutzler, who captured images of the festival. They are sending wishes into the air. Julie Bosman

title: The Bachelor Host Chris Harrison: I Know Why Youre All Single
description: Youve been hosting The Bachelor and The Bachelorette for a combined 27 seasons. Are you surprised how long the show has lasted? Absolutely. It started back in 2002, when there was hardly any reality television. Survivor had just started. My hope and dream was that The Bachelor would last one or two nights on network TV, so I might meet somebody in the network and then I could get a real job.

title: Who Made That Antiperspirant?
description: The week after Christmas in 1916, a dermatologist in Illinois published a cure for sweating. An abundance of perspiration  or hyperhidrosis, as doctors call it  could lead to emotional pain and discomfort, and the knowledge that an unpleasant odor clings to one makes the sensitive person dread to meet others. In an era in which some patients were dosed with X-rays for their sweating, Arthur W. Stillians offered something seemingly revolutionary: the under-arm application of an aluminum-chloride cream three times over the course of a week. In 20 cases in which I have used this lotion, it has never failed to give relief, he claimed in a prestigious medical journal.

title: Thousands of Bill Clinton White House Papers Released
description: WASHINGTON  She wooed Republicans in Congress while bristling at the national news media. She aspired to be a pioneer of womens rights around the world while running a full-blown war room on health care at home. She was, in her staffs view, often too defensive, too removed in public.

title: Video Reviews of The Lunchbox, Non-Stop and Fatal Assistance
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the romance The Lunchbox, the action film Non-Stop and the documentary Fatal Assistance. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Musical Surprises
description: Anthony Tommasini, chief classical music critic for The Times, presents a few unexpected moments in music, and invites readers to submit their own favorite examples.

title: Doctors Note, and Ailing Mother, Not Enough for Tycoon to Avoid Arrest
description: NEW DELHI  After failing to show up before the Supreme Court and eluding the police for a day, one of Indias most high-profile business tycoons surrendered to the police on Friday to face charges of contempt of court.

title: Concern Grows as Investors Exit Bond Holdings in Emerging Markets
description: Updated, 8:04 p.m. | Low interest rates have incited a craze for risky bonds in fast-growing economies, and few fund companies have been more adept in meeting this demand than Pimco, the worlds largest bond manager.

title: Riverbed Rejects Updated Elliott Takeover Bid
description: Riverbed Technology rejected the latest takeover proposal from the hedge fund Elliott Management on Friday, calling the $3.3 billion offer too low.

title: Getting Up in the Night Is Your Wifes Job
description: My son was 6 months old when my mother asked, Why are you getting up in the night? Thats your wifes job.

title: Haydns Bombshell and Other Surprises
description: Haydn could be a great musical jokester. Many of his pieces have unexpected twists and turns.

title: Need Help on Your Ballot?
description: Have you filled out your ballot yet? Oscarologists across the web are starting to weigh in, if youre looking for guidance. But as the Bagger writes here, its been an unusually competitive Oscar race for best picture, with even the most-seasoned pundits, the kind who can spot the leader weeks out, changing their minds in the days before Sundays show, pleading confusion.

title: Ditch the Snow Shovel
description: As heavy, wet snow blanketed New York City last month and then quickly turned to slush, the sidewalks in front of some luxury apartment buildings remained pristine. As if by magic, snowflakes melted as they touched the ground in front of these upscale addresses, releasing a faint vapor that hung momentarily in the bitter cold before vanishing altogether, thanks to what is turning out to be the ultimate amenity in an unrelenting winter: heated sidewalks.

title: Indias Growth Rate Signals a Slow Recovery
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias economy grew 4.7 percent in the three months ended in December from the same period a year earlier, government data showed Friday, evidence that the economic slump in the country is far from over.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Husband-Hunting in the Raj
description: This week, Alida Becker talks about The Fishing Fleet; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Nick Reding discusses two new books about the meat industry; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Letters: The Sixth Extinction, and More
description: In the Chillest Land

title: The Vegetable System
description: This week, Nick Reding reviews two new books about the ways in which we produce and consume meat  a picture that might have appalled several famous writers who made the case for abandoning the carnivores life, well before notions of vegetarianism and veganism became as widely fashionable as they are today.

title: The Three Rays
description: A writer is visited by inspiration.

title: Assessing Oscar Hosts
description: Hosting the Academy Awards ceremony can bring glory or infamy. After missteps in recent years, Oscars producers are returning to safer middle ground with the selection of Ellen DeGeneres.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Husband-Hunting in the Raj
description: This week, Alida Becker and Nick Reding.

title: Writers on the Left
description: LILLIAN HELLMAN

title: Using Skype to Build a Business
description: In October 2012, David Greenberg was operating a thriving tutoring business,Parliament Tutors, when Hurricane Sandy hit. Suddenly, Mr. Greenberg started getting emails from tutors saying they were unable to meet with clients who had already purchased packages for the SAT, which was just two weeks away.

title: Paperback Row
description: AFTER THE MUSIC STOPPED: The Financial Crisis, the Response, and the Work Ahead,  by Alan S. Blinder. (Penguin, $17.) This comprehensive history of the 2008 meltdown, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2013, says that it was the result of a perfect storm of events, from the bursting of the housing bubble to the financial implosion that followed the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers. Blinder, a former Fed vice chairman, is critical of both the Bush and Obama administrations, but he also praises them for taking steps to save the country from falling into a serious depression.

title: Editors Choice
description: BARK: Stories,  by Lorrie Moore. (Knopf, $24.95.) The uncrowded format of Moores first collection in 16 years allows each story the chance it deserves for leisurely appreciation and lets the reader savor just what makes her work unique.

title: Inside the List
description: Building Blocks: Theres a sweet moment in All Joy and No Fun, Jennifer Seniors smart new look at modern parenting (its at No. 16 after three weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list), in which Clint Holder, one of the fathers Senior shadowed, shows his older son how to assemble a Lego ice-cream truck. Here, let me help, he says: You put this thing on the back of it. Watching him snap the pieces together, Senior observes that Clint plumps with life, like a diabetic whos finally been handed a sucking candy. Then he notices her noticing him, and offers a sheepish-sounding explanation: Im biased about Legos, he says. Theyre what I played with when I was little. The scene will resonate with anybody whos watched The Lego Movie  half of America, in other words  which likewise features a father passionate about his Lego creations. (The movies success has spilled over onto the best-seller list; a junior novelization, Lego, the Lego Movie, remains at No. 3 in its fifth week on the childrens middle-grade list.)

title: Sparks of Life
description: The heroine of Marcel Therouxs previous novel, Far North, was an intrepid survivor named Makepeace who scavenged books from the ruins of a post-apocalyptic Manhattan, but showed little interest in actually reading them. A person is always better than a book, she reasoned.

title: Madness Most Discreet
description: Near the end of Kem Nunns crafty new novel, the title character, a 49-year-old San Francisco psychiatrist named Eldon Chance, confesses to feeling a persistent sense of vertigo, attributable no doubt to the sudden, simultaneous rush of so many large ideas. That diagnosis, like so many of Dr. Chances, is both entirely plausible and hilariously wrong.

title: Passages to India
description: In 1671, the East India Company sent 20 single women to Bombay, each supplied with an allowance of 300, a new set of clothing and a simple directive  to find a company-approved mate within a year. In those early days, Anne de Courcy remarks, marriage was often undertaken with the sort of rapidity usually confined to spotting a business opportunity and pouncing on it. But as she follows the long history of what came to be known as the fishing fleet, which supplied a steady cargo of potential brides to generations of expats, it seems clear that the official coupling of a man and a woman in British India, despite an often hastily applied gloss of romance, continued to be conducted in distinctly commercial style. By the 19th century, potential wives were paying a bond of 200 for the privilege of sailing off to a strange land to ally themselves with a virtual stranger. And pity the poor soul who  despite a ratio of three or four men to every woman, inspiring tales of proposals offered at funerals and engagements announced as husbands lay dying  failed to drag the humblest prospect to the altar. Put on a ship back to England, she would now be dismissed as one of the Returned Empties.

title: The Unvanquished
description: In 2011, writing in the Book Review about a memoir by Binyavanga Wainaina, Alexandra Fuller opened with a marvelous plea: Harried reader, Ill save you precious time. Skip this review and head directly to the bookstore.

title: Five Years Later, an Over-the-Top Wall Street Blog Returns
description: Like many in the fall of 2008, Amit Chatwani was done. Lehman Brothers had collapsed, the government had bailed out the American International Group, and the financial system was in chaos.

title: Days of the Dead
description: On our mountain only boys were born, Ladydi Garcia Martnez tells us in the opening pages of Jennifer Clements new novel, Prayers for the Stolen, and some of them turned into girls around the age of 11. Rather than a tale of transgender magic realism, however, this is the story of a young Mexican girl who grows up in a rural mountain community in the Pacific state of Guerrero  a land of red insects and women  not far from Acapulco. Although named after Diana, Princess of Wales  the saint for betrayed women  Ladydi is called Boy by her mother, Rita. Turning girls into boys  or at least making them ugly  is a matter of survival on the mountain. Girls get short haircuts at the ugly parlor; Ladydi even colors her teeth with black and yellow markers to make them look rotted. All the drug traffickers had to do was hear that there was a pretty girl around, she says, and theyd sweep onto our lands in black Escalades and carry the girl off.

title: A Body in the Snow
description: The violent murder of a young innocent underpins Andrea Portess second novel, Bury This. Beth Krause is the victim in a 1978 case that is revitalized in 2003, when a group of film students starts to make a documentary of her life. The question posed by one of them is: If 25 years can discover the Internet, the cellphone, this thing the iPod, can 25 years discover the secret of a girl murdered, abandoned, by the side of the road? But the question at the heart of Bury This isnt about the possibilities brought by advances in forensic science but about the possibilities of language in the face of the ugliest truths.

title: Willkommen
description: Among the trophies of the Second World War captured by Allied intelligence agents were Nazi scientists and their research on biological and chemical weapons. In a classified memorandum titled Exploitation of German Scientists in Science and Technology in the United States, the Joint Chiefs of Staff described these men as chosen, rare minds whose continuing intellectual productivity we wish to use. Such intellectual spoils were not to fall into Soviet hands. In 1945, Operation Overcast (renamed Operation Paperclip for the paper clips attached to the dossiers of the most troublesome cases) began. More than 1,600 Germans were secretly recruited to develop armaments at a feverish and paranoid pace that came to define the Cold War.

title: Bleak Houses
description: If anyone can make you root for the murderer, its Denise Mina, whose defiantly unsentimental novels are less concerned with personal guilt than with the social evils that create criminals and the predators who nurture them. THE RED ROAD (Little, Brown, $26), as fierce a story as any Mina has written, opens in 1997 with a shocking double murder in a seedy section of Glasgow. The murderer gives up without a fight, and that, youd think, should be that  except for the fact that the killer, Rose Wilson, is a 14-year-old prostitute (looking 16, feeling 12) and one of the men she stabbed to death was the pimp who had hired her out to service eight men.

title: Girlfish
description: Alice Hoffman has always celebrated the marvelousness of whats real in the world, even as she creates the distinctive atmosphere of uncanniness and magical potential that looms over her fiction. Her devoted readers expect melodramatic stories imbued with the atmosphere of folk tales. Omens and portents are her stock in trade. Feminist themes and generous amounts of Renaissance Faire-style potted history make her storytelling all the more suggestive. Eerie and powerful acts of nature signify undercurrents of mood the way irregular minor chords in the background music tell us how to feel during ominous scenes at the movies. Lost in a dark forest of one kind or another, Hoffmans characters have a heightened awareness of the hidden meanings that surround them as they struggle toward the light.

title: There Goes the Judge
description: Poor Judge Crater. Famous for decades after his mysterious disappearance in 1930, hes mostly forgotten today, long ago replaced in the cultural consciousness (and joke book) by Jimmy Hoffa. But good crime stories dont stay buried, and Ariel Lawhons new novel, The Wife, the Maid, and the Mistress, digs up the case of the so-called Missingest Man in New York and feasts on its bones.

title: Strong, Silent Types
description: Short-story collections might be divided into two groups. One is the hodgepodge, the mixtape, the gathering together of stray parts from here and there. D. W. Wilsons Once You Break a Knuckle keeps a rarer company  the collection in which the stories are in conversation, and together form a world to be explored not linearly but sideways, more than once, through previously unexplored corridors and secret passageways hiding in plain sight. These books, by design, are echo chambers of empathy. The world is large, they seem to say, and it is full of other people whose lives are as important to themselves as mine is to me and yours is to you. Look around.

title: In Our Pages: March 1
description: 1914: Disease Follows Snowfall

title: Director of Bostons Museum of Fine Arts to Retire
description: After 19 years as director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Malcolm Rogers said on Thursday that he plans to retire as soon as the board has named a successor.

title: Just Say Nein
description: Joachim Fests fascinating memoir about what it was like to come of age during the years of the Third Reich is unusual because its central character is not the author but the authors remarkable father. Johannes Fest was the middle-class headmaster of a primary school in suburban Berlin, a pious Catholic and father of five, a cultural conservative who revered Goethe and Kant, and a loyal German patriot  a dyed-in-the-wool Prussian, in Fests words  the kind of person who might have been expected to become an active supporter of Adolf Hitler and the National Socialists. In a foreword by Herbert Arnold (a professor emeritus of German studies at Wesleyan University who has also supplied informative notes throughout the text), the elder Fest is described as tailor-made for a career with the Nazis. And yet some quirk in his personality made him a fierce Weimar republican, ready to sacrifice himself, even his family, to principles he knew to be right even as everyone around him was yielding to mass hysteria. Not I, a best seller in Germany when it appeared in 2006, the year of the authors death at age 79, is a memorable tale of lonely courage, stoic endurance, self-imposed hardship and a life lived amid ubiquitous, all-encompassing danger: Even innocent-sounding remarks could be life-and-death matters. It reminds us that simple human decency is possible even in the most trying of circumstances.

title: A reading of Dear Spring by Charles Simic
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet reads his ode to spring.

title: Raf Simons Designs a Dynamic Dior
description: PARIS  Taut tailoring, but for a feminine body  that was the message at Dior, where the designer Raf Simons reached down to his deep mens wear fashion roots and made his collection bloom for the French house.

title: Times Minute | Yanukovych Emerges
description: Viktor F. Yanukovych, the ousted Ukrainian president, made his first public appearance since disappearing a week ago. Also on the Minute, challenges for Oscar hosts and the origin of antiperspirants.

title: Now May Be a Good Time to Bail Out of Frequent-Flier Programs
description: Fly one mile, get one frequent-flier mile in return.

title: Times Minute | Yanukovych Emerges
description: In the Video

title: Oscar Hosts and the Academys Dilemma
description: As host of the Oscars and of her own daytime talk show, Ellen DeGeneres has been making the most of cross-promotional opportunities this awards season. That sets her apart from the typical Academy M.C., but in other ways she represents a safe choice for the organization, which may have felt gun-shy after turns by Seth MacFarlane and James Franco. Heres the Timess chief television critic, Alessandra Stanley, explaining the Academys thinking when it comes to choosing Oscar hosts over the years.

title: Paris Fall 2014: Elements | Texture
description: A thematic visual diary of Paris Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

title: Talking Talent | Around the World with Chelsea Handler
description: The best-selling author Chelsea Handler, host of E!s corrosively hilarious late-night talk show Chelsea Lately, is back with a collection of travel essays titled Uganda Be Kidding Me (Grand Central Publishing, out March 4). In it, Handler recalls injuring herself (sometimes) and drinking too much (often) while laughing her way across the globe (always) alongside her merry pack of female travel companions. With her beloved brand of self-deprecating wit, she takes the reader from a safari in South Africa to a weekend of skiing in the Swiss Alps  chronicling every airport nightmare and downright dirty encounter along the way. Here, she discusses the process of writing the book, as well as ugly babies, her lesbian roommate and the delicate art of comedy.

title: Wendy Whelans Renovated Rental
description: The New York City Ballet principal Wendy Whelan lives with her husband, David Michalek, on a skinny stretch of the Upper West Side thats known among insiders as the dance belt. Since coming to Manhattan from Louisville more than 30 years ago to train at the School of American Ballet, Ms. Whelan has moved from rental to rental but has never moved out of the neighborhood.

title: Facts & Figures: Interracial Marriage vs. Same-Sex Marriage
description: First year Gallup found that a majority of Americans thought same-sex marriage should be legal: 2011

title: Yanukovych Speaks Out After Ouster
description: Viktor F. Yanukovich appeared in public for the first time since he was ousted as Ukraine's president. He spoke in Russian and said he will not give up the fight for his country's future.

title: At the RSA Security Conference, Things Get Testy and Then They Get Awkward
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was hard to avoid the shadow of Edward J. Snowden at the annual RSA security conference this week.

title: A Blockbuster Landed in Their Laps
description: Marvel Entertainment has a history of entrusting its superhero blockbusters to offbeat directors, but the brothers Russo may take the cape.

title: The Envelopes Please
Whats It All About?
description: Father-daughter memoirs have an inherent appeal, especially when the father and daughter are on an almost preposterous quest. Theres such a quest in Trespassing on Einsteins Lawn: to uncover the nature of reality. It all began when Warren Gefter, a radiologist prone to posing Zen-koan-like questions, asked his 15-year-old daughter, Amanda, over dinner at a Chinese restaurant near their home just outside Philadelphia: How would you define nothing?

title: Big Ticket | Cityscape Views for $12 Million
description: A sponsor unit at 737 Park Avenue, an Art Deco-style brick-and-limestone apartment building acquired by Macklowe Properties and the CIM Group in 2011 and since converted to 60 luxury condominiums, sold for $12,057,366.08 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The monthly carrying costs are $6,720.68.

title: Yanukovych Speaks Out After Ouster
description: Viktor F. Yanukovych appeared in public for the first time since he was ousted as Ukraines president. He spoke in Russian and said he would not give up the fight for his countrys future.

title: Fed Searches for a New Method of Offering Guidance
description: Updated, 10:25 p.m. | The Federal Reserve is struggling to redefine the central element of its economic stimulus campaign, its plans for short-term interest rates.

title: Image of the Day: February 28
In Miami Beach, a Concierge for Daytime Activities
description: Miami may be known for its pulsing night life but the Surfcomber is hoping to shake things up a bit. The 186-room hotel in Miami Beach recently created a director of daylife position with the purpose of helping guests maximize their time before the sun sets.

title: A Scorecard on Jos. A. Banks Latest Moves
description: I wish I knew how to quit you.

title: Highlights From the Clinton Documents
description: The National Archives made public on Friday afternoon a trove of secret documents detailing the inner workings of Bill Clintons White House, a disclosure of acute interest not just to the history of one presidency but to the prospects of another. Thousands of pages of internal memos and papers offered insights into Mr. Clintons decisions, as well as the role his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, may have played in shaping them. Times reporters posted standout passages and analysis below.

title: Geneva Motor Show to Showcase Extreme Opulence
description: Green can be found in many hues at an auto show: green, as in environmentally friendly; green, as in the color of envy over all the new cars. But at the Geneva auto show, green is really about the color of money.

title: Kosovo Gets a Real Game, if It Can Assemble a Team
description: After six years of rejection, cajoling, schmoozing, direct action and, finally, acceptance, Eroll Salihu is at last organizing a game that counts.

title: Back to Basics on Corporate Apologies
description: Lawrence S. Spiegel is a partner in the government enforcement and white-collar crime group of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in New York and general counsel of the firm.

title: Nick Bollettieris Age: 82. His Vision for Tennis Talent: 20/20.
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  The first surprise upon arrival was to see Nick Bollettieri wearing a shirt.

title: Will Someone Please Make a Better Online Calendar?
description: Over the last few days Ive been using a promising new calendar program called Magneto. The app was created by a start-up whose founders have put a lot of thought into how people use online calendars, and it addresses several shortcomings found in other digital organizers.

title: Plans for a Restaurant in Union Square Park Move Ahead
description: After years of legal battles, a plan to open a seasonal restaurant in the recently restored neo-Classical arch and colonnade that anchors the north end of Union Square Park is back on track. Barring any other bureaucratic roadblock, the restaurant, to be named the Pavilion, would open in June.

title: Hard Life for a von Trier Woman, Again
description: Fifteen years ago, Catherine Deneuve reflected in her journal on filming the unorthodox musical Dancer in the Dark (2000) with Bjrk and the director Lars von Trier. Tensions ran high on the demanding shoot. But despite fierce creative differences and psychological stress on all sides, Bjrk saw her feature-acting debut, as a single mother going blind who faces the death penalty, to its conclusion. And Ms. Deneuve couldnt figure out why.

title: GrubHub Files for an I.P.O.
description: GrubHub is already well known to the masses of office workers who rely on the companys online food ordering services. Now it is hoping that investors are just as eager for what on its plate.

title: Sonia Rykiel: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Ash Spill Shows How Watchdog Was Defanged
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Last June, state employees in charge of stopping water pollution were given updated marching orders on behalf of North Carolinas new Republican governor and conservative lawmakers.

title: Aftermath of Coal Ash Pond Rupture
description: An animated graphic by the Center for Energy, Environment and Sustainability at Wake Forest University shows the aftermath of the coal ash pond rupture at Duke Energys Dan River Steam Station.

title: Casting Shadows on a Fanciful World
description: Imagine you could pry off the back of Wes Andersons head as if it were a vintage TV set and rummage around inside. What would you find there? A mind like a junk drawer crammed with kite string, Swiss Army knives and remote-controlled toys, or one that springs open as neatly as a well-organized tackle box? A memory palace assembled ad hoc from brownstone apartments, underground caves and submarine compartments, or a diligently designed, continuously flowing and elegant old Alpine resort?

title: Butternut Squash With Polenta
description: Cooked together slowly, squash and polenta serve as a sweet and silky bed for caramelized onions and savory sausage.

title: Torontos Ethnic Buffet
description: When I tell my friends in Toronto how much I love their city, they often say, Really? I always assume they imagine Im just trying to be gracious, or perhaps  with characteristic Canadian modesty  theyre reluctant to acknowledge how easy their city is to love. But they also have a great deal of justifiable civic pride, and a clear sense of why Toronto is such a special and unusual place to live and visit. Theres more to this understated city than many people might realize.

title: Christian Dior: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Polentas Journey From Fancy to Familiar
description: When polenta first hit the food scene in the United States, it was the kind of delicacy that graced the likes of only Italian specialty food shops and high-end restaurants.

title: Finding a Setting That Captures a Scene
description: Wes Andersons films are best known for their eccentric characters and rigorously whimsical tone. But just as distinctively captured are their settings. Think of the colors and textures of the Indian landscapes in The Darjeeling Limited, for example, or the lovingly rendered Mediterranean locations in The Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou.

title: The Pasta Is Gluten-Free
description: Every so often I like to do a small roundup of gluten-free pasta products, to see if there is anything new and noteworthy on the market. This week was a good time to do it, as Im in New York staying with my sister Melodie, who is gluten-intolerant. Melodie used to eat a lot of rice pasta until she became concerned with reports about arsenic in rice. It is cold in New York and we are mourning the death of our 95-year-old mother, and this calls for comfort food. So I went shopping for gluten-free pasta that was not made primarily with rice flour, and put my purchases to good use.

title: For Coke, Challenge Is Staying Relevant
description: Can this brand be saved?

title: Apollo Chief Questions Effort to Limit Banks Exposure to Buyout Deals
description: Leon D. Black, the head of Apollo Global Management, questioned the wisdom of a regulatory effort to limit the ability of banks to finance risky buyout deals.

title: A Maelstrom of Fraud Without Early Warning
description: Not for the first time, Citigroup has stepped into a mess  and by extension besmirched the financial industry. Not that Citigroup committed a crime, or colluded to set foreign exchange rates or Libor prices, say. Rather, the bank is the victim of fraud in Mexico that could cost it much as $400 million. The problem is that the lender has been cheated out of the cash in one of the most basic businesses in banking. That should worry Citigroups rivals, too.

title: Putin's Foe Placed Under House Arrest
description: A Russian court placed the opposition leader Aleksei Navalny under house arrest. Mr. Navalny, a critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, said the ruling was baseless.

title: Deadly Bus Crash in Thailand
description: Watch scenes from a deadly bus crash in the eastern Prachin Buri province of Thailand.

title: Popcast: The Radical Happiness of Pharrell
description: This week, Jon Caramanica and I examine the producer, songwriter and singer Pharrell Williams, whose radically airy, upbeat second solo album, G I R L, is to be released next week in a modified version of a Beyonc-style sudden drop. (It will arrive two days after his performance on the Academy Awards telecast.)

title: In Kentucky, a Family at the Center of the Earth
description: Jerry Bransford remembers the short day trips his family used to make to Mammoth Cave, half an hour away from their home in Glasgow, Ky. His father would tell him stories about how his family first came to know the cave as slaves but eventually became famous guides, starting a legacy that would last four generations. He grew up wanting to feel what it would be like to walk in the shoes of these men, whose renown had faded with time.

title: Wheelies: The Legal Navigation Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Countering Israel Boycotts, With Glamour
description: WASHINGTON  Scarlett Johansson politely declined an invitation to speak to the 14,000 people gathering here Sunday for the annual meeting of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, as the nations most powerful pro-Israel lobbying group is known.

title: Michelle Obamas Bulkier Brows, Harry Brants Runway Moment and Dries Van Notens Curator Cameo
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: A Trip to Mammoth Cave, Ky.
description: In 1864, James Fowler Rusling, a Union soldier and abolitionist, published a pamphlet recounting his experiences in the cave as well as an interview he conducted with Materson Bransford, the slave who served as his guide.

title: Pictures of the Year: Finding Stories Everywhere
description: Barbara Davidson of the Los Angeles Times was named newspaper photographer of the year in the 2013 Pictures of the Year International competition. Daniel Berehulak of Reportage by Getty Images took the title of freelance/agency photographer of the year. Most of the images in Mr. Berehulaks winning portfolio were made on assignment for the New York Times. Pictures of the Year International is a program of the Donald W. Reynolds Journalism Institute at the Missouri School of Journalism.

title: A reading of Greening, by Kevin Young
description: The prolific writer reads his poem.

title: A reading of Rooting, by Kevin Young
description: The prolific writer reads his poem.

title: Movie Review: 'Fatal Assistance'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Fatal Assistance."

title: You Can Look, but You Cant Check In
description: While The Grand Budapest Hotel is busy with smaller design elements, one of its most striking designs is the hotel itself. Outfitted in shades of pink and purple and situated atop a hill, the hotel is grandiose and picturesque. It also happens to be nine feet tall. For wide shots of the hotel, the director Wes Anderson and his team decided to use a handmade miniature model.

title: Bill Cunningham | The White Album
description: The popularity of white outerwear this winter has been a perfect match for this particularly snowy season.

title: Look & Listen Music Festival to Spread to Brooklyn
description: Organizers of the Look & Listen Festival, which makes a point of presenting an eclectic slate of new music concerts in galleries and other spaces where the performers and audiences are surrounded by contemporary visual art, said on Friday that it will offer performances in Brooklyn for the first time since it was founded in 2002. As in past years, the festival is short  this years runs for a week and includes four concerts  but each program includes two or three ensembles or soloists, an arrangement more typical in pop than in classical music.

title: In Performance: Mark Padmore
description: The tenor Mark Padmore performs the prologue from Brittens Billy Budd.

title: Saying Thank You in 45 Seconds
description: One of the more influential cultural mainstays to emerge from Hollywood in the last 50 years may be the most maligned: the Oscar acceptance speech. Though often mocked, these high-stakes odes to self-regard, faux humility, stress management and careful planning (or lack thereof) are actually extremely revealing, even career defining. And their impact extends far beyond Oscar night. What happens in Hollywood doesnt stay in Hollywood but shapes every award celebration, from the most valuable player of the office softball team to the best apple pie at the bake-off.

title: Rice University to Demolish Former Museum Building
description: Rice University in Houston plans to demolish its Martel Center building, originally the Rice Museum, which was built by John and Dominique de Menil, the university confirmed on Friday.

title: Gauging the Tax Impact of Investments Options and Living in New Jersey
description: JIMMY FALLON has brought The Tonight Show back to New York City, and in return for leaving California, the shows owner, NBCUniversal, is receiving a tax credit that amounts to about $20 million a year.

title: Rain in California Brings Relief, and New Problems
description: LOS ANGELES  Its not quite a month of Sundays  or even a perfect game pitched in the seventh game of a World Series  but something rather extraordinary happened across California on Friday.

title: Surge in Stocks Helps Norway Oil Funds Profit Soar
description: Norways giant oil fund said on Friday that it earned 15.9 percent, or about $115 billion, on its investments last year, profiting from big bets on American and European stocks that offset losses in government bonds from around the world.

title: What Faces Cant Tell Us
description: CAN you detect someones emotional state just by looking at his face?

title: Book Review Podcast: Commercial Coupling
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Alida Becker reviews Anne de Courcys The Fishing Fleet: Husband-Hunting in the Raj. Ms. Becker writes:

title: Did Inflation Phobia Cause the Great Recession?
description: We now know that many key people at the Fed spent 2008, the year of financial doom, obsessing about inflation, which wasnt a threat at all. This is not good; whats even not-gooder is that, as David Glasner and others have pointed out, the central bankers who got this so completely wrong remain in positions of great influence, and show no sign of having rethought their views.

title: Why the Bank Leverage Ratio Is Important
description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a New York-based capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World.

title: Maison Martin Margiela: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: The Gun Report: February 28, 2014
description: With a bill allowing students and staff to carry guns on Idahos college campuses making its way through the state legislature, Greg Hampikian, a professor of biology and criminal justice at Boise State University, asks today in a Times Op-Ed, When may I shoot a student? The column, styled as a letter to the state legislature, continued, Now that well all be packing heat, I would like legal instruction in the rules of classroom engagement.  If I am working out a long equation on the board and several students try to correct me using their laser sights, am I allowed to fire a warning shot?

title: Movie Review: 'The Lunchbox'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Lunchbox."

title: Balancing Act
description: The latest Range Rover Sport has found a nice compromise between handling on-pavement and off-road performance.

title: Movie Review: 'Non-Stop'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Non-Stop."

title: Review: 2014 Range Rover Sport HSE
description: The 2014 Land Rover Range Rover Sport might be a better mountain climber than slalom runner, but don't roll your eyes at the "sport" badge on this S.U.V.

title: Save for Retirement First, the Childrens Education Second
description: A HALF-DOZEN years ago, Brian Appelbaums savings plan was focused mainly on his own retirement. But now he is married and the father of two young children.

title: A Stylist for Whom Nice Is Not an Insult
description: It could be a shoe moment, said Jeanann Williams, a fashion stylist.

title: An All-Terrain Hero Shifts Priorities
description: Many see Range Rovers as dignified transportation for the upper crust. Picture Queen Elizabeth II peering over the steering wheel of this talisman of British gentry, perhaps returning to Balmoral Castle, the royal familys summer retreat in Scotland, from a grouse shoot.

title: Oscars in Party Mode, a Few Days Early
description: LOS ANGELES  With Oscar Sunday comes Oscar Party Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. Oh and Saturday, too. The flurry of congratulatory activity leading up to the big show includes cocktails, galas, benefits and celebrations old and new.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Lanvin Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Why Republicans Dont Want to Acknowledge the Falling Deficit
description: An important budget memo was issued this week celebrating just how far the deficit had fallen over the last five years. But in one of the incongruities that define the political moment, the memo was issued by a Democrat, Senator Patty Murray of Washington, chairwoman of the Budget Committee, not a Republican.

title: Raising the Bar on Prices and Amenities
description: Just a few layers of lath and plaster can stand between two homes in New York City, and still, people may never meet their neighbors. But for apartment dwellers in a crop of new rental towers, it may be hard to remain strangers.

title: The Best of the Weeks eBay Barbs
description: Carl C. Icahn and eBay executives might not be debating on CNBC anytime soon, but the verbal war between the activist investor and the e-commerce behemoth intensified this week all the same.

title: A Purpose Beyond Profit
description: For years, Ive listened to chief executives of large companies pay dutiful lip service to concepts like corporate social responsibility, investing in the communities they operate in, treating employees as their most precious asset and living their values. Mostly, it comes off as so much canned public posturing  boxes to be checked off, rather than any sort of deep commitment.

title: Wine on Wheels
description: How often have cyclists wished for a bike basket that could securely hold a bottle of wine and two wineglasses for the duration of their ride? Probably not that often, though with the current proliferation of bike tours taking visitors closer to both nature and alcohol, they may soon be in high demand.

title: Protesters Say Theyll End Blockades in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK  In what appeared to be a major retreat by the movement to overthrow the Thai government, protesters on Friday said they were abandoning their campaign to shut down Bangkok and would dismantle their blockades of major intersections set up in January.

title: A Shakespearean Mash-Up With Scintillations of Sorcery
description: A few years back, Peter Gelb, in one of his most daft and delightful strokes as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, hatched the notion of creating a full-scale Baroque-style pastiche opera, scavenging arias and instrumental numbers from a variety of Baroque sources. The resulting odd beast of a work  The Enchanted Island, devised and written (the Mets words) by Jeremy Sams and ever so loosely based on Shakespeares The Tempest and A Midsummer Nights Dream  stirred considerable curiosity.

title: An Alien March Madness: Is There Life in Space?
description: Its not an invasion from space, but it is an invasion about space.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, South Sudan and Nigeria.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: This weeks On the Market in the Region properties include a renovated five-bedroom Tudor in New Rochelle, N.Y., and six-bedroom home in Old Tappan, N.J., featuring artistic floor and wall treatments.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks On the Market in New York City properties include an Upper East Side Co-op in a Beaux-Arts building; a Garment District condo in a former clothing factory; and Lefferts Manor townhouse built in 1910.

title: Dries Van Noten: Curating Inspiration
description: The designer gives Suzy Menkes a tour of his exhibition, "Dries Van Noten: Inspirations," at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs in Paris.

title: Cate Blanchetts Fashion Sense
description: Ms. Blanchett, who is nominated for a best actress Oscar, commands respect on both the silver screen and the red carpet.

title: Insulted by Don Rickles and Thrilled About It
description: LOS ANGELES  Philomena Lee was not the only party-hopper on Thursday night. The Bagger and Martin Scorsese made the rounds too though, sadly, not together.

title: NJOY, E-Cigarette Maker, Receives Funding Valuing It at $1 Billion
description: Even as electronic cigarettes draw the scrutiny of regulators around the world, investors are seeing potential in the fledgling industry.

title: A Romance That Shocked in Another Era
description: Characters keep talking about Manhattans falling snow in the Keen Companys polished revival of Paddy Chayefskys Middle of the Night, now at the Clurman Theater. Sometimes its invigorating, inspiring them to walk for blocks; sometimes it wears them down like the attrition of age. And sometimes its a metaphor for the familial reaction to this plays love that dare not speak its name: a May-December romance.

title: An Argument to Turn to Jesus Before the Bar
description: When Kim S. Phipps was leading the search for a new president of the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities, she called Edward O. Blews Jr. and said, Ed, this is God, and she is calling you to the C.C.C.U. presidency.

title: Ugly? Its a Crowd Pleaser Now
description: PHILADELPHIA  Look at a new car that you think is preposterous. Chances are good that 50 years from now, when few like it remain, it will attract a crowd of admirers on the street.

title: Growing Into Its Looks
description: With styling that was once dismissed as garish, Chris Rossis Lincoln Continental Mark V now draws a crowd of admirers wherever it goes.

title: The How and Why of Dal
description: I went to my local Indian grocery the other day looking for dal, but I couldnt decide which dal to buy. There were so many kinds to choose from, all enticing  bright orange massour dal, canary yellow chana dal, ivory hued urad dal and straw-colored moong dal, among others. In the end, I bought 10 one-pound packages, each a different color.

title: After 15 Years, Reunited and Restored
description: Have you ever lost a car? Of course you have  at the airport or in a snow bank, or maybe your roommate, spouse, mom or dad took off with it. And lets not forget the rented silver Altima you parked at the mall the week before Christmas.

title: CCTV Shows Crimean Parliament Takeover
description: Footage from security cameras showed the moment armed men seized Simferopols Parliament building in Ukraines Crimea region.

title: (Supreme) Court TV and the Magically Disappearing Protest
description: Lets set aside for the moment the perennial debate over whether the Supreme Court should (yes) or will (someday, surely) join the other branches of government and televise its proceedings. Instead lets consider the Courts odd and counterproductive handling of the incident captured on the dramatic, unprecedented secret video that appeared on YouTube yesterday afternoon.

title: Bill Cunningham | The White Album
description: The popularity of white outerwear this winter has been a perfect match for a particularly snowy season. A surprise, since white coats are perhaps the greatest luxury of fashion because of their need for constant cleaning. Many women wore white or off-white fur-side-out shearling coats (bottom row), though one woman preferred the leather side out, coated in gold. There were white hooded jackets, white marabou-trimmed mules and even a white Marie Antoinette wig. High school students from San Antonio made snowmen, complete with a white topper with a large brim, which they made by rolling snow along a wood banister at Bryant Park.

title: Photo: Authorities Seize $4 Million Statue in Queens
description: Officials on Friday seized a Roman statue valued at $4 million on behalf of Italian officials who say it was looted. As Tom Mashberg reported on Thursday:

title: Week in Pictures for Feb. 28
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a cemetery on Staten Island, a new PATH station platform at the World Trade Center hub, and a memorial for Ukrainian protesters in the East Village.

title: Evening Hours | February Revelry
description: From waltzes to jazz to orchids, it was a month made for celebrating.

title: Maggie Jablonski Transforms Backstage at Maison Martin Margiela
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Maggie Jablonski (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Phillips and hair by Guido Palau.

title: A Designers Palm Beach Jumble Sale
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  They came from all over, seeking a fragment of Lilly Pulitzers life and a souvenir of a woman they called an icon. Will Bannister and his wife, Leslie, came from Fort Worth, Tex.; Brandon and Cheryl Forbes Plunkett from Nashville; and Eva Cox from Cleveland, where she had built up a kitty especially for an auction of property from the Pulitzer estate.

title: Comfy in Any Costume
description: WHOCate Blanchett

title: Graydon Carter, the Last Impresario
description: On a recent chilly Monday afternoon, Graydon Carter, the Vanity Fair editor and host of a party that for two decades has been the hottest ticket in Hollywood on Oscars night, perched on a tan modernist sofa in his vast 22nd-floor corner office at 4 Times Square, looking like a Hirschfeld sketch of himself. His Buddha-like belly bulged from a blue bespoke jacket; his trademark swoop of silver hair, which by now seems to function as an alternate logo for Vanity Fair, looked like a curvilinear roof by Saarinen.

title: Almodvars World, Spun With (What Else?) Passion
description: Have you ever considered how the splashy, sultry films of Pedro Almodvar might translate into dance? Jomar Mesquita, the artistic director of Mimulus Cia de Dana, offers his interpretation in Dolores, an evening-length work heavier on atmosphere than on linear story, which opened at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday.

title: A Spiritual Advisers Help Is Twisted as Hes Tormented
description: In the tradition of thrillers about unassuming acquaintances who turn out to be deadly (Misery, Fatal Attraction) comes Repentance, a movie of modest means that nevertheless offers a fairly cohesive story and at least one standout performance. It may underplay an idea laden with potential, but at least that notion is present.

title: Heavy Rains Pound Southern California
description: A second winter storm this week swept into California, bringing more rain than this drought-hit state has had in months.

title: Cleaning Out Rauschenbergs Attic: Places in the Sun for His Late Work
description: The artist Robert Rauschenberg hated repeating himself, art-wise, and said that his works, as an honest reflection of his life, were really just evidence that Im still paying attention.

title: Kerry Calls Russia's Lavrov Over Crimea
description: Secretary of State John Kerry called Russias foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, to express concerns over military activity in Crimea that could further inflame tensions in Ukraine.

title: Side Road to Success Wins Matthew McConaughey Admiration
description: LOS ANGELES  Two aspiring actors recently stood in line at Alfred, a hip coffee house on Melrose Place here, and chatted about True Detective, the new HBO drama co-starring Matthew McConaughey. Their conversation turned to Mr. McConaughey and his Oscar-nominated role as an AIDS patient in Dallas Buyers Club.

title: Obama Warns Russia on Ukraine
description: President Obama said any intervention militarily in Ukraine would be deeply destabilizing.

title: In Paris, Oscar Viewing Becomes a Challenge
description: PARIS  During Paris Fashion Week, which runs through Wednesday, there has been a wave of anxiety among fashion editors that doesnt have anything to do with traffic jams or running late to a show. Editors have been flummoxed in trying to figure out how theyre going to watch the Academy Awards telecast on Sunday, which begins after 2 a.m. here.

description: Venezuela protests continue amid the start of a long Carnival weekend. Also on the Minute, start-ups that copy their way to success and the rise of practical robots.

title: Under Cover: How Do You Light a Woolly Mammoth?
description: When Joanna Milter, the magazines deputy photo editor, contacted the Royal BC Museum in Victoria, Canada, about photographing its replica woolly mammoth for this weeks cover story, a museum staff person warned her that the shoot would be, and we quote, a lighting challenge.

description: At the 19th NEC Bridge Festival in Yokohama City, Japan, two weeks ago, the teams that did not qualify for the quarterfinals of the NEC Cup played in a subsidiary Swiss Team event.

title: Another Light Shines Through
description: The guitarist and songwriter Bryce Dessner is best known as a member of the indie-rock band the National. Lately, though, he has spread his wings as a classical composer. Lest you jump to unwarranted conclusions, understand that Mr. Dessner has long created a quirky strain of chamber music with another group, Clogs, and that the Kronos Quartet has championed his compositions. On Friday, Mr. Dessner celebrates the release of St. Carolyn by the Sea, his debut album of orchestral music for Deutsche Grammophon, with a concert by Ensemble LPR, Le Poisson Rouges house chamber orchestra. The program includes Mr. Dessners Lachrimae and another piece from his CD, a suite from the Radiohead guitarist Jonny Greenwoods score for There Will Be Blood. Andr de Ridder, who conducts the Copenhagen Philharmonic on Mr. Dessners album, makes his New York debut with this concert. (8 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; lepoissonrouge.com.)

title: New Variations on Standard Jazz
description: The young tenor saxophonist Aaron Burnett, originally from Chicago, can play a ballad standard with feeling, and then head into an improvisation with wide intervals and split-tone effects.

title: New Season at That Motel
description: We knew going into Bates Motel that young Norman Bates (Freddie Highmore) was going to be an odd duck and that his mother, Norma (Vera Farmiga), was likely to have some odd ideas about child rearing. What we didnt know was that the whole danged town is a little unhinged.

title: From Beach to Bathroom
description: As a soloist with New York City Ballet, Tom Gold often seemed an amiable dancer, and some of his good-natured personality may be creeping into his ballets now that he has become a choreographer.

title: Family Guy Guy as Astrobiology Guy
description: WASHINGTON  When some of the nations brightest minds gathered here at the Library of Congress to celebrate Carl Sagan, the pioneering astrobiologist, the first guest speaker was someone with no professional background in science.

title: A Hometown, Amplified
description: Last summer, the Italian Conceptual artist Rudolf Stingel created something of a sensation in Venice when he covered most of the public spaces  the majestic atrium and two floors  of the 18th-century Palazzo Grassi with a digitally printed, predominantly red Ottoman carpet over which he sparingly hung a combination of abstract and Photo-Realist paintings. Mr. Stingel, who is known for continuously expanding his repertoire, has recently been immersing himself in landscapes. In 2010, the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin showed some of his earliest attempts. Now, from Tuesday through April 12, eight of his new photo-based landscapes will be shown at the Gagosian Gallery, 522 West 21st Street, in Chelsea.

title: It Takes a Funeral: So Much Angst
description: Patrice Chreau was a creature of the theater. But he had a parallel career as a moviemaker, which the Film Society of Lincoln Center is honoring in the series Patrice Chreau: The Love That Dares. If nothing he did for the screen had the genre-shaking impact of his stage work  his 1976 Ring cycle at Bayreuth helped usher in an era of Regietheater, or directors theater  he did raise eyebrows with the sexually explicit Intimacy (2001), starring all of Mark Rylance, the corseted Olivia in the Twelfth Night that just ended its Broadway run. Intimacy was much discussed for how much it showed and how real or not the sex was, though whats most real  and naked  is the emotional life of Mr. Rylances character. Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train (1998) only seems more buttoned up. As a train hurtles toward Limoges and a funeral, Mr. Chreau plunges us into a world of interlocking relationships, of sex, desire, despondency. The style is distinctly cinematic, but the emotion verges on operatic. (Through Wednesday; filmlinc.com.)

title: Let Them Wear Crowns
description: PARIS  The royal court of Undercover arrived here Wednesday night. Jun Takahashis show had the pomp and circumstance of an uncanny jubilee. It left some of the most indelible images seen so far this Fashion Week.
